text:
The years of the Marcos government (1965-86) make up a most tumultuous chapter of Philippine history. Discontent both in the countryside and in the city, economic instability, political jockeying, and the rise of a militant nationalism characterized the time. The declaration of martial law in Sep 1972 was a key event. The years leading up to it were marked by the First Quarter Storm, a series of protest demonstrations led by students in Jan-Mar 1970, and the Plaza Miranda incident in 1971, in which the campaign rally of the Liberal Party, Marcos’s rivals, was bombed. The climax of the political drama was the assassination of Benigno Aquino Jr in Aug 1983, which precipitated a series of events leading to the “snap elections” of 1986 and the fall of the regime.

The stage had been set, however, years before Ferdinand E. Marcos stepped into power. The economic boom of the 1950s was based on the export of raw materials—not a sustainable source of income—and state control of the value of the peso and of major industries, deriving from Pres Carlos P. Garcia’s Filipino First policy. In 1965, the economy began to decline. Pres Diosdado Macapagal’s policy of “decontrol” only led to rising prices and anxieties about the foreign incursion into the economy. Then senator Ferdinand E. Marcos capitalized on the situation and became the next president of the republic. He was to stay in power for over 20 years.

 

Meanwhile, the Cold War, in which the Philippines had sided with the United States, found a new face in the shape of the Vietnam War. The escalation of the war and the increasing cost in lives and resources despite the superior technology of the American forces led to protests against the war and to distrust of American interventionism. When the Philippines sent a medical team to Vietnam, nationalist protesters took to the streets to denounce what appeared to be the Philippine government’s subservience to foreign powers.

In the face of a struggling economy and corrupt government, a bright prospect for the Philippines seemed unlikely. Mga Agos sa Disyerto (Streams in the Desert), 1964, already reflected the underside of Philippine society. The fictionists in the collection would usher in a grittier variety of social realism, focusing on the world of the defeated and dispossessed. Soon, they would publish novels in a similar vein. In his classic “Tata Selo” (Old Man Selo), 1962, Rogelio Sikat aka Rogelio Sicat depicts the futility of the tenant’s assertion of his rights as tiller of the landlord’s soil and as head of his family. He repeats the same premise in his novel Dugo sa Bukang-Liwayway (Blood at Daybreak), 1965, although the novel sheds some glimmer of hope when it ends with the peasants being roused to united action. Edgardo M. Reyes, whose “Daang-Bakal” (Railroad), 1965, exposes payroll frauds in a government project, widens his horizons in the novel Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag (In the Claws of Neon Lights), 1967, to give a bleak portrait of rural immigrants forced into sordid lives in Manila. Similarly, Efren Abueg, in “Mabangis na Lungsod” (Savage City), 1962, shows the hoodlum’s power of life and death over a hapless street child. However, he offers a possible solution in his novel Dilim sa Umaga (Darkness in the Morning), 1968, which dramatizes the beginnings of the student movement during the First Quarter Storm. Dominador Mirasol in “Mga Aso sa Lagarian” (Dogs in the Sawmill), 1973, reveals management’s exploitation of workers in a sawmill, where the contractor’s privileged dogs contrast sharply with the overworked workers, one of whom dies on the job. Moises, a secondary character in “Mga Aso sa Lagarian,” becomes the principal character in Mirasol’s novel, Ginto ang Kayumangging Lupa (Gold Is the Brown Earth), 1975, the story of which occurs in the late 1960s and begins in a logging concession. Moises discovers that the Edenic forest into which he has retreated is no better alternative to the logging camp when treasure hunters invade it and kill one another for the gold. In the end, Moises joins the revolutionary army, which his son has already joined ahead of him. Novels such as these represented that stream of fiction that reflected the general condition of Philippine society at that time as one of poverty, exploitation, and corruption.

Such social conditions led to a more pressing question among writers and intellectuals: what must be done to change society for the better? The appeal of Marxism for intellectuals seemed inevitable in such a climate. In the 1930s, socialist ideas had inspired trade unions and peasant organizations and had found embodiment in the Communist Party of the Philippines. Marxist ideas, as expressed not only by Lenin, Gorky, and Plekhanov, but also by American writers of the Depression era such as Sinclair Lewis, Clifford Odets, and James Farrell had influenced Filipino writers. Now, in the late 1960s and the years that followed, the Communist armed movement reached unprecedented heights. The Communist Party of the Philippines (CPP) was reestablished by Jose Ma. Sison in 1968. Marxism, as mediated by communism, also emerged as a major intellectual force in Philippine life. The principle of “literature from the masses, to the masses” spurred the use of local languages (as against English), a new respect for folk and popular forms, more direct and simpler forms of communication, and a view that demystified the writer’s role in the creation of culture.

More and more writers would move away from the New Criticism, which was viewed as being disengaged from the problems of society. An alternative aesthetic was offered by the Manila-based Panulat para sa Kaunlaran ng Sambayanan (PAKSA), established in 1971 by such Tagalog writers as Efren R. Abueg, Jose Rey Munsayac, Dominador Mirasol, Rogelio Ordoñez, Ricardo Lee, Wilfredo Virtusio, Levy Balgos dela Cruz, Rogelio G. Mangahas, Lamberto E. Antonio, Virgilio V. Vitug, Jose F. Lacaba, Ave Perez Jacob, Virgilio S. Almario, and Bienvenido Lumbera. Heavily influenced by Mao Tse-tung’s “Talks at the Yenan Forum,” PAKSA encouraged writers to participate in mass actions such as rallies and demonstrations, to read Lope K. Santos and Amado V. Hernandez as a means of going back to the nationalist roots of Tagalog writing, and to write poetry and prose that directly challenged the status quo.

The kind of politicized writing that PAKSA encouraged is illustrated by the anthology Sigwa (Storm), 1972, which consists of the stories of Efren Abueg, Norma Miraflor, E. San Juan Jr, Wilfredo Virtusio, Ricardo Lee, and Fanny Garcia, among others. Their stories, written between 1966 and 1971, deal directly with the growing protest movement. Political awakening is the theme of many of the stories: Wilfredo Virtusio’s “Maria, ang Iyong Anak” (Maria, Your Child) and Fanny Garcia’s “Sandaang Damit” (A Hundred Dresses) show the youth becoming committed to radicalism. Ricky Lee’s “Si Tatang, si Freddie, si Tandang Senyong, at Iba Pang Tauhan ng Aking Kuwento” (Tatang, Freddie, Old Man Senyong, and Other Characters of My Story) uses metafictional devices to depict a writer’s realization of the limits of writing for one’s self at the expense of writing for the people.

In poetry, the publication of Rogelio G. Mangahas’s Mga Duguang Plakard at Iba Pang Tula (Bloody Placards and Other Poems), 1972, and Rolando Tinio’s Sitsit sa Kuliglig (Calling the Cricket), 1972, shows modernist writers moving into the sphere of politically committed literature. Mangahas’s “Bahay-bahayan” (Playhouse), an allegorical satire of neocolonialism, and Tinio’s “Ang Burges sa Kanyang Almusal” (The Bourgeois at Breakfast), a critique of the apathy of the middle class, convey their social message by using irony and other devices associated with modernism. Similarly, the poems in Emmanuel Torres’s Shapes of Silence, 1972, venture into social criticism—a departure from the more esoteric concerns of his first collection, Angels and Fugitives, 1966. In “Another Invitation to the Pope to Visit Tondo,” Torres describes the dehumanizing conditions of the poor, which Marcos’s officials tried to hide from Pope Paul VI when he visited the country in 1970.

Women writers were equally politicized, calling for a revolution in the realm of gender politics. Lorena Barros founded the group Malayang Kilusan ng Bagong Kababaihan (MAKIBAKA), and Tagalog poets such as Ruth Elynia Mabanglo, Marra PL. Lanot, Aida F. Santos, Margarita Villaluz, Maria Luisa F. Torres, Clarita Roja (pseud. of Mila D. Aguilar), and Adora Faye de Vera would describe the plight of women in the Philippines in their works. Outside the Tagalog region, Ilocano poet Florentina Somera, in “Saanak a Matay” (I Will Not Die), identifies her female persona with the nation’s poor; and Mercedes Magno, in “Babae, Lumaban Ka” (Woman, Fight), calls upon the woman to be brave, steadfast, and to take up her kampilan (cutlass) (Quindoza-Santiago 1997, 121-22).

Even the older generation of “mainstream” writers started to take a similar line as their younger and more radical successors. This trend can be seen in the Tagalog novel, with Liwayway Arceo’s Canal de la Reina, 1971, and Rosario de Guzman-Lingat’s Ano Ngayon, Ricky? (What Now, Ricky?), 1971, both of which depicted student activism and government corruption.

PAKSA’s inroads into committed literature were impeded with the imposition of martial law on 21 Sep 1972. Newspapers and magazines were suspended, and the media came under strict government surveillance as the Marcos government attempted an “ideological” reformation of society. University publications were also shut down, because these published radical writers and covered news ignored by the mainstream press. A number of writers were arrested.

Some writers went to the countryside and joined the CPP’s New People’s Army (NPA). Among them were Emmanuel Lacaba and Ma. Lorena Barros, both of whom were killed in 1976. Lacaba’s “Open Letters to Filipino Artists” expresses the poetics of revolutionary literature: the poet’s pen is “blown up to a long-barrelled gun” and his lack of sleep is “no longer for Bohemia, / The lumpen culturati, but for the people.” Lacaba’s poems were posthumously collected in Salvaged Poems, 1986. Barros was a member of the UP Writers’ Club as a poet before she founded MAKIBAKA. Her poem “A Park Is Born,” published in 1968 in the Collegian Folio, denounces the eviction of the urban poor from their homes for the sake of the First Lady’s beautification program. By the 1970s, as a cadre of the NPA, aka Red fighter, she was subverting images and metaphors associated with feminine conservativism. In “Sampaguita,” the dainty, white flower is a memento of fallen comrades “whose death makes our blades sharper, gives our bullets surer aim.” In “Two Poems,” the pain of separation, which she likens to a fallen leaf, is assuaged by the thought that it is for the sake of the people’s war (Quindoza-Santiago 1997, 135-37).

Barred from the mainstream media and press, writers of the revolutionary movement produced “underground” literature, circulated either as mimeographed copies or as carbon copies of typescripts, some folded and stapled together into booklet form, and others handwritten in composition notebooks. This literature explicitly challenged state accounts of the “New Society,” Marcos’s vision of a robust and disciplined Philippines. The first of such booklets to come out of Western Visayas was “War Poems from Panay: 1978-80” by Red fighter Servando Magbanua (pseud. of Jose Percival Estocada Jr, aka Ka Vencer), who was executed on 26 Jun 1986. It consists of 13 poems, with annotations regarding the circumstance and occasion for the writing of each poem, which are now essential as historical data. Included are “Summer,” a nature poem personifying mountains and rivers as “patriots driven to their destinies”; “Tomloy,” a celebration of the victory of a squad of “thirteen Red warriors” in a gun battle with the military; and “Poem Written beside a Peasant Comrade’s Grave on the First Anniversary of His Death,” a eulogy to an original Communist Party member killed by a paramilitary unit. Magbanua’s two Ilonggo poems, “Halad kay Waling-Waling” (Ode to Waling-Waling) and “Pamat-ud” (Testimony), were published, along with seven others in English, in STR: Mga Tula ng Digmang Bayan sa Pilipinas (STR: Poems of the People’s War in the Philippines), 1989.

Rojo Sangre (pseud.) put out two poetry collections in booklet form, typewritten and carbon copied, both titled “Ilahas nga Orkidyas kag Gerilyero, Nahardi’ng Rosas kag Insurekto … sa Kahilwayan” (Wild Orchid and Guerrilla, Rose Garden and Insurgent … to Freedom), the second booklet with the subtitle “Ikaduha nga Koleksyon” (Second Collection). Written in 1982-86, the 21 poems include eight in English and one in Tagalog, and the rest in Ilonggo. There are Ilonggo paktakon (riddles) and tanaga (short poems). For example, a set of three paktakon (riddles), “Ay Nabisto!” (Aha! Exposed!), are answered with the political slogans “Imperyalismong US” (US Imperialism), “Pyudalismo” (Feudalism), and “Burukrata Kapitalismo” (Bureaucrat Capitalism). Each poem in the collection is followed by content footnotes explaining the references to names, places, sights, and events; these are essential in the historical reconstruction of that turbulent period of the Philippines.

“War and Peace and Beyond (Collected Poems)” by Rio Roja (pseud.) is another stapled collection of typewritten poems, the first page of which contains a caveat in Ilonggo: that the poet of the collection is “nothing like Balagtas nor of the caliber of Rio Alma and Pete Lacaba, but that he is a journalist and social critic whose writings tend toward the poetic.” Edward Oliver L. de la Fuente (pseud. of Ka Philip), executed on 20 Apr 1984, had scribbled his poems on the margins of his notebook, on cigarette wrappers, and scattered pieces of paper. These were typewritten and carbon copied; some were published in Sublak, the revolutionary cultural magazine of Panay. One collection by Bayani Obrero (pseud.) is handwritten in a composition notebook. Other poetry collections from the Western Visayas, both in English and Ilonggo, in typescript and carbon copies are by Red fighters with the pseudonyms Mario Armado, Sur Estrella, Jaime Kaasanag, Rubio Rus Lucha, Chris Magbanua, Pierro Prayre, Andres Proletaryo, and Elias Sagrado.

One foreword to a typescript booklet speaks for all these poems when it states flatly that “the poems are clearly partisan,” and are always triumphalist in tone and diction. A clear example of this is “Nguyngoy sa Kagab-ihon” (Lamentation in the Night), 1989, written by Jaime Kasanag (pseud.) in 1982. A widow’s grief escalates to outrage “equal to the world’s tallest mountain” and to be pacified only by the revolution at hand (Mainstream 1989, 76). Kasanag’s poems were anthologized in STR. The most comprehensive anthology of West Visayan poetry is “Mga Binalaybay sg Rebolusyong Pilipino sa Panay” (Poems of the Filipino Revolution in Panay), in which many of these poets are represented. This anthology of 76 poems is in long-sized, onionskin, carbon-copied, typescript pages, bound together by a metal paper fastener.

Bikol poet Wilfredo Gacosta wrote at least nine poems in Filipino about his work as a Red fighter. His last three poems were “Ang mga Kaibigan,” about the bond of friendship between the grassroots and the NPA; “Agosto 5, Hindi Kita Malilimot” (August 5, I Won’t Forget You), referring to the treachery of comrades; and “Ang Kabiguan Ay May Pangakong Tagumpay” (In Failure Is the Promise of Victory), likening the revolution to Christ’s resurrection. Gacosta was killed in 1977 during a military ambush of the NPA camp on Mount Bulusan (Mainstream 1989, 35, 63-70).

The outlets for revolutionary writings included Ulos, produced by the CPP-NPA as the creative and cultural arm of the revolution and eventually published in 1987; Taliba ng Bayan; and Dare to Struggle, Dare to Dream. Among the revolutionary writers were Jason Montana, Ruth Firmeza, and Kris Montañez; their poems would be collected in STR.

Underground fiction usually followed a pattern where the protagonist experiences some injustice, which eventually leads him or her to join the revolutionary movement. The novel Hulagpos (Breaking Free) by Mano de Verdades Posadas first circulated in manuscript form in 1977; it was published in 1980. Following the tropes found in Jose Rizal’s novels, Hulagpos tells the story of Tommy Guevarra, a Filipino who studies in America and comes back during the early martial law years. Tommy is at first dazzled by the “progress” made by Marcos’s New Society, but he is eventually initiated into political activism as the novel progresses.

Magsasaka: Ang Bayaning Di-Kilala (Farmer: The Unknown Hero), 1984, is an anthology of protest stories, poems, plays, and art, some translated into Tagalog from Waray, Ilocano, Kapampangan, and English. The title poem is a Tagalog translation from Kapampangan of “Ortelano: Ing Bayaning Era Balo,” ca 1970. It presents the contradiction of the farmer’s condition—he who produces for all, possesses nothing—and ends with a call to arms. Many specimens of underground literature would come to mainstream circulation only after the fall of Marcos, in such anthologies as Kamao: Panitikan ng Protesta 1970-1986; Tula (Fist: Protest Literature 1970-1986; Poetry), 1987; Kamao: Panitikan ng Protesta 1970-1986; Kuwento (Fist: Protest Literature 1970-1986; Short Story), 1987; and Muog (Fort), 1997. They bear witness to the extent of the underground literature during the martial law years.

Opposition to, or at least criticism of, the status quo was also transmitted orally. In the Visayas, traveling composo (ballad) singers played the vital role of news reporters as they sang of human rights atrocities perpetrated by both military and paramilitary groups. One Ilonggo composo, for instance, describes in graphic detail how seven desaparecido (disappeared) youths were adjudged guilty by “the official Ikot Garcia,” tortured by the military, and taken to the grounds of the mayor’s hacienda (“sa tunga sang kampo kay Mayor asyenda”), where they were buried alive in a deep grave.

“Above ground” writers found ways of expressing their dissatisfaction amid censorship and state propaganda. Cebuano poet Don Pagusara used the formula of the tigmo (riddle) and the figure of the folk hero Juan Pusong in “Mga Tigmo ni Huwan Pusong” (The Riddles of Juan Pusong) to describe life under a tyrannical ruler. In “Hinog na Ba?” (“Is It Ripe?”), 1980, he uses symbolic imagery: the guava, banana, and mango are ripe but the little birds cannot eat them because the greedy eagle and the voracious crow have snatched them all up. Melquiadito Allego Jr’s “Daman” (“Nightmare”), published in 1978, uses surreal imagery to convey the chaos and confusion of the martial law period. The poems in Brigido Alfar’s Ang Aninipot sa Baybayon (Fireflies by the Beach), 1974, translated from Cebuano by Vicente Bandillo, express the perseverance amid difficulties of those who depend on the sea for their livelihood.

Martial law censorship forced the magazines to publish vapid fiction in its literary section, such as those about the virtues of the New Society and the First Lady’s pet project, the Green Revolution; or, at the other extreme, fiction featuring sex and violence. Writers responded in various ways to such conditions: some withdrew and produced either escapist or purely aesthetic literature that ignored the social reality, others exposed social problems and sought to conscienticize readers (Hosillos 1992, 282).

Fictionist Gremer Chan Reyes, who had been submitting works to the Bisaya magazine for two decades, received rejection slips for works which hinted at the atrocities of the Marcos administration (Dorotan 2015). His story “Agianan Paingon sa Adlaw” (A Trail toward the Sun), 1975, is an indirect critique of the social situation. It depicts the struggles of a doctor who is assigned in Maguindanao as he helps wounded guerrillas and who is tortured by the government soldiers. While a political prisoner in Davao, fictionist and poet Macario Tiu, who used the pseudonym Felipe Granrojo, wrote the story “Sky Rose,” which was published as a booklet in the Netherlands in 1979. It dramatizes the character development of a student into a Red fighter; unfolds the range of emotions deeply felt by one who is wrenched from his family, his comfortable city life, and, finally, from his comrades-in-arms either reassigned or killed in military encounters; and offers a wealth of ethnographic detail on the life of a Red fighter, including his political work among the indigenous, mountain people, the Blaan.

Writing in English, Gregorio Brillantes offers a veiled critique of the status quo in his futuristic story “The Apollo Centennial.” Set in 2069, it contrasts the technological wonders at an exhibition commemorating the 100th anniversary of the moon landing and the poverty of the people who go to view it. Earlier, Brillantes had used Swiftian irony to satirize Marcos, in his essay “Ferdinand E. Marcos: An Appreciation,” 1970. Given that students would be “smoking pot and watching smut movies” if Marcos had not given them reasons to take to the streets, Brillantes concludes: “No President has done more for his people. Never have a people owed so much to their President.” The “snap election” of Feb 1986, which ended the Marcos regime, occasioned Brillantes’s political allegory, “The Mayor of San Felipe,” the principal characters of which, named Frankie and Mely Mangrobang, are obvious allusions to the Marcos couple. Mayor Frankie is a fitness buff who describes the citizenry as “unformed, immature, and ignorant children”; and his “radiantly beautiful wife,” Mely, likes to sing an aria for party guests as a diversion from political talk.

For a time, Focus Philippines was the only nonregional magazine in circulation with a literary page. Jose F. Lacaba, writing under the pseudonym Ruben Cuevas, managed to get his poem “Prometheus Unbound,” 1973, published in it. On the surface, it was an innocuous poem, but the initial letter of each of its verses together formed an acrostic that read, “Marcos, Hitler, Diktador, Tuta” (Marcos, Hitler, Dictator, Lapdog). Thus did writers outwit censors, by producing what critics would later call the “literature of circumvention.”

During this period, F. Sionil Jose published the novels Tree, 1978, My Brother, My Executioner, 1979, Mass, 1982, and Po-on, 1984, collectively known as the Rosales Novels. A fifth book, The Pretenders, had been published, in 1962. The novels present the saga of the Samson family and are a microcosm of Philippine society, including its festering tenancy problems.

Not all, however, of the literature produced during the period was consciously political in content or intention, nor were all literary works with sociopolitical content against the state. Ilocano literature was predominantly uncritical of Marcos. Even in works that depict social injustice, insurgency, or poverty, the problems are not linked directly to Marcos or to martial law (Galam 2010, 482). The poems and stories of Herman Garcia Tabin in the early 1980s are portraits of the lives of slum dwellers, scavengers, and street vendors in the capital city, whose sordid existence gives the lie to the state narrative of Manila’s being the “City of Man” and a showcase of progress. The poems and stories, however, do not direct criticism at Marcos per se (510-13).

As martial law progressed, government support for the arts, necessarily apolitical, reached unprecedented heights, displayed in its founding of the Philippine High School for the Arts and the building of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), the Folk Arts Theater, the Philippine International Convention Center, the Metropolitan Museum of Manila, the Manila Film Center, and the Museum of Philippine Costumes. This flurry of edifice building went hand in hand with Marcos’s other infrastructure projects funded by loans from the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, loans that would saddle the Philippines in debt. The government also established the National Artist Award, intended to be the highest honor that Filipino artists can receive from the state.

State support of the arts was viewed not without skepticism. At the opening of the Cultural Center of the Philippines, protesters denounced what they believed was garish ostentation in the face of poverty and starvation. At the balcony lobby, three artists unfurled banners protesting the construction of the CCP and American incursion in the Philippines (Lacaba 1969, 11). The National Artist Award was sometimes interpreted as a token by which writers’ loyalties were bought, dissent silenced, or cooperation rewarded. The first winners in the field of literature were the unlikely pairing of former political prisoner (albeit later acquitted) Amado V. Hernandez and expatriate Jose Garcia Villa, both awarded in 1973. In at least one instance, however, it was used to mitigate state tyranny. Nick Joaquin accepted the award on the condition that Jose F. Lacaba, who was then in prison for his subversive activities, be released from jail (Joaquin and Kismadi 2011, 101, 133).

Just as many writers veered away from formalism in response to the times, literary scholarship took a more historical approach in the 1970s and early 1980s. Scholars chose literature written or produced in the regions, or local literary forms, oftentimes tracing the process of indigenization of foreign forms. Such were the works of Bienvenido Lumbera, Nicanor G. Tiongson, Resil B. Mojares, Virgilio S. Almario, Doreen G. Fernandez, Soledad S. Reyes, Florentino Hornedo, among others. Brown Heritage: Essays on Philippine Cultural Traditions and Literature, 1967, edited by Antonio G. Manuud, contains pioneering studies on Philippine literature and on the categories and cultural contexts within which it may be understood. Salimbibig: Philippine Vernacular Literature, 1980, edited by Joseph A. Galdon, SJ, is an anthology of essays on the oral literature of the Ifugao, Ivatan, Maranao, Pangasinan, and Tausug, and the oral and written literatures in Bikol, Cebuano, Hiligaynon, Kapampangan, and Tagalog. The essays have generous quotations and samples from these literatures. In criticism, E. San Juan Jr took a decidedly Marxist approach in The Radical Tradition in Philippine Literature, 1971, and in his analyses of Carlos Bulosan, Jose Garcia Villa, Amado V. Hernandez, and other writers, which would eventually comprise his Toward a People’s Literature, 1984.

The work of collecting and translating regional literature also had a surge. Such were Kapampangan Literature: A Historical Survey and Anthology, 1981, by Edna Zapanta Manlapaz; Waray Literature: An Anthology of Leyte-Samar Writings, 1982, by Gregorio C. Luangco; Lineyte-Samarnon Poems: A Collection, 1974, by Raymond Quetchenbach, SVD; and Damiana Eugenio’s compilations of Philippine folk literature.

After the ban on PAKSA, a new organization based in Manila was established. Called Galian sa Arte at Tula (GAT), it would ensure the continued publication and presentation of progressive poetry, fiction, and plays. GAT would publish pamphlets and later on an anthology of works by its members, Galian: Mga Akda sa Panahon ng Krisis (Galian: Works in a Time of Crisis), 1983. Lubas sa Dagang Bisaya (Ludabi) would hold contests and publish the winners in its anthologies, like Katitikanong Ani (Literary Harvest), 1976, and Wagas (Pure), 1980.

The founding by Ilocano writers of Gunglo Dagiti Mannurat iti Iluko (GUMIL) and by Cebuano writers of Ludabi and Bathalan-ong Halad sa Dagang (Bathalad) would ensure the growth of Philippine literature. These organizations organize workshops and literary contests, and occasionally publish the works of their members. Bathalad has recruited writers from Mindanao since the late 1960s; Ludabi followed suit in 1975.

In 1980, the local government of Pampanga established Ligligan Pamaniulat Kapampangan, a poetry and short story writing contest, but this activity did not last beyond 1982, after a change in local administration. The stories that won vary in theme. “Bye Alamang” (A Dog’s Life) depicts the abuses of the Citizen Armed Force Geographical Unit or CAGFU; “Ing Kapagpabustan” (The Lost Opportunity), the financial failures of an aspiring migrant; and “Ing Hermanu Mayul” (The Hermano Mayor), the profligacy of an overseas worker’s father. These last two stories depict the growing phenomenon of Filipinos working abroad owing to the lack of economic opportunities in the country and are thus the beginnings of a growing body of literature about the migrant experience.

The winners at the Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature reflect the discontent and pent-up frustration with the Marcos government. Several of the short stories in Jun Cruz Reyes’s Utos ng Hari at Iba Pang Kuwento (The King’s Command and Other Stories), 1981, won at the Palanca Awards during the 1970s. The title story “Utos ng Hari” (The King’s Command) is about Jojo and his frustrations with the teachers and the school administration. The character’s adolescent angst may be taken symbolically as an attack on the repressiveness of martial law. Reyes’s first novel, Tutubi, Tutubi, ’Wag Kang Magpahuli sa Mamang Salbahe (Dragonfly, Dragonfly, Don’t Let the Bad Man Catch You), 1987, won the Palanca when the novel category was introduced in the early 1980s. A loose sequel to “Utos ng Hari,” Tutubi tells of Jojo and his friends becoming committed to the cause of social change.

Other novels that won the Palanca were Lualhati Bautista’s ’Gapo (Olongapo), Dekada ’70 (The 1970s), and Bata, Bata … Pa’no Ka Ginawa? (Child, Child … How Were You Made?). ’Gapo critiques the continued presence of the American military bases. Dekada ’70 depicts the life of a middle-class family during the martial law years as seen through the eyes of Amanda Bartolome, a wife and mother of four boys. Bata, Bata … Pa’no Ka Ginawa? tells the story of the unconventional relationships of liberal-minded Lea Bustamante.

Martial law was officially lifted in 1981, as a concession to Pope John Paul’s condition for his visiting the Philippines, but discontent did not end. The assassination of Benigno Aquino Jr in 1983 alienated more writers, simultaneous with the burgeoning of the alternative press: the Mr. and Ms. Special Editions and Pahayagang Malaya aka Malaya; later, the church-sponsored Veritas Newsmagazine, the Philippine Daily Inquirer, and the National Midweek Magazine. Of great significance for literary history was the letters-to-the-editor section of the daily newspaper Malaya. Called People’s Forum, the section included poems which were, as Malaya editor-in-chief Jose Burgos put it, “full of nationalism, courage, shock, and grief, and steadfast in the search for justice and truth.” Ordinary citizens were moved to express their outrage at the regime’s perpetration of the culture of violence, such as military forces firing at fleeing protesters in full view of the passengers of the Light Rail Transit along Taft Ave, Manila; desaparecidos and “salvaged” (summarily executed) victims bearing signs of torture as they were dug out of mass graves; and a child with a bloated belly dying slowly from starvation.

A yellow booklet of poems, titled In Memoriam: A Poetic Tribute by Five Filipino Poets, by founding members of the Philippine Literary Arts Council came out shortly after the assassination. Except for Alfrredo Navarro Salanga, who had been a political detainee in Davao City, the poets had not heretofore been associated with expressions or acts of protest against the oppressive regime. Indeed, their foreword described their poems as “the explosion of the authors’ poetic genius as it was mysteriously affronted, challenged, and seduced by Aquino’s death”; and they were writing “not as partisans in a partisan game but as witnesses to a universal drama.” Most of the writing is marked by erudition, such as allusions to Oedipus and Teiresias, Wallace Stevens and Lucas the Greek; a pun on the Latin proofreading mark sic; and the deconstruction of Aquino as a “word that was dead before it was uttered.”

At the opposite end of the aesthetic and ideological scale was “Makiisa: People’s Cultural Festival,” in which literary, visual, and performing artists from all over the country gathered for the first time in united opposition to Marcos’s authoritarian regime. It was held at the Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Fort Santiago, Manila, on 28-30 Dec 1983. The festival proceedings and primary works that were either exhibited or performed were anthologized in The Politics of Culture: The Philippine Experience, 1984, which included poems by Fidel Rillo Jr, Aida Santos-Maranan, Epifanio San Juan Jr, Lilia Quindoza-Santiago, and Jose F. Lacaba.

By the mid-1980s, Marcos’s health had deteriorated, and distrust of his policies had made his hold on power tenuous. In Nov 1985, to prove that he still had the support of the people, Marcos decided to hold a “snap elections.” Aquino’s widow Corazon ran against him. Amid allegations of election fraud, Marcos was proclaimed the winner of the elections, but at the instigation of the Catholic Bishops’ Conference of the Philippines, people began to gather at EDSA days later to support Marcos’s erstwhile defense minister Juan Ponce Enrile and chief of staff Fidel V. Ramos, both of whom had withdrawn their support of Marcos.

During the six-month period leading up to the snap elections in Feb 1986, Malaya published 35 poems in all. “Quo Vadis,” 12 Sep 1985, by Lourdes Oben Santos paints a dazzling picture of the opulence of the president’s palace to emphasize the dark squalor and “silence by deadly weapons” outside it. “Same Fate,” 13 Sep 1985, by A. L. Picardal, C.Ss.R., of Iligan City, uses the malodorous images of human sacrifice offered by “high priests of the infernal kingdoms and empires” to accuse cronies and government officials of their crimes. “Poverty,” 19 Oct 1985, by Leopoldo M. de la Cruz Jr contrasts the incomprehensible “strokes of Picasso in the lines of Cirilo Bautista” with the clear-cut meaning of beggars’ “empty plates and dirty hands.” “I Was Hungry (A Prayer from Negros),” 9 Nov 1985, by Vic J. Burla of Pavia, Iloilo, throws back at the elite class the popular excuses used for the sufferings of the hungry poor, such as their so-called ignorance, laziness, and colonial mentality. “Flowers on Fire,” 15 Dec 1985, by Helvecio Mendes rues the impunity of the killers of the Italian missionary Fr Tulio Favali, as they roam freely in Kidapawan while the mourners gather around his body at Barangay Esperanza Km 125. “Beyond Illusion,” 23 Jan 1986, by Fred Diamante points to the futility of a snap election with cynical questions. “Limericks,” 26 Feb 1986, by PYRJ Agipo of V&G Subd., Tacloban City, rhymes “Reagan” with “Ray Gun” and exposes the then US president’s faux pas in assuming that Marcos would win the elections still to be held (Balce 1986). This explosion of poetic indignation was gathered together in Versus: Philippine Protest Poetry, 1983-1986, which included not only selected poems previously published in the alternative papers and magazines but also contributions from those all over the country who responded to the editors’ call for such poems.

On 25 Feb 1986, Marcos and his family were flown by the United States from Malacañan Palace to Hawaii. The end of the Marcos presidency would usher in a new period in Philippine history and culture.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero and Christoffer Mitch C. Cerda, with notes from Vijae Alquisola, Rowena Festin, Paula Hernandez, May Maravilles, Marina Quilab, and Resil B. Mojares

article.value: The years of the Marcos government (1965-86) make up a most tumultuous chapter of Philippine history. Discontent both in the countryside and in the city, economic instability, political jockeying, and the rise of a militant nationalism characterized the time. The declaration of martial law in Sep 1972 was a key event. The years leading up to it were marked by the First Quarter Storm, a series of protest demonstrations led by students in Jan-Mar 1970, and the Plaza Miranda incident in 1971, in which the campaign rally of the Liberal Party, Marcos’s rivals, was bombed. The climax of the political drama was the assassination of Benigno Aquino Jr in Aug 1983, which precipitated a series of events leading to the “snap elections” of 1986 and the fall of the regime.

The stage had been set, however, years before Ferdinand E. Marcos stepped into power. The economic boom of the 1950s was based on the export of raw materials—not a sustainable source of income—and state control of the value of the peso and of major industries, deriving from Pres Carlos P. Garcia’s Filipino First policy. In 1965, the economy began to decline. Pres Diosdado Macapagal’s policy of “decontrol” only led to rising prices and anxieties about the foreign incursion into the economy. Then senator Ferdinand E. Marcos capitalized on the situation and became the next president of the republic. He was to stay in power for over 20 years.

article.value: Meanwhile, the Cold War, in which the Philippines had sided with the United States, found a new face in the shape of the Vietnam War. The escalation of the war and the increasing cost in lives and resources despite the superior technology of the American forces led to protests against the war and to distrust of American interventionism. When the Philippines sent a medical team to Vietnam, nationalist protesters took to the streets to denounce what appeared to be the Philippine government’s subservience to foreign powers.

In the face of a struggling economy and corrupt government, a bright prospect for the Philippines seemed unlikely. Mga Agos sa Disyerto (Streams in the Desert), 1964, already reflected the underside of Philippine society. The fictionists in the collection would usher in a grittier variety of social realism, focusing on the world of the defeated and dispossessed. Soon, they would publish novels in a similar vein. In his classic “Tata Selo” (Old Man Selo), 1962, Rogelio Sikat aka Rogelio Sicat depicts the futility of the tenant’s assertion of his rights as tiller of the landlord’s soil and as head of his family. He repeats the same premise in his novel Dugo sa Bukang-Liwayway (Blood at Daybreak), 1965, although the novel sheds some glimmer of hope when it ends with the peasants being roused to united action. Edgardo M. Reyes, whose “Daang-Bakal” (Railroad), 1965, exposes payroll frauds in a government project, widens his horizons in the novel Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag (In the Claws of Neon Lights), 1967, to give a bleak portrait of rural immigrants forced into sordid lives in Manila. Similarly, Efren Abueg, in “Mabangis na Lungsod” (Savage City), 1962, shows the hoodlum’s power of life and death over a hapless street child. However, he offers a possible solution in his novel Dilim sa Umaga (Darkness in the Morning), 1968, which dramatizes the beginnings of the student movement during the First Quarter Storm. Dominador Mirasol in “Mga Aso sa Lagarian” (Dogs in the Sawmill), 1973, reveals management’s exploitation of workers in a sawmill, where the contractor’s privileged dogs contrast sharply with the overworked workers, one of whom dies on the job. Moises, a secondary character in “Mga Aso sa Lagarian,” becomes the principal character in Mirasol’s novel, Ginto ang Kayumangging Lupa (Gold Is the Brown Earth), 1975, the story of which occurs in the late 1960s and begins in a logging concession. Moises discovers that the Edenic forest into which he has retreated is no better alternative to the logging camp when treasure hunters invade it and kill one another for the gold. In the end, Moises joins the revolutionary army, which his son has already joined ahead of him. Novels such as these represented that stream of fiction that reflected the general condition of Philippine society at that time as one of poverty, exploitation, and corruption.

Such social conditions led to a more pressing question among writers and intellectuals: what must be done to change society for the better? The appeal of Marxism for intellectuals seemed inevitable in such a climate. In the 1930s, socialist ideas had inspired trade unions and peasant organizations and had found embodiment in the Communist Party of the Philippines. Marxist ideas, as expressed not only by Lenin, Gorky, and Plekhanov, but also by American writers of the Depression era such as Sinclair Lewis, Clifford Odets, and James Farrell had influenced Filipino writers. Now, in the late 1960s and the years that followed, the Communist armed movement reached unprecedented heights. The Communist Party of the Philippines (CPP) was reestablished by Jose Ma. Sison in 1968. Marxism, as mediated by communism, also emerged as a major intellectual force in Philippine life. The principle of “literature from the masses, to the masses” spurred the use of local languages (as against English), a new respect for folk and popular forms, more direct and simpler forms of communication, and a view that demystified the writer’s role in the creation of culture.

More and more writers would move away from the New Criticism, which was viewed as being disengaged from the problems of society. An alternative aesthetic was offered by the Manila-based Panulat para sa Kaunlaran ng Sambayanan (PAKSA), established in 1971 by such Tagalog writers as Efren R. Abueg, Jose Rey Munsayac, Dominador Mirasol, Rogelio Ordoñez, Ricardo Lee, Wilfredo Virtusio, Levy Balgos dela Cruz, Rogelio G. Mangahas, Lamberto E. Antonio, Virgilio V. Vitug, Jose F. Lacaba, Ave Perez Jacob, Virgilio S. Almario, and Bienvenido Lumbera. Heavily influenced by Mao Tse-tung’s “Talks at the Yenan Forum,” PAKSA encouraged writers to participate in mass actions such as rallies and demonstrations, to read Lope K. Santos and Amado V. Hernandez as a means of going back to the nationalist roots of Tagalog writing, and to write poetry and prose that directly challenged the status quo.

The kind of politicized writing that PAKSA encouraged is illustrated by the anthology Sigwa (Storm), 1972, which consists of the stories of Efren Abueg, Norma Miraflor, E. San Juan Jr, Wilfredo Virtusio, Ricardo Lee, and Fanny Garcia, among others. Their stories, written between 1966 and 1971, deal directly with the growing protest movement. Political awakening is the theme of many of the stories: Wilfredo Virtusio’s “Maria, ang Iyong Anak” (Maria, Your Child) and Fanny Garcia’s “Sandaang Damit” (A Hundred Dresses) show the youth becoming committed to radicalism. Ricky Lee’s “Si Tatang, si Freddie, si Tandang Senyong, at Iba Pang Tauhan ng Aking Kuwento” (Tatang, Freddie, Old Man Senyong, and Other Characters of My Story) uses metafictional devices to depict a writer’s realization of the limits of writing for one’s self at the expense of writing for the people.

In poetry, the publication of Rogelio G. Mangahas’s Mga Duguang Plakard at Iba Pang Tula (Bloody Placards and Other Poems), 1972, and Rolando Tinio’s Sitsit sa Kuliglig (Calling the Cricket), 1972, shows modernist writers moving into the sphere of politically committed literature. Mangahas’s “Bahay-bahayan” (Playhouse), an allegorical satire of neocolonialism, and Tinio’s “Ang Burges sa Kanyang Almusal” (The Bourgeois at Breakfast), a critique of the apathy of the middle class, convey their social message by using irony and other devices associated with modernism. Similarly, the poems in Emmanuel Torres’s Shapes of Silence, 1972, venture into social criticism—a departure from the more esoteric concerns of his first collection, Angels and Fugitives, 1966. In “Another Invitation to the Pope to Visit Tondo,” Torres describes the dehumanizing conditions of the poor, which Marcos’s officials tried to hide from Pope Paul VI when he visited the country in 1970.

Women writers were equally politicized, calling for a revolution in the realm of gender politics. Lorena Barros founded the group Malayang Kilusan ng Bagong Kababaihan (MAKIBAKA), and Tagalog poets such as Ruth Elynia Mabanglo, Marra PL. Lanot, Aida F. Santos, Margarita Villaluz, Maria Luisa F. Torres, Clarita Roja (pseud. of Mila D. Aguilar), and Adora Faye de Vera would describe the plight of women in the Philippines in their works. Outside the Tagalog region, Ilocano poet Florentina Somera, in “Saanak a Matay” (I Will Not Die), identifies her female persona with the nation’s poor; and Mercedes Magno, in “Babae, Lumaban Ka” (Woman, Fight), calls upon the woman to be brave, steadfast, and to take up her kampilan (cutlass) (Quindoza-Santiago 1997, 121-22).

Even the older generation of “mainstream” writers started to take a similar line as their younger and more radical successors. This trend can be seen in the Tagalog novel, with Liwayway Arceo’s Canal de la Reina, 1971, and Rosario de Guzman-Lingat’s Ano Ngayon, Ricky? (What Now, Ricky?), 1971, both of which depicted student activism and government corruption.

PAKSA’s inroads into committed literature were impeded with the imposition of martial law on 21 Sep 1972. Newspapers and magazines were suspended, and the media came under strict government surveillance as the Marcos government attempted an “ideological” reformation of society. University publications were also shut down, because these published radical writers and covered news ignored by the mainstream press. A number of writers were arrested.

Some writers went to the countryside and joined the CPP’s New People’s Army (NPA). Among them were Emmanuel Lacaba and Ma. Lorena Barros, both of whom were killed in 1976. Lacaba’s “Open Letters to Filipino Artists” expresses the poetics of revolutionary literature: the poet’s pen is “blown up to a long-barrelled gun” and his lack of sleep is “no longer for Bohemia, / The lumpen culturati, but for the people.” Lacaba’s poems were posthumously collected in Salvaged Poems, 1986. Barros was a member of the UP Writers’ Club as a poet before she founded MAKIBAKA. Her poem “A Park Is Born,” published in 1968 in the Collegian Folio, denounces the eviction of the urban poor from their homes for the sake of the First Lady’s beautification program. By the 1970s, as a cadre of the NPA, aka Red fighter, she was subverting images and metaphors associated with feminine conservativism. In “Sampaguita,” the dainty, white flower is a memento of fallen comrades “whose death makes our blades sharper, gives our bullets surer aim.” In “Two Poems,” the pain of separation, which she likens to a fallen leaf, is assuaged by the thought that it is for the sake of the people’s war (Quindoza-Santiago 1997, 135-37).

Barred from the mainstream media and press, writers of the revolutionary movement produced “underground” literature, circulated either as mimeographed copies or as carbon copies of typescripts, some folded and stapled together into booklet form, and others handwritten in composition notebooks. This literature explicitly challenged state accounts of the “New Society,” Marcos’s vision of a robust and disciplined Philippines. The first of such booklets to come out of Western Visayas was “War Poems from Panay: 1978-80” by Red fighter Servando Magbanua (pseud. of Jose Percival Estocada Jr, aka Ka Vencer), who was executed on 26 Jun 1986. It consists of 13 poems, with annotations regarding the circumstance and occasion for the writing of each poem, which are now essential as historical data. Included are “Summer,” a nature poem personifying mountains and rivers as “patriots driven to their destinies”; “Tomloy,” a celebration of the victory of a squad of “thirteen Red warriors” in a gun battle with the military; and “Poem Written beside a Peasant Comrade’s Grave on the First Anniversary of His Death,” a eulogy to an original Communist Party member killed by a paramilitary unit. Magbanua’s two Ilonggo poems, “Halad kay Waling-Waling” (Ode to Waling-Waling) and “Pamat-ud” (Testimony), were published, along with seven others in English, in STR: Mga Tula ng Digmang Bayan sa Pilipinas (STR: Poems of the People’s War in the Philippines), 1989.

Rojo Sangre (pseud.) put out two poetry collections in booklet form, typewritten and carbon copied, both titled “Ilahas nga Orkidyas kag Gerilyero, Nahardi’ng Rosas kag Insurekto … sa Kahilwayan” (Wild Orchid and Guerrilla, Rose Garden and Insurgent … to Freedom), the second booklet with the subtitle “Ikaduha nga Koleksyon” (Second Collection). Written in 1982-86, the 21 poems include eight in English and one in Tagalog, and the rest in Ilonggo. There are Ilonggo paktakon (riddles) and tanaga (short poems). For example, a set of three paktakon (riddles), “Ay Nabisto!” (Aha! Exposed!), are answered with the political slogans “Imperyalismong US” (US Imperialism), “Pyudalismo” (Feudalism), and “Burukrata Kapitalismo” (Bureaucrat Capitalism). Each poem in the collection is followed by content footnotes explaining the references to names, places, sights, and events; these are essential in the historical reconstruction of that turbulent period of the Philippines.

“War and Peace and Beyond (Collected Poems)” by Rio Roja (pseud.) is another stapled collection of typewritten poems, the first page of which contains a caveat in Ilonggo: that the poet of the collection is “nothing like Balagtas nor of the caliber of Rio Alma and Pete Lacaba, but that he is a journalist and social critic whose writings tend toward the poetic.” Edward Oliver L. de la Fuente (pseud. of Ka Philip), executed on 20 Apr 1984, had scribbled his poems on the margins of his notebook, on cigarette wrappers, and scattered pieces of paper. These were typewritten and carbon copied; some were published in Sublak, the revolutionary cultural magazine of Panay. One collection by Bayani Obrero (pseud.) is handwritten in a composition notebook. Other poetry collections from the Western Visayas, both in English and Ilonggo, in typescript and carbon copies are by Red fighters with the pseudonyms Mario Armado, Sur Estrella, Jaime Kaasanag, Rubio Rus Lucha, Chris Magbanua, Pierro Prayre, Andres Proletaryo, and Elias Sagrado.

One foreword to a typescript booklet speaks for all these poems when it states flatly that “the poems are clearly partisan,” and are always triumphalist in tone and diction. A clear example of this is “Nguyngoy sa Kagab-ihon” (Lamentation in the Night), 1989, written by Jaime Kasanag (pseud.) in 1982. A widow’s grief escalates to outrage “equal to the world’s tallest mountain” and to be pacified only by the revolution at hand (Mainstream 1989, 76). Kasanag’s poems were anthologized in STR. The most comprehensive anthology of West Visayan poetry is “Mga Binalaybay sg Rebolusyong Pilipino sa Panay” (Poems of the Filipino Revolution in Panay), in which many of these poets are represented. This anthology of 76 poems is in long-sized, onionskin, carbon-copied, typescript pages, bound together by a metal paper fastener.

Bikol poet Wilfredo Gacosta wrote at least nine poems in Filipino about his work as a Red fighter. His last three poems were “Ang mga Kaibigan,” about the bond of friendship between the grassroots and the NPA; “Agosto 5, Hindi Kita Malilimot” (August 5, I Won’t Forget You), referring to the treachery of comrades; and “Ang Kabiguan Ay May Pangakong Tagumpay” (In Failure Is the Promise of Victory), likening the revolution to Christ’s resurrection. Gacosta was killed in 1977 during a military ambush of the NPA camp on Mount Bulusan (Mainstream 1989, 35, 63-70).

The outlets for revolutionary writings included Ulos, produced by the CPP-NPA as the creative and cultural arm of the revolution and eventually published in 1987; Taliba ng Bayan; and Dare to Struggle, Dare to Dream. Among the revolutionary writers were Jason Montana, Ruth Firmeza, and Kris Montañez; their poems would be collected in STR.

Underground fiction usually followed a pattern where the protagonist experiences some injustice, which eventually leads him or her to join the revolutionary movement. The novel Hulagpos (Breaking Free) by Mano de Verdades Posadas first circulated in manuscript form in 1977; it was published in 1980. Following the tropes found in Jose Rizal’s novels, Hulagpos tells the story of Tommy Guevarra, a Filipino who studies in America and comes back during the early martial law years. Tommy is at first dazzled by the “progress” made by Marcos’s New Society, but he is eventually initiated into political activism as the novel progresses.

Magsasaka: Ang Bayaning Di-Kilala (Farmer: The Unknown Hero), 1984, is an anthology of protest stories, poems, plays, and art, some translated into Tagalog from Waray, Ilocano, Kapampangan, and English. The title poem is a Tagalog translation from Kapampangan of “Ortelano: Ing Bayaning Era Balo,” ca 1970. It presents the contradiction of the farmer’s condition—he who produces for all, possesses nothing—and ends with a call to arms. Many specimens of underground literature would come to mainstream circulation only after the fall of Marcos, in such anthologies as Kamao: Panitikan ng Protesta 1970-1986; Tula (Fist: Protest Literature 1970-1986; Poetry), 1987; Kamao: Panitikan ng Protesta 1970-1986; Kuwento (Fist: Protest Literature 1970-1986; Short Story), 1987; and Muog (Fort), 1997. They bear witness to the extent of the underground literature during the martial law years.

Opposition to, or at least criticism of, the status quo was also transmitted orally. In the Visayas, traveling composo (ballad) singers played the vital role of news reporters as they sang of human rights atrocities perpetrated by both military and paramilitary groups. One Ilonggo composo, for instance, describes in graphic detail how seven desaparecido (disappeared) youths were adjudged guilty by “the official Ikot Garcia,” tortured by the military, and taken to the grounds of the mayor’s hacienda (“sa tunga sang kampo kay Mayor asyenda”), where they were buried alive in a deep grave.

“Above ground” writers found ways of expressing their dissatisfaction amid censorship and state propaganda. Cebuano poet Don Pagusara used the formula of the tigmo (riddle) and the figure of the folk hero Juan Pusong in “Mga Tigmo ni Huwan Pusong” (The Riddles of Juan Pusong) to describe life under a tyrannical ruler. In “Hinog na Ba?” (“Is It Ripe?”), 1980, he uses symbolic imagery: the guava, banana, and mango are ripe but the little birds cannot eat them because the greedy eagle and the voracious crow have snatched them all up. Melquiadito Allego Jr’s “Daman” (“Nightmare”), published in 1978, uses surreal imagery to convey the chaos and confusion of the martial law period. The poems in Brigido Alfar’s Ang Aninipot sa Baybayon (Fireflies by the Beach), 1974, translated from Cebuano by Vicente Bandillo, express the perseverance amid difficulties of those who depend on the sea for their livelihood.

Martial law censorship forced the magazines to publish vapid fiction in its literary section, such as those about the virtues of the New Society and the First Lady’s pet project, the Green Revolution; or, at the other extreme, fiction featuring sex and violence. Writers responded in various ways to such conditions: some withdrew and produced either escapist or purely aesthetic literature that ignored the social reality, others exposed social problems and sought to conscienticize readers (Hosillos 1992, 282).

Fictionist Gremer Chan Reyes, who had been submitting works to the Bisaya magazine for two decades, received rejection slips for works which hinted at the atrocities of the Marcos administration (Dorotan 2015). His story “Agianan Paingon sa Adlaw” (A Trail toward the Sun), 1975, is an indirect critique of the social situation. It depicts the struggles of a doctor who is assigned in Maguindanao as he helps wounded guerrillas and who is tortured by the government soldiers. While a political prisoner in Davao, fictionist and poet Macario Tiu, who used the pseudonym Felipe Granrojo, wrote the story “Sky Rose,” which was published as a booklet in the Netherlands in 1979. It dramatizes the character development of a student into a Red fighter; unfolds the range of emotions deeply felt by one who is wrenched from his family, his comfortable city life, and, finally, from his comrades-in-arms either reassigned or killed in military encounters; and offers a wealth of ethnographic detail on the life of a Red fighter, including his political work among the indigenous, mountain people, the Blaan.

Writing in English, Gregorio Brillantes offers a veiled critique of the status quo in his futuristic story “The Apollo Centennial.” Set in 2069, it contrasts the technological wonders at an exhibition commemorating the 100th anniversary of the moon landing and the poverty of the people who go to view it. Earlier, Brillantes had used Swiftian irony to satirize Marcos, in his essay “Ferdinand E. Marcos: An Appreciation,” 1970. Given that students would be “smoking pot and watching smut movies” if Marcos had not given them reasons to take to the streets, Brillantes concludes: “No President has done more for his people. Never have a people owed so much to their President.” The “snap election” of Feb 1986, which ended the Marcos regime, occasioned Brillantes’s political allegory, “The Mayor of San Felipe,” the principal characters of which, named Frankie and Mely Mangrobang, are obvious allusions to the Marcos couple. Mayor Frankie is a fitness buff who describes the citizenry as “unformed, immature, and ignorant children”; and his “radiantly beautiful wife,” Mely, likes to sing an aria for party guests as a diversion from political talk.

For a time, Focus Philippines was the only nonregional magazine in circulation with a literary page. Jose F. Lacaba, writing under the pseudonym Ruben Cuevas, managed to get his poem “Prometheus Unbound,” 1973, published in it. On the surface, it was an innocuous poem, but the initial letter of each of its verses together formed an acrostic that read, “Marcos, Hitler, Diktador, Tuta” (Marcos, Hitler, Dictator, Lapdog). Thus did writers outwit censors, by producing what critics would later call the “literature of circumvention.”

During this period, F. Sionil Jose published the novels Tree, 1978, My Brother, My Executioner, 1979, Mass, 1982, and Po-on, 1984, collectively known as the Rosales Novels. A fifth book, The Pretenders, had been published, in 1962. The novels present the saga of the Samson family and are a microcosm of Philippine society, including its festering tenancy problems.

Not all, however, of the literature produced during the period was consciously political in content or intention, nor were all literary works with sociopolitical content against the state. Ilocano literature was predominantly uncritical of Marcos. Even in works that depict social injustice, insurgency, or poverty, the problems are not linked directly to Marcos or to martial law (Galam 2010, 482). The poems and stories of Herman Garcia Tabin in the early 1980s are portraits of the lives of slum dwellers, scavengers, and street vendors in the capital city, whose sordid existence gives the lie to the state narrative of Manila’s being the “City of Man” and a showcase of progress. The poems and stories, however, do not direct criticism at Marcos per se (510-13).

As martial law progressed, government support for the arts, necessarily apolitical, reached unprecedented heights, displayed in its founding of the Philippine High School for the Arts and the building of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), the Folk Arts Theater, the Philippine International Convention Center, the Metropolitan Museum of Manila, the Manila Film Center, and the Museum of Philippine Costumes. This flurry of edifice building went hand in hand with Marcos’s other infrastructure projects funded by loans from the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, loans that would saddle the Philippines in debt. The government also established the National Artist Award, intended to be the highest honor that Filipino artists can receive from the state.

State support of the arts was viewed not without skepticism. At the opening of the Cultural Center of the Philippines, protesters denounced what they believed was garish ostentation in the face of poverty and starvation. At the balcony lobby, three artists unfurled banners protesting the construction of the CCP and American incursion in the Philippines (Lacaba 1969, 11). The National Artist Award was sometimes interpreted as a token by which writers’ loyalties were bought, dissent silenced, or cooperation rewarded. The first winners in the field of literature were the unlikely pairing of former political prisoner (albeit later acquitted) Amado V. Hernandez and expatriate Jose Garcia Villa, both awarded in 1973. In at least one instance, however, it was used to mitigate state tyranny. Nick Joaquin accepted the award on the condition that Jose F. Lacaba, who was then in prison for his subversive activities, be released from jail (Joaquin and Kismadi 2011, 101, 133).

Just as many writers veered away from formalism in response to the times, literary scholarship took a more historical approach in the 1970s and early 1980s. Scholars chose literature written or produced in the regions, or local literary forms, oftentimes tracing the process of indigenization of foreign forms. Such were the works of Bienvenido Lumbera, Nicanor G. Tiongson, Resil B. Mojares, Virgilio S. Almario, Doreen G. Fernandez, Soledad S. Reyes, Florentino Hornedo, among others. Brown Heritage: Essays on Philippine Cultural Traditions and Literature, 1967, edited by Antonio G. Manuud, contains pioneering studies on Philippine literature and on the categories and cultural contexts within which it may be understood. Salimbibig: Philippine Vernacular Literature, 1980, edited by Joseph A. Galdon, SJ, is an anthology of essays on the oral literature of the Ifugao, Ivatan, Maranao, Pangasinan, and Tausug, and the oral and written literatures in Bikol, Cebuano, Hiligaynon, Kapampangan, and Tagalog. The essays have generous quotations and samples from these literatures. In criticism, E. San Juan Jr took a decidedly Marxist approach in The Radical Tradition in Philippine Literature, 1971, and in his analyses of Carlos Bulosan, Jose Garcia Villa, Amado V. Hernandez, and other writers, which would eventually comprise his Toward a People’s Literature, 1984.

The work of collecting and translating regional literature also had a surge. Such were Kapampangan Literature: A Historical Survey and Anthology, 1981, by Edna Zapanta Manlapaz; Waray Literature: An Anthology of Leyte-Samar Writings, 1982, by Gregorio C. Luangco; Lineyte-Samarnon Poems: A Collection, 1974, by Raymond Quetchenbach, SVD; and Damiana Eugenio’s compilations of Philippine folk literature.

After the ban on PAKSA, a new organization based in Manila was established. Called Galian sa Arte at Tula (GAT), it would ensure the continued publication and presentation of progressive poetry, fiction, and plays. GAT would publish pamphlets and later on an anthology of works by its members, Galian: Mga Akda sa Panahon ng Krisis (Galian: Works in a Time of Crisis), 1983. Lubas sa Dagang Bisaya (Ludabi) would hold contests and publish the winners in its anthologies, like Katitikanong Ani (Literary Harvest), 1976, and Wagas (Pure), 1980.

The founding by Ilocano writers of Gunglo Dagiti Mannurat iti Iluko (GUMIL) and by Cebuano writers of Ludabi and Bathalan-ong Halad sa Dagang (Bathalad) would ensure the growth of Philippine literature. These organizations organize workshops and literary contests, and occasionally publish the works of their members. Bathalad has recruited writers from Mindanao since the late 1960s; Ludabi followed suit in 1975.

In 1980, the local government of Pampanga established Ligligan Pamaniulat Kapampangan, a poetry and short story writing contest, but this activity did not last beyond 1982, after a change in local administration. The stories that won vary in theme. “Bye Alamang” (A Dog’s Life) depicts the abuses of the Citizen Armed Force Geographical Unit or CAGFU; “Ing Kapagpabustan” (The Lost Opportunity), the financial failures of an aspiring migrant; and “Ing Hermanu Mayul” (The Hermano Mayor), the profligacy of an overseas worker’s father. These last two stories depict the growing phenomenon of Filipinos working abroad owing to the lack of economic opportunities in the country and are thus the beginnings of a growing body of literature about the migrant experience.

The winners at the Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature reflect the discontent and pent-up frustration with the Marcos government. Several of the short stories in Jun Cruz Reyes’s Utos ng Hari at Iba Pang Kuwento (The King’s Command and Other Stories), 1981, won at the Palanca Awards during the 1970s. The title story “Utos ng Hari” (The King’s Command) is about Jojo and his frustrations with the teachers and the school administration. The character’s adolescent angst may be taken symbolically as an attack on the repressiveness of martial law. Reyes’s first novel, Tutubi, Tutubi, ’Wag Kang Magpahuli sa Mamang Salbahe (Dragonfly, Dragonfly, Don’t Let the Bad Man Catch You), 1987, won the Palanca when the novel category was introduced in the early 1980s. A loose sequel to “Utos ng Hari,” Tutubi tells of Jojo and his friends becoming committed to the cause of social change.

Other novels that won the Palanca were Lualhati Bautista’s ’Gapo (Olongapo), Dekada ’70 (The 1970s), and Bata, Bata … Pa’no Ka Ginawa? (Child, Child … How Were You Made?). ’Gapo critiques the continued presence of the American military bases. Dekada ’70 depicts the life of a middle-class family during the martial law years as seen through the eyes of Amanda Bartolome, a wife and mother of four boys. Bata, Bata … Pa’no Ka Ginawa? tells the story of the unconventional relationships of liberal-minded Lea Bustamante.

Martial law was officially lifted in 1981, as a concession to Pope John Paul’s condition for his visiting the Philippines, but discontent did not end. The assassination of Benigno Aquino Jr in 1983 alienated more writers, simultaneous with the burgeoning of the alternative press: the Mr. and Ms. Special Editions and Pahayagang Malaya aka Malaya; later, the church-sponsored Veritas Newsmagazine, the Philippine Daily Inquirer, and the National Midweek Magazine. Of great significance for literary history was the letters-to-the-editor section of the daily newspaper Malaya. Called People’s Forum, the section included poems which were, as Malaya editor-in-chief Jose Burgos put it, “full of nationalism, courage, shock, and grief, and steadfast in the search for justice and truth.” Ordinary citizens were moved to express their outrage at the regime’s perpetration of the culture of violence, such as military forces firing at fleeing protesters in full view of the passengers of the Light Rail Transit along Taft Ave, Manila; desaparecidos and “salvaged” (summarily executed) victims bearing signs of torture as they were dug out of mass graves; and a child with a bloated belly dying slowly from starvation.

A yellow booklet of poems, titled In Memoriam: A Poetic Tribute by Five Filipino Poets, by founding members of the Philippine Literary Arts Council came out shortly after the assassination. Except for Alfrredo Navarro Salanga, who had been a political detainee in Davao City, the poets had not heretofore been associated with expressions or acts of protest against the oppressive regime. Indeed, their foreword described their poems as “the explosion of the authors’ poetic genius as it was mysteriously affronted, challenged, and seduced by Aquino’s death”; and they were writing “not as partisans in a partisan game but as witnesses to a universal drama.” Most of the writing is marked by erudition, such as allusions to Oedipus and Teiresias, Wallace Stevens and Lucas the Greek; a pun on the Latin proofreading mark sic; and the deconstruction of Aquino as a “word that was dead before it was uttered.”

At the opposite end of the aesthetic and ideological scale was “Makiisa: People’s Cultural Festival,” in which literary, visual, and performing artists from all over the country gathered for the first time in united opposition to Marcos’s authoritarian regime. It was held at the Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Fort Santiago, Manila, on 28-30 Dec 1983. The festival proceedings and primary works that were either exhibited or performed were anthologized in The Politics of Culture: The Philippine Experience, 1984, which included poems by Fidel Rillo Jr, Aida Santos-Maranan, Epifanio San Juan Jr, Lilia Quindoza-Santiago, and Jose F. Lacaba.

By the mid-1980s, Marcos’s health had deteriorated, and distrust of his policies had made his hold on power tenuous. In Nov 1985, to prove that he still had the support of the people, Marcos decided to hold a “snap elections.” Aquino’s widow Corazon ran against him. Amid allegations of election fraud, Marcos was proclaimed the winner of the elections, but at the instigation of the Catholic Bishops’ Conference of the Philippines, people began to gather at EDSA days later to support Marcos’s erstwhile defense minister Juan Ponce Enrile and chief of staff Fidel V. Ramos, both of whom had withdrawn their support of Marcos.

During the six-month period leading up to the snap elections in Feb 1986, Malaya published 35 poems in all. “Quo Vadis,” 12 Sep 1985, by Lourdes Oben Santos paints a dazzling picture of the opulence of the president’s palace to emphasize the dark squalor and “silence by deadly weapons” outside it. “Same Fate,” 13 Sep 1985, by A. L. Picardal, C.Ss.R., of Iligan City, uses the malodorous images of human sacrifice offered by “high priests of the infernal kingdoms and empires” to accuse cronies and government officials of their crimes. “Poverty,” 19 Oct 1985, by Leopoldo M. de la Cruz Jr contrasts the incomprehensible “strokes of Picasso in the lines of Cirilo Bautista” with the clear-cut meaning of beggars’ “empty plates and dirty hands.” “I Was Hungry (A Prayer from Negros),” 9 Nov 1985, by Vic J. Burla of Pavia, Iloilo, throws back at the elite class the popular excuses used for the sufferings of the hungry poor, such as their so-called ignorance, laziness, and colonial mentality. “Flowers on Fire,” 15 Dec 1985, by Helvecio Mendes rues the impunity of the killers of the Italian missionary Fr Tulio Favali, as they roam freely in Kidapawan while the mourners gather around his body at Barangay Esperanza Km 125. “Beyond Illusion,” 23 Jan 1986, by Fred Diamante points to the futility of a snap election with cynical questions. “Limericks,” 26 Feb 1986, by PYRJ Agipo of V&G Subd., Tacloban City, rhymes “Reagan” with “Ray Gun” and exposes the then US president’s faux pas in assuming that Marcos would win the elections still to be held (Balce 1986). This explosion of poetic indignation was gathered together in Versus: Philippine Protest Poetry, 1983-1986, which included not only selected poems previously published in the alternative papers and magazines but also contributions from those all over the country who responded to the editors’ call for such poems.

On 25 Feb 1986, Marcos and his family were flown by the United States from Malacañan Palace to Hawaii. The end of the Marcos presidency would usher in a new period in Philippine history and culture.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero and Christoffer Mitch C. Cerda, with notes from Vijae Alquisola, Rowena Festin, Paula Hernandez, May Maravilles, Marina Quilab, and Resil B. Mojares
