text:
Sections

The Winter of Our Discontent: Martial Law Literature
Democratization and Decentralization: Literature from the Regions
Writing Groups and the Academe
New and Renewed Directions
Conclusion

 

For four days in Feb 1986, people congregated at the portion of Epifanio de los Santos Avenue or EDSA where stood the headquarters of the Philippine National Police and the Armed Forces of the Philippines. Amid allegations of poll fraud, Ferdinand E. Marcos had been proclaimed the winner at the “snap elections.” Corazon C. Aquino, his opponent at the polls, had called for civil disobedience and a boycott of businesses owned by Marcos’s cronies, and Marcos’s former allies Juan Ponce Enrile and Fidel V. Ramos had decided to mount a coup. Getting wind of the plot, Marcos had ordered the two arrested, but Cardinal Jaime Sin urged people to rally behind Enrile and Ramos, who had ensconced themselves inside Camp Aguinaldo on EDSA. Crowds—as many as two million people, according to some estimates—flocked to EDSA, sharing food, flowers, prayers, and songs among themselves and with the soldiers, who had been tasked to disperse them. The military eventually defected.

The upshot of the EDSA Revolt was that Marcos and his family flew to Hawaii, and Aquino flew in from Cebu where she had been staying while crowds were gathering at EDSA, and was installed as the new president of the republic.

 

The Winter of Our Discontent: Martial Law Literature

One of the immediate effects of the EDSA Revolt was a freer press. Literature written during the Marcos years that were critical of the regime finally saw publication. Such were the Palanca award-winning Tagalog novels: Tutubi, Tutubi, ’Wag Kang Magpapahuli sa Mamang Salbahe (Dragonfly, Dragonfly, Don’t Let the Bad Man Catch You) by Jun Cruz Reyes in 1987, Dekada ’70 (The 1970s) and Bata, Bata … Pa’no Ka Ginawa? (Child, Child … How Were You Made?) by Lualhati Bautista in 1988. Avoiding possible reprisal, Linda Ty-Casper had published three novels depicting life under the Marcos dictatorship abroad: The Dread Empire, 1980; Awaiting Trespass, 1985; and Wings of Stone, 1986. The last two were locally reprinted in 1989 and 1990. The Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), which had been the domain of the former First Lady Imelda Marcos, published a set of anthologies of protest literature in 1987: Kamao: Panitikan ng Protesta 1970-1986; Tula (Fist: Protest Literature 1970-1986; Poetry), Kamao: Panitikan ng Protesta 1970-1986; Kuwento (Fist: Protest Literature 1970-1986; Short Story), and Kamao: Panitikan ng Protesta 1970-1986; Dula (Fist: Protest Literature 1970-1986; Play). Versus: Philippine Protest Poetry, 1983-1986, edited by Alfrredo Navarro Salanga and Esther M. Pacheco, has poems in Tagalog and English by some 50 poets.

 

After years of being circulated in manuscript or mimeographed form, underground literature came to the surface. STR: Mga Tula ng Digmang Bayan sa Pilipinas (STR: Poems of the People’s War in the Philippines), 1999, gathers together poems by Ruth Firmeza, Emmanuel Lacaba, Jason Montana, and Kris Montañez, to name a few. Firmeza’s revolutionary novel Gera (War) was published in 1991. These works dealt with the struggles of the revolutionary cadres against bureaucrat-capitalism, feudalism, and imperialism, with the emancipation of workers and peasants and the liberation of the Philippines from imperialist control as their goals.

Reflection and commentary on the Marcos years became common in literature produced after the EDSA Revolt. The disregard for human rights and human life is dramatized in Linda Ty-Casper’s novella A Small Party in a Garden, 1988, where a father and daughter, on their way home from a party, chance upon a “salvaging”—a term for summary execution that gained currency during the Marcos regime—and are violated in turn: the father is shot and the daughter is raped. Presenting the conflict between integrity and opportunism in a politically charged setting, Ty-Casper moves beyond Marcos to the EDSA event and its aftermath in the novel Dream Eden, 1996. Ninotchka Rosca’s State of War, 1988, offers an allegorical representation of the nation. Beneath the festival in the island of K— are torture, betrayal, and an assassination plot against “The Commander,” a figure for Marcos.

Literary accounts about the Marcos regime appear to be uniformly critical of it, but the Ilocano novel Saksi ti Kaunggan (Innermost Testimony), 1986-87, by S. P. Hidalgo paints an alternative portrait. The Marcos years represent the nation’s return to an Edenic state that was corrupted by colonial powers (Galam 2008, 163).

 
 

The installation of a new government did not spell the end of long-standing social problems. The fact that living conditions did not improve despite the restoration of democracy is reflected in the short stories published in Bisaya magazine. The works of Benjamin Montejo, Alberto Alforque, Sane Batomalaque, and Mario Batausa portrayed the frustration with and indignation of common folk over the government’s unfulfilled promises of social and political reforms (Baguio 1989, 1). Batomalaque’s “Ngadto Ipon sa mga Unggoy” (Into the Company of Monkeys), 1987, is desperate in its outlook: Felipe is a farmer who sells his carabao and mortgages his farm to pay an illegal recruiter so he can work abroad. His wife takes ill, his son abandons their farm in Davao because of the frequent encounters between the military and the guerrilla groups, and his daughter gives up being a nanny in Manila to be a guest relations officer in Olongapo. His friend tells him that there will be no end to the suffering unless the government curbs the greed of politicians and capitalists who have been making monkeys of common folk. Felipe sees the signs of a drought coming and realizes that his life is a drought. In his frustration he grabs a bolo and runs amok.

In Cebuano poetry, Don Pagusara’s unpublished “Kasingkasing sa Panahon, Panahon sa Kasingkasing” (Heart of the Season, Season of the Heart) revolves around the experiences of ordinary Filipinos under Aquino’s administration, especially when she declared “total war” against Communist insurgents a year into her presidency.

 

Democratization and Decentralization: Literature from the Regions

During the Marcos regime, support for the arts was centralized and controlled by the president and the First Lady from the capital. The situation changed after EDSA, with more writers and cultural workers from within and outside the capital initiating cultural and literary projects. In 1987, Aquino signed Executive Order 118, creating the Presidential Commission for Culture and the Arts. In 1992, Republic Act 7356 led to the creation of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA), the overall policymaking body of the Philippine government concerning culture and the arts.

 
 
 

Democratization can be seen in the changes introduced to the way the National Artist Award was conferred. Created in 1973 by Marcos as the highest state honor that a Filipino artist can receive, the award was given to painter Fernando Amorsolo as a posthumous honor. After its first year, however, the Board of Directors of the CCP had the task of selecting the recipients of the title, but the president had the final say on who received the award. The award thus was a way of strengthening patronage. After 1987, a process was formalized whereby officers of the NCCA, the CCP, and the National Artists who are still alive would deliberate on the nominations for the National Artist Award. They would finalize a list of recommendations that the president would then sign and approve. The tension between its authoritarian roots and the new democratic process, however, continued to plague it.

Given the mandate to encourage the growth of a Filipino national culture, the NCCA initiated activities to promote renewed interest in regional language literature, thus narrowing the divide between the center and the peripheries. It would fund the national and regional workshops and the publication of regional literature, like Haliya: Anthology of Bikol Poets and Poems, 1990, edited by Maria Lilia F. Realubit.

The efforts have extended into the new millennium. For instance, it funded the publication of Gremer Chan Reyes’s Men at Sea and Other Stories, 2009; Lina Espina- Moore’s novel Ang Inahan ni Mila (Mila’s Mother), 2008; Satur Apoyon’s collection of stories Ang Gakit ni Noebong (The Raft of Noebong), 2008; the Women in Literary Arts Inc or WILA’s Davao Harvest, 2008; Bathalan-ong Halad sa Dagang’s (Bathalad) Pasumbingay (Proverbs), 2009; and the Davao Writers Guild’s The Best of Dagmay: 2007-2009, 2010. It launched the Ubod New Authors Series in 2005 and 2010, a collection of chapbooks by writers writing in the local languages who had not had a book published.

In the late 1980s and the early 1990s, the CCP produced special issues of its literary journal, Ani, devoted to literatures from the regions. These include Cebuano, Waray, Bikol, and Karay-a. The poems, plays, stories, and essays come with Filipino or English translations.

The presses of Ateneo de Manila University, De La Salle University, and the University of the Philippines entered into a consortium to publish and translate works from the regions. The Panitikan series, as the collection of books was called, made available out-of-print or never before printed works both from the center (Tagalog) and from the regions. Among the titles are Marcel M. Navarra: Mga Piling Kuwentong Sebuwano (Marcel M. Navarra: Selected Cebuano Stories), 1986; Sugilanon: Mga Piling Maikling Kuwentong Hiligaynon (Sugilanon: Selected Hiligaynon Stories), 1991; Panulaan at Dulaang Leytenhon-Samarnon (Leyte-Samar Poetry and Drama), 1994; Maikling Kuwentong Kapampangan at Pangasinan (Kapampangan and Pangasinan Short Stories), 1996; Tula at Kuwento ng Katutubong Bukidnon (Poems and Stories of the Indigenous Bukidnon), 1996; and Siday: Mga Tulang Bayan ng Panay at Negros (Siday: Folk Poetry of Panay and Negros), 1997.

These publications dovetailed with the scholarly efforts that had begun in the 1970s, the period of nationalism, when Filipino literary scholars and critics began to collect and describe, or record and transcribe in the case of oral literature, specimens of local language literatures as part of their dissertations and theses.

Outside of the Panitikan series, literature from the regions was published, usually with the support of universities based in the regions or of research institutions. Thus were the two-volume anthology Cebuano Poetry / Sugboanong Balak, 1988, published by the Cebuano Studies Center, and the multivolume Darangen, 1986-88, published by the Mindanao State University, University Research Center.

Kapampangan literature suffered after the eruption of Mount Pinatubo in 1991, literally and figuratively buried under an avalanche of lahar, to reemerge only in the new millennium through the efforts of Kapampangan centers. Surviving manuscripts and artifacts of Kapampangan culture were collected. Tuglong: A Kapampangan Journal (Bud: A Kapampangan Journal), 2002, was the first anthology of Kapampangan writing to emerge from the ashes. This anthology, published with the help of the Central Luzon Assistance Research Cooperative, consists of two parts: a section featuring the works of “Ding Lumang Talasulat” (The Old Writers)—Crisostomo Sotto, Canuto Tolentino, Ciriaco Sanchez, Diosdado Macapagal, Gonzalo Martin, Delfin Quiboloy, Rodolfo Mallari Sr, Querubin Fernandez Jr, Ted Panopio, and Felix Garcia—and a section on the works of “Ding Kaynakang Talasulat” (The Young Writers)—Juliet Mallari, Anne Carol D. Mabanta, Cesar Cachero, Anne Therese D. Mabanta, Timothy Sanchez, and Jay Mendoza. The poems of Jose Gallardo, regarded as a transition poet, are placed between the two sections.

The Academia ning Amanung Sisuan International and the Center for Kapampangan Studies of the Holy Angel University published in 2008 the anthology Kasapunggul a Sampaga (A Bunch of Flowers) and in 2010 Kasapunggul a Sampaga II. The first is a collection of 116 poems by Renato B. Alzadon, a Kapampangan writer based in the United States; the second is an anthology of prose and poems on various subjects by veteran and contemporary Kapampangan writers, among them Renato B. Alzadon, Ernesto Turla, Rafael David Manigago, Pedro Rivera Alzadon, Josefina Dizon Henson, Tec Sanchez-Tolosa, Myra Paz Lopez, Edgardo Bonus Sale, Tony Mecado Peña, Willie T. Dizon, and Ray Romero Tanjoco.

Efforts at fostering and preserving literature from the regions continue today, with serialized novels being published as a book and short stories and poems being compiled and translated for single-author collections or for anthologies. Examples are Hagkus: Twentieth-Century Bikol Women Writers, 2003, edited by Paz Verdades M. Santos, and the two-volume Cebuano Fiction / Sugilanong Sugboanon, 2014, edited by Erlinda K. Alburo, Vicente Bandillo, Simeon Dumdum Jr, and Resil B. Mojares. The recent establishment of the Ateneo de Naga University Press has provided another avenue for Bikol writing, even as the press’s output has been eclectic in terms of language, region, and genre. It has published poetry collections written in English, like Eighty-Four Words for Sorrow, 2015, by Simeon Dumdum, a Cebuano; in Karay-a, like Sa Gihapon, Palangga, ang Uran (Always, Beloved, the Rain), 2015, by Genevieve L. Asenjo with translations by Ma. Milagros Geremia-Lachica; in Bikol, like Cancion nin mga Tawong-Lipod (Song of the Invisible Man), 2014, by H. Francisco V. Peñones Jr, and Tignarakol (Poetry), 2013, by Luis Cabalquinto; and an anthology of short stories in Bikol, Hagong: Mga Osipon (Resonate: Stories), 2013, edited by Paz Verdades Santos and H. Francisco V. Peñones Jr.

In 2001, Filipinos Writing: Philippine Literature from the Regions, edited by Bienvenido Lumbera, was published by a trade publisher and is generally considered a definitive anthology of works from the regions. The validation of regional literature could also be seen with the inclusion of Cebuano, Ilocano, and Hiligaynon divisions in the short story category of the Palanca Awards beginning in 1997.

 

Writing Groups and the Academe

Writers’ groups were established and flourished in the wake of the Marcos government. These groups would enliven the literary scene by conducting workshops, holding writing contests, and anthologizing the works of their members for publication.

Some members of Unyon ng mga Manunulat sa Pilipinas or UMPIL broke away because of ideological differences and founded Pambansang Unyon ng mga Manunulat sa Pilipinas or Panulat. Linangan sa Imahen, Retorika, at Anyo, or LIRA, established in 1985 by Virgilio S. Almario, was originally conceptualized as a poetry clinic; it became one of the leading poetry organizations in Tagalog. LIRA would publish two anthologies in 1988 and 1990, Unang Bagting (First Chord) and Parikala (Irony), respectively. Many of its members would go on to write their own collections of poetry. A group of Tagalog fictionists formed Katha in 1989. Katha would continue the radical and political strain of short stories but would also introduce postmodern experimentation in their works. It would publish four anthologies between 1989 and 1997: Engkwentro (Encounter), 1989; Impetu (Impetus), 1990; Habilin (Message before Leaving), 1990; and Alagwa (Surge), 1997. Many of its members would also publish their own collections of stories. In Alibangbang at Iba Pang Kuwento (Alibangbang and Other Stories), 1992, and Fastfood, Megamall at Iba Pang Kwento sa Pagsasara ng Ikalawang Milenyum (Fastfood, Megamall and Other Stories at the End of the Second Millennium), 1999, Rolando B. Tolentino tackled the iniquities of the capitalist system while using postmodern experimentations with form.

In Cebu, many writers’ organizations would also be established to rival Lubas sa Dagang Bisaya or Ludabi, which remains, however, as the biggest association of Cebuano writers. Bathalad evolved to include filmmakers, musicians, and visual artists who saw the need to connect their craft to literature. The Magsusulat Inc, formed by Cebuano writers based in Manila, holds annual literary competitions, the winners at which were published in Sanggi (Harvest), 1992. Unlike other writers’ groups, Dagang Foundation Inc holds contests strictly for nonmembers. Tarantula was founded in 1996 by a new breed of young writers in Cebu. Kaliwat ni Karyapa was formed by young Boholano writers in honor of Karyapa, Bohol’s only documented babaylan (native priestess). Women in Literary Arts Inc (WILA), perhaps the only organized women writers’ group in the country today, provides publishing opportunities. The Bohol Alternative Literary Arts Council and Davao Writers Guild hold regular literary competitions and workshops. The former has produced two anthologies of award-winning works—Sobo 1 (Emergence 1) and Sobo 2 (Emergence 2)—while the latter publishes Dagmay, formerly a literary journal, now a weekly literary page of Sun Star Davao. Nomads attempts to “liberate” literature from the academe. The group holds poetry readings in the streets or in bus/jeepney terminals and storytelling sessions for children in slums or in the malls. All these groups are active.

In Pampanga, the Aguman Ding Talasulat Kapampangan published Siwala King Ilang (Voice from the Desert) in 2002, an anthology of 155 poems. About various aspects of Kapampangan life, the anthology was edited with the expressed purpose of preserving the beauty and purity of the Kapampangan language.

As writers’ organizations provide material support and training for their members, writing centers based in universities provide institutional validation for creative writing. Such writing centers sprouted in the 1990s: the Bienvenido N. Santos Creative Writing Center (BNSCWC), established in 1991 at De La Salle University (DLSU), the UST Center for Creative Writing and Literary Studies (CCWLS), established in 1999 at the University of Santo Tomas (UST), and the Ateneo Institute of Literary Arts and Practices or AILAP, established in 2001 at Ateneo de Manila University. Likhaan: UP Center for Creative Writing, established in 1979 at the University of the Philippines, was renamed Likhaan: UP Institute of Creative Writing (ICW) in 2002. These centers have established their own writing workshops to rival those being offered by UP ICW and Silliman University.

Other universities, though without formal writing centers, also began offering writing workshops. The Mindanao State University–Iligan Institute of Technology established the Iligan National Writers Workshop in 1994, what is perhaps the first truly national writers’ workshop; it allocates an equal representation from Luzon, Visayas, and Mindanao. The BNSCWC and the University of St. La Salle in Bacolod City, Negros Occidental, established the IYAS Creative Writing Workshop in 2001.

Apart from housing writing centers and hosting workshops, more universities began to offer degrees in creative writing, leading to the “academization” of literary production. The outcome is more experimental or intellectual writing, which alienates many readers accustomed to popular fare. Campus literary production was supported by student organizations and publications. Holdovers from previous decades, like Heights (Ateneo) and Varsitarian (UST), were joined by the Tomasian Writers Guild (UST), Malate (DLSU), Ugat (UP), Marejada (Ateneo de Zamboanga), and other groups. Campus organizations and publications are fertile breeding grounds for future writers.

The UP ICW in particular has had a gatekeeping function. In the 1990s until 2002, it published a series of anthologies reprinting what it thought was the best poems, stories, and essays of the year. The Likhaan books, as they were called, were discontinued, but the UP ICW continues to publish an annual journal, called Likhaan: The Journal of Contemporary Philippine Literature, which prints the best unpublished writings for the year.

 

New and Renewed Directions

Feminism and feminist literary criticism promoted the recovery of women’s writings and encouraged new writings by women and scholarship on the same. The anthologies Songs of Ourselves, 1994, edited by Edna Zapanta Manlapaz and Ang Silid ng Mahiwaga (The Enchanted Room), 1994, edited by Soledad S. Reyes, offer an overview of writings, in English and Tagalog, respectively, by Filipino women. Sa Ngalan ng Ina (In the Name of the Mother), 1997, by Lilia Quindoza-Santiago studies Philippine feminist poetry and includes an anthology of feminist poems not just in English and Filipino but also in Ilocano. An English translation of the book was published in 2002. Paz Verdades Santos’s Hagkus: Twentieth Century Bikol Women Writers, 2003, is its Bikol counterpart. The term “hagkus” refers to the piece of cloth Bikol women traditionally wrap around their middle after they give birth.

Edna Zapanta Manlapaz also wrote biographies of women writers—Angela Manalang Gloria, Estrella Alfon, and Lina Espina-Moore—and collected the poems of Manalang Gloria (The Complete Poems of Angela Manalang Gloria, 1995) and the stories of Loreto Paras-Sulit (Harvest and Other Stories by Loreto Paras Sulit, 2001). With Marjorie Evasco, she wrote Six Women Poets: Inter/Views with Angela Manalang Gloria, Trinidad Tarrosa Subido, Edith L. Tiempo, Virginia Moreno, Tita Lacambra-Ayala, Ophelia Dimalanta, 1996. Soledad S. Reyes wrote a biography of Rosario de Guzman Lingat (Rosario de Guzaman Lingat, 1924-1997: The Burden of Self and History, 2003) and prepared editions of her fiction long and short. She also edited the stories, columns, and radio scripts of Lina Flor (Lina Flor: Collected Works, 2000). Eva V. Kalaw collected the short stories of Paz Latorena in Desire and Other Stories by Paz Latorena, 2000, and Herminia Santos-Bas, the stories of Estrella Alfon in The Estrella D. Alfon Anthology, 2000.

WILA has produced the anthologies Centering Voices, 1995; Fern Garden: Anthology of Women Writing in the South, 1998; Sinug-ang: A Cebuano Trio (Trivet: A Cebuano Trio), 1999; Babayeng Sugid: Cebu Stories (Woman Story: Cebu Stories), 2012; and Travel Book, 2013. These feature the works of Erma Quizon, Erlinda Alburo, Cora Almerino, Ester Tapia, Leticia Suarez, Ruby Enario-Carlino, and Merlie Alunan. Their views on women’s issues—such as single parenthood, misogyny and self-concept, and marital relations—are progressive.

The Forbidden Fruit: Women Write the Erotic, 1992, and Kung Ibig Mo: Love Poetry by Women (If You So Desire It), 1993, were anthologies bold for their time. Single-author collections of poetry where a distinctly female consciousness asserts itself include Marjorie Evasco’s Dreamweavers: Selected Poems, 1976-1986, 1987, and Ochre Tones: Poems in English and Cebuano, 1999; Joi Barrios’s Ang Pagiging Babae Ay Pamumuhay sa Panahon ng Digma (To Be a Woman Is to Live at a Time of War), 1990; Elynia S. Mabanglo’s Kung Di Man: Mga Tula ng Pag-ibig, 1970-1992 (If It Weren’t So: Love Poems, 1970-1992), 1992; and Merlie Alunan’s Amina among the Angels, 1997, and Tales of the Spiderwoman, 2010.

Another minority literature that received increased attention in the 1990s was gay literature. Landmark works are Tony Perez’s Cubao books, which use Cubao as a setting to explore the concerns of gay males in the city, and some poems in Nicolas Pichay’s Ang Lunes na Mahirap Bunuin (The Intransigence of Mondays), 1993, a collection of poems.

The publication of the Ladlad anthologies, 1994, 1996, 2007, edited by J. Neil Garcia and Danton Remoto, allowed more gay voices to be heard. Garcia’s Philippine Gay Culture: The Last Thirty Years, 1996, is a pioneering work on the shifting discourses of homosexuality in the Philippines and an analysis of the sexual politics in selected works by Severino Montano, Orlando Nadres, and Tony Perez. Honorio Bartolome de Dios’s Sa Labas ng Parlor (Outside the Parlor), 1998, pushed Philippine gay literature into new territory. De Dios’s stories take Filipino gays out of the beauty parlor, which has been their ghetto, and depicts them in life’s various situations, as being sons, lovers, and political activists. Other writers who have written on the gay or lesbian experience are Ronald Baytan, Jhoanna Lynn Cruz, Jaime An Lim, Ralph Galan, and Aida Santos.

Gay writing broke into Cebuano literature at the start of the new millennium. In 2002, Rolando Salvaña’s “Libat” (Cross-eyed) won first place in the Cebuano short story category at the Palanca Awards. The blame for a catch of mysterious cross-eyed fish is pinned on gay people, who are promptly rounded up and jailed. Some days later, the townspeople demand the release of the detainees. Carl, a hairdresser and one of the detainees, realizes that it is Saturday, a day for weddings, debuts, baptisms, and other occasions for dolling up.

The period also saw a boom in the production of children’s literature and young adult fiction. Joining the game were several players—Adarna, Bookmark, Cacho, Tahanan, Lampara, and Anvil—which draw on folk literature and traditional stories but also encourage the production of new original material for young readers. Among the writers are Ma. Elena Paterno, Neni Sta. Romana Cruz, Marla Yotoko Chorengel, Ramon Sunico, and Rene O. Villanueva. A younger generation of writers include Christine Bellen, Glenda Oris, Eugene Evasco, and Jomike Tejido. Young adult fiction is being produced by Carla Pacis, Cyan Abad-Jugo, and Candy Quimpo Gourlay.

The Asian economic crisis in 1997 did not spare the Philippines, prompting many Filipinos to seek employment abroad and even emigration. The pull of employment overseas was already strong even in the 1980s, but it acquired unprecedented traction in the new millennium, when the full effects of the crisis began to be felt. More than 10 million Filipinos are now working in foreign lands. The 1990s saw the publication of works featuring the experiences of the growing Filipino migrant population. Such are Wilfredo Pa. Virtusio’s “Voicetape,” Fanny A. Garcia’s “Arrivederci,” and Luna Sicat-Cleto’s Mga Prodigal (The Prodigals), 2010. “Voicetape” revolves around a lost recording that captures the financial and sexual frustrations of overseas workers and their families. The conditions of Filipinos working in Italy are recounted in “Arrivederci.” The novel Mga Prodigal deals with the difficulties experienced by migrant workers in the Middle East and their families’ ways of coping.

Ruth Elynia Mabanglo presents the underside of migrant life in her collections Anyaya ng Imperyalista / Invitation of the Imperialist, 1998, and Mesa para sa Isa (Table for One), 2002. The case of Flor Contemplacion, a Filipino nanny executed in Singapore, inspired “Tulang Haka ni Flor Contemplacion” (A Conjectural Poem by Flor Contemplacion), a poem that likens her suffering to the passion, death, and resurrection of Jesus Christ. Loneliness and longing for the native land are the themes of her poems.

Migration of a different sort has resulted in the creation of a brand of Mindanao literature. Cebuano writing in Mindanao has evolved from being an extension of Cebuano writing in the Visayas to a literature tackling distinctly Mindanaoan themes—tension between cultural groups, the fragility of peace and security, and environmental exploitation. Mindanaoan literature, however, also reflects the national experience of poverty and unemployment. Marcelo Geocallo’s “Diin didto May Bagtikan sa Pugarang Banog” (Where the Hawk’s Nest Is Strong), 1995, is told from the point of view of Sultan Malawi, a Maranao chieftain who tries to protect the forests from illegal logging. Some of the people, including Malawi’s own son, however, have capitulated. Malawi, however, refuses to give up, in the end succeeding in redeeming their ancestral land. Ricardo Hynson’s “Si Eking Bulhog ug ang Kasugiran ni Tang Biyong” (Eking Bulhog and the Story of Tang Biyong), 1997, juxtaposes the experience of a modern Mindanaoan named Eking Bulhog and the legend of Tang Biyong, a local deity who causes a great deluge every so often. The story is a commentary on the wanton destruction of forestland in Mindanao, which has added to the severity of flash floods.

Writing in English, Antonio Reyes Enriquez recounts the displacement of indigenous communities in Zamboanga by militarization in Subanons, 1999. In the title story of Mig Alvarez Enriquez’s The White Horse of Alih and Other Stories, 1985, the protagonist is compelled to perform ritual suicide to avenge the wrongs Christians have done to his family. Mig Alvarez Enriquez continues to write on Zamboanga in his collection Life Strokes: Blood on the Moon and Other Stories, 1996. Sikami'n Lumad: Bagong Panitikan ng Katutubong Mindanao (New Literature of Indigenous Mindanao), 2005, contains poems, stories, chants, and rituals by writers from the different lumad (indigenous) groups of Mindanao, with Filipino translations.

The centennial of Philippine independence in 1998 was an opportune time for writers to reflect and comment on the history and state of the nation. The Philippine Centennial Literary Prize, the most lucrative and most publicized literary competition since the Commonwealth Literary Contests in 1940, provided the occasion for such literary activity. The winners in the novel category in the English division were My Sad Republic, 2000, by Eric Gamalinda; An Embarrassment of Riches, 2000, by Charlson Ong; and Voyeurs and Savages, 1998, by Alfred A. Yuson. In Filipino, Etsa-Puwera (Outsider), 2000, by Jun Cruz Reyes and Ang Aso, ang Pulgas, ang Bonsai at ang Kolorum (The Dog, the Flea, the Bonsai and the Colorum Movement), 2000, by Jose Rey Munsayac tied for first place. The second and third prizes went to (H)istoryador(a), 2006, by Vim Nadera and Tari (Cockspur), 2000, by Sergio Custodio Jr, respectively. Prizes for the epic were given to Cirilo F. Bautista for Sunlight on Broken Stones, 2000, in the English division; and to Reynaldo Duque for Candon, 2000, Teo T. Antonio for Piping-Dilat (Wide-Eyed Mute), 2000, Vim Nadera for Mujer Indigena (Indigenous Women), 2000, and Pedro L. Ricarte for Lupang Hinirang (Chosen Land), 2000, in the Filipino division.

Outside of the Centennial Literary Prize, Philippine history was generally a source of material for writers in the post-EDSA decades. Cristina Pantoja-Hidalgo’s Recuerdo, 1997, Alfred A. Yuson’s Great Philippine Jungle Energy Café, 1988, Gina Apostol’s The Revolution according to Raymundo Mata, 2009, and F. Sionil Jose’s Viajero (Traveler), 1998, are built around significant episodes of Philippine history and use metafictional devices, paratextual information, anachronism, and other experiments to problematize historiography itself. In Tagalog, works that have similar characteristics include Uro Q. de la Cruz’s Antyng-antyng (Talisman), 2003, and Ramon Guilliermo’s Ang Makina ni Mang Turing (Mang Turing’s Machine), 2013.

While realism is still a dominant mode of writing, many writes have begun to use other modes—horror, magic realism, science fiction, fantasy. The Philippine Speculative Fiction anthologies, 2005-10, would showcase some of these works. Dean Francis Alfar’s novel Salamanca, 2006, and Nikki Alfar’s collection of short stories Now, Then, and Elsewhen, 2013, are perhaps the best examples of local speculative fiction.

A number of writers who had relied on realism in presenting their analysis and criticism of Philippine society have also experimented with the speculative mode, without necessarily sacrificing the social content. Thus Ricky Lee’s Si Amapola sa 65 Kabanata (Amapola in 65 Chapters), 2011, has a manananggal (self-segmenting ghoul) as the protagonist given the mission to save society; and Jun Cruz Reyes’s Etsa-Puwera, 2000, presents a panorama of Philippine history through the experiences of a family, whose genealogy can be traced back to a union between a human and a deer transformed by the gods into a woman. Alvin B. Yapan’s Ang Sandali ng mga Mata (The Moment of the Eyes), 2006, Edgar Calabia Samar’s Walong Diwata ng Pagkahulog (Eight Muses of the Fall), 2009, and Kasunod ng 909 (After 909), 2012, and Allan Derain’s Ang Banal na Aklat ng mga Kumag (The Holy Little Book of Pests), 2013, explore history, myth, fantasy, and metafiction.

 

Popular Culture and New Media

The last 20 years saw the rise of genre fiction, like chick lit and romance novels, which greatly surpass “literary” works in sales and popularity. Precious Pages specializes in romance novels, written in Filipino or in a mix of Tagalog and English. In the mid-1990s, some writers attempted to sell “alternative romances,” which reverse the conventions, formulas, and sexist assumptions of typical romance novels, but these did not succeed. Chick lit, which supposedly features empowered women, caters to an English-reading public.

Globalization has made American popular culture and popular culture products from Korea and Japan even more pervasive and, as some might argue, pernicious. The history of the Philippine comic book is illustrative. The comic books of the 1990s and the new millennium bear little resemblance to the komiks of the earlier decades, which had adapted the American comic book for a local mass readership. The new comic books, many of which are in English, bearing illustrations in the style of manga, and costing more than what the daily wage earner makes, speak for and to a middle class who is urbane and steeped in American or American-mediated culture. To be sure, in a number of cases, native materials, usually the supernatural creatures of Philippine folklore, are also used, and local realities, like criminality and poverty, are depicted. The overall tone, however, is arguably Gotham City rather than Quezon City. Similarly, American rap music has influenced the local traditions of poetic jousting, giving rise to rap battles among the Tagalog, the encuentro among the Zamboangueños, and the hinampakay og letra among the Iliganon. In their choice of subject matter and use of chants and insults among other traits, these bear resemblances to native forms.

Recent developments in communication technology have resulted in the emergence of new forms of literary expression and new ways of circulating them. The cell phone gave birth to text poems or textula. Frank Rivera’s Makata sa Cellphone (Cell Phone Poet), 2005, is a collection of over 200 such poems. The anthologies Textanaga, 2003, Dalitext, 2003, and Dionatext, 2004, as their titles imply, consist of traditional Tagalog poetic forms that were composed using the cell phone’s Short Message Service feature.

The internet has democratized literary space. Online platforms like Wattpad have allowed just about anyone to post stories and poems. A number of them are selected by publishers for print editions. Some of these have, in turn, been adapted for the movies and television. These have been consistent best sellers. Given its laissez-faire nature, works produced in such platforms are not considered literary in some circles. The Wattpad novels are heavily influenced by Korean telenovelas and other brands of globalized popular culture.

Alongside these popular or commercial productions are coterie productions. Independent publishing has grown as more writers also want to publish outside the space of academe and commercial publications. High Chair publishes original poetry collections and chapbooks in Filipino and English that are not usually accepted by university presses and commercial publishers. The Youth and Beauty Brigade (YBB) features experimental works heavily influenced by the French experimental group Ouvroir de Litterature Potentielle or Oulipo. Pastiche, erasures, cut and paste and other techniques can be seen in works like Adam David’s The El Bimbo Variations, 2005. Both publishers have an online presence. High Chair has an online journal while YBB distributes its works online for free.

The popular magazines of the Manila Bulletin, Liwayway, Bisaya, Hiligaynon, and Bannawag, would still be an outlet for the publication of many regional literatures, but with the advent of the internet and indie publications, their prestige waned in the 1990s. Recent attempts to reestablish the prestige of these magazines can be seen in their projects that aimed to encourage the participation of younger writers and readers. In 2004, Bisaya instituted the Young Blood Writers Program, a 12-month apprenticeship program where select young writers regularly submit works to the editors for critiquing and publication. After a year, the magazine “graduates” only one writer as the “most promising new writer in Bisaya.” The program is part of the magazine’s efforts to make itself more appealing to younger readers and writers. Another attempt would be trying to publish their magazines in online platforms like Buqo so it can reach newer audiences that use mobile devices and tablets.

 

Conclusion

Philippine literature since the EDSA Revolt bears the history of the republic. It is characterized by the entry of once-marginalized authors, themes, and genres into mainstream literature, the thrust toward the retrieval and recuperation of regional literatures other than Tagalog, and the creation of democratic spaces by new media. Competing politics and aesthetics—feminism, Marxism, formalism, postmodernism, nationalism, and other -isms—inform the writing of many writers. New institutions, organizations, publications, and technologies compete to push Philippine literature toward the future.  Written by Christopher Mitch Cerda, with notes from Vijae Alquisola, Rowena Festin, Paula Hernandez, May Maravilles, and Marina Quilab

article.value: Sections

For four days in Feb 1986, people congregated at the portion of Epifanio de los Santos Avenue or EDSA where stood the headquarters of the Philippine National Police and the Armed Forces of the Philippines. Amid allegations of poll fraud, Ferdinand E. Marcos had been proclaimed the winner at the “snap elections.” Corazon C. Aquino, his opponent at the polls, had called for civil disobedience and a boycott of businesses owned by Marcos’s cronies, and Marcos’s former allies Juan Ponce Enrile and Fidel V. Ramos had decided to mount a coup. Getting wind of the plot, Marcos had ordered the two arrested, but Cardinal Jaime Sin urged people to rally behind Enrile and Ramos, who had ensconced themselves inside Camp Aguinaldo on EDSA. Crowds—as many as two million people, according to some estimates—flocked to EDSA, sharing food, flowers, prayers, and songs among themselves and with the soldiers, who had been tasked to disperse them. The military eventually defected.

The upshot of the EDSA Revolt was that Marcos and his family flew to Hawaii, and Aquino flew in from Cebu where she had been staying while crowds were gathering at EDSA, and was installed as the new president of the republic.
The Winter of Our Discontent: Martial Law Literature

One of the immediate effects of the EDSA Revolt was a freer press. Literature written during the Marcos years that were critical of the regime finally saw publication. Such were the Palanca award-winning Tagalog novels: Tutubi, Tutubi, ’Wag Kang Magpapahuli sa Mamang Salbahe (Dragonfly, Dragonfly, Don’t Let the Bad Man Catch You) by Jun Cruz Reyes in 1987, Dekada ’70 (The 1970s) and Bata, Bata … Pa’no Ka Ginawa? (Child, Child … How Were You Made?) by Lualhati Bautista in 1988. Avoiding possible reprisal, Linda Ty-Casper had published three novels depicting life under the Marcos dictatorship abroad: The Dread Empire, 1980; Awaiting Trespass, 1985; and Wings of Stone, 1986. The last two were locally reprinted in 1989 and 1990. The Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), which had been the domain of the former First Lady Imelda Marcos, published a set of anthologies of protest literature in 1987: Kamao: Panitikan ng Protesta 1970-1986; Tula (Fist: Protest Literature 1970-1986; Poetry), Kamao: Panitikan ng Protesta 1970-1986; Kuwento (Fist: Protest Literature 1970-1986; Short Story), and Kamao: Panitikan ng Protesta 1970-1986; Dula (Fist: Protest Literature 1970-1986; Play). Versus: Philippine Protest Poetry, 1983-1986, edited by Alfrredo Navarro Salanga and Esther M. Pacheco, has poems in Tagalog and English by some 50 poets.

article.value: After years of being circulated in manuscript or mimeographed form, underground literature came to the surface. STR: Mga Tula ng Digmang Bayan sa Pilipinas (STR: Poems of the People’s War in the Philippines), 1999, gathers together poems by Ruth Firmeza, Emmanuel Lacaba, Jason Montana, and Kris Montañez, to name a few. Firmeza’s revolutionary novel Gera (War) was published in 1991. These works dealt with the struggles of the revolutionary cadres against bureaucrat-capitalism, feudalism, and imperialism, with the emancipation of workers and peasants and the liberation of the Philippines from imperialist control as their goals.

Reflection and commentary on the Marcos years became common in literature produced after the EDSA Revolt. The disregard for human rights and human life is dramatized in Linda Ty-Casper’s novella A Small Party in a Garden, 1988, where a father and daughter, on their way home from a party, chance upon a “salvaging”—a term for summary execution that gained currency during the Marcos regime—and are violated in turn: the father is shot and the daughter is raped. Presenting the conflict between integrity and opportunism in a politically charged setting, Ty-Casper moves beyond Marcos to the EDSA event and its aftermath in the novel Dream Eden, 1996. Ninotchka Rosca’s State of War, 1988, offers an allegorical representation of the nation. Beneath the festival in the island of K— are torture, betrayal, and an assassination plot against “The Commander,” a figure for Marcos.

Literary accounts about the Marcos regime appear to be uniformly critical of it, but the Ilocano novel Saksi ti Kaunggan (Innermost Testimony), 1986-87, by S. P. Hidalgo paints an alternative portrait. The Marcos years represent the nation’s return to an Edenic state that was corrupted by colonial powers (Galam 2008, 163).

article.value: The installation of a new government did not spell the end of long-standing social problems. The fact that living conditions did not improve despite the restoration of democracy is reflected in the short stories published in Bisaya magazine. The works of Benjamin Montejo, Alberto Alforque, Sane Batomalaque, and Mario Batausa portrayed the frustration with and indignation of common folk over the government’s unfulfilled promises of social and political reforms (Baguio 1989, 1). Batomalaque’s “Ngadto Ipon sa mga Unggoy” (Into the Company of Monkeys), 1987, is desperate in its outlook: Felipe is a farmer who sells his carabao and mortgages his farm to pay an illegal recruiter so he can work abroad. His wife takes ill, his son abandons their farm in Davao because of the frequent encounters between the military and the guerrilla groups, and his daughter gives up being a nanny in Manila to be a guest relations officer in Olongapo. His friend tells him that there will be no end to the suffering unless the government curbs the greed of politicians and capitalists who have been making monkeys of common folk. Felipe sees the signs of a drought coming and realizes that his life is a drought. In his frustration he grabs a bolo and runs amok.

In Cebuano poetry, Don Pagusara’s unpublished “Kasingkasing sa Panahon, Panahon sa Kasingkasing” (Heart of the Season, Season of the Heart) revolves around the experiences of ordinary Filipinos under Aquino’s administration, especially when she declared “total war” against Communist insurgents a year into her presidency.
Democratization and Decentralization: Literature from the Regions

During the Marcos regime, support for the arts was centralized and controlled by the president and the First Lady from the capital. The situation changed after EDSA, with more writers and cultural workers from within and outside the capital initiating cultural and literary projects. In 1987, Aquino signed Executive Order 118, creating the Presidential Commission for Culture and the Arts. In 1992, Republic Act 7356 led to the creation of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA), the overall policymaking body of the Philippine government concerning culture and the arts.

article.value: Democratization can be seen in the changes introduced to the way the National Artist Award was conferred. Created in 1973 by Marcos as the highest state honor that a Filipino artist can receive, the award was given to painter Fernando Amorsolo as a posthumous honor. After its first year, however, the Board of Directors of the CCP had the task of selecting the recipients of the title, but the president had the final say on who received the award. The award thus was a way of strengthening patronage. After 1987, a process was formalized whereby officers of the NCCA, the CCP, and the National Artists who are still alive would deliberate on the nominations for the National Artist Award. They would finalize a list of recommendations that the president would then sign and approve. The tension between its authoritarian roots and the new democratic process, however, continued to plague it.

Given the mandate to encourage the growth of a Filipino national culture, the NCCA initiated activities to promote renewed interest in regional language literature, thus narrowing the divide between the center and the peripheries. It would fund the national and regional workshops and the publication of regional literature, like Haliya: Anthology of Bikol Poets and Poems, 1990, edited by Maria Lilia F. Realubit.

The efforts have extended into the new millennium. For instance, it funded the publication of Gremer Chan Reyes’s Men at Sea and Other Stories, 2009; Lina Espina- Moore’s novel Ang Inahan ni Mila (Mila’s Mother), 2008; Satur Apoyon’s collection of stories Ang Gakit ni Noebong (The Raft of Noebong), 2008; the Women in Literary Arts Inc or WILA’s Davao Harvest, 2008; Bathalan-ong Halad sa Dagang’s (Bathalad) Pasumbingay (Proverbs), 2009; and the Davao Writers Guild’s The Best of Dagmay: 2007-2009, 2010. It launched the Ubod New Authors Series in 2005 and 2010, a collection of chapbooks by writers writing in the local languages who had not had a book published.

In the late 1980s and the early 1990s, the CCP produced special issues of its literary journal, Ani, devoted to literatures from the regions. These include Cebuano, Waray, Bikol, and Karay-a. The poems, plays, stories, and essays come with Filipino or English translations.

The presses of Ateneo de Manila University, De La Salle University, and the University of the Philippines entered into a consortium to publish and translate works from the regions. The Panitikan series, as the collection of books was called, made available out-of-print or never before printed works both from the center (Tagalog) and from the regions. Among the titles are Marcel M. Navarra: Mga Piling Kuwentong Sebuwano (Marcel M. Navarra: Selected Cebuano Stories), 1986; Sugilanon: Mga Piling Maikling Kuwentong Hiligaynon (Sugilanon: Selected Hiligaynon Stories), 1991; Panulaan at Dulaang Leytenhon-Samarnon (Leyte-Samar Poetry and Drama), 1994; Maikling Kuwentong Kapampangan at Pangasinan (Kapampangan and Pangasinan Short Stories), 1996; Tula at Kuwento ng Katutubong Bukidnon (Poems and Stories of the Indigenous Bukidnon), 1996; and Siday: Mga Tulang Bayan ng Panay at Negros (Siday: Folk Poetry of Panay and Negros), 1997.

These publications dovetailed with the scholarly efforts that had begun in the 1970s, the period of nationalism, when Filipino literary scholars and critics began to collect and describe, or record and transcribe in the case of oral literature, specimens of local language literatures as part of their dissertations and theses.

Outside of the Panitikan series, literature from the regions was published, usually with the support of universities based in the regions or of research institutions. Thus were the two-volume anthology Cebuano Poetry / Sugboanong Balak, 1988, published by the Cebuano Studies Center, and the multivolume Darangen, 1986-88, published by the Mindanao State University, University Research Center.

Kapampangan literature suffered after the eruption of Mount Pinatubo in 1991, literally and figuratively buried under an avalanche of lahar, to reemerge only in the new millennium through the efforts of Kapampangan centers. Surviving manuscripts and artifacts of Kapampangan culture were collected. Tuglong: A Kapampangan Journal (Bud: A Kapampangan Journal), 2002, was the first anthology of Kapampangan writing to emerge from the ashes. This anthology, published with the help of the Central Luzon Assistance Research Cooperative, consists of two parts: a section featuring the works of “Ding Lumang Talasulat” (The Old Writers)—Crisostomo Sotto, Canuto Tolentino, Ciriaco Sanchez, Diosdado Macapagal, Gonzalo Martin, Delfin Quiboloy, Rodolfo Mallari Sr, Querubin Fernandez Jr, Ted Panopio, and Felix Garcia—and a section on the works of “Ding Kaynakang Talasulat” (The Young Writers)—Juliet Mallari, Anne Carol D. Mabanta, Cesar Cachero, Anne Therese D. Mabanta, Timothy Sanchez, and Jay Mendoza. The poems of Jose Gallardo, regarded as a transition poet, are placed between the two sections.

The Academia ning Amanung Sisuan International and the Center for Kapampangan Studies of the Holy Angel University published in 2008 the anthology Kasapunggul a Sampaga (A Bunch of Flowers) and in 2010 Kasapunggul a Sampaga II. The first is a collection of 116 poems by Renato B. Alzadon, a Kapampangan writer based in the United States; the second is an anthology of prose and poems on various subjects by veteran and contemporary Kapampangan writers, among them Renato B. Alzadon, Ernesto Turla, Rafael David Manigago, Pedro Rivera Alzadon, Josefina Dizon Henson, Tec Sanchez-Tolosa, Myra Paz Lopez, Edgardo Bonus Sale, Tony Mecado Peña, Willie T. Dizon, and Ray Romero Tanjoco.

Efforts at fostering and preserving literature from the regions continue today, with serialized novels being published as a book and short stories and poems being compiled and translated for single-author collections or for anthologies. Examples are Hagkus: Twentieth-Century Bikol Women Writers, 2003, edited by Paz Verdades M. Santos, and the two-volume Cebuano Fiction / Sugilanong Sugboanon, 2014, edited by Erlinda K. Alburo, Vicente Bandillo, Simeon Dumdum Jr, and Resil B. Mojares. The recent establishment of the Ateneo de Naga University Press has provided another avenue for Bikol writing, even as the press’s output has been eclectic in terms of language, region, and genre. It has published poetry collections written in English, like Eighty-Four Words for Sorrow, 2015, by Simeon Dumdum, a Cebuano; in Karay-a, like Sa Gihapon, Palangga, ang Uran (Always, Beloved, the Rain), 2015, by Genevieve L. Asenjo with translations by Ma. Milagros Geremia-Lachica; in Bikol, like Cancion nin mga Tawong-Lipod (Song of the Invisible Man), 2014, by H. Francisco V. Peñones Jr, and Tignarakol (Poetry), 2013, by Luis Cabalquinto; and an anthology of short stories in Bikol, Hagong: Mga Osipon (Resonate: Stories), 2013, edited by Paz Verdades Santos and H. Francisco V. Peñones Jr.

In 2001, Filipinos Writing: Philippine Literature from the Regions, edited by Bienvenido Lumbera, was published by a trade publisher and is generally considered a definitive anthology of works from the regions. The validation of regional literature could also be seen with the inclusion of Cebuano, Ilocano, and Hiligaynon divisions in the short story category of the Palanca Awards beginning in 1997.
Writing Groups and the Academe

Writers’ groups were established and flourished in the wake of the Marcos government. These groups would enliven the literary scene by conducting workshops, holding writing contests, and anthologizing the works of their members for publication.

Some members of Unyon ng mga Manunulat sa Pilipinas or UMPIL broke away because of ideological differences and founded Pambansang Unyon ng mga Manunulat sa Pilipinas or Panulat. Linangan sa Imahen, Retorika, at Anyo, or LIRA, established in 1985 by Virgilio S. Almario, was originally conceptualized as a poetry clinic; it became one of the leading poetry organizations in Tagalog. LIRA would publish two anthologies in 1988 and 1990, Unang Bagting (First Chord) and Parikala (Irony), respectively. Many of its members would go on to write their own collections of poetry. A group of Tagalog fictionists formed Katha in 1989. Katha would continue the radical and political strain of short stories but would also introduce postmodern experimentation in their works. It would publish four anthologies between 1989 and 1997: Engkwentro (Encounter), 1989; Impetu (Impetus), 1990; Habilin (Message before Leaving), 1990; and Alagwa (Surge), 1997. Many of its members would also publish their own collections of stories. In Alibangbang at Iba Pang Kuwento (Alibangbang and Other Stories), 1992, and Fastfood, Megamall at Iba Pang Kwento sa Pagsasara ng Ikalawang Milenyum (Fastfood, Megamall and Other Stories at the End of the Second Millennium), 1999, Rolando B. Tolentino tackled the iniquities of the capitalist system while using postmodern experimentations with form.

In Cebu, many writers’ organizations would also be established to rival Lubas sa Dagang Bisaya or Ludabi, which remains, however, as the biggest association of Cebuano writers. Bathalad evolved to include filmmakers, musicians, and visual artists who saw the need to connect their craft to literature. The Magsusulat Inc, formed by Cebuano writers based in Manila, holds annual literary competitions, the winners at which were published in Sanggi (Harvest), 1992. Unlike other writers’ groups, Dagang Foundation Inc holds contests strictly for nonmembers. Tarantula was founded in 1996 by a new breed of young writers in Cebu. Kaliwat ni Karyapa was formed by young Boholano writers in honor of Karyapa, Bohol’s only documented babaylan (native priestess). Women in Literary Arts Inc (WILA), perhaps the only organized women writers’ group in the country today, provides publishing opportunities. The Bohol Alternative Literary Arts Council and Davao Writers Guild hold regular literary competitions and workshops. The former has produced two anthologies of award-winning works—Sobo 1 (Emergence 1) and Sobo 2 (Emergence 2)—while the latter publishes Dagmay, formerly a literary journal, now a weekly literary page of Sun Star Davao. Nomads attempts to “liberate” literature from the academe. The group holds poetry readings in the streets or in bus/jeepney terminals and storytelling sessions for children in slums or in the malls. All these groups are active.

In Pampanga, the Aguman Ding Talasulat Kapampangan published Siwala King Ilang (Voice from the Desert) in 2002, an anthology of 155 poems. About various aspects of Kapampangan life, the anthology was edited with the expressed purpose of preserving the beauty and purity of the Kapampangan language.

As writers’ organizations provide material support and training for their members, writing centers based in universities provide institutional validation for creative writing. Such writing centers sprouted in the 1990s: the Bienvenido N. Santos Creative Writing Center (BNSCWC), established in 1991 at De La Salle University (DLSU), the UST Center for Creative Writing and Literary Studies (CCWLS), established in 1999 at the University of Santo Tomas (UST), and the Ateneo Institute of Literary Arts and Practices or AILAP, established in 2001 at Ateneo de Manila University. Likhaan: UP Center for Creative Writing, established in 1979 at the University of the Philippines, was renamed Likhaan: UP Institute of Creative Writing (ICW) in 2002. These centers have established their own writing workshops to rival those being offered by UP ICW and Silliman University.

Other universities, though without formal writing centers, also began offering writing workshops. The Mindanao State University–Iligan Institute of Technology established the Iligan National Writers Workshop in 1994, what is perhaps the first truly national writers’ workshop; it allocates an equal representation from Luzon, Visayas, and Mindanao. The BNSCWC and the University of St. La Salle in Bacolod City, Negros Occidental, established the IYAS Creative Writing Workshop in 2001.

Apart from housing writing centers and hosting workshops, more universities began to offer degrees in creative writing, leading to the “academization” of literary production. The outcome is more experimental or intellectual writing, which alienates many readers accustomed to popular fare. Campus literary production was supported by student organizations and publications. Holdovers from previous decades, like Heights (Ateneo) and Varsitarian (UST), were joined by the Tomasian Writers Guild (UST), Malate (DLSU), Ugat (UP), Marejada (Ateneo de Zamboanga), and other groups. Campus organizations and publications are fertile breeding grounds for future writers.

The UP ICW in particular has had a gatekeeping function. In the 1990s until 2002, it published a series of anthologies reprinting what it thought was the best poems, stories, and essays of the year. The Likhaan books, as they were called, were discontinued, but the UP ICW continues to publish an annual journal, called Likhaan: The Journal of Contemporary Philippine Literature, which prints the best unpublished writings for the year.
New and Renewed Directions

Feminism and feminist literary criticism promoted the recovery of women’s writings and encouraged new writings by women and scholarship on the same. The anthologies Songs of Ourselves, 1994, edited by Edna Zapanta Manlapaz and Ang Silid ng Mahiwaga (The Enchanted Room), 1994, edited by Soledad S. Reyes, offer an overview of writings, in English and Tagalog, respectively, by Filipino women. Sa Ngalan ng Ina (In the Name of the Mother), 1997, by Lilia Quindoza-Santiago studies Philippine feminist poetry and includes an anthology of feminist poems not just in English and Filipino but also in Ilocano. An English translation of the book was published in 2002. Paz Verdades Santos’s Hagkus: Twentieth Century Bikol Women Writers, 2003, is its Bikol counterpart. The term “hagkus” refers to the piece of cloth Bikol women traditionally wrap around their middle after they give birth.

Edna Zapanta Manlapaz also wrote biographies of women writers—Angela Manalang Gloria, Estrella Alfon, and Lina Espina-Moore—and collected the poems of Manalang Gloria (The Complete Poems of Angela Manalang Gloria, 1995) and the stories of Loreto Paras-Sulit (Harvest and Other Stories by Loreto Paras Sulit, 2001). With Marjorie Evasco, she wrote Six Women Poets: Inter/Views with Angela Manalang Gloria, Trinidad Tarrosa Subido, Edith L. Tiempo, Virginia Moreno, Tita Lacambra-Ayala, Ophelia Dimalanta, 1996. Soledad S. Reyes wrote a biography of Rosario de Guzman Lingat (Rosario de Guzaman Lingat, 1924-1997: The Burden of Self and History, 2003) and prepared editions of her fiction long and short. She also edited the stories, columns, and radio scripts of Lina Flor (Lina Flor: Collected Works, 2000). Eva V. Kalaw collected the short stories of Paz Latorena in Desire and Other Stories by Paz Latorena, 2000, and Herminia Santos-Bas, the stories of Estrella Alfon in The Estrella D. Alfon Anthology, 2000.

WILA has produced the anthologies Centering Voices, 1995; Fern Garden: Anthology of Women Writing in the South, 1998; Sinug-ang: A Cebuano Trio (Trivet: A Cebuano Trio), 1999; Babayeng Sugid: Cebu Stories (Woman Story: Cebu Stories), 2012; and Travel Book, 2013. These feature the works of Erma Quizon, Erlinda Alburo, Cora Almerino, Ester Tapia, Leticia Suarez, Ruby Enario-Carlino, and Merlie Alunan. Their views on women’s issues—such as single parenthood, misogyny and self-concept, and marital relations—are progressive.

The Forbidden Fruit: Women Write the Erotic, 1992, and Kung Ibig Mo: Love Poetry by Women (If You So Desire It), 1993, were anthologies bold for their time. Single-author collections of poetry where a distinctly female consciousness asserts itself include Marjorie Evasco’s Dreamweavers: Selected Poems, 1976-1986, 1987, and Ochre Tones: Poems in English and Cebuano, 1999; Joi Barrios’s Ang Pagiging Babae Ay Pamumuhay sa Panahon ng Digma (To Be a Woman Is to Live at a Time of War), 1990; Elynia S. Mabanglo’s Kung Di Man: Mga Tula ng Pag-ibig, 1970-1992 (If It Weren’t So: Love Poems, 1970-1992), 1992; and Merlie Alunan’s Amina among the Angels, 1997, and Tales of the Spiderwoman, 2010.

Another minority literature that received increased attention in the 1990s was gay literature. Landmark works are Tony Perez’s Cubao books, which use Cubao as a setting to explore the concerns of gay males in the city, and some poems in Nicolas Pichay’s Ang Lunes na Mahirap Bunuin (The Intransigence of Mondays), 1993, a collection of poems.

The publication of the Ladlad anthologies, 1994, 1996, 2007, edited by J. Neil Garcia and Danton Remoto, allowed more gay voices to be heard. Garcia’s Philippine Gay Culture: The Last Thirty Years, 1996, is a pioneering work on the shifting discourses of homosexuality in the Philippines and an analysis of the sexual politics in selected works by Severino Montano, Orlando Nadres, and Tony Perez. Honorio Bartolome de Dios’s Sa Labas ng Parlor (Outside the Parlor), 1998, pushed Philippine gay literature into new territory. De Dios’s stories take Filipino gays out of the beauty parlor, which has been their ghetto, and depicts them in life’s various situations, as being sons, lovers, and political activists. Other writers who have written on the gay or lesbian experience are Ronald Baytan, Jhoanna Lynn Cruz, Jaime An Lim, Ralph Galan, and Aida Santos.

Gay writing broke into Cebuano literature at the start of the new millennium. In 2002, Rolando Salvaña’s “Libat” (Cross-eyed) won first place in the Cebuano short story category at the Palanca Awards. The blame for a catch of mysterious cross-eyed fish is pinned on gay people, who are promptly rounded up and jailed. Some days later, the townspeople demand the release of the detainees. Carl, a hairdresser and one of the detainees, realizes that it is Saturday, a day for weddings, debuts, baptisms, and other occasions for dolling up.

The period also saw a boom in the production of children’s literature and young adult fiction. Joining the game were several players—Adarna, Bookmark, Cacho, Tahanan, Lampara, and Anvil—which draw on folk literature and traditional stories but also encourage the production of new original material for young readers. Among the writers are Ma. Elena Paterno, Neni Sta. Romana Cruz, Marla Yotoko Chorengel, Ramon Sunico, and Rene O. Villanueva. A younger generation of writers include Christine Bellen, Glenda Oris, Eugene Evasco, and Jomike Tejido. Young adult fiction is being produced by Carla Pacis, Cyan Abad-Jugo, and Candy Quimpo Gourlay.

The Asian economic crisis in 1997 did not spare the Philippines, prompting many Filipinos to seek employment abroad and even emigration. The pull of employment overseas was already strong even in the 1980s, but it acquired unprecedented traction in the new millennium, when the full effects of the crisis began to be felt. More than 10 million Filipinos are now working in foreign lands. The 1990s saw the publication of works featuring the experiences of the growing Filipino migrant population. Such are Wilfredo Pa. Virtusio’s “Voicetape,” Fanny A. Garcia’s “Arrivederci,” and Luna Sicat-Cleto’s Mga Prodigal (The Prodigals), 2010. “Voicetape” revolves around a lost recording that captures the financial and sexual frustrations of overseas workers and their families. The conditions of Filipinos working in Italy are recounted in “Arrivederci.” The novel Mga Prodigal deals with the difficulties experienced by migrant workers in the Middle East and their families’ ways of coping.

Ruth Elynia Mabanglo presents the underside of migrant life in her collections Anyaya ng Imperyalista / Invitation of the Imperialist, 1998, and Mesa para sa Isa (Table for One), 2002. The case of Flor Contemplacion, a Filipino nanny executed in Singapore, inspired “Tulang Haka ni Flor Contemplacion” (A Conjectural Poem by Flor Contemplacion), a poem that likens her suffering to the passion, death, and resurrection of Jesus Christ. Loneliness and longing for the native land are the themes of her poems.

Migration of a different sort has resulted in the creation of a brand of Mindanao literature. Cebuano writing in Mindanao has evolved from being an extension of Cebuano writing in the Visayas to a literature tackling distinctly Mindanaoan themes—tension between cultural groups, the fragility of peace and security, and environmental exploitation. Mindanaoan literature, however, also reflects the national experience of poverty and unemployment. Marcelo Geocallo’s “Diin didto May Bagtikan sa Pugarang Banog” (Where the Hawk’s Nest Is Strong), 1995, is told from the point of view of Sultan Malawi, a Maranao chieftain who tries to protect the forests from illegal logging. Some of the people, including Malawi’s own son, however, have capitulated. Malawi, however, refuses to give up, in the end succeeding in redeeming their ancestral land. Ricardo Hynson’s “Si Eking Bulhog ug ang Kasugiran ni Tang Biyong” (Eking Bulhog and the Story of Tang Biyong), 1997, juxtaposes the experience of a modern Mindanaoan named Eking Bulhog and the legend of Tang Biyong, a local deity who causes a great deluge every so often. The story is a commentary on the wanton destruction of forestland in Mindanao, which has added to the severity of flash floods.

Writing in English, Antonio Reyes Enriquez recounts the displacement of indigenous communities in Zamboanga by militarization in Subanons, 1999. In the title story of Mig Alvarez Enriquez’s The White Horse of Alih and Other Stories, 1985, the protagonist is compelled to perform ritual suicide to avenge the wrongs Christians have done to his family. Mig Alvarez Enriquez continues to write on Zamboanga in his collection Life Strokes: Blood on the Moon and Other Stories, 1996. Sikami'n Lumad: Bagong Panitikan ng Katutubong Mindanao (New Literature of Indigenous Mindanao), 2005, contains poems, stories, chants, and rituals by writers from the different lumad (indigenous) groups of Mindanao, with Filipino translations.

The centennial of Philippine independence in 1998 was an opportune time for writers to reflect and comment on the history and state of the nation. The Philippine Centennial Literary Prize, the most lucrative and most publicized literary competition since the Commonwealth Literary Contests in 1940, provided the occasion for such literary activity. The winners in the novel category in the English division were My Sad Republic, 2000, by Eric Gamalinda; An Embarrassment of Riches, 2000, by Charlson Ong; and Voyeurs and Savages, 1998, by Alfred A. Yuson. In Filipino, Etsa-Puwera (Outsider), 2000, by Jun Cruz Reyes and Ang Aso, ang Pulgas, ang Bonsai at ang Kolorum (The Dog, the Flea, the Bonsai and the Colorum Movement), 2000, by Jose Rey Munsayac tied for first place. The second and third prizes went to (H)istoryador(a), 2006, by Vim Nadera and Tari (Cockspur), 2000, by Sergio Custodio Jr, respectively. Prizes for the epic were given to Cirilo F. Bautista for Sunlight on Broken Stones, 2000, in the English division; and to Reynaldo Duque for Candon, 2000, Teo T. Antonio for Piping-Dilat (Wide-Eyed Mute), 2000, Vim Nadera for Mujer Indigena (Indigenous Women), 2000, and Pedro L. Ricarte for Lupang Hinirang (Chosen Land), 2000, in the Filipino division.

Outside of the Centennial Literary Prize, Philippine history was generally a source of material for writers in the post-EDSA decades. Cristina Pantoja-Hidalgo’s Recuerdo, 1997, Alfred A. Yuson’s Great Philippine Jungle Energy Café, 1988, Gina Apostol’s The Revolution according to Raymundo Mata, 2009, and F. Sionil Jose’s Viajero (Traveler), 1998, are built around significant episodes of Philippine history and use metafictional devices, paratextual information, anachronism, and other experiments to problematize historiography itself. In Tagalog, works that have similar characteristics include Uro Q. de la Cruz’s Antyng-antyng (Talisman), 2003, and Ramon Guilliermo’s Ang Makina ni Mang Turing (Mang Turing’s Machine), 2013.

While realism is still a dominant mode of writing, many writes have begun to use other modes—horror, magic realism, science fiction, fantasy. The Philippine Speculative Fiction anthologies, 2005-10, would showcase some of these works. Dean Francis Alfar’s novel Salamanca, 2006, and Nikki Alfar’s collection of short stories Now, Then, and Elsewhen, 2013, are perhaps the best examples of local speculative fiction.

A number of writers who had relied on realism in presenting their analysis and criticism of Philippine society have also experimented with the speculative mode, without necessarily sacrificing the social content. Thus Ricky Lee’s Si Amapola sa 65 Kabanata (Amapola in 65 Chapters), 2011, has a manananggal (self-segmenting ghoul) as the protagonist given the mission to save society; and Jun Cruz Reyes’s Etsa-Puwera, 2000, presents a panorama of Philippine history through the experiences of a family, whose genealogy can be traced back to a union between a human and a deer transformed by the gods into a woman. Alvin B. Yapan’s Ang Sandali ng mga Mata (The Moment of the Eyes), 2006, Edgar Calabia Samar’s Walong Diwata ng Pagkahulog (Eight Muses of the Fall), 2009, and Kasunod ng 909 (After 909), 2012, and Allan Derain’s Ang Banal na Aklat ng mga Kumag (The Holy Little Book of Pests), 2013, explore history, myth, fantasy, and metafiction.
Popular Culture and New Media

The last 20 years saw the rise of genre fiction, like chick lit and romance novels, which greatly surpass “literary” works in sales and popularity. Precious Pages specializes in romance novels, written in Filipino or in a mix of Tagalog and English. In the mid-1990s, some writers attempted to sell “alternative romances,” which reverse the conventions, formulas, and sexist assumptions of typical romance novels, but these did not succeed. Chick lit, which supposedly features empowered women, caters to an English-reading public.

Globalization has made American popular culture and popular culture products from Korea and Japan even more pervasive and, as some might argue, pernicious. The history of the Philippine comic book is illustrative. The comic books of the 1990s and the new millennium bear little resemblance to the komiks of the earlier decades, which had adapted the American comic book for a local mass readership. The new comic books, many of which are in English, bearing illustrations in the style of manga, and costing more than what the daily wage earner makes, speak for and to a middle class who is urbane and steeped in American or American-mediated culture. To be sure, in a number of cases, native materials, usually the supernatural creatures of Philippine folklore, are also used, and local realities, like criminality and poverty, are depicted. The overall tone, however, is arguably Gotham City rather than Quezon City. Similarly, American rap music has influenced the local traditions of poetic jousting, giving rise to rap battles among the Tagalog, the encuentro among the Zamboangueños, and the hinampakay og letra among the Iliganon. In their choice of subject matter and use of chants and insults among other traits, these bear resemblances to native forms.

Recent developments in communication technology have resulted in the emergence of new forms of literary expression and new ways of circulating them. The cell phone gave birth to text poems or textula. Frank Rivera’s Makata sa Cellphone (Cell Phone Poet), 2005, is a collection of over 200 such poems. The anthologies Textanaga, 2003, Dalitext, 2003, and Dionatext, 2004, as their titles imply, consist of traditional Tagalog poetic forms that were composed using the cell phone’s Short Message Service feature.

The internet has democratized literary space. Online platforms like Wattpad have allowed just about anyone to post stories and poems. A number of them are selected by publishers for print editions. Some of these have, in turn, been adapted for the movies and television. These have been consistent best sellers. Given its laissez-faire nature, works produced in such platforms are not considered literary in some circles. The Wattpad novels are heavily influenced by Korean telenovelas and other brands of globalized popular culture.

Alongside these popular or commercial productions are coterie productions. Independent publishing has grown as more writers also want to publish outside the space of academe and commercial publications. High Chair publishes original poetry collections and chapbooks in Filipino and English that are not usually accepted by university presses and commercial publishers. The Youth and Beauty Brigade (YBB) features experimental works heavily influenced by the French experimental group Ouvroir de Litterature Potentielle or Oulipo. Pastiche, erasures, cut and paste and other techniques can be seen in works like Adam David’s The El Bimbo Variations, 2005. Both publishers have an online presence. High Chair has an online journal while YBB distributes its works online for free.

The popular magazines of the Manila Bulletin, Liwayway, Bisaya, Hiligaynon, and Bannawag, would still be an outlet for the publication of many regional literatures, but with the advent of the internet and indie publications, their prestige waned in the 1990s. Recent attempts to reestablish the prestige of these magazines can be seen in their projects that aimed to encourage the participation of younger writers and readers. In 2004, Bisaya instituted the Young Blood Writers Program, a 12-month apprenticeship program where select young writers regularly submit works to the editors for critiquing and publication. After a year, the magazine “graduates” only one writer as the “most promising new writer in Bisaya.” The program is part of the magazine’s efforts to make itself more appealing to younger readers and writers. Another attempt would be trying to publish their magazines in online platforms like Buqo so it can reach newer audiences that use mobile devices and tablets.
Conclusion

Philippine literature since the EDSA Revolt bears the history of the republic. It is characterized by the entry of once-marginalized authors, themes, and genres into mainstream literature, the thrust toward the retrieval and recuperation of regional literatures other than Tagalog, and the creation of democratic spaces by new media. Competing politics and aesthetics—feminism, Marxism, formalism, postmodernism, nationalism, and other -isms—inform the writing of many writers. New institutions, organizations, publications, and technologies compete to push Philippine literature toward the future.  Written by Christopher Mitch Cerda, with notes from Vijae Alquisola, Rowena Festin, Paula Hernandez, May Maravilles, and Marina Quilab
