text:
Sections

The Spanish Colonial Period
The Golden Age (1903-42)
The Postwar Period
From 1987 to the Present

 

Philippine literature in Spanish includes all the poems, stories, novels, and essays written by Filipinos in the Spanish language. This literature began as a tool in the religious and political conquest of the Philippines in the 16th century, but eventually blossomed into a literature of protest against the Spanish colonizers from 1885 to 1896 and later the American rulers, from 1899 to the 1930s.

 

The Spanish Colonial Period

The earliest known samples of Philippine poetry in Spanish appeared in the first decade of the 17th century, less than 40 years after the introduction of Spanish culture in the islands, apparently under the guidance of the Dominican priest Francisco Blancas de San Jose. His religious books featured the verses of his printers, the Chinese immigrant Juan de Vera, and the Bulaqueño Fernando Bagongbanta. De Vera’s “Gracias a los Castellanos” (Thanks to the Spaniards), 1602, tells of his coming to Manila in search of food and peace and his conversion to Christianity.

 

Other Chinese versifiers in Binondo were Jose Ma. Nicaisay, who wrote “Manila Preciosisima” (Most Precious Manila), 1606; Tomas Chui Dian, who wrote “Corre en Mis Venas Sangre Celestial” (Heavenly Blood Runs in My Veins), 1613; and Carlos Calao, who wrote “Que Dios le Perdone” (May God Forgive Him), 1614. Their verses centered on two themes: the Catholic religion and Hispanidad or all things Spanish.

Ladino or bilingual poets also published their interlinear verses in Tagalog and Spanish with religious and Hispanidad themes. These themes would recur through the centuries in Philippine poetry in Spanish. Ladino poetry persisted for almost a century, if not longer. Bagongbanta’s bilingual verses, published in 1604, celebrate Spain’s spiritual and material contributions to the islands—the Catholic religion, corn, tomatoes, wheat, and potatoes. In 1610, Tomas Pinpin published his Spanish grammar for the use of the Tagalog. In one of his poems, he espoused national unity by exhorting the different Philippine tribes to embrace the Cross, learn Spanish, and be loyal to the king. He, like Bagongbanta, also composed ladino poems. Other ladino poems were published by Pedro Suarez Osorio in 1638, Pedro Bucaneg in 1638, Gaspar Aquino de Belen in 1704, and Felipe de Jesus in 1708. Francisco Baltazar could well be our greatest ladino poet as evidenced by his composition “Paalam Na sa Iyo” (Farewell to You), a poem of superb and delicate quality.

In the 19th century, a call for reforms was made by creole and mestizo writers Luis Rodriguez Varela, Pedro Pelaez, Juan de Atayde, and Jose A. Burgos. Creole poetry’s earliest expression is El Parnaso Filipino (The Filipino Parnassus), 1813, a collection of Varela’s poems. Its fame lies less on its literary quality than on its political statement: the need for unity among the peninsulars, creoles, mestizos, and indios (Christianized natives) who comprised the Filipino nation.

 

In 1879, the Liceo Artistico-Literario sponsored a literary contest open to all peninsular, creole, and native writers. The winners in the poetry division were the peninsulares (Spaniards born in Spain) Eusebio A. Escobar and Gualterino Marino Seco, the creole Jose Juan de Icaza, and the natives Mariano Romasanta and Jose Rizal. Rizal’s winning piece was “A la Juventud Filipina” (To the Filipino Youth).

Second to Rizal as literary figures were Graciano Lopez Jaena, Marcelo H. del Pilar, Pedro A. Paterno, and Antonio Luna. Other writers of the period were Mariano Ponce, Antonio Ma. Regidor, Isabelo de los Reyes, Gregorio Sancianco, Jose Ma. Panganiban, and Eduardo Lete.

In 1880, Luis Arnedo published Pedro Paterno’s Sampaguitas y Varias Poesias (Sampaguitas and Other Poems). It was intended to be the first volume of a project, Biblioteca Filipina, which was never realized. From Rizal’s maturing pen came gems like “Me Piden Versos” (They Asked Me for Verses), 1882; “Alas Flores de Heidelberg” (To the Flowers of Heidelberg), 1886; and “El Canto de Maria Clara” (The Song of Maria Clara), 1887. Rizal’s poetry would blossom in 1895 with “Mi Retiro” (My Retreat), considered as one of his best works. It was also in 1895 that Fernando Ma. Guerrero published “Borja ante el Cadaver de la Emperatriz Isabel” (Borja before the Corpse of Empress Isabel) and Cecilio Apostol published “El Terror de los Mares Indicos” (The Terror of the Indian Seas).

 

In 1896, Rizal wrote his valedictory poem, “Mi Ultimo Adios” (My Last Farewell), which has been translated into many languages. Emilio Jacinto’s “A la Patria” (To the Fatherland), 1897, and Jose Palma’s “En la Ultima Pagina del Noli Me Tangere” (On the Last Page of the Noli Me Tangere), 1898, were only the first poems of a tradition inspired by Rizal’s martyrdom and works.

When La Solidaridad, the novels of Rizal, and other works that awakened the Filipino national conscience failed to move the Spanish government, the call for reforms was transformed into a cry for freedom. However, revolutionary literature in Spanish did not get published until Antonio Luna founded the newspaper La Independencia in 1898. On its staff were Fernando Ma. Guerrero, Cecilio Apostol, and Jose Palma, who would become the poets of the war against America. Another excellent poet of this period was Manuel Ramirez Cabrera.

Undoubtedly, Guerrero had a mastery of form, technique, and language. So did Apostol, whose “A los Anonimos Martires de la Patria” (To the Anonymous Martyrs of the Country) and “Al Heroe Nacional” (To the National Hero), 1898, became classics. Palma provided the lyrics of the Philippine National Anthem with “Filipinas.” His other poems, such as, “Ven, Oh Paz!” (Come, Oh Peace!), “Mi Caida” (My Downfall), “El Kundiman” (The Native Love Song), and “De Mi Jardin” (From My Garden) are literary gems of great value. Guerrero would dominate lyric poetry, and Apostol, the epic.

Two other excellent poets were Manuel Romero and Carlos Peñaranda. Their works were impressive, but they were not attuned to the new aspirations of the people.

 

The history of the Philippine novel in Spanish begins with Pedro Paterno’s Ninay: Costumbres Filipinas (Ninay: Philippine Customs), 1885. Paterno’s Ninay was written and first published in Spain. Ninay’s principal influences were the Spanish prose narratives, which sketched regional Spanish types and customs in the style known as costumbrismo. Focusing on vignettes and short pictorial descriptions, these narratives treated the plot as secondary to the detailed description of country customs. The tortuous plot of Ninay incorporates descriptions of the pasiyam (nine-night prayers for the dead) and the pilgrimage to Antipolo.

Perhaps the most important Spanish influence on the Philippine novel tradition in Spanish is Benito Perez Galdos, whose Doña Perfecta, 1876, has striking similarities with Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere. A strong social satire against Spanish clericalism and hypocrisy, Doña Perfecta has the same basic plot as the Noli. A young man educated in a foreign country arrives in his homeland, which he realizes is very backward. He has come for his fiancée, the daughter of a rich and influential native. His homecoming is ominous because of the powerful presence of priests who direct the conscience and social affairs of the citizens. The priests are hypocritical, meddling, ignorant, and conservative. The young man is liberal and freethinking. The opposition is radical and the young man not only fails to marry his fiancée and change the ideas of his opponents—he is also overcome and effectively frustrated. In the Noli, the hero Ibarra escapes.

In El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1891, Ibarra, after 13 years abroad, returns to the Philippines disguised as Simoun. He has made a huge fortune, which he will now use to avenge himself on his enemies, and rescue from the cloister his sweetheart Maria Clara. Again, he is frustrated, and the novel ends with Simoun’s suicide. Both novels had an important social function—that of sociopolitical criticism. They also helped to forge unity among Filipinos of different regions, which in turn contributed to the outbreak and triumph of the revolution.

 

 

The essay in Spanish began in the 17th century with the publication by the Spanish missionaries of meditations, translations, studies on the Philippine languages, and explanations of Christian tenets. Dominican friar Francisco Blancas de San Jose wrote Arte y Reglas de la Lengua Tagala (Grammar and Rules of the Tagalog Language), 1610, which is the first attempt to codify the rules of writing and speaking Tagalog.

The learning of the Spanish language, with the aid of grammar and vocabulary manuals, opened up several avenues for the expository prose in Spanish written by Filipinos: the memorias (memoirs), reseñas (resumes), informes (accounts), and memoriales (reports to evoke response from the authorities). Either official or private in nature, these essays covered topics such as politics, religion, technology, and others.

In the 19th century, the reform movement used the essay form as a means to present issues, expose and condemn Spanish abuses, and provoke the people into action. The strong nationalist sentiments produced not only editorials, columns, and feature articles but also letters, diaries, sermons, speeches, travelogues, papeles volantes (loose sheets), and prosa poetica (poetic prose).

The literature of the reform movement was essentially a profession of adherence and loyalty to Spain, an appeal to Spain’s sense of justice, and a strong protest against friar rule. Because it was addressed to the Spanish government and because its writers were in Madrid and Barcelona, where they wrote the essays, most of the works were written in Spanish.

The reform movement may be said to have begun at the turn of the 19th century, with Luis Rodriguez Varela’s Proclama Historical que para Animar a los Vasallos a que Defiendan a Su Rey del Furor de Su Falso Amigo, Napoleon, Primer Emperador de los Franceses (Historical Proclamation Which Aims to Exhort the Vassals to Defend Their King from the Ire of His False Friend, Napoleon, First Emperor of the French), 1809, which already expressed the beginnings of a Filipino consciousness. A model of “pulpit oratory” was Pedro Pelaez’s Colecciones de Sermones (A Collection of Sermons), 1869. Pelaez was the leading exponent of the secularization of the Philippine parishes, and he published his articles of protest in the Madrid newspaper El Clamor Publico. However, his follower, Fr Jose Burgos, is better known for the work Manifiesto de los Leales filipinos en Defensa de Su Honra y Fidelidad (Manifesto of the Loyal Filipinos in Defense of Their Honor and Faithfulness), 1864.

An early figure in the propaganda movement was Gregorio Sancianco, who was the first Filipino to write a treatise on Philippine problems, El Progreso de Filipinas (The Progress of Filipinas), 1881. A part of the book builds a defense of the small farmer, whose apathy caused by abuse and exploitation is often mistaken for indolence. This later became Rizal’s source for his own essay, “Sobre la Indolencia de los Filipinos” (On the Indolence of the Filipinos), 1890.

Rizal delivered his first political speech when Juan Luna and Felix Resureccion Hidalgo won in an international painting contest in 1884 in Madrid. He published his articles in the movement’s periodical, La Solidaridad, 1889-90. His versatility is seen in his combative “La Verdad para Todos” (Truth for All), his bitterness in “Ingratitudes” (Ingratitude), and his acute sense of history in the prophetic “Filipinas dentro de Cien Años” (The Philippines within a Century). His satirical essays “La Vision de Fray Rodriguez” (A Vision of Fray Rodriguez), “Por Telefono” (By Telephone), and “Una Visita del Señor a las Filipinas” (A Visit of Our Lord to the Philippines) all criticize the obscurantism of the friars in the Philippines.

A conscious attempt to grapple with the concept of “Filipino” is found in Pedro Paterno’s series of works, 1887-92, which exalt the people’s pre-Hispanic civilization. La Antigua Civilizacion Tagalog (Ancient Tagalog Civilization), 1887, depicts the people as highly civilized even before the Spaniards came; El Cristianismo en la Antigua Civilizacion Tagalog (Christianity in Ancient Tagalog Civilization), 1892, equates indigenous religious beliefs and practices with Christian doctrines and rituals. Other books by Paterno are pseudoethnographic studies of Filipino marriage customs, morality, and the Tagalog political structure. The best features of Paterno’s rhetoric are contained in his inspiring inaugural speech at the Malolos Congress on 15 Sep 1898.

Marcelo H. del Pilar’s La Soberania Monacal en Filipinas (The Monastic Sovereignty in the Philippines), 1888, is a brilliant analysis of the power of the friars in the Philippines—in the economic, political, and religious spheres. La Frailocracia Filipina (Philippine Friarcracy), 1889, makes a forcefully logical denunciation of friar rule.

Graciano Lopez Jaena’s speeches and articles were collected in the book Discursos y Articulos Varios (Speeches and Various Articles), 1891. First and foremost an orator, Lopez Jaena wrote articles which were often florid and oratorical, but which also reveal an eclectic knowledge of the Philippines, as seen in his survey of the colony’s agricultural products and a proposal for an arts and trade curriculum. His Fray Botod (Friar Potbelly), ca 1889, a sarcastic description of a “typical” friar in the Visayas, is considered his masterpiece.

Collections of essays during this period include Antonio Luna’s Impresiones (Impressions), 1891; Jose Felipe del Pan’s Hay Que Vivir! (One Has to Live), 1884; Carlos Peñaranda’s Prosa (Prose), 1893; and E. Polo de Lara’s Tipos y Costumbres (Types and Customs), 1897. Antonio Luna’s editorials in the newspaper that he founded, La Independencia, called for independence from Spain, and later from America. While La Independencia was revolutionary, Republica Filipina was conservative. Its staff was composed of writers like Paterno, Manuel Xerez Burgos, Leon Luis, and Manuel Guerrero.

Apolinario Mabini lived through both the revolution against Spain and the Filipino-American War. “El Verdadero Decalogo” (The True Decalogue), which he translated himself into Tagalog as “Ang Tunay na Sampung Utos” (The True Ten Commandments), expressed his concept of a democratic Filipino government and citizenry. His “Ordenanzas de la Revolucion” (Ordinances of the Revolution) was used by Gen Emilio Aguinaldo as a basis for the program of the revolutionary government established on 12 Jun 1898.

An essay aptly depicting the temper of the ilustrados (educated native) at the height of the Filipino revolutionaries’ victory and showing the generation gap at the turn of the century is “Venerables Puputs” (The Venerable Puputs), 1898, by Manuel Guerrero. It is an anticlerical piece in the tradition of the satires of Rizal, Lopez Jaena, and M. H. del Pilar. It pokes fun at colonial mentality and religious fanaticism as personified by two spinsters and a married woman well placed in society. They are convinced that the insurrectos (insurgents) are masons because of the triangle and the three points on their flag, and they lament the release of the Jesuits from prison instead of the friars. Serving as foil is the married one’s 15-year-old granddaughter, a free spirit who finds these three religious devotees laughable.

Isabelo de los Reyes began writing during the time of the reform movement, and then continued writing well into the American colonial period. Like Pedro Paterno, he used history to express his nationalism; but, unlike Paterno, his historical accounts were more carefully and accurately researched. His books consist of Historia de Ilocos (History of Ilocos), 1890; two volumes of El Folk-Lore Filipino (Philippine Folklore), 1889, Las Islas Visayas en la Epoca de la Conquista (The Visayan Islands in the Time of Conquest), 1889, and Historia de Filipinas (History of the Philippines), 1889. De los Reyes, who wrote in both Spanish and Ilocano, founded El Ilocano in 1889, the first regional paper established by a Filipino. It published articles in both Spanish and Ilocano.

 

The Golden Age (1903-42)

The first four decades of the 20th century were the golden age of Philippine Spanish literature, which ironically coincided with the decline of Spanish political influence in the country. More than 200 newspapers and magazines in Spanish were established in Cebu, Iloilo, and Manila (Alinea 1967, 515-16; Mariñas 1974, 51). El Renacimiento, La Democracia, La Vanguardia, El Debate, La Opinion, El Comercio, El Mercantil, La Defensa, El Heraldo de Cebu, El Pueblo de Iloilo, and El Tiempo, and several magazines like Renacimiento Filipino, Cultura Social, Cultura Filipina, Carnaval, Confetti, El Obrero, Veritas, and Excelsior became the publishing outlets for poems, columns, polemics in verses, and fiction in Spanish. The Philippines Free Press and the Independent would be in both Spanish and English for some time. Individual collections of verse, stories, essays, and dramas were being published, as were novels.

Spanish literary contests were held during the first four decades of the century. The Manila Grand Opera was filled to capacity when Jesus Balmori and Manuel Bernabe held a balagtasan or poetic joust. Plays and zarzuelas in Spanish were being staged. Speeches were delivered and songs were composed. Tertulias (art gatherings) and veladas (evening parties) were held. There were Filipino-produced movies in Spanish in the 1930s.

A class of writers using Spanish had matured, and the presence of a new colonizer, the Americans, provided them with a theme. The persistence of Hispanidad was an expression of the Filipinos’ continued resistance against the new masters. Recto, Apostol, Balmori, and Bernabe would dominate literature in Spanish, with Antonio Abad becoming a symbol of the tenacious promotion of the Spanish language and literature amid rapid Americanization. On the other hand, Pedro Paterno, through his plays, and Trinidad H. Pardo de Tavera, through his essays and speeches, promoted the Americanization of the islands.

At the beginning of the American colonial period, love for country was expressed in the themes of Hispanidad and Filipinidad (things Philippine). The defense, conservation, and promotion of the nation’s Hispanic heritage, especially the Spanish language and the Catholic religion, became an expression of resistance to Americanization.

Poems that were paeans to the country were written. Descriptions of its scenery, its golden traditions, its heroes, the virtues of the Malay race, and Hispanic culture embodied the poets’ patriotism. Guerrero and Apostol, and later, Jesus Balmori, Manuel Bernabe, Claro M. Recto, Teodoro M. Kalaw, Macario Adriatico, Manuel Ravago, Tirso Irureta Goyena, Enrique Fernandez Lumba, and others would condemn the new Western morality and exalt Hispanidad, even as the country sank deeper and deeper into Sajonismo (Saxon culture) of the American rule.

Balagtasan-type poetic jousts in Spanish were held between Balmori and Bernabe, Balmori and Isidro Marfori, Guerrero and Apostol, Bernabe and Zoilo Hilario, Bernabe and Flavio Zaragoza Cano, and Bernabe and Alejo Valdes Pica on topics of contemporary interest. Periodicals like La Vanguardia and El Renacimiento and cultural institutions like the Casino Español de Manila sponsored literary contests in honor of some person or in celebration of some occasion. Pacifico Victoriano won three literary prizes, in 1903 for a poem on Rizal, in 1904 for a poem dedicated to the Immaculate Conception, and in 1909 for a composition about Don Quixote (Mariñas 1974, 66). In a contest sponsored by El Renacimiento celebrating Rizal Day in 1908, Balmori’s poems “Specs,” “Vae Victis,” and “Himno a Rizal” won him all three prizes. Claro M. Recto’s poem “El Elogio del Castellano” won at the literary contest sponsored by the Casino Español de Manila on the inauguration of the Casa de España in 1917; Adelina Gurrea’s poem “El Nido” won the contest for 1919; and Balmori’s “A Nuestro Señor Don Quijote de la Mancha” (To Our Lord Don Quixote of La Mancha) and “Triptico Real” (Royal Triptych), for 1920, with Isidro Malfori’s “Por Amor a España” (For the Love of Spain) taking second prize (Martin de la Camara 1923, 46, 48, 143, 241).

The Premio Zobel was established in 1921 and was awarded for the first time in 1922. Among the poets who received it were Bernabe in 1924, Bernabe and Balmori in 1926, Flavio Zaragoza Cano in 1929, Pacifico Victoriano in 1934, Franciso Villanueva Jr in 1934, Evangelina Guerrero Zacarias in 1935, Ramon Escoda in 1936, and Antonio Fernandez in 1937; among the fictionists, Guillermo Gomez Rivera in 1922, Buenaventura Rodriguez in 1924, Enrique K. Laygo in 1925, Antonio Abad in 1929, Buenaventura L. Varona in 1933, Luis Guzman Rivas in 1940, and Francisco Rodriguez in 1941.

The Commonwealth Literary Contests in 1940 had a Spanish division. In poetry, the winners were Balmori’s “Mi Casa de Nipa” (My Nipa Hut) and Flavio Zaragoza Cano’s De Mactan a Tirad (From Mactan to Tirad), both collections eventually published in 1941; in the short story, Benigno del Rio’s collection “Prejuicio de Raza” (Racial Prejudice) and Jose Hernandez Gavira’s collection “Inday Silang”; in the essay, Antonio Abad’s “De la Hora Transeunte” (Of the Transient Hour) and Pedro Aunario’s “Pugna de Lenguas” (Struggle of Languages), submitted under the pseudonym “Elias”; in the novel, Antonio Abad’s El Campeon (The Champion), published in 2013.

A number of individual collections of poetry were published: Vibraciones (Vibrations), 1899, by Ramirez Cabrera; Rimas Malayas (Malay Rhymes), 1904, by Balmori; Bajo los Cocoteros (Under the Coconut Trees), 1911, by Claro M. Recto; Adelfas (Rosebays), 1913, by Zoilo Hilario; Luzonicas (Luzon Poems), 1911, by Vicente Bautista; Melancolicas (Sad Verses), 1912, by Palma; Horas de Luz (Hours of Light), 1913, by Francisco Villanueva; Crisalidas (Chrysalides), 1914, by Guerrero; Patria y Redencion (Country and Redemption), 1914, by Hilario; Aromas de Ensueño (Dream Scents), 1915, by Isidro Marfori; Arias de Primavera (Airs of Spring), 1915, by Victoriano; Electra, 1915, by Valdes Pica; Cadencias (Cadences), 1917, by Marfori; Intimas (Innermost Things), 1919, by Valdes Pica; De Mi Jardin Sinfonico (From My Symphonic Garden), 1921, by Jose Hernandez Gavira; A la Laguna de Bai (To Laguna Bay), 1921, by Fernando Canon; Rubaiyat de Omar Khayyam, 1924, a translation by Bernabe of Edward Fitzgerald’s English translation of the Rubaiyat; El Libro de Mis Vidas Manileñas (The Book of My Manila Lives), 1928, by Balmori; Emocionario (Emotionary) by Francisco Zaragoza Carillo; Cantos del Tropico (Songs of the Tropics), 1929, by Bernabe; Cantame un Canto en Español (Sing Me a Spanish Song), 1934, and Mi Copa Bohemia (My Bohemian Cup), 1937, by Hernandez Gavira; Pentelicas (Things from Pentelicus), 1941, by Apostol; De Mactan a Tirad, 1941, by Flavio Zaragoza Cano; and Rosas de Amor (Roses of Love), 1917, and Lineas Finales (Final Lines) by Tirso de Irureta Goyena.

Other poets were Anselmo de Jesus, Norberto Romualdez, Lorenzo Perez Tuells, Tomas Tirona, Jose Lauchengco, Alberto Campos, Esteban Nedruda, Jesus Casuso, Leoncio Magno, Monico Mercado, Juan Reyes, Jose G. Reyes, Jose Teotico, Vicente Pelaez, Antonio Zacarias, and Emeterio Barcelon.

With the entrenchment of an Americanized culture in the Philippines through the public school system, the entry of British and American literature, and the spread of the English language, poetry in Spanish declined. The Spanish literary tradition of the Philippines since its beginning in the 17th century had stressed patriotism, religion, and Hispanidad—themes which spurred it to greatness but eventually also stunted its growth.

The golden age of Philippine literature in Spanish also saw the phenomenal growth of the Philippine short story in Spanish. Of all the literary types that flourished during this period, it was this genre that inspired the most numerous and the best writers. Many essayists, poets, dramatists, and newspaper editors tried their hand at the short story. Various literary contests stimulated the publication of short stories both in book form and in the literary sections of the newspapers, particularly La Vanguardia, El Debate, and Nueva Era. Newspapers published one story a day and three or four on weekends (Alinea 1967, 513).

Among the best fictionists of the period were Enrique Laygo, Buenaventura Rodriguez, Manuel S. Guerrero, Fernando Ma. Guerrero, Antonio M. Abad, Jesus Balmori, Francisco Rodriguez, Vicente del Rosario, Carlos Ledesma, Alejo Valdes Pica, and Evangelina Guerrero-Zacarias. Those who wrote for Renacimiento Filipino were Jose Mariño, Angel Guerra, and Pascual Poblete.

Fictionists who won at literary contests were Enrique Laygo, Enrique Centenera, Vicente de Jesus, Marcelino Ocampo, Jose Hernandez Gavira, and Estanislao Alinea. Other writers were Epifanio de los Santos, Jose Teotico, Rafael and Miguel Ripoll, and Benigno del Rio. The most distinguished of these short story writers was Laygo, who won the Premio Zobel in 1925 for his collection of short stories Caretas (Masks), 1931. The most noteworthy collections of short stories, besides Caretas, were del Rio’s manuscript “Prejuicio de Raza” and Evangelina Guerrero Zacarias’s Primicias (First Fruits), 1935.

At this time, there appeared two new forms of the short story: “the instantanea or rafaga, a brief anecdote or account of incidents, and the prosa romantica or romantic prose, full of figures of speech and flowering phrases” (Alinea 1967, 513). Jesus Balmori excelled in these new forms.

The stories are distinct in kind and content. There are memorable stories about love, as in Balmori’s “Redencion” (Redemption), 1900; Mariño’s “Los Fugitivos” (The Fugitives), 1922; and Alinea’s “Amor Inmortal” (Immortal Love), 1939. “El Suegro de Kokumura” (The Father-in-Law of Kokumura), 1904, by Manuel Guerrero, and “La Cara del Diablo” (The Face of the Devil), 1903, are humorous and satiric. Abad’s “Fotogenia” (Photogenic), 1939, and Maria del Rosario’s “El Pasado se Compra” (The Past Can Be Bought), 1936, emphasize the double standards of morality. There are also vivid character sketches blended with local color, some of which embody moral criticism, like Pascual H. Poblete’s “Capitan Ipe, el Caritativo” (Captain Ipe, the Charitable), 1917. As with the Spanish poetry of the time, there is a questioning of American values in the fiction produced by Filipinos using Spanish. In the title story of Guillermo Gomez Windham’s prizewinning collection of articles and fiction La Carrera de Candida (Candida’s Career), 1922, the central character aspires to be like her American teacher and the women she reads about in American magazines, only to become a cabaret dancer in the city and be rejected by polite society.

The background of these stories is varied. There are stories about provincial life as in Rodriguez’s “Nelia,” 1912; Luna’s “La Maestra de Mi Pueblo” (The Teacher of My Town), 1927; Mariño’s “El Bandolero” (The Bandit), 1911; and Alinea’s “Amor Inmortal” (Immortal Love), 1939. Other stories are about the rich and the working class in the city, such as Mariño’s “Paralelismo” (Parallelism), 1913, Valdes Pica’s “El Caso Gonzales” (The Case of Gonzales), 1935, and Bernabe’s “El Maestro Que Paro en la Carcel” (The Teacher Who Ended Up in Jail), 1936. The more sordid aspects of city life are portrayed in Rodriguez’s “Cajita Roja” (Red Box), 1934, and Wenceslao Flores’s “La Limosna” (The Alms), 1939.

The stories are about ordinary characters: teachers, bank clerks, office workers, artists, politicians, barrio officials, fugitives, beggars, sweepstakes vendors, priests, prostitutes, and lepers. These characters are placed in dramatic situations, sometimes involving death, as in Balmori’s “Tormenta” (Torment), 1906, and Rodriguez’s “Nelia”; or betrayal, as in Mariño’s “Paralelismo.”

In other stories, the characters are confronted with the harsh truth and forced to live with it, as in Balmori’s “Redencion” and Hernandez Gavira’s “Cuando el Amor Muere” (When Love Dies), 1929. These characters appeal to our sympathies because they struggle against the unjust restrictions of the social, moral, or even religious codes of the world in which they find themselves.

The stories are rendered in various forms. Mariño’s “Los Fugitivos” (The Fugitives), 1922, and “De Tierras Ignotas: La Leyenda de los Cinco Hermanos” (Unknown Lands: The Legend of the Five Brothers), 1910, are examples of Muslim legends. Abad’s “El Dolor del Viejo Campeon” (The Anguish of the Old Champion), 1925, and Balmori’s “Los Ojos Que Cerro la Gloria” (The Price of Glory), 1918, are beast fables. Mariño’s “El Bandolero” (Highwayman) is a frame story. Luna’s “La Maestra de Mi Pueblo” (The Lady Teacher of My Town), and Fernando Ma. Guerrero’s “La Loca Errabunda” (The Wandering Mad Woman), 1928, are character sketches. Josefa Diaz’s “Yo Soy Casi Honorable” (I Am Almost Honorable), 1931, is in the epistolary form. Balmori’s “Bienaventurados los Humildes” (Blessed Are the Meek), 1941, is a type of nature story in debate form.

These short stories belong to no classifiable school. They are transcripts of experience directly observed by the writers and set down with such simplicity and fidelity that they become in themselves unforgettable experiences. They strongly resemble the short stories of the French writers Alphonse Daudet, Guy de Maupassant, and Prosper Merimee in their concern for the middle and lower classes, their sympathy for their wretchedness, their attention to the immediate situation of the lives of the characters, and their emphasis on moral issues. These stories give the readers a panoramic view of life during the American colonial and Commonwealth periods. All of them, whether serious or humorous, emphasize the moral concerns of the writers and display the writers’ mastery of the Spanish language.

The novel was also popular. Novels were serialized in periodicals. A series of booklets, edited by A. Ventura Mestres, called La Novela Semanal consisted of novelas cortas (short novels), the first of which was Alejo Valdes Pica’s La Chispa (The Spark), 1922 (Manuel 1995, 9). Other titles in the series include Jesus Balmori’s Hacia Donde Nos Lleva el Corazon (Toward Where the Heart Brings Us) and Buenaventura Rodriguez’s Desperto la Fiera (The Beast Awakes).

Thirty years after Ninay, Pedro Paterno published a collection of novelas cortas under the title Aurora Social, 1910. This collection consisted of El Alma Filipina (The Filipino Soul), Amor de un Dia (A Day’s Love), Boda a la Moderna (Modern Wedding), Maring: Amor del Obrero Filipino (Maring: Love of the Filipino Worker), Los Heraldos de la Raza (Heralds of the Race), and Los Amores de Antipolo (The Loves of Antipolo). These novelas use melodramatic plots to explore social problems such as poverty, the corruption of the rich, the unjust treatment of the labor class, and the abusiveness and irresponsibility of the capitalist class. More important perhaps than Paterno are Francisco de Paula Entrala and Jose Felipe del Pan, both prolific writers. Their novelas dealt with Philippine society and its customs. Novels were serialized in the newspapers of the period. Among them were those written by women novelists like Antonia Rodriguez de Ureta and Ana Garcia Latorre.

A number of novelists emerged during the American period: Luis F. Nolasco, Antonio M. Abad, A. R. Teodoro, Buenaventura Rodriguez, Estanislao Alinea, Enrique Centenera, Rafael Ripoll, Benigno del Rio, Ramon Escoda, and Luis Guzman Rivas, who published Pigmeos (Pygmies), 1939. One novelist from Pampanga was Jose Flaviano Sanchez.

Jesus Balmori wrote three novels: Bancarrota de Almas (Bankruptcy of Souls), 1910; Se Deshojo la Flor (The Flower Was Stripped of Its Petals), 1915; and Los Pajaros de Fuego (Firebirds), published in 2010. These are conceived and executed in a romantic structure with romantic subjects and a romantic style. The romantic hero of Bancarrota is a poet who dies from consumption. His pregnant sweetheart enters into a marriage of convenience, vowing that she will always love her poet-lover. A more convoluted plot is that of Se Deshojo, which follows the numerous affairs of a married man who is also an artist with a bohemian spirit. His suffering wife dies from consumption; unable to find peace, he eventually kills himself. Los Pajaros recounts the fall of the Robles family brought about by the war and by their own moral decadence.

Antonio M. Abad wrote four novels, three of which were prizewinners: El Ultimo Romantico (The Last Romantic), 1927, Premio Zobel, honorable mention; La Oveja de Nathan (Nathan’s Sheep), 1929, Premio Zobel; El Campeon (The Champion), Commonwealth Literary Contests; and La Vida Secreta de Daniel Espeña (The Secret Life of Daniel Espeña), 1960. These novels reveal Abad’s concern with and insight into current events of historical significance. La Oveja, set in the 1920s, explores the independence question, denounces Western materialism, unmasks American duplicity, and condemns American imperialism. The concerns of Abad’s last novel, Daniel Espeña, are more metaphysical as he raises questions about the salvation of the soul and the wages of sin. David Evangelista, a hardened criminal, changes his name to Daniel Espeña to escape the law. He marries a pious woman and donates large sums of money to charity. But the purgation of his soul lasts through three generations, and through terrible catastrophes both moral and natural, with all the heartaches attendant upon these. Costumbrismo is still evident in this last Filipino novel in Spanish, such as in the numerous notes on scientific names of plants and the detailed depiction of tulisanes (bandits) who rob and kill on the Visayan highway.

The essay in Spanish continued to enjoy great popularity. Subjects were folklore, literature, social, political, and religious problems. The essay was a formidable tool for forming public opinion. Patriotic works were written by Trinidad Pardo de Tavera and Manuel Guerrero, who wrote scientific, philological, and historical studies; Leoncio Gonzalez Liquete, who wrote technical essays; and Kalaw and Manuel Ravago, who wrote philosophical essays. In the early 20th century, outstanding writers of the Spanish legacy were Rafael Palma, who wrote “El Alma de España” (The Soul of Spain), 1900; Macario Adriatico, “Voto por el Intercambio de Ideas” (I Vote for the Exchange of Ideas); and Tirso de Irureta Goyena, “Por el Idioma y Cultura Hispanos” (For the Spanish Language and Culture), 1917.

Patriotic writings continued to appear in the papeles volantes of Anacleto Ramos and in newspapers like La Patria, El Renacimiento, La Vanguardia, La Opinion, El Mercantil, El Debate, and other magazines. The more significant essayists were Claro M. Recto, Teodoro M. Kalaw, Vicente Sotto, Epifanio C. de los Santos, Trinidad Pardo de Tavera, Jorge Bocobo, Rafael Palma, Fernando Ma. Guerrero, and Cecilio R. Apostol.

The newspaper El Ideal published a series of articles alternately written by Jaime C. de Veyra and Mariano Ponce, who both wanted to promote a national consciousness. These articles, written in 1911-12, ranged over topics of social, historical, and political interest; these were then compiled in a book called Efemerides Filipinas (Philippine Almanac), 1914. Another columnist was Teodoro M. Kalaw, whose series of essays from 1926 to 1927 was called Dietario Espiritual (Spiritual Diary). While Kalaw’s fame was usually associated with the controversial editorial of Fidel Reyes, “Aves de Rapiña” (Birds of Prey), 1908, his Cinco Reglas de Nuestra Moral Antigua (Five Perspectives from Our Ancient Morality), 1935, and Hacia la Tierra del Zar (Toward the Land of the Czar), 1908, are of considerable literary merit.

Columnists were Jesus Balmori, Antonio M. Abad, and Benigno del Rio. As American rule became more firmly established, contrary positions were taken by the writers in Spanish. Pardo de Tavera attacked religious fanaticism in essays and speeches, like “El Legado del Ignorantismo” (The Legacy of Ignorantism). Nationalist and anti-American themes were tackled in the essays of Kalaw, Palma, and Irureta Goyena. Adriatico’s speeches stirred his audience, as did those of Sergio Osmeña, Manuel Quezon, and Claro M. Recto. Some of the more notable essays of the period are Recto’s “El Castellano como Factor de Nuestra Nacionalidad” (Spanish as a Factor in Our Nationality); Palma’s “Alma Mater,” 1950; Epifanio C. de los Santos’s Filipinos y Filipinistas (Filipinos and Filipinists), 1909; Vicente Sotto’s “Una Rapida Vuelta al Mundo” (A Quick Trip Round the World), 1930; and Jose G. Reyes’s Ideales de Humanidad (Ideals of Humanity), 1933. Benigno del Rio’s Tangencias (Tangents), published in 1955, is a record of the author’s impressions when he stayed in Spain in 1929-30. It is written in poetic prose “without uppercase letters or punctuation marks, in the manner of Vargas Vila” (Mariñas 1974, 69).

 

The Postwar Period

World War II generally had a devastating effect on Philippine literature in any language, including Spanish. Newspapers and magazines diminished in number: La Voz de Manila, El Debate, and Nueva Era in Manila; La Prensa in Cebu; Ahora and Veritas in Iloilo; Civismo in Bacolod; and El Sur in Zamboanga. However, it also inspired two of the most moving poems in Spanish: Bernabe’s “Romeria de la Muerte” (Pilgrimage of Death) and “Bataan! Corregidor!”

The postwar years saw the reemergence of Spanish newspapers and magazines. Apart from Nueva Era, La Voz de Manila, and El Debate, there were La Semana, Ahora, La Opinion, Veritas, Civismo, and El Sur (Brillantes 2006, 162-63). A Spanish law required all university and college students to take several classes of Spanish, including a course in Filipino literature in Spanish. The textbooks—such as Horacio de la Costa’s Filipino Writers in Spanish, 1957; the second edition of Remigio S. Jocson’s Florilego Hispano-Filipino (Spanish-Filipino Anthology), 1958, first published in 1928; Rosario Valdes de Lamug’s Antorchas de la Patria (Lights of the Fatherland), 1968; Edmundo Farolan’s Literatura Filipino-Hispana (Filipino-Spanish Literature), 1980; and Edgardo Tiamson’s Latidos del Alma Filipina (Beats of the Filipino Soul), 1984—for that course established a canon (Knowlton 1962, 381; 1985, 39-40). Literary contests were established or revived. Bernabe was declared Poeta Nacional by the University of Santo Tomas in 1950 (Brillantes 2006, 74). The Premio Zobel, which had been interrupted by World War II, was resumed in 1953. Among the winners were Vicente de Jesus in 1953, Adelina Gurrea in 1956, Esperanza Lazaro de Baxter in 1957, Fernando de la Concepcion in 1960, Zaragoza Carillo in 1961, and Benito Valdez Vaccani in 1966.

Posthumous collections of works in Spanish were published: Rizal’s Poesias (Poems), 1961, and Guerrero’s Aves y Flores (Birds and Flowers), 1971. More important, new works were being collected. In poetry, there were Hernandez Gavira’s Mi Bandera (My Flag), 1945; Jose Montes’s Bajo el Cielo de Manila (Under the Manila Skies), 1943; Bernardo Garcia’s Al Pie del Mayon (At the Foot of Mayon), 1953; Remigio Jocson’s Luciernagas (Glowworms), 1953; Adelina Gurrea’s A lo Largo del Camino (Along the Road), 1954, En Agraz (Unripeness), 1968, and Mas Senderos (More Paths), 1967; Guerrero Zacarias’s Kaleidoscopio Espiritual (Spiritual Kaleidoscope), 1959; and Emeterio Barcelon and Francisco Zaragoza’s Rimas Filipinas (Filipino Verses), 1964. Critics consider Bernabe’s Perfil de Cresta (Profile of the Crest), 1957, the best of the lot.

In fiction, there were Adelina Gurrea’s Cuentos de Juana (Juana’s Tales), 1942, a collection of stories about encounters with creatures from Visayan folklore, and Enrique G. Centenera’s novel Tomor-cheg, serialized in El Debate, in 1969.

The best essays in Spanish were those that exalted the virtues and heroism of the Filipino race, defended the Hispanic legacy, and prophesied the coming of the new colonial masters. By the 1950s, there was no longer any reason for such essays to be written. Still, there were some representative essays of this period: Enrique Fernandez Lumba’s “Hispanofilia Filipina” (Philippine Love of Spain), 1954; Manuel Briones’s Discursos y Ensayos: Tematios y Vida Filipina (Speeches and Essays: Philippine Themes and Life), 1955; Vicente Guzman Rivas’s “En España Son Asi” (It’s That Way in Spain), 1959; and Encarnacion Alzona’s "El Legado de España a Filipinas" (The Legacy of Spain to the Philippines), 1956. Recto’s “El Monroismo Asiatico” (Asiatic Monroism), 1929, was thought to be the pinnacle of Philippine prose in Spanish until the publication of Recto’s undelivered speeches in 1960. They were later published in a bilingual edition, The Recto Valedictory, in 1985. This book, which carries an English translation by Nick Joaquin, is a compilation of Recto’s speeches that he had intended to deliver in Madrid in 1960 when death stopped him in Rome. In the 1960s, the straightforward, almost belligerent style of Guillermo Gomez Rivera, best illustrated by his Filipino: Origen y Conotacion y Otros Ensayos (Filipino: Origin and Connotation and Other Essays), 1966, contrasted strongly with the impeccable language and serene style of Fernandez Lumba and the flowing lyrical prose of Nilda Guerrero Barranco in Nostalgias (Nostalgia), 1969.

Other writers tried to continue the literary tradition in Spanish: Guillermo Gomez Rivera, Angel Estrada, Edmundo Farolan, Eliodoro Ballesteros, and Federico Licsi Espino. Espino’s poems in Spanish have been collected in Ave en Jaula Lirica / Bird in the Lyric Cage, 1970; Caras y Caretas del Amor (Faces and Masks of Love), 1970; Latigazos de Luz (Lashes of Light), 1974; and Tambor de Sangre (Percussive Blood), which won first prize at the III Bienal de Poesia Ramon de Basterra in Spain in 1977. He received the Premio Zobel in 1978 (Brillantes 2000).

After martial law was declared in 1972, the only remaining Spanish dailies would be El Debate and Nueva Era. That this stream of literature was drying up was also evident in the erratic results of the Premio Zobel. It ceased in 1942, and its revival in 1951 yielded only one entry: a poem in 31 verses. In 1955 and 1958, there were no entries. The contest was suspended from 1967 to 1973. Since 1975 it has ceased to be a literary award, the entries now dealing with sundry topics on the country’s Hispanic heritage. In the succeeding years, no work of literary merit would come out except for the essays and short stories of Nilda Guerrero Barranco and the poems of Federico Licsi Espino.

Besides the survivors of the war, other writers continued to develop the prewar theme of Hispanidad. But it was Bernabe and Recto who would remain as revered Hispanic writers. When Recto and Bernabe died in 1960, the glorious age of Philippine literature in Spanish finally ended. But El Maestro, the organ of the newly organized Solidaridad Filipino-Hispana, served as an impetus for new writers: Guillermo Gomez Rivera, Conchita Huerta, and Federico Licsi Espino, among others.

The Centro Cultural of the Spanish Embassy in Manila launched in 1985 an annual literary contest which encourages more research on Filipino-Spanish topics rather than literary creativity. Hispanidad in the Philippines is a thing of the past, and it would be impossible for Filipino writers to attain the heights of Philippine literature in Spanish reached by such giants as Rizal, Guerrero, Palma, Apostol, Recto, Balmori, Bernabe, and Abad.

 

From 1987 to the Present

Despite the fact that readership in Spanish has declined, Philippine literature in Spanish has persisted in the decades after martial law. Print outlets for writings in Spanish were the Spanish-language papers, but owing to lack of funds and editors, only Nuevo Era, edited by Gomez Rivera, lasted until it too ceased publication in 2008 (Donoso and Gallo 2011, 25). Of these, Cronica de Manila, 1994-97, being a Sunday supplement to a mainstream national newspaper Manila Chronicle, probably had the widest reach. It published articles by Emmanuel Luis Romanillos, Erwin Thaddeus Bautista, Guillermo Gomez Rivera, and Lourdes Castrillo Brillantes (Gallo 2008, 36). In the new millennium, the annual magazine Perro Berde gives space to new works in Spanish, translations, and reprints. A few academic journals occasionally publish or translate literature in Spanish.

With the diminishment of print outlets, writers resorted to online publishing. Revista Filipina: Revista Trimestral de Lengua y Literatura Hispanofilipina, established in 1997 and uploaded at http://revista.carayanpress.com, has been the most important online site for Philippine literature in Spanish. It has connected Filipino writers in Spanish of different generations, the established and the new, and has also made links between writers based in the Philippines and both Filipino writers using Spanish based abroad and scholars of Philippine literature in Spanish from the United States and Spain (Donoso and Gallo 2011, 26). The international character of Revista Filipina is evident in the fact that Edmundo Farolan, its editor, edits it from Canada, while Carayan Press, of which it is an official publication, is run by Edwin Agustin Lozada in California. Contributors come from Europe, the Americas, and the Philippines.

Book publishers have not shut out Filipino writings in Spanish completely. These include university presses, like the University of the Philippines Press and the University of Santo Tomas Publishing House, and trade publishers, like Carayan Press in the United States and Anvil Publishing and Phoenix in the Philippines (Donoso and Gallo 2011, 27). A series called Oriente, edited by Andrea Gallo and published in Spain, puts the works of contemporary Filipino writers in Spanish in print. The books in the series are under the imprint of Moreno Mejias, a publishing house based in Seville, Spain. Three titles have been issued so far. Some writers self-publish. The output of Philippine literature in Spanish is small but steady. Throughout the first decade of the new millennium, at least one book written in Spanish was published each year.

The bulk of the published literature has been poetry. These include Tercera Primavera (Third Spring), 1981, 2000 Versos (2000 Verses), 2000, Nuevas Poesias (New Poems), 2003, and Itinerancias (Comings and Goings), 2006, by Edmundo Farolan; Con Cimbalos de Caña (With Cymbals of Cane), 2011, by Guillermo Gomez Rivera; La Nao de Manila (The Ship from Manila), 2004, by Hilario Zialcita Legarda; Witch’s Dance at Iba Pang Tula sa Filipino at Español (Witch’s Dance and Other Poems in Filipino and Spanish), 2000, and Riding the Full Moon and Other Poems in Filipino and Spanish, 2008, by Marra PL. Lanot; Noelses: Selected Poems in English, Tagalog, Spanish, 1985-2005, 2005, by Noel Guivani Ramiscal; En la Linea del Horizonte (On the Horizon), 2009, by Daisy Lopez; Sueños Anonimos / Anonymous Dreams, 2001, and Bosquejos/Sketches, 2002, by Edwin Agustin Lozada; Brazos Abiertos / Open Arms, 2009, by Paulina Constancia Lee y Cornejo; Romancero Sentimental (Sentimental Romancer), 2010, and Homenaje (Tribute), 2010, by Esperanza Lazaro Baxter. Lo Ultimo de Filipinas, 2001, edited by Jaime B. Rosa, is a collection of Tagalog, English, and Spanish poems by Filipinos. The poems in Spanish were written by Wystan de la Peña, Salvador Malig, Mario Aguado, Ramon Guevara y Biel, Emmanuelle Perlas A. Andaya, Amador Rey A. Beloncillo, Marra PL. Lanot, Noel Guivanni Ramiscal, and Macario Ofilada Mina (Gallo 2008, 271).

Gomez Rivera, Farolan, and Zialcita may be said to belong to an earlier generation, for whom Spanish was the language of the home although its influence in daily life was vanishing. The other writers belong to later generations, for whom Spanish was learned in school. The writing styles are also diverse. Zialcita’s and Gomez Rivera’s poems are predominantly in the classical style, following regular rhyme and meter, while Farolan’s embrace free verse and postmodern techniques (Gallo 2008, 368; Donoso and Gallo 2011, 37, 83-84).

Of these books, those by Farolan, Gomez Rivera, Lopez, and Lozada were published abroad, in the United States, Spain, or Colombia. However, that many of these books are published in bilingual editions suggests that while the production and circulation of Philippine literature in Spanish have gone beyond the Philippines, its writers continue to have Filipinos as their primary readers. Many of the poems remain connected to Philippine realities and history. The persona in Farolan’s “Elogio a la Hispanidad” (Elegy to Things Spanish), for example, rues the violation on his identity wrought by American colonialism and urges “Filipinas” to return “a Madre España y a los hermanos latinos” (to Mother Spain and to Latino brothers)—a perspective which puts it within the tradition of the anti-American poetry of the poets of the golden age. The poems in Guillermo Gomez Rivera’s Con Cimbalos de Caña continue the tradition of the panegyric, which has its origin in the loa. “La Fragua Encendida: A Gloria Zobel de Ayala de Padilla” (The Glowing Forge: To Gloria Zobel de Ayala de Padilla) honors the Zobel family’s patronage of Philippine literature in Spanish (Donoso and Gallo 2011, 49-50). At the core of the collection is the sense of melancholy over a lost world (Gallo 2012, 55). The generational conflicts in Gomez Rivera’s play El Caseron (The Big House), 1975, set in the early 1900s, explore the problem of national identity. The “white lady” of local urban legend in Agustin Lozada’s “La Dama de Blanco” (The White Lady), who “posee / la llave escondida / del secreto / de quien eres tu” (possesses / the hidden key / to the secret / of who you are) is suggestive of the paradoxical position that Spanish colonial culture has come to occupy, at once limbic, because unacknowledged, and ubiquitous, because constitutive of daily practices and habits.

Nonfiction, including essays, memoirs, and histories, have also been published. These include America en Filipinas (America in the Philippines), 1992, by Antonio Molina Memije; La Revolucion Filipina, 1896-1898: El Nacimiento de una Idea (The Philippine Revolution, 1896-1898: The Birth of an Idea), 2000, by Virgilio Reyes Alcantara; Sampaguitas en la Cordillera: Reencuentro con Filipinas en Chile (Jasmines in the Cordillera: Reencountering the Philippines in Chile), 2006, by Elizabeth Medina Seno; and Mis Memorias de la Guerra de Filipinas (My Memories of the Philippine War), 2006, by Maria Dolores Tapia del Rio. Macario Ofilada Mina’s San Juan de la Cruz: El Sentido Experiencial del Conocimiento de Dios (Saint John of the Cross: The Experiential Sense of the Knowledge of God), 2002, and Filosofia, Lenguaje, Mistica: Desde las Entrañas del Espiritu (Philosophy, Language, Mystery: From the Innermost Recesses of the Spirit), 2005, evince his training in philosophy (Gallo 2008, 369-73).

In the last 20 years, works of fiction were published by Alejandro Sotto, Edmundo Farolan, and Paulina Constancia in Nuevo Horizonte and Revista Filipina. Cuentos Hispano Filipinos / Hispano-Philippine Stories, 2009, consists of three stories by Farolan, and four stories by Constancia, with their English translations. Farolan’s are segments of an intended novel chronicling several generations of a family. Constancia’s stories depict humorous situations in a style whose simplicity is suggestive of deeper meanings or of satire.

Alongside these publications of new works by contemporary writers in Spanish are reprints and translations of works from the golden age. These include Cuentos de Balmori (Balmori’s Stories), 1987, translated by Pilar E. Mariño and edited by Edgardo Tiamson; Philippine Short Stories in Spanish, 1900-1941, 1989, edited and translated by Pilar E. Mariño; Cuento/Kwento, 1997, a selection from Mariño’s Philippine Short Stories in Spanish translated into Filipino by Magdalena C. Sayas; and The Other Stories, 1900-1910: English Translation of Selected Philippine Short Stories in Spanish, 2002, compiled by Pilar E. Mariño, edited by Lourdes Castrillo Brillantes, Patricia Brillantes Silvestre, and Edgardo Tiamson, and translated by Teresita A. Alcantara.

The series Classicos Hispanofilipino, launched by the Instituto Cervantes de Manila, produces critical annotated editions of classic works of Philippine literature in Spanish. To date, the titles published are Adelina Gurrea’s Cuentos de Juana (Juana’s Tales), 2009, edited by Beatriz Alvarez Tardio; Jesus Balmori’s World War II novel Los Pajaros de Fuego (Firebirds), 2010, edited by Isaac Donoso Jimenez; and Antonio E. Abad’s El Campeon, 2013, edited by Salvador Garcia, with notes by Luisa Young.

Similarly, Georgina Padilla y Zobel has begun publishing bilingual editions of the Premio Zobel winning works, beginning with Antonio E. Abad’s La Oveja de Nathan, co-winner in 1929, in 2013. The novel was translated by Lourdes Brillantes Castrillo, Lilia Ramos de Leon, and Edgardo Tiamson.

Meanwhile, interest in Philippine literature in Spanish is evident in the scholarly writings of Wystan dela Peña, Erwin Thaddeus Bautista, Emmanuel Luis Romanillos, and Rocio Ortuño Casanova. The field has also been attracting foreign scholars, among them Isaac Donoso, Andrea Gallo, Adam Lifshey, and Beatriz Alvarez Tardio. Translation of Philippine Spanish literature is being pursued by Lourdes Brillantes, Salvador Malig, Mario Aguado, Teresita A. Alcantara, Luisa Young, Marlon James Sales, among others.

Many more poems, stories, novels, plays, and essays by the writers mentioned are awaiting publication, collection, or critical inquiry. Indeed, while it is unlikely that Philippine literature in Spanish should experience a renaissance in the near future, its golden past and its dogged persistence in the present despite odds ensure it a place in the annals of Philippine literature.  Written by Edgardo Tiamson, Pilar E. Mariño, Florentino Hornedo, and Nicanor G. Tiongson, updated by Jonathan Chua, with notes from Lourdes Brillantes

article.value: Sections

Philippine literature in Spanish includes all the poems, stories, novels, and essays written by Filipinos in the Spanish language. This literature began as a tool in the religious and political conquest of the Philippines in the 16th century, but eventually blossomed into a literature of protest against the Spanish colonizers from 1885 to 1896 and later the American rulers, from 1899 to the 1930s.
The Spanish Colonial Period

The earliest known samples of Philippine poetry in Spanish appeared in the first decade of the 17th century, less than 40 years after the introduction of Spanish culture in the islands, apparently under the guidance of the Dominican priest Francisco Blancas de San Jose. His religious books featured the verses of his printers, the Chinese immigrant Juan de Vera, and the Bulaqueño Fernando Bagongbanta. De Vera’s “Gracias a los Castellanos” (Thanks to the Spaniards), 1602, tells of his coming to Manila in search of food and peace and his conversion to Christianity.

article.value: Other Chinese versifiers in Binondo were Jose Ma. Nicaisay, who wrote “Manila Preciosisima” (Most Precious Manila), 1606; Tomas Chui Dian, who wrote “Corre en Mis Venas Sangre Celestial” (Heavenly Blood Runs in My Veins), 1613; and Carlos Calao, who wrote “Que Dios le Perdone” (May God Forgive Him), 1614. Their verses centered on two themes: the Catholic religion and Hispanidad or all things Spanish.

Ladino or bilingual poets also published their interlinear verses in Tagalog and Spanish with religious and Hispanidad themes. These themes would recur through the centuries in Philippine poetry in Spanish. Ladino poetry persisted for almost a century, if not longer. Bagongbanta’s bilingual verses, published in 1604, celebrate Spain’s spiritual and material contributions to the islands—the Catholic religion, corn, tomatoes, wheat, and potatoes. In 1610, Tomas Pinpin published his Spanish grammar for the use of the Tagalog. In one of his poems, he espoused national unity by exhorting the different Philippine tribes to embrace the Cross, learn Spanish, and be loyal to the king. He, like Bagongbanta, also composed ladino poems. Other ladino poems were published by Pedro Suarez Osorio in 1638, Pedro Bucaneg in 1638, Gaspar Aquino de Belen in 1704, and Felipe de Jesus in 1708. Francisco Baltazar could well be our greatest ladino poet as evidenced by his composition “Paalam Na sa Iyo” (Farewell to You), a poem of superb and delicate quality.

In the 19th century, a call for reforms was made by creole and mestizo writers Luis Rodriguez Varela, Pedro Pelaez, Juan de Atayde, and Jose A. Burgos. Creole poetry’s earliest expression is El Parnaso Filipino (The Filipino Parnassus), 1813, a collection of Varela’s poems. Its fame lies less on its literary quality than on its political statement: the need for unity among the peninsulars, creoles, mestizos, and indios (Christianized natives) who comprised the Filipino nation.

article.value: In 1879, the Liceo Artistico-Literario sponsored a literary contest open to all peninsular, creole, and native writers. The winners in the poetry division were the peninsulares (Spaniards born in Spain) Eusebio A. Escobar and Gualterino Marino Seco, the creole Jose Juan de Icaza, and the natives Mariano Romasanta and Jose Rizal. Rizal’s winning piece was “A la Juventud Filipina” (To the Filipino Youth).

Second to Rizal as literary figures were Graciano Lopez Jaena, Marcelo H. del Pilar, Pedro A. Paterno, and Antonio Luna. Other writers of the period were Mariano Ponce, Antonio Ma. Regidor, Isabelo de los Reyes, Gregorio Sancianco, Jose Ma. Panganiban, and Eduardo Lete.

In 1880, Luis Arnedo published Pedro Paterno’s Sampaguitas y Varias Poesias (Sampaguitas and Other Poems). It was intended to be the first volume of a project, Biblioteca Filipina, which was never realized. From Rizal’s maturing pen came gems like “Me Piden Versos” (They Asked Me for Verses), 1882; “Alas Flores de Heidelberg” (To the Flowers of Heidelberg), 1886; and “El Canto de Maria Clara” (The Song of Maria Clara), 1887. Rizal’s poetry would blossom in 1895 with “Mi Retiro” (My Retreat), considered as one of his best works. It was also in 1895 that Fernando Ma. Guerrero published “Borja ante el Cadaver de la Emperatriz Isabel” (Borja before the Corpse of Empress Isabel) and Cecilio Apostol published “El Terror de los Mares Indicos” (The Terror of the Indian Seas).
