The war resulted in the loss of writers, one of whom was Manuel Arguilla, who was slain by the Japanese. Others continued to write even after the war, such as Manuel A. Viray and Amador Daguio. In Daguio’s “Wedding Dance,” 1953, Lumnay, the protagonist, refuses to go to the ritual wedding dance of her former husband Awiyao, who is remarrying despite his love for Lumnay because of her infertility.

Many younger and already published authors of the 1930s quickly gained even greater prominence for their work. In fiction, these include Francisco Arcellana, Estrella Alfon, and N. V. M. Gonzalez. Known in the prewar period for experimentation, Arcellana continued to play with form in his newer work, four of which were brought together in Selected Stories, 1962 (Abad 2012, xx). In “The Yellow Shawl,” originally titled “Wing of Madness,” which won second prize at the annual short story contest sponsored by the Free Press in 1953, Arcellana juxtaposes the present anxieties of life with memories of the recent war, obliquely rooting the trials of the everyday within the violence of history. The story has three parts, the first two focusing on a man’s and a woman’s respective perspectives during a tense pre-romantic encounter, and the last part moving back in time to World War II, where a Japanese soldier takes the young girl’s mother to a separate room while she and her father are forced to wait and listen, a yellow shawl hanging on the wall. Arcellana has been lauded for having perfected the “underwritten story,” using devices that are more characteristic of lyric poetry than of fiction. Thus, the emotive power of his short stories derives from imagery, symbol, and repetition.

Estrella Alfon’s short stories often explore the complexity and conflicts of sexuality and gender. In “Low Wall,” a confrontation arises between neighbors when a young boy looks over the wall to watch a young girl bathing. In the title story of her collection, Magnificence and Other Stories, 1960, she explores the taboo topic of child molestation, committed by a trusted adult friend. The nuances of the female psyche as well as gender roles have been Alfon’s strong suit. In the story, the mother’s fierce and violent reaction when she discovers the molester’s true intentions is contrasted with the father’s insignificant role in the story. There is a sharp contrast, too, in Alfon’s treatment of the little brother and sister. However, this willingness to explore these issues head-on brought Alfon condemnation as well. In 1955, a sexually “explicit” scene in her story “Fairy Tale for the City” brought the author to trial for obscenity, and was then left out of the aforementioned collection.

N. V. M. Gonzalez also continued to write short stories and novels. Shortly after the war, he published his first short story collection, Seven Hills Away, 1947. That was followed by another five books over the next 50 years. He also wrote two new novels, A Season of Grace, 1957, and The Bamboo Dancers, 1961. The latter follows Ernie Rama, an ambivalent and alienated Filipino intellectual, who travels abroad in an attempt to break away from his culture and his country’s traditions, only to find himself lost and alone in a strange cosmopolitan world.

Although he had been published before the war, it was during the postwar period that Nick Joaquin broke into the forefront of the country’s literary production. In 1952, he published his first collection of stories and poetry aptly titled Prose and Poems. Contrary to most writers in English, whose influences were primarily Anglo-American, Joaquin’s stories extensively drew on Hispanic and Catholic traditions and used a baroque style that was both independent of and concurrent with Latin American writers like Alejo Carpientier and Miguel Angel Asturias (Patke and Holden 2009, 75-6). In his fiction, Joaquin conceives of the Filipino as a historical creation, the result of the forced yoking together of conflicting forces. In “The Summer Solstice,” the submerged ancient culture rears its head defiantly in the tadtarin, a ritual celebrating fertility and the female principle, which coincides with the folk Christian devotional feast dedicated to Saint John the Percursor. Meanwhile, in his poetry, Joaquin is a blend of cultures and traditions: Bible, Greek mythology, Mother Goose, Lorca, and Rizal. “The Innocence of Solomon” is psalm-like, intoned with purposely imperfect rhyming: “But wisdom never was content / and flesh when ripened falls at last: / what will I have when the seasons mint / your golden breasts into golden dust?”

Subsequently, Joaquin expanded his novella of the same name into the influential novel The Woman Who Had Two Navels, 1961, which used modernist techniques in intertwining Filipino history and the expatriate life in Hong Kong. The story revolves around two women: Connie Escobar and her mother, Concha Vidal. Connie, tormented by painful realizations about her family, her marriage, and her past, takes refuge in a lie: she insists to all who would listen that she has two navels. The illusion enables her to set herself apart from other people and thus retreat into a world where she need never make moral choices nor assume responsibility for anything. Concha, for her part, is obsessed with her past and her youth, and constantly seeks self-­renewal in her affairs with younger men. The novel uses a revolving point of view to highlight the central theme: the difficulty of distinguishing between right and wrong, truth and falsehood, illusion and reality.

Joaquin also contributed to Filipino drama and nonfiction with the play A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino, 1966, and numerous essay collections such as La Naval de Manila and Other Essays, 1964, and A Question of Heroes, 1977, a series of essays investigating the pantheon of Filipino heroes and their significance to Philippine culture.

In the 1950s and 1960s, alienation in various forms became a recurring theme in many works in English. The position of English in the Philippines as an official yet second or foreign language, along with the predominantly urban, middle-class, and colonial centered discourses that it implied, meant that the English-language writer was in many ways alienated both from his own “Self” and Philippine society and culture at large. The writers themselves make this claim, with Arcellana speaking about the twice-removed Filipino writer, owing to both language difference and the already inherent gap between the artist and his art, and with N. V. M. Gonzalez’s classification of the Philippine nation into three “countries”: the City, the Barrio, and the Mountain (Abad 2012, xxiv-xxv). Simultaneous to these developments was the influx of existentialism into the United States and subsequently the Philippine cultural scene (Lumbera and Lumbera 2005, 190). Existential thought corresponded very well with the alienation felt by the Philippine writer in English.

 

These ideas had a marked influence on a number of younger postwar writers. Following after Alfon, Kerima Polotan explored in stories the psychological conflicts and angst of contemporary women. In Stories, 1968, masterful handling of the elements of the short story is evident in the dynamic characterization of protagonists—all female, all conflicted—and in well-crafted dialogue and action. “The Face of Virtue” details both Celia Gomez’s motives for an abortion—a form of escape—and her attempt at escaping from her dull married life. In “The Virgin,” the uptight and inhibited Miss Mijares, long restrained by a desk job and her family obligations, is unsettled and visibly shaken by the arrival of a stranger.

 

Varied forms of alienation are depicted in Gregorio Brillantes’s The Distance to Andromeda, 1960, between men and God and life itself, often reaching the metaphysical plain. The stories do not contain a plot in the traditional sense; their evocative power is created by a lyrical style, symbolism, and the Joycean epiphany, where meaning is unified by the psychological coherence of the characters. Brillantes’s characters live as strangers in the midst of a familiar crowd of relatives and friends, unable to communicate with one another. In “Faith, Love, Time and Dr. Lazaro,” the doctor ironically fails to sympathize with his own patients, having been made numb by rote, and catches a glimpse of the sensitivity he has lost, and will not ever recover, in his son. In the title story, 13-year-old Ben leaves the cinema with a sense of the universe’s vastness and his own insignificance, but feels also God’s protection.

The search for one’s identity became a prevalent theme at the time, especially as an allegorical representation of the search for national identity. This theme is present in the aforementioned novels of N. V. M. Gonzalez and Nick Joaquin (Lumbera and Lumbera 2005, 192-93). Many of the works at this time intertwined Philippine history with their narratives, such as in Polotan’s novel, The Hand of the Enemy, 1962, in which the violent outcome of the Sakdal uprising hangs like a shadow over Rene and the town of Tayug, and where the idealistic Emma goes to escape from her materialistic husband Doming. Both of these trends are also apparent in Wilfrido Nolledo’s war novel, But for the Lovers, 1970, where the surviving and scavenging Filipino—represented by the amnesiac Maria Alma—both desires and is fought over by the competing desires of different colonizers/cultures (Spanish, American, and lastly, Japanese) during World War II.

In many ways, But for the Lovers “[sums] up the motifs and themes of the search as the writer in English had pursued it for an entire decade” (Lumbera and Lumbera 2005, 195). Heavily influenced by experimental writers in the West, the novel playfully intertwines English with Tagalog and Spanish to create a dense, lyrical, and exuberant language in the text.

This was itself a culmination of another trend: since the publication of his short stories in the 1960s, Nolledo found himself at the forefront of a group of writers who were “set off by a deliberate and sometimes overpowering reverence for the turn of phrase … [and who sought] virtue in conscious artifice of language and situation,” a group that included Erwin Castillo, Cesar Ruiz Aquino and Alfred A. Yuson (Dalisay 1998, 142). However, this density of language was often considered impenetrable for the typical English-reading audiences, let alone for the rest of the country.

In poetry, the most significant and contrary development in this period was the introduction of American formalism or New Criticism, which emphasized strict form, technique, and organic unity; which sought irony, tension, and ambiguity; and which aimed for a completely objective, formal analysis of the literary work, treating the text as an object divorced from the rest of society and history (Tyson 2006, 138-43; Lumbera and Lumbera 2005, 182). This mode of criticism arrived in the Philippines after a number of Filipinos were sent by the Commonwealth government to study in the United States, where they studied literature, creative writing, and poetry.

In the 1950s and 1960s, New Criticism quickly became the dominant aesthetic influence for Filipino poets in English. In contrast with the previous period, whose many poets took themes and images from the same English Romantic tradition, New Criticism’s focus on form and the objective text worked hand in hand with various individual attempts to reconcile language and experience, thus producing a series of more individual poetics among the poets of this generation (Abad 2008, 8-10). The most important poet in this tradition was Edith L. Tiempo, whose work from this time was collected in Tracks of Babylon, 1966. The sonnet “Lament for the Littlest Fellow” builds upon a single image of a marmoset in a cage to lead up to its persona’s small epiphany: the realization that she and her husband are themselves encaged (Abad 1998, 15). Carlos Angeles, who wrote Stun of Jewels, 1962, was also noted for the startling imagery of his poems, tending to minimize, if not efface, the specific details of a scene in favor of a philosophical or emotional point of universal significance. In “Gabu,” Angeles describes the sea crashing endlessly into the desolate shore, an eternally recurring spark of furious vitality that never comes to fruition.

Much of New Criticism’s long-term success can be attributed to its consolidation in national writers’ workshops. Edith and Edilberto Tiempo introduced the workshop model into the archipelago, beginning with the Silliman National Summer Writers Workshop in 1962. This was quickly followed by the UP National Writers Workshop in 1964. Both of these institutions, and the many national and regional workshops that followed suit, have had a significant effect on Philippine literature as a whole, becoming an avenue for the formation of national and regional writing communities, as well as for creating a system of mentorship and patronage across generations. Because of its focus on form, technique, and textual support, New Criticism was a boon for writers in English seeking to hone their craft (Lumbera and Lumbera 2005, 182). Although it is no longer espoused with the same doctrinal rigidity, it continues to be the aesthetic base for creative writing classes and writers’ workshops, especially at the Silliman workshop.

The waning of this “universalist” and “autonomous” aesthetic began in the 1960s, when the two trends of reaching back into Philippine history and of problematizing national identity also bloomed in poetry. In 1961, Alejandrino Hufana published his Poro Point: An Anthology of Lives, a collection of poems about various characters in a “mythical” coastal Ilocano town. Together, these poems create a modern equivalent of an epic about the Iloco people. In the same year, Ricaredo Demetillo’s attempt at the modern epic was published with Barter in Panay, 1961, a retelling of an episode from the historical narrative Maragtas, 1901, in which 10 Bornean datus arrive in the Visayas islands and establish a home. In 1970, Cirilo F. Bautista attempted his own rendition of the epic with The Archipelago, whose varied verses traverse all of Spanish colonial history, from the arrival of Magellan to the death of Rizal.

Influenced by even newer paradigms of literary, scientific, and cultural thought—most especially that of structuralism and poststructuralism (Abad 2008, 13)—poets in the 1980s, like Alfred A. Yuson, Simeon Dumdum Jr, and Eric Gamalinda, wrote poems that contained a playful, inventive energy, that approached large ideas and grand statements indirectly (Patke and Holden 2009, 113; Abad 2008, 13), and that often focused on achieving a “heightened consciousness of language … [and] deep sense of the poem as artifice” (Abad 2008, 15). Although published in 1987, the poems collected in Simeon Dumdum Jr’s Third World Opera best exemplify these traits. In the title poem, an actor runs up to a member of the audience, the governor, and kicks him in the groin, while the theater breaks into applause. Meanwhile, in “February,” 1986, dreary verses of drought are suddenly broken by swift exclamations of “Sudden wind! / Sudden fall! / Sudden sap rising! / Leaf for leaf!” which signals both the coming of the long-awaited rain and references the EDSA Revolt (Dumdum 1999, 204).

However, an even stronger break from New Criticism’s obsession with form was the nationalist movement, which peaked again in the 1950s and 1960s. These decades saw the publications of The Revolt of Masses, 1956, and A History of the Filipino People, 1960, by Teodoro Agoncilio, who offered an analysis of Philippine history through the lens of class struggle. He would then be followed in the 1970s by the books The Philippines: A Past Revisited, 1975, of Renato Constantino, “whose articles on U.S. imperialist control over Philippine society have changed the way Filipinos read their recent history” (Lumbera and Lumbera 2005, 199). In the 1960s, the introduction of Maoism and the formation of the second Communist Party of the Philippines (CPP) offered a new response to the persistent problems of the country post-independence. The declaration of martial law in 1972 exacerbated the brutal inequality and led to further calls for demonstration and revolution.

In this context of cultural nationalism and political ferment, the problem of using English to write for and about Filipinos resurfaced. A number of writers during this subperiod switched from writing in English to writing in the national language, such as Emmanuel Lacaba, who began writing in Filipino and Visayan, and the playwright Alberto Florentino. Almost every writers’ conference from the 1960s onward engaged the “language problem.” Some writers abandoned English for Filipino; others stayed militantly—sometimes apologetically—with English. Jose F. Lacaba, for example, who was writing English verse in college, started experimenting with what is now called bagay poetry, and has become a major poet and translator of poems in Filipino, though he still writes prose in English. His Days of Disquiet, Nights of Rage, 1971, details his experiences of the First Quarter Storm. His brother Emmanuel Lacaba did not engage in the debates, but moved from English to Filipino when he cast his lot with the masses and joined the guerrilla movement.

Poet-critic-playwright Bienvenido Lumbera writes poetry and plays in Tagalog, criticism and literary history in English and Tagalog. Cirilo F. Bautista writes poetry in both languages, as do many younger poets. Rolando Tinio, whose work for his master of fine arts was a volume of poetry in English, returned to and stayed with the Tagalog of his childhood, and thus uncovered a vein of vision and memory until his death. He also translated major dramatic works into Tagalog, but wrote essays in English.

Despite the movement toward Filipino, many Marxist-inspired works were written in English. Emmanuel Torres’s poetry collection, Shapes of Silence, 1972, critiques various habits and institutions in Philippine society. In “Another Invitation to the Pope to Visit Tondo,” the pope “slums” through the lives of the faithful, the masses are left with chances and leftovers, and the workers have holes in their pockets. Meanwhile, in “At the Factory,” workers warm their machines under the watchful eye of the bundy clock, while the boss daydreams of Swiss banks and hoarding more and more capital. Other collections include Prison and Beyond: Selected Poems 1958-1983, 1984, by Jose Maria Sison, A Comrade Is as Precious as a Rice Seedling, 1984, and Why Cage Pigeons, 1985, both by Mila D. Aguilar. In Aguilar’s “The Song of the Revolution,” the love of a husband and wife intertwines with revolutionary struggle, and the two proclaim to “Set the people like a seal on your heart, / like a seal on your arm. / For the flash of their anger / is a flash of fire, / a flame that consumes” (Aguilar 1999, 224-25).

The Lacaba brothers also wrote committed work in English, despite their eventual decisions to turn away from the language. A few years after martial law, and after his own personal decision to stop writing poems in English, Jose F. Lacaba wrote the seemingly innocuous “Prometheus Unbound,” with the initial letters of each line spelling “Marcos Hitler Diktador Tuta” (Marcos, Hitler, Dictator, Lapdog). Meanwhile, Emmanuel Lacaba’s work in both English and Filipino were posthumously published in Salvaged Poems, 1986. This includes “Open Letters to Filipino Artists,” a three-part poem, written in three different times and locations, that shows the transformation of a young poet who goes into the mountains and becomes one with the people. He declares: “Here among workers and peasants our lost / Generation has found its true, its only home.”

By and large, however, the aesthetics of proletariat and peasant literature ran counter to the dominant trends in Philippine poetry in English at that time. This was represented in the 1980s by poets like Gemino Abad, Cirilo F. Bautista, Ricardo de Ungria, and Alfred A. Yuson. In his collection In Another Light: Poems and Essays, Abad offers both a fully worked-­out poetics and an attempt to use the Chicago neo-­Aristotelian method of literary criticism in analyzing Philippine poetry. His primary concern is to capture “the-­poem-­of-­it” in any material—whether it be an idea, event, or another piece of writing—­that he transforms into a poem. Poetry itself is indefinable, and can never be subsumed into doctrine. If one were to demand some politics in Abad’s aesthetics, it would be expressed in this way: “No artist is free or can grow in depth or stature without … appreciation and respect for other orientations of mind, other realms of sensibility, other politics, other mysticisms.” In 1981, Abad, Bautista, de Ungria, Yuson, and Alfrredo Navarro Salanga founded the Philippine Literary Arts Council, which in 1982 published the first issue of what would for many years later be the quarterly journal Caracoa. According to Garcellano (2001, 53-61), although varying tremendously in their personal styles, these poets share a view of poetry and language as transcending the material and political and achieving a supposed universalism that ignores the underlying ideologies and social structures within which language is used in the first place.

In contrast, throughout these decades, Filipino fictionists in English increasingly grappled with the political. In the 1960s, a number of writers already began to lean in this direction. One example is Luis Teodoro, many of whose stories, collected in The Undiscovered Country, 2004, have as their central conflict the vacillation of the petty bourgeoisie between siding with the mass movement and participating in the existing system of power. In “The Trial of Professor Riesgo,” a professor is put on trial for allowing a subversive document to be published in the academic journal he edits. He is then confronted with his own political apathy when he has either to affirm or to deny his responsibility for its publication.

 

Naturally, this movement exploded even further during martial law, from works like Edith L. Tiempo’s A Blade of Fern, 1978, and Linda Ty-Casper’s Dread Empire, 1980, both published in the United States, to Nick Joaquin’s metaphysical detective novel Cave and Shadows, 1983, a whodunit that recreates the events in Manila a month before martial law. More strictly realist, though similar in its attempt to situate present conflicts within Philippine history, was F. Sionil Jose’s pentalogy, the Rosales saga. In its complete form, the Rosales saga traces the history of the Samson family from its roots in Rosales, Pangasinan, in the late 19th century, as seen in the final novel, Po-on, 1984, all the way up to the demonstrations against Marcos in Manila in the 1970s, as seen in Mass, 1979. For their successful and expansive depiction of Filipinos’ centuries-long struggle, the novels are considered an important achievement (Lumbera and Lumbera 2005, 200).

Ninotchka Rosca’s State of War, 1988, is heavily influenced by the Latin American writers. The novel focuses on three characters—­a handsome son of a leading family, an activist woman tortured by the military, and a courtesan’s daughter who is desired by a military officer—­caught in the turbulent years of the Marcos dictatorship. It weaves family history, guerrilla warfare, indigenous folklore, and gender conflict into a baroque narrative of struggle against patriarchy and authoritarianism. Described as an exemplary example of early “martial law fiction,” the novel is “immediate,” “partisan,” and “apocalyptic” in nature, ever ready to cry out against the dictatorship and supportive of armed revolution (Burns 1994, 198).

 

The Post-EDSA Period

The decades following the EDSA Revolt have seen an increase in diversity in Philippine literature in English, both in terms of the backgrounds of the authors involved and in terms of the themes, forms, and genres employed in the texts. The influence of various critical frameworks, including poststructuralism, postmodernism, and postcolonialism, was felt. Globalization easily became the most pervasive phenomenon that influenced both craft and material, as it gave Filipinos access to cultural knowledge from around the world even as the millions-strong Filipino diaspora began to take shape as a truly collective national experience.

The diversification of cultural influences can also be attributed to the return of freedom of speech and freedom of the press after the Marcos dictatorship, despite the return to power of the pre-Marcos oligarchy, as well as the eventual growth of the Internet and other avenues of digital communication from the late 1990s onward. Born out of the mentality and contradictions of the digital age, many of the most recent works from this period exhibit increasing fragmentation, an awareness of the constructedness of the page, the blending of genres and subgenres, and the mixing of written texts with other art forms like text, photography, and komiks (Cayanan, Cruz, and David 2011, 9-12).

After EDSA, a range of historical realities, foremost of which were the persistence of socioeconomic problems that had plagued Philippine society and the 1991 collapse of the Soviet Union, virtually obliterated the radical tradition of Philippine fiction in English, with a shift toward a middle-class sensibility. This is evident in the crop of later martial law–related fiction, including Eric Gamalinda’s Empire of Memory, 1992, and Rosca’s second novel, Twice Blessed, 1992 (Burns 1994: 201-3). Alfred A. Yuson’s Great Philippine Jungle Energy Café, 1988, which had won a Palanca award for the novel in 1986, mixes self-conscious modernist strategies with postmodernist techniques, like anachronism, wordplay, parody and pastiche, magical realism and metafiction, eschewing a one-track construction of Philippine history in favor of a postmodern but middle-class conception of the nation. Other works that deal with the martial law period include Gina Apostol’s Bibliolepsy, 1995; Katrina Tuvera’s The Jupiter Effect, 2004, which tells the coming-of-age story of two siblings, Kiko and Gaby, the children of a key Marcos official; and Cyan Abad Jugo’s Salingkit: A 1986 Diary, 2012, a young adult novel about 12-year-old Kitty Eugenio’s first encounters with change, love, and heartbreak.

Foreign influences have expanded far beyond the European and American canon to include African, South American, Asian, and especially Southeast Asian literatures. Metafictional, magical realist, and other non-realist strategies dominated other novels, like Erwin Castillo’s The Firewalkers, 1992, and Gina Apostol’s The Revolution according to Raymundo Mata, 2009, a fragmentary novel that revolves around a revolutionary memoir that is translated, edited, and presented to the reader with constant intervention (footnotes, introduction, glossaries) from its editors. They now share bookshelves with more traditionally realist narratives like Jose Y. Dalisay’s novels Killing Time in a Warm Place, 1994, which follows the life of an activist turned Marcos bureaucrat, and Soledad’s Sister, 2008, a dark comedy that tracks the journey of a dead overseas Filipino worker’s body from the airport to her hometown.

Interestingly, a good majority of these works are historical novels, in which history is not merely a setting but also a force that drives character and plot. Other historical novels include Gamalinda’s Centenial Literary Prize–winning novel My Sad Republic, 2000, which paints a romantic but historically inaccurate and ideologically problematic portrait of the revolutionary Papa Isio, and Rony Diaz’s Canticle for Three Women: The La Merced Cycle, 2012, which dissects, through the narratives of three women connected to the Hacienda La Merced, the problems of feudalism, oligarchy, and power in post-World War II Philippines.

Creative nonfiction has only recently been seen as a genre equal to fiction and poetry. Recent works include Bienvenido Santos’s autobiographical series of books, the first of which is Memory’s Fiction: A Personal History, 1993, and Cristina Pantoja-Hidalgo’s Passages: Travel Essays, 2007, as well as essay anthologies like Children of the Ever Changing Moon, 2007, by Young Moro Writers, and The Davao We Know, 2011, personal accounts about Davao. Recent publications have also included hitherto uncollected work from older writers, such as Gregorio Brillantes’s The Cardinal’s Sins, the General’s Cross, the Martyr’s Testimony, and Other Affirmations, 2005, which collects 34 of his essays and columns published between 1967 and 2005.

Meanwhile, various subgenres of fiction, like romance, chick lit, detective fiction, and speculative fiction, have found support from mainstream book publishers and online publications alike, with a steadily growing reading base of young professionals. Crime stories include F. H. Batacan’s Smaller and Smaller Circles, 2002, which follows two Jesuits sleuths as they solve a series of gruesome murders in Payatas, and a number of short stories in the anthology Manila Noir, 2013. Meanwhile, a notable writer in the chick-lit genre is Tara F. T. Sering, whose Almost Married, 2003, follows one woman’s journey to discovering whether she is ready for marriage. The book won a National Book Award in 2004 for the young adult novel, a decision that sparked controversy owing to the awarding body’s erroneous identification of young adult literature with chick lit.

Speculative fiction—an umbrella term that encompasses multiple modes/genres of non-realistic storytelling, like fantasy, horror, magical realism, and superhero stories—is perhaps the most popularly marketed of the new “genres,” and already has amassed a sizeable amount of work. Much of this is collected in the annual anthology Philippine Speculative Fiction, 2005, edited by Dean Francis Alfar, such as Joshua Lim So’s “Feasting,” a horrific tale about a father who goes abroad to work and sends back boxes of meat for his family. Short story collections include Ian Casocot’s Heartbreak and Magic, 2011, which examines various forms of human loss through magic and “fantasy” in narratives set in Casocot’s Dumaguete; the fantasy collection A Bottle of Storm Clouds, 2012, by Eliza Victoria; and the horror collection Waking the Dead, 2009, by Yvette Tan. Novels include Alfar’s magical realist Salamanca, 2006, about a complicated relationship between a writer and his reluctant muse, whose beauty turns a house into glass; and Victoria’s science fiction Project 17, 2013, a fast-paced investigation into a series of robot assassinations in a futuristic Bulacan and Manila.

Thematically, most contemporary writers have no qualms about the use of, mixing of, and/or writing about popular culture and literature. Often, they use pop culture in a fashion both ironic and socially aware, thus blurring the conventional notions of the “literary.” Carljoe Javier’s story collection, Geek Tragedies, 2011, employs various genres and pop culture motifs to explore contemporary male geek culture in the Philippines. Lourd de Veyra’s Super Panalo Sounds! (Super Winner Sounds!), 2011, chronicles the rise and fall of a group of musicians set in the seedy, often corrupt, sometimes surprisingly uplifting underbelly of the Philippine rock scene. Mass media, which is simultaneously the medium and the greatest example of contemporary pop culture, is often criticized in contemporary works, such as in Dustin Celestino’s story “MediaEx Presents: Savages,” which unveils the commodification integral to Philippine media through the story of Carlito and the destruction brought about by two Media personalities who do anything and everything to earn for their respective shows.

 

Although precolonial history and folklore have always been a source for Filipino writers in English, stretching from as far back as the romantic stories of the 1920s to Gilda Cordero-Fernando’s wonder tales in the 1950s and 1960s, and the novels of Yuson and Rosca in the 1980s, a recent surge in the use of folklore motifs can be seen. Many contemporary works delve into indigenous folklore/culture, reinterpreting the past for the present day. This is best represented by Rosario Cruz-Lucero’s story collections Feast and Famine: Stories of Negros, 2003, and La India, or Island of the Disappeared, 2012. The former includes “The Death of Fray Salvador Montano,” which follows one Spanish priest’s attempt in the 19th century to construct a dictionary for the natives. The latter includes “Inventing Datu Calantiao and His Code,” a historiographic metafiction that weaves back and forth from past and present and from fiction and “reality” to relate the “discovery” and creation of the Code of Kalantiaw.

Because the recovery of folk culture is the recovery of heritage, and because the rewriting of history is a rewriting of dominant/domineering narratives of nationhood and society, these movements thus make room for the recovery of marginalized and minority voices in Philippine literature. This is another powerful trend in the post-EDSA years. Works in this vein challenge dominant narratives and binaries along axes of gender, sexuality, and ethnicity. As with folklore, this work has a long history, and can be seen already in the exploration of Muslim-non-Muslim conflict and identities in the stories of Ibrahaim Jubaira and of Antonio Enriquez (in Spots on Their Wings and Other Stories, 1977, and Surveyors of the Liguasan Marsh, 1981).

In 1994, J. Neil Garcia and Danton Remoto edited and published Ladlad, a landmark anthology of gay literature that had sequels in 1996 and 2007. The breadth of thematic concerns suggests that contemporary Philippine gay literature covers a rainbow of political, generational, geographical, and aesthetic colors. Xerxes Matza’s story depicts gay “lifestyles,” including what mainstream society might consider repulsive, while Nicolas Pichay’s poem “An OCW Tries the Personals” suggests where romance might be found outside of bars and bathhouses. Murphy Red’s essay “Gayspeak in the Nineties” is a look into gay lingo, with a glossary by Ram Garcia.

Cristina Pantoja-Hidalgo’s Recuerdo, 1996, is an epistolary novel that rereads Philippine history from the perspective of women in a family’s history. This production of counter-histories is common to many of other works as well, such as Rosario Cruz-Lucero’s collection Herstory, 1990, and Criselda Yabes’s biography / literary memoir Sarena’s Story: The Loss of a Kingdom, 2010, which explores the oft-ignored history of the sultanate of Sulu through the eyes of its women: the princesses and the servants.

Meanwhile, the many stories of Charlson Ong detail the predicaments of being Chinese Filipino, as does his novel Banyaga: A Song of War (Alien: A Song of War), 2006, which follows the tragedy-filled rags-to-riches story of four Chinese children migrants in Manila. Ong’s first novel, the Rizal-inspired An Embarrassment of Riches, 2000, which won second place in the Centennial Literary Prize, also delves into the Chinese question in Philippine society. Other writers who tackle Chinese-Filipino themes include Jaime An Lim, Caroline Hau, and R. Kwan Laurel.

More and more writers are also setting their stories in the regions, “often in explicit contrast to middle-class life in Manila” (Patke and Holden 2009, 154). In Vicente Groyon’s The Sky over Dimas, 2004, Margie Jarabas Torrecarrion calls on her son Rafael to return to Negros, an island he swore he would never return to again, to take his father away from the worker’s daughter he has holed up with for months. Meanwhile, Carlos Ojeda Aureus’s Nagueños, 1997, is a collection of stories set in the streets, schools, and churches of Naga, the “Queen City” of Bicol. Most of the stories center around a middle-aged man, steeped in Catholic theology, brooding over the deritualization of the Church after Vatican II as well as the decay of morality in society at the end of the millennium.

While one can say that this use of regional settings has always been present in Philippine literature written in English, this recent development comes side by side with various efforts at promoting literature from the regions, which include increased critical attention on Philippine literatures outside English, Tagalog, and Spanish (Lumbera and Lumbera 2005, 384), the formation of writing groups, like the Davao Writers Guild, and the emergence of various writers’ workshops in the regions, like the Cornelio Faigao Memorial Annual Writers Workshop in Cebu City, the IYAS National Writers’ Workshop in Bacolod City, and the Iligan National Writers Workshop in Iligan City. Many works are also being translated into English, such as Gremer Chan Reyes’s The Sea Child, 2008; the two-volume Sugilanong Sugboanon (Cebuano Fiction), 2009, which collects 28 pieces of Cebuano fiction from the 19th century to the present day; Antisipasyon asin Iba Pang mga Rawitdawit sa Bikol asin Ingles (Anticipation and Other Stories in Bicol and English), 2012, which collects the poems of Bikol writer Victor Dennis T. Nierva, and Selebrasyon at Lamentasyon (Celebration and Lamentation), 1998, which collects stories from Panay written in Hiligaynon, Aklanon, and Karay-a.

Beyond genres and themes, there is also the growth of newer forms like the comic book. The rise of the graphic novel as well as an increase in criticism on the subject has put forth the legitimacy of comics as a valid form of storytelling. Many established and budding comics writers meet every year in the annual Komikon, a convention for Philippine komiks that began in 2005. One of the most renowned in the field is Arnold Arre, whose The Mythology Class, 1999, about an anthropology student who gets caught up with spirits from the world of Philippine myth and legend, won the National Book Award in 2000. Another major writer is Gerry Alanguilan, who has worked on both Filipino and American comics. His four-part Elmer, originally published in the Philippines between 2006 and 2008, explores the sudden sentience of chickens in the 1970s and their subsequent fight for rights. Finally, Budjette Tan’s Trese series mixes multiple trends in contemporary Philippine literature into one work. It follows Alexandra Trese as she solves mysterious and gruesome crimes, often committed by gangs of mythological creatures.

However, this increasing diversity is belied by the fact that the majority of contemporary Philippine writers are members of the urban and university-trained middle class, and are mostly “liberal without being radical” (Groyon 2007, xi). Many contemporary fictionists use the English language “unapologetically, refusing to be burdened by colonial guilt” (Dalisay 1998, 144). That said, they also use their bilingual/multilingual abilities to good effect with the confident incorporation of other Philippine languages into their texts, such as in the occasional multilinguistic melange in Yuson’s Great Philippine Jungle Energy Café (Groyon 2007, xiv).

Many of the trends of diversification appear in Philippine poetry in English, too. As with fiction, Philippine poetry in English benefited from the opening up of the press after the fall of the dictatorship. That development eventually allowed the publication of poetry to be supported by both university presses (its main outlet) and commercial presses. The poststructuralist “open clearing” has developed even further, so that, in the new millennium, all key assumptions about poetry are at one time or another suspended. It should first be noted, though, that not all writers took up playfully cynical, self-critical “postmodern” concerns. Marjorie Evasco’s Ochre Tones, 1999, a collection of English and Cebuano poems, delves into the link between the spiritual and the physical, between contemporary man and ancient and mystical forces around him. In Evasco’s work, the sea often appears as a vehicle for these connections, from the primordial “navel of a nether sea” in “Uyayi for Busay,” to God’s ethereal blue in “Is It the Kingfisher?,” a blue that is “the color / Which makes our souls visible” (Evasco 1999, 303).

A number of new and intersecting trends can be identified in poetry in English. In lieu of the “natural,” many poets, reflecting their own demographics, situate their works in the city, both as the setting for their works and as a subject for exploration. Conchitina Cruz’s Dark Hours, 2005, looks at the many processes in which urban space informs/defines its inhabitants’ lives and vice versa. The prose poem “Dear City” is an accusatory letter (with the subtle hint of a painfully enthralled eulogy) that blames the city for the corruption of life-giving water into floods and dirt and death. In Cruz’s poetry, the city is both friend and enemy, foreground and background, so much of a precondition for the persona’s existence that she is unable to escape it.

Related to the issue of urbanity, another trend in Philippine poetry in English is the blurring of boundaries between high culture and low culture and the increasing use of pop culture references in poetry. Like his fiction, Lourd de Veyra’s poetry makes frequent use of pop aesthetics. His “Jesus Disco DJ” infuses the rhythms and beats of pop with the images of Jesus DJ-ing for a club, commenting on the way in which religious ecstasy drowns out reality. Eric Gamalinda’s “Zero Gravity,” the title poem of his collection, eulogizes the 1969 lunar landing as a moment of religious transcendence, when the image of the future allows its massive TV audience to suspend, for even just that moment, all the suffering of the present world. Meanwhile, tabloid gossip is the instigator of Marne Kilates’s “Python in the Megamall,” which portrays the crowd’s willing submission to a sensationalism of their own making.

Reinterpretations of folklore are also prevalent. The story of Alunsina is of particular interest given its number of reinterpretations. Neil Garcia’s “Legend of the Seafoam” retells the creation myth while dichotomizing the couple into the fiery, masculine creator Tungkung Langit and his “negative”: the water-like, feminine, shadow Alunsina. In contrast, Conchitina Cruz’s “Alunsina Takes a Walk in the Rain” leaves the grand mythic mode used by Garcia but retains a similar dichotomy between the male God’s strong, fiery pleas—a pushing presence his wife rejects—and the lonely speechlessness of his tearful rain—an absence Alunsina finds difficult to ignore. Kristine Domingo takes the myth even further; the first part of her three-section collection Alunsina’s Wrist, 2004, spreads the story out into 12 simultaneously distilled, decentered, and yet verbally explosive poems that trace out, bit by bit, Alunsina’s story of pain, grief, and recovery.

In fiction and poetry alike, there is a sense of recovering, restoring, or reinscribing one’s heritage in the increasing use of folklore and history. Such are Elsa Coscolluela’s aims, especially with regard to women’s history, in poems like “Katalona” (Priestess) and “Katipunera.” In the former, the “priestess” speaks of colonial devastation and calls for a return to an alleged underlying native identity. In the latter, the persona, implicitly Gregoria de Jesus, speaks of her husband and the revolution, her love for him and his death, as well as her own dedication and fervor.

In the age of globalization, many poems feature traveling personas aiming to identify and articulate their displacement and/or cultural translocation. This is a common theme in the poems of Ricardo de Ungria, especially in his books Decimal Places, 1991, and Body English, 1996. In “Angel Radio,” the persona’s trip across Brooklyn Bridge calls his mind back to the Pasig River, to a childhood memory of transcendent crossing, that is then drawn back suddenly to the United States, to Ellis Island where “unspeakable voices / seem to waft in their wake” and to San Francisco where the first American teachers left for the Philippines, interpellating the Filipino as “half-devil and half child.” Other examples include the poems of diasporic writers like Virginia Cerenio, Fatima-Lim Wilson, and Luisa Igloria.

Globalization is seen not only in themes of displacement but in the very use of language itself. In Lola Coqueta, 2009, Isabela Banzon combines English with Bahasa, mixing the already multicultural “Filipino” with the rhythms and equally complex significations of Malay. The simultaneous futility and yet creativity of translation are also seen in poems like Paolo Manalo’s “Galing” and “Bahala Na,” which attempt to render the Filipino words into English not via providing their literal translations but through associative meanings and experience. A more humorous and lighthearted take on the matter can be seen in Manalo’s “The Third Wheel (Happy Ending, Not Really),” which plays with archetypes of romantic and forbidden love in the reincarnation cycles of three lovers in various times, cultures, and classes.

The confessional poem is popular among young poets, as seen in the anthology Crowns and Oranges, 2008. In most of the poems, the reader is easily drawn into the small snapshots of the poet’s lives, ranging from mundane events, such as passing through a national park (“At Quezon National Park” by Jennifer Cariño) or musings about the houses one has lived in (“A House” by Mikael de Lara Co), to deep philosophical and political conundrums, such as an uncle telling his niece that reality is so much more than the abbreviations she uses to communicate with people (“Life Is a Wait-to-Be-Seated Cafe Lines for a Teen-age Niece” by Jun dela Rosa), or warnings to a country often on the brink of disaster (“Foreword to a Nation about to Crumble” by Joseph Saguid). Most poems embed a private or shared transgression—real or imagined—and proceed to develop ways on how the persona attempts to deal with it, while the reader, the confessor, has no choice but to give them absolution.

That said, many younger poets in the new millennium have veered even further away from the poetry favored by the previous generation, problematizing key assumptions of the New Critical tradition: strict form, organic unity, coherent imagery, and even the overall mediation of a unified persona or voice. The very construction of this persona is dissected in Mark Anthony Cayanan’s “Placelessness” series. In “But What I Really Want to Say Is,” the “I” unveils, bit by bit, the inevitable machinations of the confessional poem, ultimately declaring: “I am telling you what I want is for you to tell me / It is mine, too. Not an epiphany, not a punch line, / but a mirror, but a kiss, but in the air, perfume, effluvium” (Cayanan 2011, 78).

While they have not completely abandoned the small, particular, and slowly built epiphany, many contemporary poets focus instead on investigating forms of experience. This is most evident when the particular experience involves other arts, such as in Mookie Katigbak’s “Cello Music,” or in how seeing and being intersect in the various stages of photography in Mabi David’s “Looking.” In Michael Balili’s “Meditations on Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo’s The Penitent,” the ekphrasis eschews the typical poetic block in favor of a series of short, often one-verse-long, passages. These fragment the painting into multiple discreet images—from the wound of Christ to monstrance to the light—that reconstruct the experience of eyes flitting across the surface of the canvas, searching for meaning.

Not surprisingly, language itself provides the key to exploring these forms. Common to many of these poets is the recognition that language is not merely a means of expression, but the very medium of both being and knowing. Thus, special attention is given to the materiality of language, to the ways in which its sound, syntax, grammar, morphology, and overall arrangements facilitate meaning. An overt example is Francisco Guevarra’s “There Was the Climate,” where a fumbling “my” in various stages of its formulation interjects repeatedly into the poem, asserting the slow construction of the word/identity (both aurally and visually) while disturbing any easy absorption into the text (Guevarra 2012):

… What Adam swept during

a pretense of a rose is—or,    my

 

rendered elastic what he had hoped

mym y to be another immovable hue.

Subsequently, neither lineation, spacing, nor even the very fact of the page (its size, its shape, its whiteness) is taken for granted. Lines no longer merely drop along the left side of the page, but can instead swing back and forth across the horizontal axis. This freedom with lineation and page design is used to create multiple effects. For example, in Marc Gaba’s “Study of Copernicus, 1514,” the circulatory motion of the words alludes to the Copernican revolution and coincides with the astronomer’s hesitant movements within the church. On the other hand, Vincenz Serrano’s “From Short Walks” divides each of its pages into three parts—a fragmented couplet, a photograph, and a prose block, each of which provides separate and simultaneous points of entry into the text.

In the works above, the traditional composition of poetry no longer holds; it yields instead to different styles of playful experimentation and generic mixing. The prose poem appears frequently, such as in Mikael de Lara Co’s “Proposal,” where a series of violent proposals builds a steady momentum toward its final, breathless staccato. Building on and away from Dark Hours, where the prose poem is also heavily featured, Conchitina Cruz’s Elsewhere Held and Lingered, 2008, fields a variety of forms: a set of footnotes without a main body (“Inventory of a Year”), a set of marginalia without a main body (“Marginalia”), a multiple choice quiz (“Multiple Choice”), and an index of last lines (“Index of Last Lines”). Inspired by Raymond Queneau’s Exercises in Style, Adam David’s El Bimbo Variations takes the initial two lines of the Eraserheads' song “Ang Huling El Bimbo” and rewrites them in multiple styles (antonymy, univocalism, tautogram, Jose Garcia villanelle), genres (koan, moral lesson, comic strip, tabloid news clipping), and functions (circular logical analysis, HTML, chord book), in both Filipino and English. Ironically, this work composed entirely of constraints is simultaneously the most open and diverse of projects, encapsulating many of the trends of the period, from the diversification and collapse of genres (poetry, fiction, comics) and subgenres (horror, romance, erotica), to the dissolution of “high” and “low” cultures. It is attentive to the materiality of language and is completely comfortable with the mixing of English and Filipino.

 

It should be noted, however, that any claims toward revolutionary shifts in poetry are belied by the fact that much of its “diversity” remains tethered to developments in North American poetry—to the works of Gertrude Stein, Jorie Graham, Louise Gluck, Charles Olson. Significantly, many of the Filipino poets mentioned above have received, or are currently in the process of acquiring, master’s degrees and doctorates from American universities. At the same time, and true to the definition of the word, the American avant-garde leanings of these poets render an already elite-centric English even more inaccessible to the general public, so that despite the liberating spirit which seems to inform these various investigations into being and language, the pieces are mostly limited to a tiny sliver of the population, though with different degrees of insularity.

This is not, however, the necessary state of things, especially as the very infrastructure of literary production in the Philippines begins to shift. Much of these developments have both directly and indirectly been shaped by the Internet. The different avenues of digital communication have given Philippine writers more freedom to pursue their own individual projects, as well as cheaper venues in which to publish them. E-book publishers and online journals, like Kritika Kultura and High Chair, which is also a collective, make full use of the electronic/digital medium to publish works that for whatever reason (format, aesthetics, politics) would not have been published in traditional print venues. In 2011, Kritika Kultura published Anthology of New Philippine Writing in English, which features many of the trends noted above as well as an example of hyperlink fiction (Kristine Marie Reynaldo’s “Anamnesis”); a series of pictures showing the ink of a one-page prose poem incrementally disappearing (Petra Magno’s “ADHD”); and a series of quotes (which are not the author’s), culled from social media, and arranged into a narrative (Anna Opposa’s “Facebook Makes and Breaks Relationships”).

Although the traditionally “well-crafted” piece (for fiction and poetry alike) continues to dominate on the institutional level—in workshops and creative writing courses and awarding bodies like the Palanca—these new forms, styles, and publication venues are steadily gaining ground, pounding gleefully at the gates of the literati and driving the “literary” forward into the unforeseeable horizon.

 

Conclusion

The century-long history of Philippine literature in English is inextricable from the social and material conditions that have circumscribed the use of the English language in the archipelago. Much like Spanish in the previous centuries, the institutionalization of English in the American colonial period imbued the language with prestige and power, not least because it was the primary means of access to the colonial center. Not surprisingly, literature in English began in the university halls, and much of it has continued to be written by graduates of the university system—with a number of notable exceptions, like Joaquin and Villa. This fact is most evident in how writing in English has quickly become a primarily urban, middle-class, and upper-class phenomenon, which is reflected in the subject-positions of a majority of its writers.

In little over a hundred years of development, Philippine literature in English, especially fiction, has gone through two somewhat analogous cycles of moving toward and withdrawing from direct and radical political engagement, though not necessarily from social consciousness. Both of these instances are connected to the historical events of their times, and both led to heavy introspection among Philippine writers concerning the status of the English language vis-à-vis the project of nation-building (Alegre and Fernandez 1984, 161; Lumbera and Lumbera 2005, 198-99).

On both the personal and societal level, Philippine writers in English have learned to master the language of the colonizer and to deal with (and write about) the inherent contradictions that come with using it. Although the writers’ primary literary and cultural influences continue to be American, Philippine writers in English have also always delved into indigenous and Hispanic traditions and are now exploring, because of globalization, African, South American, and various Asian and Southeast Asian traditions.

The last three decades have seen a diversification of styles, themes, genres, and forms. The influences of globalization, various critical theories, a growing reading public, and different kinds of digital technology and communication have all contributed to this explosion of literary activity. Whatever will eventually become of English in the Philippines, these new technological developments, the social and material conditions of the country and the rest of the world, the momentum of over one hundred years of literary activity, and the ambitions, positions, and contradictions of Philippine writers in English will doubtless steer the course of its literature in the century to come.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez, updated by Dominic Sy

article.value: Sections

Of the many linguistic traditions in Philippine literature, Philippine literature in English is simultaneously one of the most recent and one of the most prolific. It constitutes, in the overall literary landscape, a larger stream than that written in Spanish, a much smaller stream than that written in the local languages like Tagalog, Cebuano, Ilonggo, Ilocano, Waray, Kapampangan, Pangasinan, Bikol, but is certainly the most visible one because of its exposure in the educational system and its accessibility through publications. This situation is due to a century’s worth of imposition and institutional support for English across the archipelago since the early 1900s, evident in the continued prestige the language holds in many facets of Philippine society.

There is a long-standing debate on the use of English by Filipino writers and the political implications of such use. Critic Gemino Abad stresses the eventual ability of Filipino writers to make the colonial language their own (2008, 1-5; 2012, xiii-xiv). On the other hand, Edel Garcellano argues that the use of English is inextricable from the ongoing processes of imperial domination and class exploitation in contemporary Philippine society (2001, 60-72). It remains primarily a language of the elite, an institutionalized medium facilitating economic and cultural exchange within bourgeois and imperial spheres of influence, while excluding the majority of the population. J. Neil Garcia contributes to this debate by, first, giving Abad credit for showing that the English language is not merely a “foreign” language but has, through time and contact and usage, become a uniquely hybrid Philippine English. He notes, however, that Abad’s essentialist and universalist logic has been used as justification for discrimination against cultures perceived to be “primitive” simply because they are different from this essential, Euro-centric idea of man (Garcia 2004, 60-100).
