article.value: A prolific writer and illustrator of children’s books is expatriate Jose Aruego, who successfully published in New York during his lifetime. A Crocodile’s Tale: A Philippine Folk Story, 1972, is about an ungrateful crocodile who threatens to eat a boy who has saved his life. The boy is rescued by a monkey. In Juan and the Asuangs, 1970, a small boy from a barrio saves dogs and chicken from the manananggal (a self-segmenting ghoul) with the help of a magic recipe he learned from his grandmother. At the time of his death in 2012 in New York where he lived and worked for decades, Aruego had published over 80 books for young readers.

The Philippine Board on Books for Young People (PBBY) was established in 1983 to encourage the development and publication of children’s literature and its readership. An important step was to work for the proclamation of the third Tuesday of July as National Children’s Book Day, to be celebrated in schools across the nation. One of the important activities of the PBBY has been a yearly competition for writers and illustrators of children’s books sponsored by the Cultural Center of the Philippines and the National Library of the Philippines. The Illustrators’ Prize was first awarded in 1984 and is known today as the PBBY Alcala Prize. The Writers’ Prize, first given in 1985, was later renamed the PBBY Salanga Prize. The awards are named after founding members of the PBBY, illustrator Larry Alcala and writer Alfrredo Navarro Salanga.

The early winners of the Writers’ Prize are Rodolfo Mallari for “Malikoban”in 1984; Aurora Batnag for “Si Matabangka at ang Tagapag-ingat ng Hangin” (Matabangka and the Keeper of the Winds) in 1985; Maria Elena Paterno for “Mga Kuwintas ng Sampaguita” (Garlands of Sampaguita) in 1986; Edgardo Maranan for “Awit ni Pulaw” (Song of Pulaw), “Si Sibol at si Gunaw” (Bloom and Doom), and “Si Sabel, si Sabiong Lumba-Lumba at ang Hiwaga sa Laot” (Sabel, Sabiong Lumba-Lumba and the Wonder at Sea), from 1989 to 1991; and Cesar Aljama for “Ang mga Diwata sa Lawa” (Gods at the Lake) in 1992.

Recent recipients of the PBBY Salanga Prize are Russell Molina for “Anong Gupit Natin Ngayon?” (How Would You Like Your Haircut Today?) in 2012, Michael Jude C. Tumamac for “Ngumiti si Andoy” (Andoy Smiled)in 2013, and three honorable mention citations in 2014: Michael de Guzman for “Reyna Elena” (Queen Elena),Genaro Gojo Cruz for “Gaano Ba Kalayo Patungong Paaralan?” (How Far Is It to School?),and Susan Ann Alegro Quirante for “Ang Misay sa Aming Bahay” (Our House Misay).

The first Illustrators’ Prize winners are Jess Abrera, Renato Gamos, Juanito Sy, Joel Yau, Jose Melchor Silvestre, Raymundo Mortel, Joanne de Leon, Salvador Convocar, and Eleanor Ramos. Recent recipients of the PBBY Alcala Prize are Hubert Fucio in 2012, Dominic Agsaway in 2013, and Aaron Paul Asis in 2014.

Other institutions took up the cause of the genre. For the years 1982-83, Mr. & Ms. sponsored a writing contest for the children’s short story in English and Pilipino. For two years, the 10 best works were selected. The 1982 winners in the English category are “Kiko and the Magic Bamboo” by Gretchen B. Ira, “The Most Beautiful Mother” by Aurora G. Reyes, “The Eagle-Eating Monkey” by Sylvia Mendez Ventura, “The Boy Who Hated the Wind” by Mary Agnes A. Dizon, and “Cardo and the Black-Ink Fish” by Melissa Y. Moran. The prizewinning works in the Pilipino category are “Ang Higante sa Kennon Road” (The Giant at Kennon Road) by Aurora Batnag, “Ang Aking Bisikleta” (My Bicycle) by Aurora G. Reyes, “Ang Lapis at ang Kandila” (The Pencil and the Candle) by Danilo Abacahin, “Kung Bakit Laging Nag-aaway ang Pusa at Aso” (Why the Cat and Dog Constantly Fight) by Saturnina A. Fadul, and “Ang Awit ng Kuliglig” (The Song of the Cricket) by Nicodemus B. Melgar.

In 1988, the PBBY sponsored a Bookmakers’ Prize for child writers and illustrators in the grade-school level. The contest was in two divisions, English and Pilipino. Philip Tan Gaute, writer, and Jason Khong Hun, illustrator, won in the English division for “Indarapatra and Sulayman.” Ricci Pillar Sugui, writer, and Kim Dy Liaco, illustrator, won in the Pilipino division for “Isang Heneral, Isang Bayani” (One General, One Hero). Although meant to encourage the production of children’s literature by child writers and artists, the contest has not been sustained, and the writing of children’s literature has generally been an activity of adult writers.

Other significant events occurred during the decade of the 1980s to promote the development of children’s literature in the country. The first was the production of a Filipino version of the popular children’s television show Sesame Street, called Calle Sesame, in 1983. Calle Sesame was practically a clone of its US counterpart, with minor changes and concessions to its Filipino child audience. A year later, this was replaced by a show with similar objectives and formatting, but with a more definite Filipino identity, as evident in the puppets used and the distinctly Filipino setting. The name was also changed to Batibot (a word which means “enduring,” “healthy,” or “vigorous”), and slowly the format and theme of the show grew away from Sesame Street, until it achieved an identity of its own. Batibot and other children’s television shows, such as Pin Pin, Yan ang Bata (That’s the Kid), and 5 and Up, might be credited with helping to develop an audience and therefore a market, for children’s literature in the country. Batibot included a storytelling segment that features folktales and teaches preliteracy and beginning literacy skills. Perhaps its greatest contribution was its promotion of a greater awareness of alternative means of education—namely, that education is not confined to a school but can take place at home, with a television show, with books and stories.

The 1980s saw the legitimization of children’s literature, as key cultural institutions began to give it space. The Creative Writing Center at the University of the Philippines, Diliman, Quezon City, sponsored its first summer workshop on writing for children in 1983. Another workshop was held in 1989. In Nov 1989, the Goethe-Institut, in cooperation with the Children’s Communication Center, sponsored a workshop on children’s book design and illustration. The first prize winner in a competition among the workshop participants was published in an impressive volume titled Manik Buangsi, with a story by Virgilio S. Almario and illustrations by Albert E. Gamos.

Two years later, a similar workshop also sponsored by the Goethe-Institut resulted in the formation of a group of children’s book illustrators called Ilustrador ng Kabataan (Ang INK). The original members of this group include Melchor Silvestre Jr, Buds Convocar, Beaulah Taguiwalo, Norman Isaac, and Joanne de Leon. To this day, Ang INK remains the only organization of illustrators for children in the country. Its members have distinguished themselves by excelling in their art and demonstrating their craft through annual art exhibits.

A sign that children’s literature, indeed, had arrived was the introduction of a short story for children category in both the English and Filipino divisions of the Palanca Awards in 1989. Winners include Amado Lacuesta, Ramon Sunico, Alfred A. Yuson, and Maria Elena Paterno. This validation of the genre is a result of all previous efforts to develop books for children. More support came via the Cultural Center of the Philippines, when it devoted an issue of its literary journal Ani to children in 1989 and established a children’s literature category in its Creative Writing Grants program.
From the 1990s to the Present: A Publishing Boom

As the 1990s arrived, publishing companies began to invest seriously in Filipino children’s books. In 1990, Bookmark launched its Filipino Folktale series with titles by an author whose work as a student it had published two decades earlier. Marla Yotoko Chorengel authored The First Cashew Nut, Marmol, Why the Sky Is High, Bathala and the Gift of Rice, and Gabi and the Engkanto. The books were handsome volumes, lavishly illustrated and in full color, and this time, it seemed, people were ready to buy them. Two more titles, Dikya: The Jellyfish and Maksing and Mona were released the following year. The Filipino Folktale series was Bookmark’s flagship series for children’s literature, planned in response to a general complaint from parents and educators that there was no Filipino children’s book that could compare with its Western counterparts.

Bookmark also experimented with narrative poetry for adolescent and pre-adolescent readers, with Marivi Soliven’s The Unicorn, 1992, and Chun, 1993. Both original works, The Unicorn revolved around the theme of growing up and leaving behind “childish” things, and Chun focused on the issue of racial discrimination through the eyes of a child.

Today, Bookmark principally publishes two children’s biography series. The Great Men and Women of Asia series, in partnership with the Ramon Magsaysay Award Foundation (RMAF), features the lives of the RMAF awardees. The Modern Heroes for the Filipino Youth series focuses on Filipino personalities who have contributed positively to society (Yabut 2014). Its fiction title, The Day of Darkness by Gutch Gutierrez, received the first Kids’ Choice Award in the 2014 National Children’s Book Awards (NCBA). Another book, Si Sibol at Si Gunaw by Ed Maranan, was produced as a ballet. Khan: A Teacher of Everything by Nikki Dy-Liacco was translated into five local languages in Pakistan.

Cacho Publishing House began its children’s book line in cooperation with Batibot, the children’s television show. Since 1990, it has launched titles that have the advantage of recall by parents and recognition by children. Ang Pamilyang Ismid (The Ismid Family), 1990, Ang Alamat ng Araw at Gabi (The Legend of Day and Night), 1990, Si Linggit Laban kay Barracuda (Linggit versus Barracuda), 1990, Si Inggulo at ang Planeta ng Pakaskas (Inggulo and the Recklessly Speeding Planet), Si Elephas at Estegodon noong Unang Panahon (Elephas and Estegodon Once upon a Time), 1992, and Ang Patsotsay na Iisa ang Pakpak (The One-Winged Patsotsay), 1992, are thin books with soft covers, but printed on coated paper, and with full color illustrations. The books did well in the market.

The Trampoline series, also launched by Cacho in 1990, was conceived to move away from the “traditional” children’s book concept. Except for Kung Bakit Umuulan (Why It Rains), which is a modern retelling of a folktale, all the stories in the series are original tales, distinctly modern in the telling. Similar in format to the Batibot books, the Trampoline series was designed as a cooperative effort between writers, illustrators, and publishers. There is a deliberate attempt to use the modern children’s idiom, in text as well as in illustration. The Trampoline series offers the Filipino child-reader bilingual text and full-color, innovative illustrations. Chosen from among story winners at the Palanca Awards, the four stories are Kung Bakit Umuulan by Rene O. Villanueva with illustrations by Robert Alejandro, a retelling of a Panay creation myth that stresses the importance of equality in human relations; Ang Unang Baboy sa Langit (The First Pig in Heaven), also by Rene O. Villanueva with illustrations by Ibarra C. Crisostomo, a clever tale on an old theme, the value of cleanliness; The Boy Who Ate Stars by Alfred A. Yuson, illustrated by Beth Parrocha, a modern-day parable of humans’ greed and their destruction of the environment; and Two Friends, One World by Ramon Sunico, illustrated by Joanne de Leon, which tells the same story from two differing points of view, that of a blind boy and his seeing friend. Two more titles were launched in 1991: Sampaguita by Maria Elena Paterno, with illustrations by Beaulah Taguiwalo; and Ang Nawawalang Araw (The Vanishing Sun), by Ramon Sunico, with illustrations by Joanne de Leon.

Cacho soon began to focus on the young adult genre, alongside other players in the industry who felt the need to serve the reading needs of older children and teenagers. In 1998, PBBY and the Asia/Pacific Cultural Centre for UNESCO sponsored a writing workshop that focused on writing for this age group. The facilitator for the session on novel writing was Jackie French, a popular and critically acclaimed Australian writer. The workshop led to the publication by Cacho in 1997 of the novella Owl Friends by Carla M. Pacis and The Secret by Lin Acacio-Flores. More titles followed in the subsequent years: Birdlight, 2000; O.C.W., 2001; and, in 2002, Enrique El Negro by Pacis and Adventures of a Child at War by Flores. Cacho’s next YA novels were “I Hate My Mother,” 2007, by Perpilili Vivienne Tiongson and Playing It Safe, 2007, by G. T. Los Baños, and Tall Story, 2010, by Candy Quimpo Gourlay, a UK-based former Filipino journalist who granted Cacho publishing rights for the Philippine editions of these titles. This development was a milestone in the industry because the titles were published by David Fickling Books, an imprint of Macmillan UK (Pacis and Sunico 2016). The number of print runs of these YA novels indicates a popular demand for them.

In 2013, Cacho and Anvil merged into one publishing house, with Anvil as its publishing imprint (Bolasco 2015). Anvil Publishing had ventured into children’s literature. In 1991, it published the Kris the Bumper series by Rene O. Villanueva with illustrations by Ibarra Crisostomo. The series consisted of six books—one each on counting, shapes, color, opposites, and first words, and one character search activity book. The books were published as a set in 1996. In 2004 it began to publish Christine S. Bellen’s retellings of the Lola Basyang stories, like Ang Alamat ng Lamok (The Legend of the Mosquito), Ang Mahiwagang Biyulin (The Enchanted Violin), Plautin ni Periking (Periking’s Flute), and Ang Parusa ng Duwende (The Dwarf’s Punishment). Some of the books have been adapted into ballet and a television feature.

Anvil has also published poetry books such as Children of Two Seasons, 2007, by Lara Saguisag, illustrated by Hubert Fucio, and The Google Song and Other Rhymes for Our Times, 2012, by Edgardo Maranan; YA titles like Bad Kings, 2006, by Gilda Cordero-Fernando, illustrated by Gilbert R. Perez and Dennis L. Espiritu, The Secret of the Cave, 2011, by Edgardo Maranan, illustrated by Dorothea Ysabel Maranan, The Magic Circle, 2012, by Gilda Cordero-Fernando, illustrated by Gilbert Daroy, May Tiyanak sa Loob ng Aking Bag (Goblins inside My Bag), 2012, by Eugene Evasco, and Salingkit: A 1986 Diary, 2012, by Cyan Abad-Jugo.

Tahanan Books, now Tahanan Books for Young Readers, was founded in 1991. Its name comes from the Filipino word for “home,” where the love for reading and learning begins, as its company profile advocates. It focuses on books on Philippine history and culture. The demand for high quality books in Filipino and other languages has led it to issue dual editions in English and in Filipino, bilingual editions with translations on the same page, and editions in other local languages (Ong 2014).

OMF Literature Inc began publishing a few children’s titles in the 1980s but it was not until 1993 when its brand of children’s books was created. Hiyas Books were intended to be strong in Christian values, as exemplified in the works of its two popular authors, Luis P. Gatmaitan and Grace D. Chong. Gatmaitan, a pediatrician, has a continuing storybook series, Mga Kuwento ni Tito Dok (Uncle Doc’s Stories), on health, wellness, and other childhood medical issues. His story Sandosenang Sapatos (A Dozen Shoes), 2002, is about a shoemaker whose own daughter is maimed and has no need for shoes. It has been turned into a children’s musical and translated into Japanese, Bahasa, Thai, and Khmer. Chong writes the Oh, Mateo! Series, which has an endearing young boy named Mateo eager to learn new things.

Hiyas has also published books for children aged six years and below. The Great Duck and Crocodile Race, 2011, by Robert Magnuson is ideal to be read aloud. It won the National Children’s Book Award in 2012.

Acknowledged as the first publishing house of children’s books outside Metro Manila, ABC Educational Development Center, based in Kidapawan City, Cotabato, began publishing children’s books in 2000. Its initial titles were by author Mary Ann Ordinario Floresta: The Crying Trees, illustrated by Yasmin S. Ong, My Muslim Friend, illustrated by Joanne de Leon, and War Makes Me Sad, illustrated by Biboy Blu. Then a Mindanao-based neophyte, Floresta had encountered difficulties in interesting Manila-based publishers in her stories but has since 2000 released 30 titles, which are also used for therapy sessions for children who have experienced war in the region (Floresta 2014). All the books carry English-Filipino texts, and some have been translated into Bahasa. My Muslim Friend has been translated to Nihongo.

Visprint Inc began publishing in 2001 with ABNKKBSNPLAko?! by Bob Ong, whose true identity remains unknown today. Visprint did not begin as a publisher for the youth market but developed a line of entertaining books for the youth as it received book proposals geared toward that largely untapped age group. Its other titles are comic strip compilations or graphic novels: Kikomachine by Manix Abrera, Trese written by Budjette Tan and illustrated by KaJo Baldisimo, and Anim na Sabado ng Beyblade at Iba Pang Sanaysay (Six Saturdays of Beyblade and Other Essays) by Ferdinand Pisigan Jarin. Visprint titles have been included in the Department of Education’s reading lists and adapted into movies (Ramirez 2014).

Vibal Publishing Inc and its sister company LG&M Chikiting Books began publishing children’s books in 2002. Its titles on family and experiences of preschoolers are popular, including Ang Aking Pamilya (My Family), 2006, by Genaro Gojo Cruz, Ang Bago Kong Kalaro (My New Playmate), 2013, by Rhandee Garlitos, and Ang Sampung Bukitkit (The Ten Dandelions), 2011, by Eugene Evasco, illustrated by Ibarra C. Crisostomo, which was named one of the Best Reads for 2012 by PBBY and the National Book Development Board’s (NBDB) National Children’s Book Awards.

It also carries children’s books on sensitive issues: Ang Bonggang-Bonggang Batang Beki (The Super Fabulous Gay Boy) by Rhandee Garlitos is about an effeminate boy, while Si Faisal at si Farida (Faisal and Farida), also by Rhandee Garlitos, examines the cultural identity of Muslims. Si Kaitlin at ang Game Machine (Kaitlin and the Game Machine) by Ferdinand Pisigan Jarin relates the importance of disconnecting from technology and connecting to real people. A few of its stories have been translated into Ilocano and Bisaya. Ang Aking Unang Diksiyonaryong Caton (My First Syllabary Dictionary) and Children’s Treasury for Filipinos are available in the mother tongue languages identified by the Department of Education (Calalang 2015).
Vibal Digital pioneered in developing interactive e-books and picture book apps in 2011. Its first e-book for children was Ibong Adarna, which is available for free download for readers.

In the same year, picture book apps were developed for mobile devices. These include Yummy Fly Pie, written and illustrated by Jomike Tejido; Mariang Sinukuan, retold by Eugene Evasco, illustrated by Leo Cultura; Pagpagayuk, retold by Evasco, illustrated by Piya Constantino; Amansinaya, retold by Evasco, illustrated by Jomike Tejido; and Ang Mahiwagang Kamiseta (The Enchanted Shirt) by Evasco, illustrated by Ghani Madueño.

Lampara Publishing House Inc was born as a sister company of Precious Pages Corporation, which carries popular romance novels. In 2002, Lampara began to publish a variety of children’s books which are marketed as series, including Modernong Alamat (Modern Legends), Kuwentong Nanay (Mother Stories), Mga Premyadong Kuwentong Pambata (Prizewinning Children’s Stories), Juan Tamad (Lazy Juan), and Illustrated Classics. Its series on award-winning stories makes available to the public Palanca stories which otherwise would have remained in manuscript form. Some of these stories are available as storytelling videos and have been used for television programs. It has released a YA novel, Moymoy Lulumboy: Ang Batang Aswang (Moymoy Lulumboy: The Witch Kid), 2014, by Segundo Matias Jr, illustrated by Jomike Tejido (Matias 2014).

Lampara has begun translating some of its stories into Bisaya, Cebuano, and Ilocano. Following its acquisition of translation rights from foreign publishers, it has made available Filipino novels originally written in English, like E. B. White’s Charlotte’s Web (Matias 2014).

The Center for Arts, New Ventures and Sustainable Development or CANVAS began in 2005 with Elias and His Trees, based on a French story adapted by Augie Rivera and artworks by the late Romeo Forbes. Its books begin with an original artwork by a visual artist that inspires a children’s story, which in turn inspires accompanying illustrations for the picture book. A special appeal of CANVAS books is that the artworks are rendered as full-size paintings, which are sought by collectors.

Its award-winning titles include The Rocking Horse by Becky Bravo and illustrated by Elmer Borlongan, which won the Gintong Aklat Award in 2008. Two other titles won major literary awards: the National Book Award in 2009 for The Boy Who Touched Heaven by Iris Gem Li, illustrated by Serj Bumatay, co-published with Adarna; the National Children’s Book Award in 2012 for a horror children’s story, Doll Eyes by Eline Santos, illustrated by Joy Mallari.

article.value: Nadia and the Blue Stars, 2012, by Francesca Nicole Chan Torres and illustrated by Liv Romualdez Vinluan was used to help victims of trauma from conflict and natural disasters. It has been distributed to children in evacuation centers in Zamboanga and adapted into a play in Chabacano by Ateneo de Zamboanga University (Alampay 2014).

Summit Media first added children’s titles and YA literature to its principal line of magazine glossies in 2012 under the Dream Big Books and Pop Fiction imprints, respectively. Dream Big Books began when Summit publisher Lisa Gokongwei Cheng and her siblings commissioned writer Yvette Fernandez and illustrator Abi Goy to work on a children’s biography on their father, industrialist John Gokongwei, on the occasion of his 85th birthday. Big John, 2012, was soon followed by biographies of successful individuals and role models: Nanay Coring, 2012; Ninoy, Cory, and Noynoy, 2012; Simply Jesse, 2013; and Princess Lea, 2013.

Summit’s Pop Fiction imprint grew out of what the Summit editorial staff discovered to be a very popular section of their teen magazine’s website CandyMag.com, Teentalk. “She’s Dating the Gangster” by Bianca E. Bernardino was a favorite story, so it was published as a book, with illustrations by Boizei Malicdem, in 2013. It remains a best seller and has been reissued under three different covers and adapted into a movie by Star Cinema. The Pop Fiction series also includes stories sourced from Wattpad, the Toronto-based online writing community that invites writers to post anything they have written. In Mar 2014, Wattpad signed a contract with Pop Fiction to publish Filipino Wattpad stories in the Philippines. The imprint has proven that teens continue to read books (Ko 2015).

The Department of Education’s Mother-Tongue-Based Multi-Lingual Education program, which requires the use of the local language as medium of instruction for kindergarten and for grades 1-3, has led to the development of children’s literature outside Manila and attracted the interest of Manila-based publishers to translate texts to other Philippine languages.

Even before this policy was in place, however, Mother Tongue Publishing Inc, founded in 2006 by Mario and Beaulah Taguiwalo, had been publishing books in as many Philippine languages as possible. Its first books were the Philippine editions of “The Mountain That Loved a Bird” by Alice McLerran, a story first published in the United States and Japan, with illustrations by Eric Carle. It had been translated to other languages and reillustrated by various artists in different parts of the world. The Philippine editions carried new art by Taguiwalo and were translated into Filipino as Ang Bundok na Nagmahal sa Ibon by Rene O. Villanueva; into Ilocano as Ti Bantay a Nagayat iti Maysa a Billit, by Herminio S. Beltran Jr; into Karay-a as Ang Bukid nga Nagpalangga sang Pispis by Genevieve Asenjo; and into Bisaya (Cebuano) as Ang Bukid nga Nahigugma sa Langgam by Grace Monte de Ramos (Taguiwalo 2014).

There are other efforts in the regions. In 2009, three children’s books were published in the Kuwentong Katutubo series, written by Aeta and Mangyan communities under the auspices of the Pamulaan Center for Indigenous Peoples Education in partnership with local community schools. The Pamulaan Center is an educational institution based in Davao del Sur dedicated to the training of indigenous people in organizational capabilities so that they would have better access to education, basic necessities, and alternative sources of livelihood. These storybooks were written in the local language, with English and Filipino translations all on the same spreads. Diya, Kanyam Buay (The Land Is Our Life) was written by Alangan-Mangyans Ma. Dolores Andrinay, Ligaya Lintawagin, and Resureccion Taywan. The illustrator June Anthony Galicia is also a Mangyan. In Agpalkuyugan Pepito (The Journey of Pepito) is author Pepito Caquipotan’s personal story about how he strayed from the Mangyan ways of life and experienced alienation. The illustrator was Roger Pumihic. Istorya na Lima a Dinum (The Legend of the Five Rivers) is a retelling of a legend told by the Aeta elders of Quirino, written by Carlos David, an Aeta, and illustrated by Avid Sanchez, David Pantaleon, both Aeta, and Roger Pumihic (Doyo 2009).

In 2010, a children’s book in Pangasinan was published, Pasirayewya Malapati (The Boastful Dove) by Erwin Fernandez. It was published by Ulupan na Pansiyansiya’s Salitan Pangasinan, with this expressed objective: “buhayin ang isang naghihingalong wika” (revive a dying language) (Evasco 2016).

The Ina nin Bikol Foundation Inc is a nongovernment organization in Bicol that publishes materials in Bikol for children and young adults as part of its scholarship and literacy programs. A first anthology in the Balaog Children Series was An Poon kan Pili asin Iba Pang Osipon na Pan-aki (The Origin of Pili and Other Stories for Children), edited by Fr Wilmer Tria, SJ, and Kristian Sendon Cordero, illustrated by Jeremeel Lu. It has three stories, one each by Francisco V. Peñones Jr, Christine S. Bellen, and Kristian S. Cordero in Bikol, Filipino, and English. It is described as a pre-Ibalon account as it ends where the Bikol epic begins. A German translation of The Origin of Pili was released in 2012.

An anthology of Bikol children’s stories was published in 2012 by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts and the Arejola Foundation, which sponsors the Premio Tomas Arejola para sa Literaturang Bikolnon, with short story for children as one of the categories. Yudi Man: Mga Osipon ki Nonoy asin Nene (No Kidding: Stories for Nonoy and Nene), edited by Carlos Arejola and Lorna Billanes, is a collection of prizewinning stories in the category. It has released Bikol translations of classics by Fr Wilmer Tria, SJ, like The Little Prince by Antoine Saint-Exupery and The Prophet by Kahlil Gibran (Cordero 2014).

The Ina nin Bikol Foundation and the Ateneo de Naga University Press, both headed by Tria, are committed to develop published materials dedicated for children and young adults. The Department of Digital Animation of the university has produced “An Lalong ni Kulakog” (Kulakog’s Rooster) by Omar Aguilar, a 10-minute video animation which received a special citation in the 2013 Metro Manila Film Festival.

Alice Tan Gonzales has a collection of seven Hiligaynon stories for children, May Isa ka Kuring nga Harik ag Iban pa nga Sugilanon para sa Kabataan (There Was a King Cat and Other Stories for Children), published in Iloilo in 2010 by Seguiban Printing and Publishing Enterprises. In 2013, Maria Luisa S. Defante-Gibraltar had a series of children’s books in Hiligaynon published by Manila-based Emerald Publishing House: Ang Baboy ni Akoy (Akoy’s Pig), Ang Karabaw kag si Islaw (Islaw’s Carabao), Anay (Termites), Si Bangbang nga Alibangbang (Bangbang the Butterfly), Bulak nga Rosal (The Gardenia Flower), and Kag Pista Minatay(Feast of the Dead).

In 2011, Balay Suguidanun (The House of Storytelling in Philippine Languages) was launched as an online platform for literature in Cebuano, Karay-a, Filipino, Hiligaynon, Waray, an initiative of writer Genevieve Asenjo. It sponsored a literary prize for children’s stories in Karay-a from 2011 to 2012. Mabaskognga Hiligaynon (Strong Hiligaynon), 2013, is a book of original stories, nursery rhymes, and short poems by Asenjo, intended for grade 1 students (Asenjo 2014, 2015). Also involved in the same project are Abdon Balde for Bicol and Grace Monte de Ramos for Cebuano.

In Ilocano, the magazine Bannawag has a regular feature of children’s poems and original children’s stories in Ilocano from time to time (Tabag 2014). Gunglo Dagiti Mannurat nga Ilokano or GUMIL, the largest association of writers in Ilocano, has published the first of what it envisions to be a series on Ilocano short stories for children, Dagiti Napili a Kabukbukodan a Kapipintasan a Sarita a para Ubbing, Umuna a Libro (The Best Original Ilokano Short Stories for Children, Volume 1), 2015. It has works by Anna Liza Gaspar, Cles Rambaud, Godfrey Dancel, Martin Rochina, and Mighty Rasing (Angeles 2015). The organization was encouraged by the brisk sale of the first book of children’s poetry that Saniata Publications released in 2012. Bullalayaw (Rainbow) was sold out in three months through direct selling, an indication of a market for such books.

The Golden Arrow of Mt. Makilkilang and Other Cordillera Folktales, 2013, published by the Cordillera Green Network, is an anthology of folktales from the Kalinga, Benguet, Apayao, and Mountain Province collected during the various Eco-Youth Summits in the Cordillera (Evasco 2016).

In 2014, Si Kilat ag si Daeogdog (Kilat and Daeogdog) by John E. Barrios was published by the RB Publishing House in Kalibo, Aklan, along with Golda: Rogoldfish nga Suplada (Golda: The Snobbish Goldfish) by Nynn Arwena Tamayo. This initiative is part of the advocacy to promote Aklanon and the local culture. Si Kilat has been translated into Hiligaynon. Hubon Manunulat, an Ilonggo writers’ group, has also published a collection of short stories for children, edited by Leoncio P. Deriada, Sugilanonay Kita (Let Us Tell Each Other Stories), 2014 (Barrios 2015).

In 2010, the Gig and the Amazing Sampaguita Foundation Inc, a nonprofit private organization founded and headed by Marissa Oca Robles, published 10 books in full color which represented the best seafarer stories from its inaugural Gig Book Storywriting Contest. The stories may be primarily directed toward a specific audience, but they provide another opportunity for authors and illustrators to be recognized and published. The stories tackle the dynamics of families with an absentee father at sea. The winning stories from the second Gig Book Storywriting Contest have been made available on Amazon. The books in the series are not commercially sold but are distributed to schools, libraries, and communities (Taguiwalo 2015).

The First Read Project of nonprofit organization Save the Children Philippines began in 2013 to address the earliest stages of literacy acquisition for children aged zero to four, many of whom do not have access to books that would prepare them for formal schooling. It has embarked on a publishing program of high-quality materials which are distributed free of charge to its target beneficiaries. It selects materials that are age-appropriate, context-specific, culturally sensitive, and written in the mother tongue of the communities. It has original stories in Filipino, translations of existing books in partnership with Adarna House and Tahanan Books, and books published in Mindanao developed by minority groups. These books written in the mother tongue of the indigenous communities involved consultations with local language groups, tribal leaders, teachers, local language experts, and representatives from the National Commission on Indigenous People. The series on games, rhymes, and lullabies have been recorded on CDs (Carasig 2015).

The institutional validation that children’s literature received in the late 1980s continues to be affirmed today. Aside from Palanca Awards, other awards have provided incentives for the creators of children’s literature. The National Book Awards (NBA) of the Manila Critics Circle, which began in 1982, recognizes outstanding books in different categories published in the preceding year. From 1990 to 2008, the NBA had a children’s literature category. When this was discontinued, the PBBY and NBDB organized the National Children’s Book Awards to honor outstanding children’s and YA books published in the country the previous two years. There are no categories or rankings in the NCBA. The text, the illustrations, book design, and the total look of the books are evaluated, and the selection would constitute the “Best Reads” for the year. A maximum of 10 titles is the goal, but the number has always been fewer, proof that the industry has much room for growth.

The 2010 NCBA Best Reads are Araw sa Palengke (Market Day) by May Tobias-Papa and illustrated by Isabel Roxas; Tuwing Sabado (On Saturdays) by Russell Molina and illustrated by Sergio Bumatay III; Can We Live on Mars? by Gidget Roceles-Jimenez and illustrated by Bru; Lub-Dub, Lub-Dub by Russell Molina and illustrated by Jomike Tejido; Tagu-Taguan (Hide and Seek), written and illustrated by Jomike Tejido; and Just Add Dirt by Becky Bravo and illustrated by Jason Moss.

The 2012 NCBA Best Reads are Ay Naku! (Oh My!) by Reni Roxas, illustrated by Sergio Bumatay III; Ang Sampung Bukitkit (The Ten Bukitkit) by Eugene Y. Evasco, illustrated by Ibarra C. Crisostomo; Doll Eyes by Eline Santos, translated by Augie Rivera and illustrated by Joy Mallari; Tall Story by Candy Gourlay, illustrated by Yasmin S. Ong; The Great Duck and Crocodile Race, written and illustrated by Robert Magnuson; and The Secret Is in the Soil by Gidget Roceles Jimenez and Flor Gozon Tarriela, illustrated by Liza Flores.

The 2014 NCBA Best Reads are Ngumiti si Andoy (Andoy Smiled) by Xi Zuq (Michael Jude Tumamac), illustrated by Dominic Agsaway; Hating Kapatid (50-50) by Raissa Rivera-Falgui, illustrated by Fran Alvarez; What You Should Know about Andres Bonifacio and the Katipunan by Weng Cahiles, illustrated by Isa Natividad; and The Girl in a Box by Felinda Bagas, illustrated by Aldy Aguirre. For the first time, the Save the Children Award, specifically for the best book for children ages zero to four, was given during the 2014 NCBA. It went to Bahay Kubo (Nipa Hut), a board book illustrated by Pergylene Acuña.

Another award is the Best Children’s Short Story given by the Catholic Mass Media Awards every two years beginning in 2001. In 2014, a Kids’ Choice Award was introduced. One book from a shortlist of 10 is chosen by a panel of child judges from private and public schools. The award was won by The Day of Darkness by Zig Marasigan and Gutch Gutierrez, who were also the illustrators.
Conclusion

Children’s book publishing has become a viable and thriving business today, a feat in itself considering that a few decades ago children’s books did not sell. Publishers, whose numbers have increased, seem to agree that their success in the field is due to a combination of several factors: their knowledge of their target market, the development of a new generation of buyers who prefer locally produced books over imported ones, a growing awareness on craft, and the increasing professionalism in the areas of writing, illustrating, packaging, and marketing. The industry continues to manifest promising though cautious growth in terms of the quantity and quality of titles each year.

It is noteworthy that topics not written about in the past and formerly considered inappropriate for children have been woven into children’s books. Sexual abuse is the subject of Ang Batang Ayaw Gumising (The Boy Who Doesn’t Want to Wake Up), 1997, by Rene O. Villanueva and illustrated by John D. Crisostomo, and Ang Lihim ni Lea (Lea’s Secret), 2007, by Augie Rivera and illustrated by Ghani Madueño. Papa’s House, Mama’s House, 2004, by Jean Lee Patindol and illustrated by Mark Ramsel Salvatus III, is about a child coping with separated parents. Ang Ikaklit sa Aming Hardin (The Sunflower in Our Garden), 2012, by Bernadette Neri and illustrated by CJ de Silva, deals with lesbian parents (Evasco 2016).

The publishing industry faces challenges in marketing books in a country where books are still considered luxury items by the average Filipino. There is no existing public library system in most parts of the country and even the largest bookstore chain is not present in every province, thus clearly limiting the access to books. It is not surprising that literacy remains a major issue of the population. There have been significant developments and initiatives which have tried to address the problems of access and literacy. All of these programs have promoted and extensively used the children’s books published in the country.

There have been private foundations committed to promoting the love and habit of reading, among them the Sa Aklat Sisikat Foundation that worked with grade 4 students and teachers from 1999 to 2011 in an innovative reading program for 31 school days. The Inquirer Read-Along Program began in 2007 as the Philippine Daily Inquirer’s corporate social responsibility program to address the declining reading habit in the young and the increase in school dropout rates.

The growth in children’s book publishing may be seen as part of a larger development in Philippine publishing in general. Participants in this growth have been writers, illustrators, book designers, publishers, teachers, and a new generation of parents and book buyers, all of whom are more aware of the demands of nationalism and the importance of a child-centered children’s literature.  Written by Maria Elena Paterno, updated by Neni Sta. Romana-Cruz

Sections

Literature in Chinese
Literature in English and Filipino

 

Chinese-Philippine literature may refer to the writings by the Chinese residing in the Philippines; to the works written in Chinese by Chinese Filipinos; or to works written in any language by Chinese Filipinos. More narrowly, however, Chinese-Philippine literature is equated with the writings in Chinese, English, Filipino, and other languages by Filipinos of Chinese descent, which deal with their experiences as Chinese in the Philippines. A distinction may be made between “Philippine Chinese,” referring to immigrants, and “Chinese Filipinos,” referring to those whose identity is primarily Filipino but with Chinese racial origins. Some overlapping or transitioning occurs, however, so that one writer’s oeuvre may contain both works that reflect an immigrant’s sentiments and works that evince a rootedness in Philippine realities.

 

Thus, all these are examples of Chinese-Philippine literature. “Juan de la Cruz—the Friendly Filipino,” 1986, a story written in Chinese by èŽŠå­�æ˜Ž (ZhuÄ�ng ZÄ­ming) using the pseudonym ç´«èŒ— (ZÄ­ming), describes the friendship between a Chinese shopkeeper and Juan, a Filipino farmer. “The Moment of Leaving,” 1947, a poem written in Chinese by æ�œè‹¥ (Dù Ruò), an immigrant, expresses his fondness for the Philippines (trans. Fang 1988, 153):

Oh, Manila, I was unwilling to part from you

You have made me grow

For that, I feel grateful.

Jaime An Lim’s story “Bye Bye Birdie,” 1971, shows an old-generation Chinese getting ridiculed for his inability to speak the local language.

A third group may be identified, with which, however, this article is not concerned. As Gloria Chiu Yap notes in her study of Chinese-Philippine fiction, there are a handful of writers of Chinese descent whose works feature Chinese characters or Chinese Filipinos but do not explore their experience in the Philippines primarily. Practically all of Clinton Palanca’s stories fall under this category. Conversely, there are stories written by Filipinos whose theme is the Chinese-Philippine experience. These include Dionisio Gabriel’s “China Opera,” 1969, which depicts the subordinate condition of young Chinese women. “Mr. Cheng and the Great Wall of Culture,” 1960, by Tita Lacambra-Ayala explores the conflict young Chinese feel between a Western education and a traditional family background.

 

Literature in Chinese

Contact between the Chinese and the Filipinos go back to the Sung and Ming Periods. Books from those periods mention places that would eventually form part of the Philippine archipelago. Traders from southern China exchanged their fabrics, porcelain ware, metal products, and other goods, with local beeswax, mother-of-pearl, bird’s nest, and raw silk, among others things.

To the story of Philippine literature, however, the significant early contribution of the Chinese was printing. The three earliest books in the Philippines were published in Binondo, and two of them were in Chinese: Doctrina Christiana en Letra y Lengua China, Compuesta por los Padres Ministros de los Sangleyes, de la Orden de Sancto Domingo. Con Licencia, por Keng Yong, China, en el Parian de Manila (Christian Doctrine in Chinese Characters and Language, Composed by the Ministerial Fathers of the Chinese, of the Order of Santo Domingo. With License by the Chinese Keng Yong, in the Parian of Manila), ca 1605; and æ–°åˆ»åƒ§å¸«é«˜æ¯�ç¾¨æ’°ç„¡æ¥µå¤©ä¸»æ­£æ•™çœŸå‚³å¯¦éŒ„ (XÄ«nkè SÄ“ngshÄ« GÄ�omÅ­-xiàn Zhuàn Wújí TiÄ�nzhÅ­ Zhèngjiào ZhÄ“nchuán Shílù; A Printed Edition of the Veritable Record of the Authentic Tradition of the True Faith in the Infinite God, by the Religious Master GÄ�omÅ­-xiàn), 1593, or Hsin-k’o Seng shih Kao Mu-hsien Chaun Wu chi T’ien chu Cheng Chiao Chen-ch’uan Shih lu in the Wade-Giles system. The book is also known by its abbreviated title, Shih lu (True Record), and by the Spanish title, Tratado de la Doctrina de la Santa Iglesia y de Ciencias Naturales (Jurilla 2008, 19-22). In addition, the first movable printer in the Philippines was co-founded by a Christianized Chinese, Juan de Vera, who worked with Fr Francisco Blancas de San Jose.

It was toward the end of the 19th century that the conditions for the emergence of a Philippine-Chinese literature were set: the appearance of the first Chinese newspaper and of the first Chinese school in the Philippines. These were precursors of the intellectual movement that produced the first generation of Chinese writers. The Chinese newspapers provided the venue for the writers to contribute their pieces; the Chinese schools trained the students and provided the writers and the readership. This period of enlightenment coincided with the awakening of Philippine nationalism, as a reaction to increased Spanish oppression (Tan 1972).

Edited by æ¥Šç¶­æ´ª (Yáng Wéihóng), it became the avenue for exiled Chinese reformists to criticize the Chinese government’s conservatism (Fang 1988, 33-34). From 1888 to 1919, three other newspapers appeared: ç›Šå�‹æ–°å ± (YìyÅ�u XÄ«n Bào; Useful Friends Daily News), 1899; æ°‘æ„�å ± (Mínyì Bào; Manila Advantage Daily News), 1900; and å…¬é‡Œå ± (GÅ�nglÄ­ Bào; Social Justice Daily News), 1910. The decades after World War II marked the emergence of what can be called the Chinese Filipino literature. Till then, writings by the Chinese in the Philippines had been centered on China. The earliest works described their loneliness in the Philippines, their longing to return to China, and their dreams for China. The Philippines for the Chinese then was a temporary resting place. Being immigrants, most of the early Philippine Chinese wrote about their memories of China and their desire to return to China. They also described Chinese affairs and wrote many critiques of the Chinese government. During the Communist takeover of China, many Philippine Chinese wrote antiviolence literature, like Tragedy of Liberation, 1953, a play by è�’å±± (HuÄ�ng ShÄ�n; pseud. of è”¡ç§€å ±[Cài Xiùbào]), and “The Old Soldiers Go to the Front,” 1954, a poem by å‹µ (Lì; pseud. of æž—å‹µå¿— [LÄ«n Lìzhì]), both published in World News. More China-centered than Philippine-centered, these works are not really Chinese-Filipino literature. They are more the literature of the sojourner (Fang 1988, 144).

Many other writers also focused on the social problems of living in the Philippines. In “The ACR,” 1953, a short story by ä»­é�’ (Rèn QÄ«ng; pseud. of æž—å•Ÿç¥¥ (LÄ«n QÄ­xiáng), the main character loses his life when he goes into his burning house to save his Alien Certificate of Registration or ACR, without which he will be deported to China. Their only relatives are in China, but they cannot return to their country to die there because they cannot afford the funeral expenses. Loneliness partly arises from the inability to assimilate (Fang 1988, 137, 146).

However, the outbreak of the Pacific War and the establishment of the People’s Republic of China under the control of the Chinese Communist Party shattered dreams of ever returning home and gave rise to the first generation of Philippine-born Chinese. The writings of this group and their successors focused on the experiences of the Chinese Filipinos. The chief concerns of their works were identity and assimilation, as well as their war experiences.

Moreover, the Filipinization of the Chinese schools, begun in the 1960s, produced Chinese Filipinos who could not read, speak, and write well in Chinese. Many Filipinos of Chinese descent, raised in the 1970s and 1980s, are no longer so familiar with the customs and traditions of their ancestors as their parents and grandparents were. Because of these factors, contemporary literature by Chinese Filipinos has been written in English or in Filipino, although such a literature has also been produced in Chinese. Immigrant writing and the writing of the Filipinized Chinese would coexist just as the generations of Chinese would and as new waves of immigrants would arrive.

Immigrants from China, Taiwan, and Hong Kong were encouraged to stay in the Philippines for economic reasons. It is these immigrants and Chinese Filipinos who have enough Chinese language education who have become the leaders in contemporary literature in Chinese. An indication that Chinese-Philippine literature has come to be recognized as being part of Philippine literature is the fact that there is a Chinese language category at UMPIL’s Gawad Pambansang Alagad ni Balagtas. The recipients have been Claro Ben Lim, 1991; James T. C. Na, 2008; Bartolome Chua, 2009; Go Bon Juan, 2010; Sze Manchi, 2011; Benito Tan, 2012; and Grace Hsieh-Hsing, 2013. Joaquin Sy received the award for translation in 2007.

However, another tendency may be inferred from the efforts of SCAL, founded by James T. C. Na. It periodically publishes the SCAL Compilation. It has so far issued four numbers, in 2004, 2006, 2008, and 2010. The series of anthologies features works by Chinese Filipinos, and has been distributed and sold to China, Singapore, and Malaysia. Thus, while it makes the literature visible in the Philippines, it is also contributing to the internationalization of Chinese-Philippine literature.

 

Literature in English and Filipino

Chinese-Philippine literature in English is a relatively recent development and seems to be de facto Chinese Filipino in character. The oldest among Chinese-Filipino writers in English were educated in the late 1960s and the 1970s, during which time the Chinese language began to be supplanted as a first language for them by Filipino or English. Constituting an early generation of Chinese-Filipino writers are Benito Lim, Lilia Lopez Chua, Doreen Yu, and Paul Stephen Lim . Their works express the conflict felt by many Chinese Filipinos—that between their Chinese heritage and their Filipino environment. Paul Stephen Lim won a Palanca award for his one-act play Password, 1975, and has broken ground in the United States as well, where he has settled, teaching at the University of Kansas, and continues to write plays. His play Woeman was staged in New York in 1982, and his collection of short stories Some Arrivals, But Mostly Departures was published locally in the same year. Robby Kwan Laurel, Caroline Hau, Felicidad Cua Lim, and Charlson Ong constitute another generation.

 

Charlson Ong has consistently explored the Chinese-Filipino experience in his collections of short stories Men of the East, 1990, which won the National Book Award, The Woman of Am-kaw and Other Stories, 1992, and Conversion and Other Fictions, 1996, and in his novels An Embarrassment of Riches, 2000, a Centennial Literary Prize winner, Banyaga: A Song of War (Alien: A Song of War), 2006, and Blue Angel, White Shadow, 2011, a murder-mystery thriller set in Chinatown.

Because these writers write in English, they find no difficulty in publishing their works in mainstream magazines and journals. Thus, one finds Benito Lim’s “A Bird’s Eye View of Chinatown” in Mithi, 1985, and Anthony Tan ’s poems “Filial Piety” and “Second Elegy for the Chinese Dead” in Jose. An important outlet for Chinese-Philippine literature is Tulay, begun in 1987, a periodical published by Kaisa Para Sa Kaunlaran. It aims to bridge the gap between the Chinese and the Filipinos and between the older immigrant Chinese and the younger, more Filipinized Chinese. It has published literature by Chinese-Filipino writers, whether writing in Chinese, in Filipino, or in English, and translations of Chinese folktales, histories, classic literature, and moral tales.

Among the books by Chinese-Filipino writers in English are The Sultanate: A Novel of a Davao Chinese Seeking His Cultural Identity, 1969, by Jose Anglioto; the poetry collections Descending the Stairs Twice, 1983, by Lilia Lopez Chua, And If I Were This Poem and Other Poems, 1987, and Poems from Two Places, 1995, both by Felicidad Cua Lim aka Bliss Cua Lim, and The Fate of All Progeny, 2008, by Lia Lopez-Chua; Blending Cultures, 1986, a collection of works by the students of Lin Ting Ting, several of which deal with the Filipino-Chinese experience; Discovering New Horizons, 1989, an anthology of fiction, poetry, and essays by such writers as Jane Que Tiu, Maningning Miclat and her father Mario Miclat, Eddie Choa, Andrew Arriola, and Albert C. Lim; and Jaime An Lim’s Hedonicus: Stories / Trios: Poems, 1998. R. Kwan Laurel’s Ongpin Stories, 2007, consists of eight loosely connected stories all set in Chinatown, Ongpin being the street in Manila most intimately associated with the Chinese in the Philippines. The cast of characters include a math wizard who dreams of making it in Hong Kong, a wealthy businessman who is at loggerheads with the parish priest, and the narrator’s father, a hardware store owner struggling to compete with the “white ghosts.” Xin-Mei’s Afraid to Be Chinese, 2006, consists of, according to the author’s prologue, 10 stories “about Chinese women and their secrets.… about women who are caught between the Chinese and Filipino cultures.” The stories in Caroline Hau’s Recuerdos de Patay, 2015, cover a broader spectrum: snapshots of the war are recollected from the point of view of a guerrilla fighter, a member of the Wha Chi, in “The True Story of Ah To”; the kidnapping for ransom of Filipino Chinese looms in the background of stories like “Firetrees and Orange Sundays”; and the cultural differences between the generations inform the conflict in “New Year’s Day.” Susie L. Tan, aka Lin Ting Ting, retells Chinese and Filipino folk stories in the two-volume Tales for Big Children, 1995, which show parallelisms between them.

Studies in Chinese-Philippine literature in Filipino are not numerous, but there are a handful of writers of Chinese-Philippine literature in Filipino. Among them are screenwriter Ricardo Lee , whose “Huwag! Huwag Mong Kukuwentuhan ang Batang si Wei-fung!” (Don’t! Don’t Tell the Child Wei-fung Stories) portrays the divisions within the Chinese community in a fictional town called Egauldad even as its members seek inclusion in a foreign land; and most prolifically, Joaquin Sy, whose stories have appeared in the journal Mithi and whose essays, published in Tulay, have been collected in Tamad Nga Ba si Juan? at Iba Pang Sanaysay at Salin (Is Juan Really Lazy? and Other Essays and Translations), 1991, and Tsapsuy, 1997. Sy’s essays are critical and sometimes satirical takes on such concerns as nationalism in the age of globalization, the propagation of the national language, the problem of crime, and relations between the ethnic Chinese and Filipinos. He writes from the position of the Chinese Filipino, appreciative of his Chinese heritage, committed to Philippine development, and critical of practices inimical to that end.

Kaisa Para Sa Kaunlaran was instrumental in putting Chinese-Filipino writings, whether in English or Chinese, or in Filipino translation, in public circulation and integrating the Chinese Filipino into mainstream Philippine life. Tsinoy, coined by the founders of Kaisa, is a now an accepted term for the present-day Chinese Filipinos who are Tsino (Chinese) and Pinoy (Filipino). Since its founding, Kaisa has published over 50 titles related to Chinese-Filipino life and history aside from 28 volumes of Tulay. These include The Chinese Immigrants, edited by Teresita Ang See and Chinben See; and Tsinoy: The Story of the Chinese in Philippine Life, 2005, edited by Teresita Ang See, Go Bon Juan, Doreen Yu, and Yvonne Chua; and, to date, four volumes of The Chinese in the Philippines: Problems and Perspectives, 1990, 1997, 2007, 2013, all edited by Teresita Ang See, covering various aspects of Chinese-Philippine life. The main purpose is to enhance the understanding of the Tsinoy in Philippine life, to be a bridge of acceptance and tolerance, to give Tsinoy a voice in mainstream society.

 

The literary titles from Kaisa include Tsapsuy: Mga Sanaysay, Tula, Salin, at Iba Pa (Tsapsuy: Essays, Poems, Translations, and Others), 1997, edited by Joaquin Sy. It features writers like Go Bon Juan, Nancy Lao Bi Eng, James T. C. Na, Charlie Go, Isuan Lee, Lu Liong To, Lin Gu Feng, Ong Lian Kiao, Jose Ledesma, Lyonel Ty, Sze Manchi, Ivan Tsang, and Bartolome Chua. The prominent themes that run through the anthology are the feelings of alienation, questions on nationalism, and the need for cooperation among the Chinese and the Filipinos. For example, Eddie Choa’s poem, “Ako’y Banyaga sa Aking Bayan” (I Am a Foreigner in My Own Country), 1993, published in Tulay, expresses the sentiments of someone who feels like an outsider despite his living in the Philippines for many years.

The same sentiments are expressed by the writers included in Voices / Mga Tinig: The Best of Tulay, 1997, edited by Teresita Ang See, Caroline S. Hau , and Joaquin Sy. Writers like R. Kwan Laurel, Jacqueline Co, Anita Lo, Bliss Cua Lim, Krysty Choi, Karen Huang, Harriet Ann Dy, Doreen Yu, Audrey Lim Tan, Augusto Dy, Melchor C. Te, Grace Pe-Bacani, Carmelea Ang See, Ma. Lucila T. Uy, Fannie Tan Koa, Anson Sia Dichaves, Juvy Dy Ong, Joaquin Sy, Go Bon Juan, Eddie Choa, Ramoncito Lim Ching, Ong Lian Kiao, Sze Man Chi, and Ivan Tsang explore questions related to the Chinese-Filipino experience from the point of view of someone who has immersed into the Philippine way of life.

Shaping many Chinese-Filipino writings is the cultural conflict that Chinese Filipinos feel. It arises from their having Chinese roots, on the one hand, and their being raised in the Philippines, on the other. For Chinese Filipinos, the roots are deep in the Philippine soil and the bonds are with the Filipino people, but they are proud to acknowledge their Chinese racial origins. Benito Lim’s stories show the problems that arise out of the split-family system, in which a migrating Chinese leaves his Chinese wife in China and marries a Filipino woman in the Philippines. Doreen Yu focuses on the problems of young Chinese women who have been exposed to ideas of liberation. Their education usually clashes with their family’s Confucian ideals. In her “Anais,” 1976, and “Twentieth-Century Romance,” 1978, the protagonists rebel against traditional Chinese practices like arranged marriages. Benito Lim’s “Fantasy of the Maid,” 1960, dramatizes a gap that is both generational and cultural: a Chinese mother cannot communicate with her adopted son, who prefers to speak with her yaya (governess). In Paul Stephen Lim’s short story in English, “Flight,” 1982, one finds the expression of the problem that have plagued many Chinese Filipinos. The main character Wing says:

I am Chinese, and yet my roots are in the Philippines. So why is it that I have never identified (and continue to feel that I will never be able to identify) completely with the Filipinos? I know only one thing, that every day I feel the alienation growing—what is it the priest says at Mass?—“Through me, with me, in me.”

Charlson Ong’s Banyaga, 2006, presents a panoramic view of Filipino-Chinese relations. Spanning all the major periods in 20th-century Philippine history, the novel follows the lives of a group of Chinese friends who go to Manila: one in search of his father, two orphaned and sold to a candlemaker, another one apprenticing with an uncle, and the last adopted by a Spanish couple. Ong shows the different subject positions that the friends occupy as the narrative progresses—as merchants, guerrillas, traitors, mall tycoons, and indeed, as the title of the novel suggests, aliens. The novel resists stereotyping the Chinese as victims, and in several places, the mutual othering between the Chinese and Filipino characters is overcome by compassion (Gonzalez 2013, 47-49).

By 2000, it seems that Chinese-Philippine literature could speak of a canon. Intsik: An Anthology of Chinese-Filipino Writing, 2000, edited by Caroline Hau, is a step in that direction. Published by Anvil, a major trade publisher, it compiles the previously published works of those who were closely associated with Chinese-Philippine literature—Benito Lim, Paul Stephen Lim, Charlson Ong, Teresita Ang See, Joaquin Sy, Wilson Lee Flores—alongside new works by younger writers, including Shirley Lua, Ronald Baytan, and Gad Lim, that were written especially for the anthology. A Chinese edition of the book was published in 2003.

Chinese-Philippine literature will continue to be produced, whether in Chinese, English, or Filipino, for as long as its writers exist: Chinese immigrants who transition from being overseas Chinese to “locals” and new generations of Filipinos of Chinese descent who reflect on the effects of their ethnic origins. While the readership of the corpus in English or Filipino is secure, its counterpart in Chinese is made accessible by translation. The survival of Chinese-Philippine literature as a separate category of Philippine literature will probably be threatened only when ethnicity ceases to signify in appreciations of Philippine life and identity. Until then, there remain “things Chinese-Philippine” from which writers of Chinese origins or descent in the Philippines can create a literature.  Written by Jonathan Chua, updated by Daisy See, Jeffrey Yap, and Teresita Ang See, with notes from Caroline Hau and Peng Cheng Fang

article.value: Sections

Chinese-Philippine literature may refer to the writings by the Chinese residing in the Philippines; to the works written in Chinese by Chinese Filipinos; or to works written in any language by Chinese Filipinos. More narrowly, however, Chinese-Philippine literature is equated with the writings in Chinese, English, Filipino, and other languages by Filipinos of Chinese descent, which deal with their experiences as Chinese in the Philippines. A distinction may be made between “Philippine Chinese,” referring to immigrants, and “Chinese Filipinos,” referring to those whose identity is primarily Filipino but with Chinese racial origins. Some overlapping or transitioning occurs, however, so that one writer’s oeuvre may contain both works that reflect an immigrant’s sentiments and works that evince a rootedness in Philippine realities.

A third group may be identified, with which, however, this article is not concerned. As Gloria Chiu Yap notes in her study of Chinese-Philippine fiction, there are a handful of writers of Chinese descent whose works feature Chinese characters or Chinese Filipinos but do not explore their experience in the Philippines primarily. Practically all of Clinton Palanca’s stories fall under this category. Conversely, there are stories written by Filipinos whose theme is the Chinese-Philippine experience. These include Dionisio Gabriel’s “China Opera,” 1969, which depicts the subordinate condition of young Chinese women. “Mr. Cheng and the Great Wall of Culture,” 1960, by Tita Lacambra-Ayala explores the conflict young Chinese feel between a Western education and a traditional family background.
Literature in Chinese

Contact between the Chinese and the Filipinos go back to the Sung and Ming Periods. Books from those periods mention places that would eventually form part of the Philippine archipelago. Traders from southern China exchanged their fabrics, porcelain ware, metal products, and other goods, with local beeswax, mother-of-pearl, bird’s nest, and raw silk, among others things.

To the story of Philippine literature, however, the significant early contribution of the Chinese was printing. The three earliest books in the Philippines were published in Binondo, and two of them were in Chinese: Doctrina Christiana en Letra y Lengua China, Compuesta por los Padres Ministros de los Sangleyes, de la Orden de Sancto Domingo. Con Licencia, por Keng Yong, China, en el Parian de Manila (Christian Doctrine in Chinese Characters and Language, Composed by the Ministerial Fathers of the Chinese, of the Order of Santo Domingo. It was toward the end of the 19th century that the conditions for the emergence of a Philippine-Chinese literature were set: the appearance of the first Chinese newspaper and of the first Chinese school in the Philippines. These were precursors of the intellectual movement that produced the first generation of Chinese writers. The Chinese newspapers provided the venue for the writers to contribute their pieces; the Chinese schools trained the students and provided the writers and the readership. This period of enlightenment coincided with the awakening of Philippine nationalism, as a reaction to increased Spanish oppression (Tan 1972).

The decades after World War II marked the emergence of what can be called the Chinese Filipino literature. Till then, writings by the Chinese in the Philippines had been centered on China. The earliest works described their loneliness in the Philippines, their longing to return to China, and their dreams for China. The Philippines for the Chinese then was a temporary resting place. Being immigrants, most of the early Philippine Chinese wrote about their memories of China and their desire to return to China. They also described Chinese affairs and wrote many critiques of the Chinese government. During the Communist takeover of China, many Philippine Chinese wrote antiviolence literature, like Tragedy of Liberation, 1953, a play by è�’å±± (HuÄ�ng ShÄ�n; pseud. of è”¡ç§€å ±[Cài Xiùbào]), and “The Old Soldiers Go to the Front,” 1954, a poem by å‹µ (Lì; pseud. of æž—å‹µå¿— [LÄ«n Lìzhì]), both published in World News. More China-centered than Philippine-centered, these works are not really Chinese-Filipino literature. They are more the literature of the sojourner (Fang 1988, 144).

Many other writers also focused on the social problems of living in the Philippines. In “The ACR,” 1953, a short story by ä»­é�’ (Rèn QÄ«ng; pseud. of æž—å•Ÿç¥¥ (LÄ«n QÄ­xiáng), the main character loses his life when he goes into his burning house to save his Alien Certificate of Registration or ACR, without which he will be deported to China. However, the outbreak of the Pacific War and the establishment of the People’s Republic of China under the control of the Chinese Communist Party shattered dreams of ever returning home and gave rise to the first generation of Philippine-born Chinese. The writings of this group and their successors focused on the experiences of the Chinese Filipinos. The chief concerns of their works were identity and assimilation, as well as their war experiences.

Moreover, the Filipinization of the Chinese schools, begun in the 1960s, produced Chinese Filipinos who could not read, speak, and write well in Chinese. Many Filipinos of Chinese descent, raised in the 1970s and 1980s, are no longer so familiar with the customs and traditions of their ancestors as their parents and grandparents were. Because of these factors, contemporary literature by Chinese Filipinos has been written in English or in Filipino, although such a literature has also been produced in Chinese. Immigrant writing and the writing of the Filipinized Chinese would coexist just as the generations of Chinese would and as new waves of immigrants would arrive.

article.value: More Chinese-language writings appear in book form either with translations into English or Filipino or as translations. Crossroads: Short Essays on the Chinese Filipinos, 1988, edited by Teresita Ang See and Lily Chua, contains selected essays originally written in Chinese, taken from the now-defunct Orient News, and their English translations. The essays in the book touch on such issues as Chinese education in the Philippines and racial identity. The poetry collections of Grace Hsieh Hsing (è¬�é¦¨), èªªçµ¦èŠ±è�½ (ShuÅ� GÄ•i HuÄ� TÄ«ng; To the Flowers), 1990, and æ³¢æ–¯è²“ (BÅ�sÄ« MÄ�o; The Persian Cat), 1990, come with English translations by John Shih (æ–½ç´„ç¿°), who also translated her poems “City Wind,” “La Generala,” and “Maria Clara,” all published in 1990 in Panorama, and “Tandang Sora,” 1991, and “Ongpin Street,” 1994, published in Traveller’s Literary Companion to Southeast Asia, 1995. Her Halo-Halo: Poems of the Philippines, 2015, is a trilingual collection, with translations of her poems into Filipino by Joaquin Sy and into English by Rita Tan. The literary works of James T. C. Na, were translated by John Shih, Joaquin Sy, and Rita Ching Tan. äº”æœˆèŠ±ç¯€ (WÅ­yuè HuÄ�jié; Flowers of May), 2003, by Cua Ching Tam (æŸ¯æ¸…æ·¡) and è§£æ”¾ç«¥å¹´ (JiÄ•fàng Tóngnián; Liberated Innocence), 2010, by Sze Manchi (æ–½æ–‡å¿—) and were translated by Joaquin Sy as Flores de Mayo: Tatlong Piling Kwento and Pinalayang Kamusmusan, respectively.

It follows the travails of A Song, a boy from Fujian Province, who comes to the Philippines to find work—as storekeeper and newspaper boy—on the eve of the Sino-Japanese war. He is unsuccessful in love, as the family and friends of his girlfriend A Hong consider him beneath her and another girl, Niuniu, who is in love with him although she is already married, does not share his commitment to the anti-Japanese cause. When the war between China and Japan erupts, A Song returns to China to join the resistance movement.
James T. C. Na’s poem ã€Šé‡Žç”Ÿæ¤�ç‰©ã€‹ (The Wild Plant), 1986, here translated by John Sy, expresses the same conflict:

It has leaves

but not the stem

It has stem

but not the root

It has root

but not the soil

 

It is a kind of wild plant

by the name of

oversea Chinese

Not all see the situation as a problem. Using the popular Filipino dessert of crushed ice, milk, gelatin, grains, purple yam, and ice cream, as a central image, Grace Hsieh-Hsing celebrates the “hyphenated” condition of the Chinese Filipino in her poem “Halo Halo” (1990, 20-21, translated by John Shih):

In reality, this is a carnival

celebrating abundant harvest!

…

Look! There are so many

so many magnificent colors—red, orange, yellow, green

grey, blue, purple … all contained in my cup

glistening

An indication that Chinese-Philippine literature has come to be recognized as being part of Philippine literature is the fact that there is a Chinese language category at UMPIL’s Gawad Pambansang Alagad ni Balagtas. The recipients have been Claro Ben Lim, 1991; James T. C. Na, 2008; Bartolome Chua, 2009; Go Bon Juan, 2010; Sze Manchi, 2011; Benito Tan, 2012; and Grace Hsieh-Hsing, 2013. Joaquin Sy received the award for translation in 2007.

However, another tendency may be inferred from the efforts of SCAL, founded by James T. C. Na. It periodically publishes the SCAL Compilation. It has so far issued four numbers, in 2004, 2006, 2008, and 2010. The series of anthologies features works by Chinese Filipinos, and has been distributed and sold to China, Singapore, and Malaysia. Thus, while it makes the literature visible in the Philippines, it is also contributing to the internationalization of Chinese-Philippine literature.
Literature in English and Filipino

Chinese-Philippine literature in English is a relatively recent development and seems to be de facto Chinese Filipino in character. The oldest among Chinese-Filipino writers in English were educated in the late 1960s and the 1970s, during which time the Chinese language began to be supplanted as a first language for them by Filipino or English. Constituting an early generation of Chinese-Filipino writers are Benito Lim, Lilia Lopez Chua, Doreen Yu, and Paul Stephen Lim . Their works express the conflict felt by many Chinese Filipinos—that between their Chinese heritage and their Filipino environment. Paul Stephen Lim won a Palanca award for his one-act play Password, 1975, and has broken ground in the United States as well, where he has settled, teaching at the University of Kansas, and continues to write plays. His play Woeman was staged in New York in 1982, and his collection of short stories Some Arrivals, But Mostly Departures was published locally in the same year. Robby Kwan Laurel, Caroline Hau, Felicidad Cua Lim, and Charlson Ong constitute another generation.
