article.value: Charlson Ong has consistently explored the Chinese-Filipino experience in his collections of short stories Men of the East, 1990, which won the National Book Award, The Woman of Am-kaw and Other Stories, 1992, and Conversion and Other Fictions, 1996, and in his novels An Embarrassment of Riches, 2000, a Centennial Literary Prize winner, Banyaga: A Song of War (Alien: A Song of War), 2006, and Blue Angel, White Shadow, 2011, a murder-mystery thriller set in Chinatown.

Because these writers write in English, they find no difficulty in publishing their works in mainstream magazines and journals. Thus, one finds Benito Lim’s “A Bird’s Eye View of Chinatown” in Mithi, 1985, and Anthony Tan ’s poems “Filial Piety” and “Second Elegy for the Chinese Dead” in Jose. An important outlet for Chinese-Philippine literature is Tulay, begun in 1987, a periodical published by Kaisa Para Sa Kaunlaran. It aims to bridge the gap between the Chinese and the Filipinos and between the older immigrant Chinese and the younger, more Filipinized Chinese. It has published literature by Chinese-Filipino writers, whether writing in Chinese, in Filipino, or in English, and translations of Chinese folktales, histories, classic literature, and moral tales.

Among the books by Chinese-Filipino writers in English are The Sultanate: A Novel of a Davao Chinese Seeking His Cultural Identity, 1969, by Jose Anglioto; the poetry collections Descending the Stairs Twice, 1983, by Lilia Lopez Chua, And If I Were This Poem and Other Poems, 1987, and Poems from Two Places, 1995, both by Felicidad Cua Lim aka Bliss Cua Lim, and The Fate of All Progeny, 2008, by Lia Lopez-Chua; Blending Cultures, 1986, a collection of works by the students of Lin Ting Ting, several of which deal with the Filipino-Chinese experience; Discovering New Horizons, 1989, an anthology of fiction, poetry, and essays by such writers as Jane Que Tiu, Maningning Miclat and her father Mario Miclat, Eddie Choa, Andrew Arriola, and Albert C. Lim; and Jaime An Lim’s Hedonicus: Stories / Trios: Poems, 1998. R. Kwan Laurel’s Ongpin Stories, 2007, consists of eight loosely connected stories all set in Chinatown, Ongpin being the street in Manila most intimately associated with the Chinese in the Philippines. The cast of characters include a math wizard who dreams of making it in Hong Kong, a wealthy businessman who is at loggerheads with the parish priest, and the narrator’s father, a hardware store owner struggling to compete with the “white ghosts.” Xin-Mei’s Afraid to Be Chinese, 2006, consists of, according to the author’s prologue, 10 stories “about Chinese women and their secrets.… about women who are caught between the Chinese and Filipino cultures.” The stories in Caroline Hau’s Recuerdos de Patay, 2015, cover a broader spectrum: snapshots of the war are recollected from the point of view of a guerrilla fighter, a member of the Wha Chi, in “The True Story of Ah To”; the kidnapping for ransom of Filipino Chinese looms in the background of stories like “Firetrees and Orange Sundays”; and the cultural differences between the generations inform the conflict in “New Year’s Day.” Susie L. Tan, aka Lin Ting Ting, retells Chinese and Filipino folk stories in the two-volume Tales for Big Children, 1995, which show parallelisms between them.

Studies in Chinese-Philippine literature in Filipino are not numerous, but there are a handful of writers of Chinese-Philippine literature in Filipino. Among them are screenwriter Ricardo Lee , whose “Huwag! Huwag Mong Kukuwentuhan ang Batang si Wei-fung!” (Don’t! Don’t Tell the Child Wei-fung Stories) portrays the divisions within the Chinese community in a fictional town called Egauldad even as its members seek inclusion in a foreign land; and most prolifically, Joaquin Sy, whose stories have appeared in the journal Mithi and whose essays, published in Tulay, have been collected in Tamad Nga Ba si Juan? at Iba Pang Sanaysay at Salin (Is Juan Really Lazy? and Other Essays and Translations), 1991, and Tsapsuy, 1997. Sy’s essays are critical and sometimes satirical takes on such concerns as nationalism in the age of globalization, the propagation of the national language, the problem of crime, and relations between the ethnic Chinese and Filipinos. He writes from the position of the Chinese Filipino, appreciative of his Chinese heritage, committed to Philippine development, and critical of practices inimical to that end.

Kaisa Para Sa Kaunlaran was instrumental in putting Chinese-Filipino writings, whether in English or Chinese, or in Filipino translation, in public circulation and integrating the Chinese Filipino into mainstream Philippine life. Tsinoy, coined by the founders of Kaisa, is a now an accepted term for the present-day Chinese Filipinos who are Tsino (Chinese) and Pinoy (Filipino). Since its founding, Kaisa has published over 50 titles related to Chinese-Filipino life and history aside from 28 volumes of Tulay. These include The Chinese Immigrants, edited by Teresita Ang See and Chinben See; and Tsinoy: The Story of the Chinese in Philippine Life, 2005, edited by Teresita Ang See, Go Bon Juan, Doreen Yu, and Yvonne Chua; and, to date, four volumes of The Chinese in the Philippines: Problems and Perspectives, 1990, 1997, 2007, 2013, all edited by Teresita Ang See, covering various aspects of Chinese-Philippine life. The main purpose is to enhance the understanding of the Tsinoy in Philippine life, to be a bridge of acceptance and tolerance, to give Tsinoy a voice in mainstream society.

The literary titles from Kaisa include Tsapsuy: Mga Sanaysay, Tula, Salin, at Iba Pa (Tsapsuy: Essays, Poems, Translations, and Others), 1997, edited by Joaquin Sy. It features writers like Go Bon Juan, Nancy Lao Bi Eng, James T. C. Na, Charlie Go, Isuan Lee, Lu Liong To, Lin Gu Feng, Ong Lian Kiao, Jose Ledesma, Lyonel Ty, Sze Manchi, Ivan Tsang, and Bartolome Chua. The prominent themes that run through the anthology are the feelings of alienation, questions on nationalism, and the need for cooperation among the Chinese and the Filipinos. For example, Eddie Choa’s poem, “Ako’y Banyaga sa Aking Bayan” (I Am a Foreigner in My Own Country), 1993, published in Tulay, expresses the sentiments of someone who feels like an outsider despite his living in the Philippines for many years.

The same sentiments are expressed by the writers included in Voices / Mga Tinig: The Best of Tulay, 1997, edited by Teresita Ang See, Caroline S. Hau , and Joaquin Sy. Writers like R. Kwan Laurel, Jacqueline Co, Anita Lo, Bliss Cua Lim, Krysty Choi, Karen Huang, Harriet Ann Dy, Doreen Yu, Audrey Lim Tan, Augusto Dy, Melchor C. Te, Grace Pe-Bacani, Carmelea Ang See, Ma. Lucila T. Uy, Fannie Tan Koa, Anson Sia Dichaves, Juvy Dy Ong, Joaquin Sy, Go Bon Juan, Eddie Choa, Ramoncito Lim Ching, Ong Lian Kiao, Sze Man Chi, and Ivan Tsang explore questions related to the Chinese-Filipino experience from the point of view of someone who has immersed into the Philippine way of life.

Shaping many Chinese-Filipino writings is the cultural conflict that Chinese Filipinos feel. It arises from their having Chinese roots, on the one hand, and their being raised in the Philippines, on the other. For Chinese Filipinos, the roots are deep in the Philippine soil and the bonds are with the Filipino people, but they are proud to acknowledge their Chinese racial origins. Benito Lim’s stories show the problems that arise out of the split-family system, in which a migrating Chinese leaves his Chinese wife in China and marries a Filipino woman in the Philippines. Doreen Yu focuses on the problems of young Chinese women who have been exposed to ideas of liberation. Their education usually clashes with their family’s Confucian ideals. In her “Anais,” 1976, and “Twentieth-Century Romance,” 1978, the protagonists rebel against traditional Chinese practices like arranged marriages. Benito Lim’s “Fantasy of the Maid,” 1960, dramatizes a gap that is both generational and cultural: a Chinese mother cannot communicate with her adopted son, who prefers to speak with her yaya (governess). In Paul Stephen Lim’s short story in English, “Flight,” 1982, one finds the expression of the problem that have plagued many Chinese Filipinos. The main character Wing says:

I am Chinese, and yet my roots are in the Philippines. So why is it that I have never identified (and continue to feel that I will never be able to identify) completely with the Filipinos? I know only one thing, that every day I feel the alienation growing—what is it the priest says at Mass?—“Through me, with me, in me.”

Charlson Ong’s Banyaga, 2006, presents a panoramic view of Filipino-Chinese relations. Spanning all the major periods in 20th-century Philippine history, the novel follows the lives of a group of Chinese friends who go to Manila: one in search of his father, two orphaned and sold to a candlemaker, another one apprenticing with an uncle, and the last adopted by a Spanish couple. Ong shows the different subject positions that the friends occupy as the narrative progresses—as merchants, guerrillas, traitors, mall tycoons, and indeed, as the title of the novel suggests, aliens. The novel resists stereotyping the Chinese as victims, and in several places, the mutual othering between the Chinese and Filipino characters is overcome by compassion (Gonzalez 2013, 47-49).

By 2000, it seems that Chinese-Philippine literature could speak of a canon. Intsik: An Anthology of Chinese-Filipino Writing, 2000, edited by Caroline Hau, is a step in that direction. Published by Anvil, a major trade publisher, it compiles the previously published works of those who were closely associated with Chinese-Philippine literature—Benito Lim, Paul Stephen Lim, Charlson Ong, Teresita Ang See, Joaquin Sy, Wilson Lee Flores—alongside new works by younger writers, including Shirley Lua, Ronald Baytan, and Gad Lim, that were written especially for the anthology. A Chinese edition of the book was published in 2003.

Chinese-Philippine literature will continue to be produced, whether in Chinese, English, or Filipino, for as long as its writers exist: Chinese immigrants who transition from being overseas Chinese to “locals” and new generations of Filipinos of Chinese descent who reflect on the effects of their ethnic origins. While the readership of the corpus in English or Filipino is secure, its counterpart in Chinese is made accessible by translation. The survival of Chinese-Philippine literature as a separate category of Philippine literature will probably be threatened only when ethnicity ceases to signify in appreciations of Philippine life and identity. Until then, there remain “things Chinese-Philippine” from which writers of Chinese origins or descent in the Philippines can create a literature.  Written by Jonathan Chua, updated by Daisy See, Jeffrey Yap, and Teresita Ang See, with notes from Caroline Hau and Peng Cheng Fang

text:
The term “diaspora”—from the Greek word for “scattering” or “dispersion”—has historically been used to refer to the involuntary displacement of large segments of an ethnic or national population from its territory (Liddell, Scott, and Jones 1940). In the Philippine context, diaspora is synonymous with the export of labor that dates back to the early 20th century, when some 120,000 Filipino peasant laborers were transported to Hawaii and, later, the West Coast of the United States, to work as itinerant farmhands and cannery workers. The phenomenon assumed its contemporary guise in the 1970s when then-president Ferdinand Marcos instituted a labor export policy as a short-term solution to uneven labor opportunities in the country, while taking advantage of global market demands, particularly in the oil fields and burgeoning cities of the Middle East. By 2012, up to 10.5 million Filipinos—about a tenth of the population—were working in nearly 200 countries, sending back to their families billions of dollars in remittances that fuel a significant aspect of the domestic economy (CFO 2013). Scholars identify this reality as one of the most definitive national experiences of the nation today.

The bulk of what is widely considered as the country’s tradition of diasporic writing—sometimes lumped together with “exilic” or “expatriate” writing—is more intertwined with the intellectual, rather than labor, character of the Filipino diaspora. With the exception of a few cases, the literature of the diaspora is written by Filipinos who voluntarily spent time or completely settled overseas, mostly for careers in academia, not for the sheer economic necessity that had historically compelled Filipinos to leave the country. At the outset, diasporic writing, which owes a debt to its practitioners’ ties with universities and other cultural institutions, is already divorced from the phenomenon that it generally connotes.

There is also a colonialist dynamic behind the phenomenon; a great concentration of the works tends to emanate from an important center of the colonial or neocolonial power—that is, Madrid during the Spanish period (1521-1898) and California and New York in the United States afterward (1898-present).

The origins of diasporic writing can be traced back to the reform movement in Spain in the 1880s and 1890s, with Filipinos writing and publishing essays and polemics that criticize Spanish colonial rule in the Philippines. Among them was Pedro Paterno, who studied at the University of Salamanca and earned a law degree from the University of Madrid. His Spanish poetry collection Sampaguitas y Otras Poesias Varias (Jasmine and Other Poems) came out in Madrid in 1880, and Ninay, the first known Filipino novel in Spanish, was published five years later. Despite its alleged superficiality and self-exoticism, Ninay is credited for being a foundational work on an emergent national culture (Matibag 2010, 35). It exalts Filipino tradition and thus rebukes the civilizing logic of European colonization. The narrative, which chronicles two love triangles, uses the devices of costumbrismo, with plot secondary to ethnographic descriptions of local middle-class customs, all in an attempt to introduce to Spain its far-flung colony. The portrayal of Philippine culture in Ninay is as a hybrid of Malay, aboriginal, Chinese, Spanish, and Indian elements (40). It also highlights the antiquity of this culture and the productivity of the colony and its people, “in service of a changing concept of ‘Filipino’” (Lumbera quoted in Matibag 2010, 38).

 

This “representative” or “performative” ethos—that the works were written to “perform” the Philippines largely for the benefit of a foreign audience—would become a mark of diasporic writing. Ninay, which was in a language that fewer than 10 percent of the indios (Christianized native) at that time understood, was said to be a response to Jose Rizal’s exhortation to his fellow expatriates to produce “a collection that would represent the Philippines to a wider world.”

After Ninay, the next two novels that were published in Europe were Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1887, and El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1891. Both a political and an artistic achievement, the novels are recognized not only for catalyzing the 1896 Philippine Revolution but also for being the “earliest artistic expressions of the Asian colonial experience from the point of view of the oppressed” (Augenbraum 2006, xxiii). In both books, Philippine society is portrayed as a hapless victim of an abusive and extremely powerful Spanish clergy, a ruthless “friarocracy” in coalition with the local Filipino elite.

American colonial rule marks a critical turn in the history of Philippine diasporic writing, as the colonial regime declared English as the primary medium of instruction in the newly established public education system. At about the same time, the first contingent of Filipino peasant laborers were shipped by the Hawaiian Sugar Planter’s Association to Hawaii, paving the way for the eventual spilling over of Filipinos into continental United States. These two factors—the mandatory learning of the colonial tongue and the physical act of migration, in addition to the myriad cultural, moral, and existential crises they would birth—would form the basis of a long tradition of Philippine diasporic writing in America.

As early as the first decade of the 20th century, there were already attempts by Filipino migrants in the United States to use the new language to articulate their experiences. The first issue of the short-lived quarterly The Filipino Students’ Magazine came out in 1905 in Berkeley, California. It contained the earliest examples of English poetry by Filipinos, written by pensionados, or scholars of the American colonial government. Among them was “The Flood” by Ponciano Reyes, the first known Filipino poem in English (Abad 2008, 50). The narrative poem of 40 verses celebrates the “quiet dignity” of labor—fishermen, farmers, and traders—as they toil on the Pasig River as a storm looms (51). Its homage to the working class is reminiscent of how Ninay attempts to show the productivity and resilience of Filipinos.

The first book of poetry by a Filipino that was published in the United States is Marcelo de Gracia Concepcion’s Azucena, 1925. American readers noted the author’s “distinct sensibility and unusual ways of using English” even while the words are clearly “those of a Western hand” (Carbo 1995, xv).

This precarious status between being assimilated in and “other-ed” by the American literary establishment would be highlighted in the case of Jose Garcia Villa, the first major figure in the literature of the diaspora. His stories appeared in American periodicals and were included in the 1932 and 1933 editions of the annual Best American Short Stories series, edited by the critic Edward O’Brien, Villa’s most prodigious advocate. In 1933, his stories were gathered in Footnote to Youth: Tales of the Philippines and Others, published by Charles Scribner’s Sons with funding from Villa. O’Brien’s introduction underscored Villa’s foreignness, that he had come from “a totally unrelated civilization,” sidestepping the three decades that the Philippines had been an American colony (Chua 2013-14, 21). American reviews described some of the stories in Footnote as “experimental” and “unusual” but undermined their formal merits and instead focused on their “magic,” a “strange quality … that must come from the Philippines.” Already, Villa’s ethnicity was impinging at his attempt at a universalist poetics.

Some scholars have put forth this “nativist anxiety” to explain Villa’s shift to poetry, announced in the publication of Have Come, Am Here, 1942. The poetry collection earned for Villa comparisons to Wallace Stevens, Emily Dickinson, e. e. cummings, the metaphysical poets, and even Dante. Critics thus placed him squarely in the Anglo-American poetic tradition, often without the exoticized assessments lavished on Footnote. However, the unwanted specter of his ethnicity eventually returned to haunt him; some reviews explained the peculiarities of his poetry as a function of his ethnicity and, therefore, his position as outsider to the language and Western literary tradition.

The publication of Villa’s Volume Two, 1949, was met with less critical acclaim. Negative reviews picked on his ethnicity. His “cavalier” use of English, praised in Have Come, Am Here, is dismissed as “an insensitivity to the conventional meanings and uses of words” (Yu 2004, 359). This critical trajectory continued with Selected Poems and New, 1958. By this time, his foreignness was being cited to account for his “self-indulgent” poetic mannerisms and ultimately led to Villa’s erosion from the American modernist canon, a turn abetted by the concurrent rise of the confessional mode.

Villa’s self-fashioning as an apolitical aesthete is unique in the larger purview of Philippine diasporic writing, which is otherwise characterized by attempts at establishing Filipino-ness. The tradition is replete with “motifs of departure, nostalgia, incompletion, rootlessness, leave taking, and dispossession … with the Philippine as either the original or terminal reference point” (Campomanes 1992, 49). Specifically, the works of the first Filipino immigrants in America revolved around two central themes: their process of adaptation to the new country and Philippine history and politics.

Both are present in the works of Carlos Bulosan. Like Villa but for a different reason, Bulosan stands as an anomaly in the larger fabric of Filipino diasporic writing. Unlike his mostly educated and middle-class counterparts, Bulosan was a high school dropout who was largely self-taught. He regarded the pensionados with “suspicion and contempt” and highlighted his shared peasant origins with the “faceless, nameless manongs” (57). His poetry and fiction foreground the collective experiences of oppression suffered by Filipinos, whether it is feudal inequity in the Philippines or racial ostracism in Depression era America. Like Rizal’s novels, his first collection of stories, The Laughter of My Father, 1944, depicts Philippine society as grossly unequal. This time, however, it is a morally bankrupt local elite and newly arrived “American capitalists” who hold power in the markedly feudal society. As the stories unfold, however, the poor eventually get their due, usually through their own clever devising—Bulosan’s own contribution to the trickster trope. These satiric attacks on an unequal society were largely misunderstood during his time; that The Laughter of My Father is seen as a purely humorous collection is a fact that Bulosan lamented (Tolentino 1986, 452-53).

Bulosan’s best-known work is his “personal history,” America Is in the Heart, 1946. The fictionalized autobiography has been called a “social classic,” chronicling his poor childhood in rural Pangasinan, his journey to America, and his years as an itinerant farmer in California and later involvement in the foundation of early labor unions (McWilliams 1973, xvi). Violent scenes of poverty, racism, and trauma pepper the narrative. America in the novel is an inhospitable land, as the arrival of the first Filipinos in the United States coincided with the Great Depression and with it a racist backlash against immigrants for crowding the already saturated job market. While the book ends with an affirmation of America, or at least the ideals of liberal democracy that it supposedly symbolized, it has been argued that “the totality of the book’s contents”—in addition to the spirit of his other works—“contradicts the protagonist’s affirmation of America in the conclusion” (Alquizola quoted in San Juan 1993, 153).

Bulosan also published two poetry books: Letter from America, 1942, and The Voice of Bataan, 1943, a slim volume of wartime monologues featuring the voices of a cast of soldiers.

 

The post-World War II novels and short stories of Bienvenido Santos, a pensionado, are populated by lonely and alienated Filipino expatriates. Poignant and expertly crafted, his works are sometimes criticized for their “defeatist” and “reconciliatory” tendencies, exemplified by the docile characters in his best-known stories, “Scent of Apples,” 1955, and “The Day the Dancers Came,” 1967 (San Juan 1993, 153). Properly contextualized, however, this spirit is rooted in a “distinctive historical epoch of Filipino dispossession,” particularly the post-World War II period, when the Philippines’ status as a neocolony was being cemented (154). Santos’s later works offered a more directed treatment of the neocolonial condition. Solomon King, the protagonist in his novel The Man Who (Thought He) Looked Like Robert Taylor, 1983, feels a strong, imaginary connection to the eponymous Hollywood icon, seen as a metaphor for the Filipino’s unrequited affinity with the United States and American culture. He can recite American poetry from memory, a skill that he takes pride in but that nobody else in America seems to care about. In What the Hell for You Left Your Heart in San Francisco, 1987, Santos offers a cross-section of a Filipino immigrant community in San Francisco, a cast that includes old-timers, professionals, and second-generation Filipinos. America in Santos’s works is an ambivalent site—a place of “greener pastures” but also of estrangement and loneliness, as the ties that the old-timers have with the Philippines become severed.

Another pensionado was N. V. M. Gonzalez, who was already an established name in the Philippines when he went to the United States on a Rockefeller grant in the late 1940s. In 1947, his collection Seven Hills Away was published in America. Mostly set in his native Mindoro, his stories are noted for their restraint and clarity, painting a bucolic picture of life in rural Philippines. Of all diasporic writers, Gonzalez is perhaps the most “nativist”—in the United States, he was influenced by a number of “Southern Agrarians,” academic New Critics who espoused a militant regionalism that he thought matched his “provincial” background. In The Bamboo Dancers, 1957, America is more sinister than in the works of Santos. It is a place of “alienation, ghostliness, and disembodied existence” (Espiritu quoted in Burns 2008, 51). The estrangement felt by the protagonist Ernie Rama is due to the disconnection between his Western education and the realities of Philippine life. He can only achieve moral and cultural regeneration by returning to his native land and reintegrating with its rituals and myths.

It was the revolutionary timbre of Bulosan’s works, not the lonely voices of Santos or Gonzalez, that came to influence a new generation of Filipino-American writers in the 1970s, notwithstanding they were close in class and social stature to Santos and Gonzalez. Concentrated in the San Francisco area, the so-called Flip generation forms a distinct stream in diasporic writing. They sought to stress their identities as Filipino-Americans—or those born in the United States—as distinct from the Filipino immigrants’. They felt a disconnection from the exilic literature of Santos and Gonzalez. Instead, Oscar Peñaranda, Serafin Syquia, and Sam Tagatac built on Bulosan’s critiques and offered their own accounts of racism in the increasingly hostile American society in the anthologies Flips, 1971, and Liwanag (Light), 1975. But whereas Bulosan’s works were written from an outsider’s point of view, the Flips assert that they are not “exiled guests” in America but are “hosts” (Peñaranda 2004, 235).

The group also attempted to establish a genealogical link with old-timers and their social history as a source of further empowerment. The persona in Virginia Cerenio’s “You Lovely People,” 1983, addresses an unnamed manong. The body as a locus of history is also used in some poems in Jeff Tagami’s October Light, 1987. The persona in Peñaranda’s “Mano Po, Lakai” (Your Blessing, Lakai), 1996, also pays homage to the hardships of the first immigrants.

The anthology Returning a Borrowed Tongue, 1995, continues the Flips’ critique of colonialism, with poems plumbing the psychological effects of Spanish and American influence. Examples include Nick Carbo’s “Little Brown Brother,” Eugene Gloria’s “Assimilation,” Jaime Jacinto’s “Tongue Tied,” and Michael Melo’s “Unlearning English.” Both Al Robles’s Rappin with Ten Thousand Carabaos in the Dark, 1996, and Eugene Gloria’s Drivers at the Short-Time Motel, 2000, return to the lyrical mode to comment on social issues. Included in Carbo’s El Grupo McDonald’s, 1995, is the poem “Running Amok,” which traces the trope of the crazed Filipino “savage.”

Similarly, Catalina Cariaga critiques colonialism in her poetry collection Cultural Evidence, 1999. While rooted in Filipino history and Filipino-American experiences, her poems straddle multiple traditions and experiments with form. Her use of collage, intertextual dialogues, and other experiments influenced Barbara Jane Reyes’s “Anthropologic,” 2003, which plays on the colonialist nuance inherent in the practice of anthropology. The seven-page poem is a mishmash of scientific reports, untranslated Filipino words, excerpts from critical works on Orientalism, erasures, and “white spaces.” It also claims solidarity with other victims of American effacement with a reference to Native American leader Geronimo and the 1904 Saint Louis World’s Fair. The abstract poetry of Eileen Tabios in Beyond Life Sentences, 2003, which uses surrealism and “found words” from other texts, intends to subvert the English narrative, which she says has historically been used by the American regime as a colonizing tool.

Other poets engage Filipino-American history through more conventional form. The poems in Vince Gotera’s Ghost Wars, 2003, recreate the experience of war, both the pain and the pleasure, for veterans and their families. Patrick Rosal takes on a range of voices and personas in My American Kundiman, 2006, in which he professes his conflicted feelings for America using the kundiman, an indigenous Filipino song of unrequited love. Other figures in this stream include Cyn Zarco, Shirley Ancheta, Peter Bacho, Dawn Mabalon, Jon Pineda, Oliver de la Paz, Jean Vengua, Aimee Nezhukumatathil, and Michelle Bautista.

Interestingly, “homegrown” poets, who were born and raised in the Philippines before they moved to the United States, were decidedly less adamant about asserting their ethnicity although this element remains present in their poems. Eric Gamalinda’s Zero Gravity, 1999, ruminates on the idea of memory as a key to rootedness but ultimately disavows it. In “Enough,” the persona distances himself from his homesick friends and admits to enjoying his activities in his adopted country. Amigo Warfare, 2007, follows this path. Named after the guerrilla tactic used by Filipino revolutionaries against American occupation forces, the collection paints a world rendered apocalyptic after the 9/11 attacks, but it ignores America’s imperial ambitions, veering off instead to the realm of metaphysics.

One section of Luis Francia’s Museum of Absences, 2003, also examines post-Sep 11 Manhattan. “New York Mythologies” is dedicated to the “undocumented victims” of the tragedy. The lyricism and tenderness of Luisa Igloria reverberate as she examines themes like the link between colonialism and the diaspora. In Juan Luna’s Revolver, 2009, she traces the roots of the persona’s displacement to the decisive encounters between Filipinos and colonial powers. There are allusions to figures like Rizal, Luna, and the Filipino “tribes” exhibited at the World’s Fair, lending the collection unmistakable historical gravitas without sacrificing poignancy.

 

Other “homegrown” poets who have settled in the United States and continue to write include Luis Cabalquinto, Fatima Lim-Wilson, Felix Fojas, Fidelito Cortes, and Rowena Tiempo-Torrevillas, who also writes essays.

In fiction, globally recognizable events in Philippine history and politics are fertile ground for material. In most cases, the works are imbued with allegorical weight and private lives are tasked to encompass Philippine history and society. The preponderance of this mode in diasporic writing, even as it also occurs in fiction published in the Philippines, further attests to the “performative” aspect of the tradition.

Stevan Javellana’s World War II novel Without Seeing the Dawn, 1947, became a “modest best seller” when it was published in New York. An imaginative retelling of the Philippines’ long history of invasions by a series of colonial powers, the work uses the story of a farmer-turned-soldier to depict the devastation that war brings to a small town. Wilfrido Nolledo’s novel But for the Lovers, 1970, is set in Japanese-occupied Philippines, written in a vigorous, prolix prose that is described as “recognizably English” but heavily interspersed with Tagalog and Spanish epithets, puns, and nuances. This language, in addition to the novel’s complex and highly experimental narrative technique, is blamed for the novel’s limited audience in the Philippines. Linda Ty-Casper’s Three-Cornered Sun, 1979, returns to the Philippine Revolution of 1896 with a family whose members are each endowed with allegorical value, some more than others. Awaiting Trespass, 1985, also attempts at allegory, this time of the Marcos dictatorship. Ninotchka Rosca’s State of War, 1988, offers a vision of the country’s colonial history in the context of martial law, using carnivalesque elements amid a backdrop of political conspiracy and romance. The historical ramifications of the Filipino-American War reverberate in Cecilia Manguerra-Brainard’s story “The Black Man in the Forest,” 1986. Her novel When the Rainbow Goddess Wept, 1994, follows a young girl’s archetypal journey from innocence to its shattering against the backdrop of the Japanese occupation.

The Filipino-Americans’ share in this tradition includes Michelle Skinner’s collection of short stories Balikbayan: A Filipino Homecoming, 1988, which is replete with powerful allusions to life under martial law and emphasizes the American support of Marcos. The elite’s decadent lifestyle during the dictatorship is the subject of Sabina Murray’s Slow Burn, 1990, there seen through the life of teenager Isobel della Fortuna. Murray’s short story collection The Caprices, 2002, is about the brutality of the Pacific Campaign during World War II.

Jessica Hagedorn’s Dogeaters, 1990, started an “unprecedented” outpouring of Filipino works in the United States after a “sparse” output up to the 1970s, a “cultural explosion” abetted by the commemorations of the Philippine independence centenary in 1998. The “relentless thematic diversity”—from migration to generational conflict and continuity and historical reconstructions of key events in Philippine history—was matched by the broad array of forms: novels, short story collections, autobiographies, personal essays, poems, and plays (Ponce 2012, 1). Dogeaters also ushered in an era of formal experimentation in Filipino novels in the United States that typifies a new, sophisticated articulation of resistance to American hegemony that subsequent notable novels would display.

Using pastiche and other elements of Western high postmodernism, Hagedorn tells the story of the waning years of the Marcos dictatorship, seen through a diversity of characters, including a schoolgirl, a Fil-Am DJ and male prostitute, a business tycoon, a beauty queen, a general, a German director, and New People’s Army cadres. Philippine society in Dogeaters is grossly unequal, by turns overly religious and seedy, obsessed with celebrity, social mobility, and anything American. It is prey to relentless and entrenched corruption, and populated by druggies, thugs, whores, and other depraved characters. Real-life events and figures, like the assassination of Marcos critic Benigno Aquino, the Imelda-led construction of a film center, and Marcos and Imelda themselves are represented in the novel. Some critics say that its very structure—the narrative interspersed with fictitious newspaper clippings, radio transcripts, scripts, gossip, and letters, among other texts—blunts its satiric potential and transforms its radical content to mere exoticized spectacle.

A clear successor to Dogeaters’ formal acrobatics is Miguel Syjuco’s Ilustrado (Educated Native), 2010. Published to even bigger acclaim, Ilustrado was hailed as an inventive, stylistic achievement from the Canadian resident. The unpublished manuscript of the novel won the Palanca grand prize and the Man Asian Literary Prize in 2008. The novel opens with the dead body of a Filipino writer in the United States, whose life is pieced together by his protégé, named Miguel Syjuco, through the former’s body of work, which includes poems, novels, polemics, and memoirs. In the process, the novel traces 150 years of Philippine history and includes a meta-commentary on the contemporary literary scene. Like its portrayal in Dogeaters, Philippine society in Ilustrado is dark, brutal, and ceaselessly corrupt, if occasionally funny and absurd. It is a victim of the whims of history and the ruling classes, on whom the novel lays the most blame. Ilustrado is written to address a foreign audience, taking pains to explain all manner of Filipino phenomena. This outward-looking attitude is usually explained by the commercial demands of international publishing.

Another diasporic author who plays wildly with form is Gina Apostol. Her American debut, the martial law novel Gun Dealer’s Daughter, 2012, is an “amnesiac thriller” that probes the dual idea of memory, in the private sense and as a collective national experience, through circuitous prose and the meandering consciousness of its eponymous protagonist, Soledad Soliman. Like the protagonist of Syjuco’s novel, Sol pieces together her personal history and, in so doing, her country’s during martial law. It gains allegorical weight by intertwining Sol’s bildungsroman with the political consciousness of martial law–era Philippines. The lavish and cosmopolitan lifestyle of the country’s elite is described at length, later linked to the unscrupulous arms business that provided muscle to the Marcos regime. Like Ilustrado, the novel attempts to stress the elite’s complicity in the pervasive inequality, but it does not depict America as a place of refuge. It rebukes America’s specter in the guise of American military officials who power the Marcos machinery from behind the scenes.

Works that explore the clash of cultures in the United States and the precarious, often violent position of Filipino immigrants adrift in a multicultural sea include M. Evelina Galang’s Her Wild American Self, 1996, and One Tribe, 2006; Jaime Jacinto’s Heaven Is Just Another Country, 1996; Marianne Villanueva’s Mayor of the Roses, 2005; Lysley Tenorio’s Monstress, 2012; and Marivi Soliven’s Mango Bride, 2013.

The intersection between the diasporic condition and queer poetics—characterized as being in constant limbo—has also been put forth, evident in the works of Bino Realuyo and R. Zamora Linmark. Realuyo’s Umbrella Country, 1999, is a coming-of-age tale for 11-year-old Gringo, who navigates a squalid neighborhood in 1970s Manila, where young boys dress up in make-believe Miss Universe pageants. Zamora Linmark’s fragmented Rolling the R’s, 1997, likewise features a group of “queer” Filipino teens, this time in 1970s Honolulu. In both books, patriarchal violence simmers beneath the flamboyant and easygoing episodes.

 

Ilocano being the language of the first immigrants to plantation-era Hawaii, Ilocano writing enjoys a foremost spot in diasporic literature in the regional languages. Ilocano-Hawaiian writers have been writing in all genres since the early 1970s, concurrent with the 1971 founding of Gunglo Dagiti Mannurat nga Ilokano iti Hawaii, a branch of GUMIL-Filipinas, the nationwide association of Ilocano writers in the Philippines. Since then, the group has regularly published anthologies of prizewinning entries in different genres. The works became a venue for Ilocano writers to disabuse readers of negative stereotypes of the Ilocano as uneducated, hot-tempered, and untrustworthy immigrants. First among these was Dagiti Pagwadan a Filipino iti Hawaii (Inspiring Filipinos in Hawaii), 1973, a compilation of biographical sketches of successful Ilocano in Hawaii, a project reminiscent of Roman Cariaga’s seminal The Filipinos in Hawaii. The second anthology Dandaniw (Poetry), 1974, contains poems in Ilocano and English, including ballads, satire, and elegies, mostly about love, nature, and the farming life. Over the next 40 years, the group would publish 15 anthologies and stage 22 plays. The later poems, like Pacita Saludes’s “Sakada” (Plantation Workers), 2005, looks back at the hardships of the first generation of plantation workers and proudly declares the benefits of such hardships to their family.

The Ilocano-Hawaiian short stories are “gripped with nostalgia” for lost home. The tone is of “fierceness, a veiled rage” against powerlessness and marginalization in the new land (Perez 2008, 110). Common characters are old-timers, mostly retired plantation laborers, and modern-day workers, who are invariably forced to adapt to a new land while they dream of returning to the Philippines. The protagonist in Carlos Laforga’s “Idi Nagbalik Hawaii ni Uncle Angelo” (Uncle Angelo’s Return to Hawaii), 1984, has spent his life working in Hawaii and returns to the Philippines to start a family. His happiness is short-lived when his wife dies in childbirth and the baby succumbs to sickness after a year. He flies off to Hawaii to deal with the grief but finds the place hostile and one which only deepens his isolation. Pelagio Halaba’s “Adda Supapak ti Tunggal Biddut” (There Is a Reward for Every Error), 1984, is set in a construction site where hostility exists between Filipino and Korean workers. The Korean architect fabricates stories to put the Filipinos in a bad light, which the construction company owner, a Filipino, believes. The foreman-supervisor, another Filipino, vindicates the Ilocano group and, to register his distaste over the perceived betrayal, resigns.

Aside from Ilocano writers, those who write in the other regional languages about the diaspora include Michael Obenieta, who writes in English and Cebuano and moved to Kansas in 2007. He continues to write Cebuano poems in his blog and to serve as the administrator of the online literary website Kabisdak since its inception. In 2011, he was first runner-up at the Maureen Egen Writers Exchange Award, sponsored by the nonprofit organization Poets and Writers. The Cebuano poet Corazon Almerino leads a group of Cebuano writers who have settled in the United States and continues to write, as do her co-members in Women in the Literary Arts Tina Martinez-Juan, Catherine Viado, Ma. Paloma Sandiego, and Dindin Cañete. Ma. Milagros Geremia-Lachica, a major Karay-a poet and fictionist, migrated to the United States in 1997 but continues to be published in the Philippines. Ang Pagsulat Bayi (Writing Is Woman), 2006, collects 63 of her poems in Karay-a, which she translates to English. Divided into four sections, the poems chart her journey from Panay to the United States. There are elements of folklore and Panay’s oral literature in the first section, the second probes the everyday experiences of Panay life, the third contains her feminist poems, and the last follows the persona as she examines the contradictions of her newfound home.

In Tagalog, Ruth Elynia Mabanglo has extensively written about the diasporic condition since moving to Hawaii to teach in 1990. Her book Anyaya ng Imperyalista / Invitation of the Imperialist, 1998, is a bilingual collection of poems that probe the often perilous position of Filipino migrant workers. In the title poem, an enigmatic and powerful man invites the persona to dinner. The persona later realizes that it is she who is on the serving plate. The man devours her, and he finishes everything except her right hand—her writing hand—whose fingers grow back immediately after he bites them off, and vow to vanquish the man. Poignant homage to the eponymous figure is “Tulang Haka ni Flor Contemplacion” (A Conjectural Poem by Flor Contemplacion), which imagines the real-life nanny’s final rebellious thoughts as she awaits her execution. Her suffering is compared to the passion, death, and resurrection of Jesus Christ. “Bilang OCW” (As an OCW) also details the violence endured by migrant workers, from the separation at the airport to the very real possibility of death. The persona in Mabanglo’s next collection, Mesa para sa Isa: Mga Tula (A Table for One: Poems), 2002, also speaks from the point of view of someone longing for home, from the particular experience of a teacher of Filipino and Philippine literature. The nostalgia sometimes manifests as poeticizing of indigenous myths, like in “Tulang Haka nina Tungkung Langit at Alunsina” (Conjectural Poem by Tungkung Langit and Alunsina) and “Ang Pag-ibig ni Saragnayan (Saragnayan’s Love).

Outside America, there are sporadic presences of diasporic writing at the turn of the century. As there is not a historic relationship between the Philippines and the host countries, these diasporic works do not articulate and represent a similar tension that is inevitable in the tradition nurtured in the United States.

The foremost diasporic writer in this category is the Bikol writer Merlinda Bobis, who moved to Australia in 1991. Already noted in the Philippines for her feminist poetry, Bobis expands her canvas in Australia through fiction that fuses magical and indigenous elements with political content. In the title story of her collection White Turtle, 1999, an old woman from a village in the Philippines is taken by an Australian anthropologist to a writer’s festival in Sydney. There is a disconnection between the old woman and the audience, until she has “a real conversation” with a child and something happens that befuddles the crowd and disrupts the entire festival. In her novel Fish-Hair Woman, 2011, the eponymous character lives in a village caught in the cross fire among soldiers, insurgents, and private armies. Estrella uses her meters-long hair to retrieve dead bodies from the river. Like “White Turtle,” Fish-Hair Woman draws on the country’s rich indigenous tradition—the figure of the long-haired babaylan (native priestess), for one—to explore modern political realities, like corruption and extrajudicial killings.

Bobis’s poetry is no less imaginative. A romantic ode to an Australian beloved with a metafictional twist is the title poem in her collection Summer Was a Fast Train without Terminals, 1998, in which the persona tells the beloved: “I, too, can love you / in my dialect, you know, / punctuated with cicadas / and their eternal afternoons.” This language, the persona writes, is “prised from [her] wishbone.” The image of the wishbone recurs in her poems, capturing the always taut diasporic middle ground between the two worlds that she inhabits.

Also writing in Australia is Arlene Chai, whose two novels, The Last Time I Saw Mother, 1997, and Eating Fire and Drinking Water, 2011, revisit the Marcos dictatorship through the lens of women protagonists, a familiar terrain and epoch explored by countless other novels. Elsewhere, Jim Pascual Agustin, who migrated to South Africa in 1994, engages the violence of imperialism in many parts of the globe in Alien to Any Skin, 2011. In Sound before Water, 2013, the bucolic scenes from South Africa reminds the persona of pastoral scenes from the Philippines. The diasporic writers in Europe include Ella Wagemakers-Sanchez in the Netherlands, Edna Weisser in Germany, and Reine Arcache Melvin in France. In 2000, Trans Euro Express: Filipinas in Europe, a collection of essays, was published in Germany.

Since the 1930s, there has been scholarship on the plight of the Ilocano plantation workers, found in the academic and popular writings of Filipino anthropologist Roman Cariaga, including his master’s thesis, published as The Filipinos in Hawaii: Economic and Social Conditions, 1906-1936, 1937. The study challenges the widespread stereotypes and racism against Filipinos in Hawaii. Carlos Romulo, better known as a diplomat and bureaucrat, similarly wrote polemical works on US-Philippine relations, war memoirs, and the novel The United, 1951.

Scholarship on the Filipino diasporic condition or the literature it inspires is nourished sometimes by the writers themselves, such as Francia, Gamalinda, and Tabios, who have expounded on the implications of race in their poetics. Igloria edited a collection of ruminative essays in Not Home, But Here: Writing from the Filipino Diaspora, 2003. The following year saw the publication of an expansive compendium of poetics essays, Pinoy Poetics: A Collection of Autobiographical and Critical Essays on Filipino and Filipino-American Poetics, 2004, edited by Carbo. The volume also contains an exhaustive literary timeline of all Filipino works published overseas, from the Spanish to the contemporary period. Anthologies of creative works also served a critical function, with editors often attempting to situate the book and the works in the ongoing tradition. Notable ones include Without Names: Poems by Bay Area Pilipino American Writers, 1985; Brown River, White Ocean: An Anthology of Twentieth-Century Philippine Literature in English, 1996; Screaming Monkeys: Critiques of Asian American Images, 2003; The Thirdest World: A Collection of Three Stories by Filipino Writers, 2001; Going Home to a Landscape: Writings by Filipinas, 2003; and the multidisciplinary tome Vestiges of War, 2003, which examines American colonialism in the Philippines through essays, archival and contemporary photographs, and poetry.

Succeeding generations of scholars, mostly based in American universities, continue the tradition, often with specific areas of interest in the Filipino-American experience. San Juan, aside from being the foremost expert on Bulosan, has written radical scholarship and analyses on the historically charged position of Filipinos in America. Vicente Rafael’s White Love and Other Events in Filipino History, 2000, charts the enduring effect of American cultural imperialism in vital episodes of Philippine history, including the “spectral presence” of diasporic Filipino communities within the modern Philippine nation-state. Catherine Ceniza Choy’s Empire of Care, 2003, situates the large population of Filipino nurses in American hospitals in the larger fabric of US-Philippine relations, American colonialism, and the racialization of Filipinos. Linda España-Maram’s Creating Masculinity in Los Angeles’s Little Manila, 2008, examines the politically defiant nature of the leisure activities of working class Filipinos in the 1920s to the 1940s Los Angeles, including the extent to which authorities tried to control such displays of virility. Theodore Gonzalves’s The Day the Dancers Stayed, 2009, historicizes the political implications of the performances in Filipino “cultural nights” at American campuses and connects these with the development of a diasporic identity. Dylan Rodriguez’s Suspended Apocalypse: White Supremacy, Genocide, and the Filipino Condition, 2010, roots the alienation of Filipinos in America to a broader, more global nexus of “profound racial and white supremacist violence.” Martin Ponce’s Beyond the Nation: Diasporic Filipino Literature and Queer Reading, 2012, suggests a connection between race and sexuality by applying a “queer diasporic” reading to major figures of the Filipino diaspora, such as Villa, Bulosan, and Hagedorn.

Other scholars who have written on the subject include Leny Mendoza Strobel, Timothy Yu, Oscar Campomanes, Sharon Delmendo, Augusto Espiritu, Joaquin Gonzalez, Evelyn Rodriguez, Victor Bascara, Julian Go, and Neferti Tadiar. Caroline Hau, who is based in Japan, is an expert on the Chinese diaspora to the Philippines.

Outside the realm of traditional publishing, among an “emergent” form of diasporic writing is the testimonio, or testimonial narratives, that include oral histories, diaries, letters, memoirs, and eyewitness accounts (de Guzman 2008, 606). Some scholars have collected and studied letters of Filipina domestic helpers to their families and nongovernment organizations, which document their difficult plight and challenge the “official memory” of the overseas Filipino worker (OFW) phenomenon put forth by the government. Poems written by OFWs in Saudi Arabia have been gathered by Odine de Guzman in From Saudi with Love: 100 Poems, 2003. The poems, most of which were submitted to a literary contest sponsored by the Overseas Filipino Press Club, recount the workers’ anxiety, alienation, and loneliness, and profess their love for their family, partners, and country. There are also meditations on life and humorous anecdotes. De Guzman notes the strong influence of the indigenous oral tradition in the poems in Filipino, including the balagtasan, awit, salawikain, and bugtong (cited in Ordoñez 2013).

Described as “dispersed” and “coreless,” the country’s tradition of diasporic writing necessarily operates within the context of the often lopsided relationship between the Philippines and the host countries. In particular, the writers in America have to grapple with historical realities that had rendered the Filipino identity in their new land invisible, if not antagonistic, a factor that also raises inevitable questions on exclusion and representation. That most of these writers do not belong to the economically driven exodus that chiefly characterizes the Filipino diaspora is a gap that should be stressed, alongside other issues like language, audience, and the dangers of self-exoticism. As exile and displacement become a pervasive national reality, the documentational value of diasporic writing should be clear. Aided by a perspective unique to the condition, the best of the works can also present fresh ways of engaging familiar and new themes.  Written by Glenn Diaz

article.value: The term “diaspora”—from the Greek word for “scattering” or “dispersion”—has historically been used to refer to the involuntary displacement of large segments of an ethnic or national population from its territory (Liddell, Scott, and Jones 1940). In the Philippine context, diaspora is synonymous with the export of labor that dates back to the early 20th century, when some 120,000 Filipino peasant laborers were transported to Hawaii and, later, the West Coast of the United States, to work as itinerant farmhands and cannery workers. The phenomenon assumed its contemporary guise in the 1970s when then-president Ferdinand Marcos instituted a labor export policy as a short-term solution to uneven labor opportunities in the country, while taking advantage of global market demands, particularly in the oil fields and burgeoning cities of the Middle East. By 2012, up to 10.5 million Filipinos—about a tenth of the population—were working in nearly 200 countries, sending back to their families billions of dollars in remittances that fuel a significant aspect of the domestic economy (CFO 2013). Scholars identify this reality as one of the most definitive national experiences of the nation today.

The bulk of what is widely considered as the country’s tradition of diasporic writing—sometimes lumped together with “exilic” or “expatriate” writing—is more intertwined with the intellectual, rather than labor, character of the Filipino diaspora. With the exception of a few cases, the literature of the diaspora is written by Filipinos who voluntarily spent time or completely settled overseas, mostly for careers in academia, not for the sheer economic necessity that had historically compelled Filipinos to leave the country. At the outset, diasporic writing, which owes a debt to its practitioners’ ties with universities and other cultural institutions, is already divorced from the phenomenon that it generally connotes.

There is also a colonialist dynamic behind the phenomenon; a great concentration of the works tends to emanate from an important center of the colonial or neocolonial power—that is, Madrid during the Spanish period (1521-1898) and California and New York in the United States afterward (1898-present).

The origins of diasporic writing can be traced back to the reform movement in Spain in the 1880s and 1890s, with Filipinos writing and publishing essays and polemics that criticize Spanish colonial rule in the Philippines. Among them was Pedro Paterno, who studied at the University of Salamanca and earned a law degree from the University of Madrid. His Spanish poetry collection Sampaguitas y Otras Poesias Varias (Jasmine and Other Poems) came out in Madrid in 1880, and Ninay, the first known Filipino novel in Spanish, was published five years later. Despite its alleged superficiality and self-exoticism, Ninay is credited for being a foundational work on an emergent national culture (Matibag 2010, 35). It exalts Filipino tradition and thus rebukes the civilizing logic of European colonization. The narrative, which chronicles two love triangles, uses the devices of costumbrismo, with plot secondary to ethnographic descriptions of local middle-class customs, all in an attempt to introduce to Spain its far-flung colony. The portrayal of Philippine culture in Ninay is as a hybrid of Malay, aboriginal, Chinese, Spanish, and Indian elements (40). It also highlights the antiquity of this culture and the productivity of the colony and its people, “in service of a changing concept of ‘Filipino’” (Lumbera quoted in Matibag 2010, 38).

article.value: This “representative” or “performative” ethos—that the works were written to “perform” the Philippines largely for the benefit of a foreign audience—would become a mark of diasporic writing. Ninay, which was in a language that fewer than 10 percent of the indios (Christianized native) at that time understood, was said to be a response to Jose Rizal’s exhortation to his fellow expatriates to produce “a collection that would represent the Philippines to a wider world.”

After Ninay, the next two novels that were published in Europe were Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1887, and El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1891. Both a political and an artistic achievement, the novels are recognized not only for catalyzing the 1896 Philippine Revolution but also for being the “earliest artistic expressions of the Asian colonial experience from the point of view of the oppressed” (Augenbraum 2006, xxiii). In both books, Philippine society is portrayed as a hapless victim of an abusive and extremely powerful Spanish clergy, a ruthless “friarocracy” in coalition with the local Filipino elite.

American colonial rule marks a critical turn in the history of Philippine diasporic writing, as the colonial regime declared English as the primary medium of instruction in the newly established public education system. At about the same time, the first contingent of Filipino peasant laborers were shipped by the Hawaiian Sugar Planter’s Association to Hawaii, paving the way for the eventual spilling over of Filipinos into continental United States. These two factors—the mandatory learning of the colonial tongue and the physical act of migration, in addition to the myriad cultural, moral, and existential crises they would birth—would form the basis of a long tradition of Philippine diasporic writing in America.

As early as the first decade of the 20th century, there were already attempts by Filipino migrants in the United States to use the new language to articulate their experiences. The first issue of the short-lived quarterly The Filipino Students’ Magazine came out in 1905 in Berkeley, California. It contained the earliest examples of English poetry by Filipinos, written by pensionados, or scholars of the American colonial government. Among them was “The Flood” by Ponciano Reyes, the first known Filipino poem in English (Abad 2008, 50). The narrative poem of 40 verses celebrates the “quiet dignity” of labor—fishermen, farmers, and traders—as they toil on the Pasig River as a storm looms (51). Its homage to the working class is reminiscent of how Ninay attempts to show the productivity and resilience of Filipinos.

The first book of poetry by a Filipino that was published in the United States is Marcelo de Gracia Concepcion’s Azucena, 1925. American readers noted the author’s “distinct sensibility and unusual ways of using English” even while the words are clearly “those of a Western hand” (Carbo 1995, xv).

This precarious status between being assimilated in and “other-ed” by the American literary establishment would be highlighted in the case of Jose Garcia Villa, the first major figure in the literature of the diaspora. His stories appeared in American periodicals and were included in the 1932 and 1933 editions of the annual Best American Short Stories series, edited by the critic Edward O’Brien, Villa’s most prodigious advocate. In 1933, his stories were gathered in Footnote to Youth: Tales of the Philippines and Others, published by Charles Scribner’s Sons with funding from Villa. O’Brien’s introduction underscored Villa’s foreignness, that he had come from “a totally unrelated civilization,” sidestepping the three decades that the Philippines had been an American colony (Chua 2013-14, 21). American reviews described some of the stories in Footnote as “experimental” and “unusual” but undermined their formal merits and instead focused on their “magic,” a “strange quality … that must come from the Philippines.” Already, Villa’s ethnicity was impinging at his attempt at a universalist poetics.

Some scholars have put forth this “nativist anxiety” to explain Villa’s shift to poetry, announced in the publication of Have Come, Am Here, 1942. The poetry collection earned for Villa comparisons to Wallace Stevens, Emily Dickinson, e. e. cummings, the metaphysical poets, and even Dante. Critics thus placed him squarely in the Anglo-American poetic tradition, often without the exoticized assessments lavished on Footnote. However, the unwanted specter of his ethnicity eventually returned to haunt him; some reviews explained the peculiarities of his poetry as a function of his ethnicity and, therefore, his position as outsider to the language and Western literary tradition.

The publication of Villa’s Volume Two, 1949, was met with less critical acclaim. Negative reviews picked on his ethnicity. His “cavalier” use of English, praised in Have Come, Am Here, is dismissed as “an insensitivity to the conventional meanings and uses of words” (Yu 2004, 359). This critical trajectory continued with Selected Poems and New, 1958. By this time, his foreignness was being cited to account for his “self-indulgent” poetic mannerisms and ultimately led to Villa’s erosion from the American modernist canon, a turn abetted by the concurrent rise of the confessional mode.

Villa’s self-fashioning as an apolitical aesthete is unique in the larger purview of Philippine diasporic writing, which is otherwise characterized by attempts at establishing Filipino-ness. The tradition is replete with “motifs of departure, nostalgia, incompletion, rootlessness, leave taking, and dispossession … with the Philippine as either the original or terminal reference point” (Campomanes 1992, 49). Specifically, the works of the first Filipino immigrants in America revolved around two central themes: their process of adaptation to the new country and Philippine history and politics.

Both are present in the works of Carlos Bulosan. Like Villa but for a different reason, Bulosan stands as an anomaly in the larger fabric of Filipino diasporic writing. Unlike his mostly educated and middle-class counterparts, Bulosan was a high school dropout who was largely self-taught. He regarded the pensionados with “suspicion and contempt” and highlighted his shared peasant origins with the “faceless, nameless manongs” (57). His poetry and fiction foreground the collective experiences of oppression suffered by Filipinos, whether it is feudal inequity in the Philippines or racial ostracism in Depression era America. Like Rizal’s novels, his first collection of stories, The Laughter of My Father, 1944, depicts Philippine society as grossly unequal. This time, however, it is a morally bankrupt local elite and newly arrived “American capitalists” who hold power in the markedly feudal society. As the stories unfold, however, the poor eventually get their due, usually through their own clever devising—Bulosan’s own contribution to the trickster trope. These satiric attacks on an unequal society were largely misunderstood during his time; that The Laughter of My Father is seen as a purely humorous collection is a fact that Bulosan lamented (Tolentino 1986, 452-53).

Bulosan’s best-known work is his “personal history,” America Is in the Heart, 1946. The fictionalized autobiography has been called a “social classic,” chronicling his poor childhood in rural Pangasinan, his journey to America, and his years as an itinerant farmer in California and later involvement in the foundation of early labor unions (McWilliams 1973, xvi). Violent scenes of poverty, racism, and trauma pepper the narrative. America in the novel is an inhospitable land, as the arrival of the first Filipinos in the United States coincided with the Great Depression and with it a racist backlash against immigrants for crowding the already saturated job market. While the book ends with an affirmation of America, or at least the ideals of liberal democracy that it supposedly symbolized, it has been argued that “the totality of the book’s contents”—in addition to the spirit of his other works—“contradicts the protagonist’s affirmation of America in the conclusion” (Alquizola quoted in San Juan 1993, 153).
Bulosan also published two poetry books: Letter from America, 1942, and The Voice of Bataan, 1943, a slim volume of wartime monologues featuring the voices of a cast of soldiers.

article.value: The post-World War II novels and short stories of Bienvenido Santos, a pensionado, are populated by lonely and alienated Filipino expatriates. Poignant and expertly crafted, his works are sometimes criticized for their “defeatist” and “reconciliatory” tendencies, exemplified by the docile characters in his best-known stories, “Scent of Apples,” 1955, and “The Day the Dancers Came,” 1967 (San Juan 1993, 153). Properly contextualized, however, this spirit is rooted in a “distinctive historical epoch of Filipino dispossession,” particularly the post-World War II period, when the Philippines’ status as a neocolony was being cemented (154). Santos’s later works offered a more directed treatment of the neocolonial condition. Solomon King, the protagonist in his novel The Man Who (Thought He) Looked Like Robert Taylor, 1983, feels a strong, imaginary connection to the eponymous Hollywood icon, seen as a metaphor for the Filipino’s unrequited affinity with the United States and American culture. He can recite American poetry from memory, a skill that he takes pride in but that nobody else in America seems to care about. In What the Hell for You Left Your Heart in San Francisco, 1987, Santos offers a cross-section of a Filipino immigrant community in San Francisco, a cast that includes old-timers, professionals, and second-generation Filipinos. America in Santos’s works is an ambivalent site—a place of “greener pastures” but also of estrangement and loneliness, as the ties that the old-timers have with the Philippines become severed.

Another pensionado was N. V. M. Gonzalez, who was already an established name in the Philippines when he went to the United States on a Rockefeller grant in the late 1940s. In 1947, his collection Seven Hills Away was published in America. Mostly set in his native Mindoro, his stories are noted for their restraint and clarity, painting a bucolic picture of life in rural Philippines. Of all diasporic writers, Gonzalez is perhaps the most “nativist”—in the United States, he was influenced by a number of “Southern Agrarians,” academic New Critics who espoused a militant regionalism that he thought matched his “provincial” background. In The Bamboo Dancers, 1957, America is more sinister than in the works of Santos. It is a place of “alienation, ghostliness, and disembodied existence” (Espiritu quoted in Burns 2008, 51). The estrangement felt by the protagonist Ernie Rama is due to the disconnection between his Western education and the realities of Philippine life. He can only achieve moral and cultural regeneration by returning to his native land and reintegrating with its rituals and myths.

It was the revolutionary timbre of Bulosan’s works, not the lonely voices of Santos or Gonzalez, that came to influence a new generation of Filipino-American writers in the 1970s, notwithstanding they were close in class and social stature to Santos and Gonzalez. Concentrated in the San Francisco area, the so-called Flip generation forms a distinct stream in diasporic writing. They sought to stress their identities as Filipino-Americans—or those born in the United States—as distinct from the Filipino immigrants’. They felt a disconnection from the exilic literature of Santos and Gonzalez. Instead, Oscar Peñaranda, Serafin Syquia, and Sam Tagatac built on Bulosan’s critiques and offered their own accounts of racism in the increasingly hostile American society in the anthologies Flips, 1971, and Liwanag (Light), 1975. But whereas Bulosan’s works were written from an outsider’s point of view, the Flips assert that they are not “exiled guests” in America but are “hosts” (Peñaranda 2004, 235).

The group also attempted to establish a genealogical link with old-timers and their social history as a source of further empowerment. The persona in Virginia Cerenio’s “You Lovely People,” 1983, addresses an unnamed manong. The body as a locus of history is also used in some poems in Jeff Tagami’s October Light, 1987. The persona in Peñaranda’s “Mano Po, Lakai” (Your Blessing, Lakai), 1996, also pays homage to the hardships of the first immigrants.

The anthology Returning a Borrowed Tongue, 1995, continues the Flips’ critique of colonialism, with poems plumbing the psychological effects of Spanish and American influence. Examples include Nick Carbo’s “Little Brown Brother,” Eugene Gloria’s “Assimilation,” Jaime Jacinto’s “Tongue Tied,” and Michael Melo’s “Unlearning English.” Both Al Robles’s Rappin with Ten Thousand Carabaos in the Dark, 1996, and Eugene Gloria’s Drivers at the Short-Time Motel, 2000, return to the lyrical mode to comment on social issues. Included in Carbo’s El Grupo McDonald’s, 1995, is the poem “Running Amok,” which traces the trope of the crazed Filipino “savage.”

Similarly, Catalina Cariaga critiques colonialism in her poetry collection Cultural Evidence, 1999. While rooted in Filipino history and Filipino-American experiences, her poems straddle multiple traditions and experiments with form. Her use of collage, intertextual dialogues, and other experiments influenced Barbara Jane Reyes’s “Anthropologic,” 2003, which plays on the colonialist nuance inherent in the practice of anthropology. The seven-page poem is a mishmash of scientific reports, untranslated Filipino words, excerpts from critical works on Orientalism, erasures, and “white spaces.” It also claims solidarity with other victims of American effacement with a reference to Native American leader Geronimo and the 1904 Saint Louis World’s Fair. The abstract poetry of Eileen Tabios in Beyond Life Sentences, 2003, which uses surrealism and “found words” from other texts, intends to subvert the English narrative, which she says has historically been used by the American regime as a colonizing tool.

Other poets engage Filipino-American history through more conventional form. The poems in Vince Gotera’s Ghost Wars, 2003, recreate the experience of war, both the pain and the pleasure, for veterans and their families. Patrick Rosal takes on a range of voices and personas in My American Kundiman, 2006, in which he professes his conflicted feelings for America using the kundiman, an indigenous Filipino song of unrequited love. Other figures in this stream include Cyn Zarco, Shirley Ancheta, Peter Bacho, Dawn Mabalon, Jon Pineda, Oliver de la Paz, Jean Vengua, Aimee Nezhukumatathil, and Michelle Bautista.

Interestingly, “homegrown” poets, who were born and raised in the Philippines before they moved to the United States, were decidedly less adamant about asserting their ethnicity although this element remains present in their poems. Eric Gamalinda’s Zero Gravity, 1999, ruminates on the idea of memory as a key to rootedness but ultimately disavows it. In “Enough,” the persona distances himself from his homesick friends and admits to enjoying his activities in his adopted country. Amigo Warfare, 2007, follows this path. Named after the guerrilla tactic used by Filipino revolutionaries against American occupation forces, the collection paints a world rendered apocalyptic after the 9/11 attacks, but it ignores America’s imperial ambitions, veering off instead to the realm of metaphysics.

One section of Luis Francia’s Museum of Absences, 2003, also examines post-Sep 11 Manhattan. “New York Mythologies” is dedicated to the “undocumented victims” of the tragedy. The lyricism and tenderness of Luisa Igloria reverberate as she examines themes like the link between colonialism and the diaspora. In Juan Luna’s Revolver, 2009, she traces the roots of the persona’s displacement to the decisive encounters between Filipinos and colonial powers. There are allusions to figures like Rizal, Luna, and the Filipino “tribes” exhibited at the World’s Fair, lending the collection unmistakable historical gravitas without sacrificing poignancy.
