article.value: Other “homegrown” poets who have settled in the United States and continue to write include Luis Cabalquinto, Fatima Lim-Wilson, Felix Fojas, Fidelito Cortes, and Rowena Tiempo-Torrevillas, who also writes essays.

In fiction, globally recognizable events in Philippine history and politics are fertile ground for material. In most cases, the works are imbued with allegorical weight and private lives are tasked to encompass Philippine history and society. The preponderance of this mode in diasporic writing, even as it also occurs in fiction published in the Philippines, further attests to the “performative” aspect of the tradition.

Stevan Javellana’s World War II novel Without Seeing the Dawn, 1947, became a “modest best seller” when it was published in New York. An imaginative retelling of the Philippines’ long history of invasions by a series of colonial powers, the work uses the story of a farmer-turned-soldier to depict the devastation that war brings to a small town. Wilfrido Nolledo’s novel But for the Lovers, 1970, is set in Japanese-occupied Philippines, written in a vigorous, prolix prose that is described as “recognizably English” but heavily interspersed with Tagalog and Spanish epithets, puns, and nuances. This language, in addition to the novel’s complex and highly experimental narrative technique, is blamed for the novel’s limited audience in the Philippines. Linda Ty-Casper’s Three-Cornered Sun, 1979, returns to the Philippine Revolution of 1896 with a family whose members are each endowed with allegorical value, some more than others. Awaiting Trespass, 1985, also attempts at allegory, this time of the Marcos dictatorship. Ninotchka Rosca’s State of War, 1988, offers a vision of the country’s colonial history in the context of martial law, using carnivalesque elements amid a backdrop of political conspiracy and romance. The historical ramifications of the Filipino-American War reverberate in Cecilia Manguerra-Brainard’s story “The Black Man in the Forest,” 1986. Her novel When the Rainbow Goddess Wept, 1994, follows a young girl’s archetypal journey from innocence to its shattering against the backdrop of the Japanese occupation.

The Filipino-Americans’ share in this tradition includes Michelle Skinner’s collection of short stories Balikbayan: A Filipino Homecoming, 1988, which is replete with powerful allusions to life under martial law and emphasizes the American support of Marcos. The elite’s decadent lifestyle during the dictatorship is the subject of Sabina Murray’s Slow Burn, 1990, there seen through the life of teenager Isobel della Fortuna. Murray’s short story collection The Caprices, 2002, is about the brutality of the Pacific Campaign during World War II.

Jessica Hagedorn’s Dogeaters, 1990, started an “unprecedented” outpouring of Filipino works in the United States after a “sparse” output up to the 1970s, a “cultural explosion” abetted by the commemorations of the Philippine independence centenary in 1998. The “relentless thematic diversity”—from migration to generational conflict and continuity and historical reconstructions of key events in Philippine history—was matched by the broad array of forms: novels, short story collections, autobiographies, personal essays, poems, and plays (Ponce 2012, 1). Dogeaters also ushered in an era of formal experimentation in Filipino novels in the United States that typifies a new, sophisticated articulation of resistance to American hegemony that subsequent notable novels would display.

Using pastiche and other elements of Western high postmodernism, Hagedorn tells the story of the waning years of the Marcos dictatorship, seen through a diversity of characters, including a schoolgirl, a Fil-Am DJ and male prostitute, a business tycoon, a beauty queen, a general, a German director, and New People’s Army cadres. Philippine society in Dogeaters is grossly unequal, by turns overly religious and seedy, obsessed with celebrity, social mobility, and anything American. It is prey to relentless and entrenched corruption, and populated by druggies, thugs, whores, and other depraved characters. Real-life events and figures, like the assassination of Marcos critic Benigno Aquino, the Imelda-led construction of a film center, and Marcos and Imelda themselves are represented in the novel. Some critics say that its very structure—the narrative interspersed with fictitious newspaper clippings, radio transcripts, scripts, gossip, and letters, among other texts—blunts its satiric potential and transforms its radical content to mere exoticized spectacle.

A clear successor to Dogeaters’ formal acrobatics is Miguel Syjuco’s Ilustrado (Educated Native), 2010. Published to even bigger acclaim, Ilustrado was hailed as an inventive, stylistic achievement from the Canadian resident. The unpublished manuscript of the novel won the Palanca grand prize and the Man Asian Literary Prize in 2008. The novel opens with the dead body of a Filipino writer in the United States, whose life is pieced together by his protégé, named Miguel Syjuco, through the former’s body of work, which includes poems, novels, polemics, and memoirs. In the process, the novel traces 150 years of Philippine history and includes a meta-commentary on the contemporary literary scene. Like its portrayal in Dogeaters, Philippine society in Ilustrado is dark, brutal, and ceaselessly corrupt, if occasionally funny and absurd. It is a victim of the whims of history and the ruling classes, on whom the novel lays the most blame. Ilustrado is written to address a foreign audience, taking pains to explain all manner of Filipino phenomena. This outward-looking attitude is usually explained by the commercial demands of international publishing.

Another diasporic author who plays wildly with form is Gina Apostol. Her American debut, the martial law novel Gun Dealer’s Daughter, 2012, is an “amnesiac thriller” that probes the dual idea of memory, in the private sense and as a collective national experience, through circuitous prose and the meandering consciousness of its eponymous protagonist, Soledad Soliman. Like the protagonist of Syjuco’s novel, Sol pieces together her personal history and, in so doing, her country’s during martial law. It gains allegorical weight by intertwining Sol’s bildungsroman with the political consciousness of martial law–era Philippines. The lavish and cosmopolitan lifestyle of the country’s elite is described at length, later linked to the unscrupulous arms business that provided muscle to the Marcos regime. Like Ilustrado, the novel attempts to stress the elite’s complicity in the pervasive inequality, but it does not depict America as a place of refuge. It rebukes America’s specter in the guise of American military officials who power the Marcos machinery from behind the scenes.

Works that explore the clash of cultures in the United States and the precarious, often violent position of Filipino immigrants adrift in a multicultural sea include M. Evelina Galang’s Her Wild American Self, 1996, and One Tribe, 2006; Jaime Jacinto’s Heaven Is Just Another Country, 1996; Marianne Villanueva’s Mayor of the Roses, 2005; Lysley Tenorio’s Monstress, 2012; and Marivi Soliven’s Mango Bride, 2013.

The intersection between the diasporic condition and queer poetics—characterized as being in constant limbo—has also been put forth, evident in the works of Bino Realuyo and R. Zamora Linmark. Realuyo’s Umbrella Country, 1999, is a coming-of-age tale for 11-year-old Gringo, who navigates a squalid neighborhood in 1970s Manila, where young boys dress up in make-believe Miss Universe pageants. Zamora Linmark’s fragmented Rolling the R’s, 1997, likewise features a group of “queer” Filipino teens, this time in 1970s Honolulu. In both books, patriarchal violence simmers beneath the flamboyant and easygoing episodes.

Ilocano being the language of the first immigrants to plantation-era Hawaii, Ilocano writing enjoys a foremost spot in diasporic literature in the regional languages. Ilocano-Hawaiian writers have been writing in all genres since the early 1970s, concurrent with the 1971 founding of Gunglo Dagiti Mannurat nga Ilokano iti Hawaii, a branch of GUMIL-Filipinas, the nationwide association of Ilocano writers in the Philippines. Since then, the group has regularly published anthologies of prizewinning entries in different genres. The works became a venue for Ilocano writers to disabuse readers of negative stereotypes of the Ilocano as uneducated, hot-tempered, and untrustworthy immigrants. First among these was Dagiti Pagwadan a Filipino iti Hawaii (Inspiring Filipinos in Hawaii), 1973, a compilation of biographical sketches of successful Ilocano in Hawaii, a project reminiscent of Roman Cariaga’s seminal The Filipinos in Hawaii. The second anthology Dandaniw (Poetry), 1974, contains poems in Ilocano and English, including ballads, satire, and elegies, mostly about love, nature, and the farming life. Over the next 40 years, the group would publish 15 anthologies and stage 22 plays. The later poems, like Pacita Saludes’s “Sakada” (Plantation Workers), 2005, looks back at the hardships of the first generation of plantation workers and proudly declares the benefits of such hardships to their family.

The Ilocano-Hawaiian short stories are “gripped with nostalgia” for lost home. The tone is of “fierceness, a veiled rage” against powerlessness and marginalization in the new land (Perez 2008, 110). Common characters are old-timers, mostly retired plantation laborers, and modern-day workers, who are invariably forced to adapt to a new land while they dream of returning to the Philippines. The protagonist in Carlos Laforga’s “Idi Nagbalik Hawaii ni Uncle Angelo” (Uncle Angelo’s Return to Hawaii), 1984, has spent his life working in Hawaii and returns to the Philippines to start a family. His happiness is short-lived when his wife dies in childbirth and the baby succumbs to sickness after a year. He flies off to Hawaii to deal with the grief but finds the place hostile and one which only deepens his isolation. Pelagio Halaba’s “Adda Supapak ti Tunggal Biddut” (There Is a Reward for Every Error), 1984, is set in a construction site where hostility exists between Filipino and Korean workers. The Korean architect fabricates stories to put the Filipinos in a bad light, which the construction company owner, a Filipino, believes. The foreman-supervisor, another Filipino, vindicates the Ilocano group and, to register his distaste over the perceived betrayal, resigns.

Aside from Ilocano writers, those who write in the other regional languages about the diaspora include Michael Obenieta, who writes in English and Cebuano and moved to Kansas in 2007. He continues to write Cebuano poems in his blog and to serve as the administrator of the online literary website Kabisdak since its inception. In 2011, he was first runner-up at the Maureen Egen Writers Exchange Award, sponsored by the nonprofit organization Poets and Writers. The Cebuano poet Corazon Almerino leads a group of Cebuano writers who have settled in the United States and continues to write, as do her co-members in Women in the Literary Arts Tina Martinez-Juan, Catherine Viado, Ma. Paloma Sandiego, and Dindin Cañete. Ma. Milagros Geremia-Lachica, a major Karay-a poet and fictionist, migrated to the United States in 1997 but continues to be published in the Philippines. Ang Pagsulat Bayi (Writing Is Woman), 2006, collects 63 of her poems in Karay-a, which she translates to English. Divided into four sections, the poems chart her journey from Panay to the United States. There are elements of folklore and Panay’s oral literature in the first section, the second probes the everyday experiences of Panay life, the third contains her feminist poems, and the last follows the persona as she examines the contradictions of her newfound home.

In Tagalog, Ruth Elynia Mabanglo has extensively written about the diasporic condition since moving to Hawaii to teach in 1990. Her book Anyaya ng Imperyalista / Invitation of the Imperialist, 1998, is a bilingual collection of poems that probe the often perilous position of Filipino migrant workers. In the title poem, an enigmatic and powerful man invites the persona to dinner. The persona later realizes that it is she who is on the serving plate. The man devours her, and he finishes everything except her right hand—her writing hand—whose fingers grow back immediately after he bites them off, and vow to vanquish the man. Poignant homage to the eponymous figure is “Tulang Haka ni Flor Contemplacion” (A Conjectural Poem by Flor Contemplacion), which imagines the real-life nanny’s final rebellious thoughts as she awaits her execution. Her suffering is compared to the passion, death, and resurrection of Jesus Christ. “Bilang OCW” (As an OCW) also details the violence endured by migrant workers, from the separation at the airport to the very real possibility of death. The persona in Mabanglo’s next collection, Mesa para sa Isa: Mga Tula (A Table for One: Poems), 2002, also speaks from the point of view of someone longing for home, from the particular experience of a teacher of Filipino and Philippine literature. The nostalgia sometimes manifests as poeticizing of indigenous myths, like in “Tulang Haka nina Tungkung Langit at Alunsina” (Conjectural Poem by Tungkung Langit and Alunsina) and “Ang Pag-ibig ni Saragnayan (Saragnayan’s Love).

Outside America, there are sporadic presences of diasporic writing at the turn of the century. As there is not a historic relationship between the Philippines and the host countries, these diasporic works do not articulate and represent a similar tension that is inevitable in the tradition nurtured in the United States.

The foremost diasporic writer in this category is the Bikol writer Merlinda Bobis, who moved to Australia in 1991. Already noted in the Philippines for her feminist poetry, Bobis expands her canvas in Australia through fiction that fuses magical and indigenous elements with political content. In the title story of her collection White Turtle, 1999, an old woman from a village in the Philippines is taken by an Australian anthropologist to a writer’s festival in Sydney. There is a disconnection between the old woman and the audience, until she has “a real conversation” with a child and something happens that befuddles the crowd and disrupts the entire festival. In her novel Fish-Hair Woman, 2011, the eponymous character lives in a village caught in the cross fire among soldiers, insurgents, and private armies. Estrella uses her meters-long hair to retrieve dead bodies from the river. Like “White Turtle,” Fish-Hair Woman draws on the country’s rich indigenous tradition—the figure of the long-haired babaylan (native priestess), for one—to explore modern political realities, like corruption and extrajudicial killings.

Bobis’s poetry is no less imaginative. A romantic ode to an Australian beloved with a metafictional twist is the title poem in her collection Summer Was a Fast Train without Terminals, 1998, in which the persona tells the beloved: “I, too, can love you / in my dialect, you know, / punctuated with cicadas / and their eternal afternoons.” This language, the persona writes, is “prised from [her] wishbone.” The image of the wishbone recurs in her poems, capturing the always taut diasporic middle ground between the two worlds that she inhabits.

Also writing in Australia is Arlene Chai, whose two novels, The Last Time I Saw Mother, 1997, and Eating Fire and Drinking Water, 2011, revisit the Marcos dictatorship through the lens of women protagonists, a familiar terrain and epoch explored by countless other novels. Elsewhere, Jim Pascual Agustin, who migrated to South Africa in 1994, engages the violence of imperialism in many parts of the globe in Alien to Any Skin, 2011. In Sound before Water, 2013, the bucolic scenes from South Africa reminds the persona of pastoral scenes from the Philippines. The diasporic writers in Europe include Ella Wagemakers-Sanchez in the Netherlands, Edna Weisser in Germany, and Reine Arcache Melvin in France. In 2000, Trans Euro Express: Filipinas in Europe, a collection of essays, was published in Germany.

Since the 1930s, there has been scholarship on the plight of the Ilocano plantation workers, found in the academic and popular writings of Filipino anthropologist Roman Cariaga, including his master’s thesis, published as The Filipinos in Hawaii: Economic and Social Conditions, 1906-1936, 1937. The study challenges the widespread stereotypes and racism against Filipinos in Hawaii. Carlos Romulo, better known as a diplomat and bureaucrat, similarly wrote polemical works on US-Philippine relations, war memoirs, and the novel The United, 1951.

Scholarship on the Filipino diasporic condition or the literature it inspires is nourished sometimes by the writers themselves, such as Francia, Gamalinda, and Tabios, who have expounded on the implications of race in their poetics. Igloria edited a collection of ruminative essays in Not Home, But Here: Writing from the Filipino Diaspora, 2003. The following year saw the publication of an expansive compendium of poetics essays, Pinoy Poetics: A Collection of Autobiographical and Critical Essays on Filipino and Filipino-American Poetics, 2004, edited by Carbo. The volume also contains an exhaustive literary timeline of all Filipino works published overseas, from the Spanish to the contemporary period. Anthologies of creative works also served a critical function, with editors often attempting to situate the book and the works in the ongoing tradition. Notable ones include Without Names: Poems by Bay Area Pilipino American Writers, 1985; Brown River, White Ocean: An Anthology of Twentieth-Century Philippine Literature in English, 1996; Screaming Monkeys: Critiques of Asian American Images, 2003; The Thirdest World: A Collection of Three Stories by Filipino Writers, 2001; Going Home to a Landscape: Writings by Filipinas, 2003; and the multidisciplinary tome Vestiges of War, 2003, which examines American colonialism in the Philippines through essays, archival and contemporary photographs, and poetry.

Succeeding generations of scholars, mostly based in American universities, continue the tradition, often with specific areas of interest in the Filipino-American experience. San Juan, aside from being the foremost expert on Bulosan, has written radical scholarship and analyses on the historically charged position of Filipinos in America. Vicente Rafael’s White Love and Other Events in Filipino History, 2000, charts the enduring effect of American cultural imperialism in vital episodes of Philippine history, including the “spectral presence” of diasporic Filipino communities within the modern Philippine nation-state. Catherine Ceniza Choy’s Empire of Care, 2003, situates the large population of Filipino nurses in American hospitals in the larger fabric of US-Philippine relations, American colonialism, and the racialization of Filipinos. Linda España-Maram’s Creating Masculinity in Los Angeles’s Little Manila, 2008, examines the politically defiant nature of the leisure activities of working class Filipinos in the 1920s to the 1940s Los Angeles, including the extent to which authorities tried to control such displays of virility. Theodore Gonzalves’s The Day the Dancers Stayed, 2009, historicizes the political implications of the performances in Filipino “cultural nights” at American campuses and connects these with the development of a diasporic identity. Dylan Rodriguez’s Suspended Apocalypse: White Supremacy, Genocide, and the Filipino Condition, 2010, roots the alienation of Filipinos in America to a broader, more global nexus of “profound racial and white supremacist violence.” Martin Ponce’s Beyond the Nation: Diasporic Filipino Literature and Queer Reading, 2012, suggests a connection between race and sexuality by applying a “queer diasporic” reading to major figures of the Filipino diaspora, such as Villa, Bulosan, and Hagedorn.

Other scholars who have written on the subject include Leny Mendoza Strobel, Timothy Yu, Oscar Campomanes, Sharon Delmendo, Augusto Espiritu, Joaquin Gonzalez, Evelyn Rodriguez, Victor Bascara, Julian Go, and Neferti Tadiar. Caroline Hau, who is based in Japan, is an expert on the Chinese diaspora to the Philippines.

Outside the realm of traditional publishing, among an “emergent” form of diasporic writing is the testimonio, or testimonial narratives, that include oral histories, diaries, letters, memoirs, and eyewitness accounts (de Guzman 2008, 606). Some scholars have collected and studied letters of Filipina domestic helpers to their families and nongovernment organizations, which document their difficult plight and challenge the “official memory” of the overseas Filipino worker (OFW) phenomenon put forth by the government. Poems written by OFWs in Saudi Arabia have been gathered by Odine de Guzman in From Saudi with Love: 100 Poems, 2003. The poems, most of which were submitted to a literary contest sponsored by the Overseas Filipino Press Club, recount the workers’ anxiety, alienation, and loneliness, and profess their love for their family, partners, and country. There are also meditations on life and humorous anecdotes. De Guzman notes the strong influence of the indigenous oral tradition in the poems in Filipino, including the balagtasan, awit, salawikain, and bugtong (cited in Ordoñez 2013).

Described as “dispersed” and “coreless,” the country’s tradition of diasporic writing necessarily operates within the context of the often lopsided relationship between the Philippines and the host countries. In particular, the writers in America have to grapple with historical realities that had rendered the Filipino identity in their new land invisible, if not antagonistic, a factor that also raises inevitable questions on exclusion and representation. That most of these writers do not belong to the economically driven exodus that chiefly characterizes the Filipino diaspora is a gap that should be stressed, alongside other issues like language, audience, and the dangers of self-exoticism. As exile and displacement become a pervasive national reality, the documentational value of diasporic writing should be clear. Aided by a perspective unique to the condition, the best of the works can also present fresh ways of engaging familiar and new themes.  Written by Glenn Diaz
