article.value: Motifs found in the literatures of various nations, especially of Asia, are recognizable in Philippine indigenous literature. The abduction and rescue of King Rama’s faithful wife Sita in the Indian epic Ramayana is paralleled by that of Radia Mangandiri’s wife Putli Tihaia in the Maranao epic Maharadia Lawana. The “water-from-the-rock” motif, found in Igorot tales involving the hero Lumawig, is associated with Moses in Hebrew literature and Arjuna in the Indian Mahabharata. The myth of the deluge and the repopulation of the world is universally found, ranging from the story of Noah’s ark to the Ifugao tales about Bugan and Wigan. The story of a fish or whale swallowing the hero, such as the Biblical Jonah, the fairy-tale puppet Pinocchio, and Indian folk heroes, is echoed by Lam-ang being eaten up by the giant fish berkakan. A motif common in Indian folk literature is the “ring in the fish,” especially made famous in world literature by the Sanskrit drama Shakuntala, and contained in the Maranao epic Indarapatra and Sulayman.

Popular fairy-tale motifs abound in the Philippines. The Puss-in-boots character—that is, the loyal animal who cleverly helps its master—might be a monkey. The Philippine version of the Tom Thumb character measures one dangkal, according to at least 30 versions of the tale in the Philippines; this motif is also used in the awit (metrical romance) Si Eliseo at Feliza (Eliseo and Feliza).

The Malay trickster is Pelandok, the clever mouse deer. In the Philippines, Pelandok has evolved into a person who makes fools of oppressive rulers, such as a local datu or sultan, the gobernadorcillo or a Spanish officer. One Pilandok tale, which can be traced to the Jataka and Arabian tales, has found its way into a contemporary short story in English, written by Carlos Bulosan, and titled “My Father Goes to Court,” 1944. Bulosan’s adaptation is an example of his attempt to, in his own words, “utilize our common folklore, tradition, and history in line with my socialist thinking.”

To date, there are 27 Philippine versions and 11 foreign parallels of the star or bird-maiden motif. The most famous among these is probably the awit Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird), which has been reproduced in various artistic genres, such as dance and drama. The swan maiden in the Thai version is called Manohra, the youngest of seven princesses. She is caught by the forester and presented to the Prince, who, after a test to prove his worth, marries her. In the Philippine version, it is the hunter who marries the youngest star maiden, whose wings he has stolen to keep her earthbound. When she discovers the wings he has kept hidden, she leaves him and their child to return home. The hunter wins her back after a series of adventures and tests, which he passes with the help of people, animals, and insects. Although the basic plot is the same for all versions, variants occur in the details. For example, the beautiful princesses may come down as crows, large ducks, or stars. The wings may be a feather dress, hidden in a bamboo flute, the hunter’s blowgun, bag, or the roof rafters. Other awit or korido versions of the same motif are Jaime del Prado, and the Kapampangan Mariang Pau.

The Philippine Cinderella is Mariang Alimango (Maria the Crab), a folktale motif that is also the source of at least two awit titled Mariang Alimango and Proceso. In the fairy godmother’s role is Maria’s mother, transformed into a crab which appears before Maria as she performs a chore. In other versions, the magical helper is a crocodile, an old woman, or a beautiful lady. The hero is the son of the town’s richest man. The heroine is taken in a golden calesa (horse-drawn carriage) to the church, where the meeting between her and the hero occurs. A 20th-century version of Mariang Alimango is Milagring in Gregorio Coching’s novel Nanay Ko! (My Mother!), 1926, one of many novels with the Cinderella motif. The formula of the rich-boy-poor-girl romance, which has been used numerous times in popular novels, derives from the Cinderella motif.

Despite Spanish attempts to suppress the folk cultural forms, which the colonizers perceived to be pagan,” these persisted as integral elements of the colonial forms. For example, the free exchange between folktale motifs and the plots from the metrical romances is illustrated in what is popularly known as the epic of Lam-ang. Literary scholar Resil B. Mojares (1983, 35) describes it as “a hybrid work that combines pagan and Christian elements, both from pre-contact” and Spanish times. The earliest known written version of it is by Fr Gerardo Blanco in 1889. Its original source may have been a Tinguian folktale called “Silammang.” Some Spanish influences are the invocation to God, some characters’ names, and the titles of kapitan (captain), Don, and Doña. It has the features of a medieval romance, such as its title: Historia ti Pacasaritaan ti Panagbiag ni Lam-ang iti Ili ti Nalbuan nga Asawa ni Doña Ines Cannoyan iti Ili a Calanotian (Life Story of Lam-ang of the Town of Nalbuan, Husband of Doña Ines Cannoyan of the Town of Calanotian), 1924.

The Bikol korido draws more from folktale motifs than from European models, except for the very popular ones like Doce Pares (Twelve Peers) and Siete Infantes de Lara (Seven Sons of Lara). The trickster character Juan Osong is the model for the hero of the korido Mag-amang Pobre (Poor Father and Son). Doña Maria asin Don Juan (Doña Maria and Don Juan) combines both the trickster and swan-maiden motifs. Felizardo asin Catalina (Felizardo and Catalina) and Pobreng Eduardo (Poor Eduardo) have heroes who rise above their humble origin by marrying princesses. In the 1920s, when the short story genre was developing in the country as a result of American influence, Juan Osong and his adventures were still favorite material for the Bikol short story.

The propaganda movement in the 19th century deliberately used folk forms to criticize the friars and the colonial government. Emilio Jacinto’s prose works, Pahayag (Statement) and Liwanag at Dilim (Light and Darkness), 1896, contain epigrammatic and metaphorical elements that show traces of the proverb and tanaga tradition.

At the turn of the present century, journalism, which influenced much of contemporary literature, continued the ethnic tradition. Editorials included poems adapted from folk songs and children’s rhymes, such as “Sit-si-rit-sit.” Present-day poetry draws heavily from the same source.

The mythical figure Mariang Makiling, popularized by Jose Rizal, recurs in contemporary poems of social and political protest, such as the Tagalog “Mariang Makiling,” 1979, by Jose F. Lacaba and the Ilonggo “Sa Imo, Mariang Makiling” (To You, Mariang Makiling), 1989, by Eugenio M. de Pablo. The Mariang Makiling motif is also used to delineate the conflict between the rural and urban cultures in Philippine fiction, such as Remigio Mat. Castro’s Tagalog novel Makiling, 1933, and Macario Pineda ’s Ang Ginto sa Makiling (The Gold in Makiling), 1947.

The Kapampangan folk hero Sinukwan, king of Mount Arayat, is believed to have married Mariang Makiling. Contemporary adaptations of his story are Leon Ma. Gonzalez’s Sinukwan, Ana Filipinas Vergara’s Una Leyenda de Arayat (A Legend of Arayat), and Evangelina Hilario-Lacson’s Sinukwan: A Fantasy.

In the Philippine short story in English, folklore is deliberately used to infuse “local color” to create a gothic atmosphere or to emphasize the individualism of the central character, who may embody certain characteristics of a folk hero. Early writers in English using folklore for these purposes were Manuel Arguilla, Amador Daguio, Loreto Paras-Sulit, Delfin Fresnosa, Sinai C. Hamada, Paz Latorena, Bienvenido Santos, and N. V. M.Gonzalez. Nick Joaquin’s novels, The Woman WhoHad Two Navels, 1961, and Cave and Shadows, 1983, and some of his short stories build layer upon layer of the Philippine folkloric and Hispanic traditions to define the contemporary Filipino soul.

The novel Batbat hi Udan (Story of Udan), 2009, continues the epic tradition of the Higa-unon, the ethnic group to which the author Telesforo Sungkit Jr belongs. Its language is a Filipino that is a mix of Tagalog and Higa-unon; its text is a mesh of epic formulas and the elements and techniques of the realistic novel. The protagonists are datus and bagani (warriors), and their antagonists, besides the datu and bagani of enemy tribes, are the tagbaya, or supernatural beings. Repetition and parallelism, often explained by critics of oral literature to be a memory aid (aka mnemonic device) for epic chanters, are here used as devices of the realistic novel to delineate character, express intense emotion, create a poetic effect, or tighten the plot structure by means of foreshadowing and dramatic irony. Batbat hi Udan is plot driven, which characterizes one type of realistic fiction, rather than episodic, which is the structure of the epic.
The Spanish Influence

The coming of the Spaniards produced a body of religious literature: saints’ lives, sermons, dialogues, exempla (moral anecdotes), and gozos (hymns). These forms were later to contribute to both the didactic and aesthetic impulses of Philippine literature.

The fusion of the Spanish form and indigenous material is seen as early as the first printed book in which we find samples of written literature, the Memorial de la Vida Christiana en Lengua Tagala (Guidelines for the Christian Life in the Tagalog Language), 1605, by Dominican friar Francisco Blancas de San Jose. The Memorial includes bilingual or ladino poetry, consisting of verses alternating between Spanish and the Tagalog translation, as well as the first known poem to be written completely in Tagalog. These were complimentary verses, so called because they praised the book in which they were printed in order to encourage people to read the book. The writing of complimentary verses was a practice adapted from the poets of the Spanish Renaissance period, such as Lope de Vega and Miguel de Cervantes.

By the 17th century, religious poetry had become a synthesis of all the traditions that had flowed into Philippine literature. The dalit, for example, was formerly an indigenous poem with a serious theme but became transformed into religious lyric poetry. But pre-Spanish pantheism persisted. For instance, an Ilonggo religious poem, anonymously written, begins with an invocation to the Bathala, who is described as being flanked by the tamawo Mantiw and Lulid, and who resides at Mount Kanlaon. Bathala is also identified with the “ibon-ibon Adarna,” the description of which alludes to the dove that represents the Holy Spirit.

During this period, the growth of the epic was inhibited by the introduction of two narrative-verse forms, the pasyon and the awit/korido (metrical romances), especially in the Christianized areas of the country. The pasyon derived its quintilla-verse form and dialogue and narrative format from the Spanish passion, like Retablo de la Vida de Cristo (Tableaux of the Life of Christ), 1585, by Juan de Padilla and Decada de la Pasion de Cristo (Decade of the Passion of Christ), 1576, by Juan Coloma. The earliest known Filipino pasyon is the Tagalog Mahal na Passion ni Jesu Christong Panginoon Natin na Tola (Holy Passion of Our Lord Jesus Christ in Verse), ca 1704, by Gaspar Aquino de Belen. The most popular pasyon is Casaysayan nang Pasiong Mahal ni Jesucristong Panginoon Natin na Sucat Ipag-alab nang Puso nang Sinomang Babasa (The Story of the Holy Passion of Our Lord Jesus Christ That Should Inflame the Heart of the Reader), 1814, which has since spawned adaptations and imitations, political parodies, serious political diatribes, at least one expressing a Communist ideology, as well as versions in the various Philippine languages. In the 18th century, another direct offspring of the pasyon was its dramatized version, the sinakulo.

article.value: Philippine secular narrative poetry was derivative of the romance (Spanish ballad) and the libro de caballeria (book of chivalry). The awit or korido, as the Philippine metrical romance came to be called, adapted characters and plots from the French Charlemagne cycle, the British legends of the Round Table, the myths of Greece and Rome, and Spanish history and culture. Although many awit/korido were written primarily for entertainment, the didactic impulse even in this genre was not completely effaced. Some conduct books were written in the awit/korido form to warn the youth against such vices as drinking and gambling. There were awit/korido about saints and Biblical characters such as Maria Magdalena, Santa Elena, San Ignacio de Loyola, Adan and Eba, the martyr of Golgotha, Reyna Esther, Judith, Haring Solomon, and the three Kings. On the other hand, the Mexican corrido, which is more topical, has its parallel in the Ilonggo composo.

The existence of the awit/korido in the various Philippine languages and up to the present time attests to their continuing popularity, especially Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird), Siete Infantes de Lara (Seven Sons of Lara), Don Juan Tiñoso, and Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura). Moreover, features of this genre interweave with the Philippine poetry and novel traditions.

The awit/korido tradition recurs in various genres even as new literary forms emerge to meet the demands of new social and historical realities. Works expressing social or political themes in the awit form were written by Aurelio Tolentino, Lope K. Santos, and Jose Corazon de Jesus, aka Huseng Batute. Some novels are “modernized” awit/korido, because they follow the same conventions (e.g., a convoluted plot, a host of minor characters, accidental meetings, and magical elements). Some writers who used this formula in their popular novels were Gaudencio Alcazar, Nemesio Caravana, Zoilo Galang, Susana de Guzman, Magdalena Jalandoni, Hilaria Labog, Jose N. Sevilla, and Florentino Suico. If the sinakulo was the dramatized offspring of the pasyon, the moro-moro/komedya/kumidya/linambay/curaldal was that of the awit/korido.

The development of conduct books sometime during the 19th century illustrates the gradual assimilation of the European tradition into secular prose narrative, especially the novel. Joaquin Tuason’s Ang Bagong Robinson (The New Robinson), 1879, is an extended halimbawa / pananglitan / exemplum / exemplary tale, or an anecdote with a moral. It is a Tagalog translation of a German adaptation of Daniel Defoe’s novel Robinson Crusoe. Similarly several times removed from the original is Fr Modesto de Castro’s “educational moral novel,” Pag Susulatan nang Dalauang Binibini na si Urbana at ni Feliza na Nagtuturo ng Mabuting Kaugalian (Letters between Two Maidens Urbana and Feliza, Which Teach Good Conduct), 1864, which is a direct adaptation of the manual de urbanidad (guide to urbanity). However, there is here already an attempt to localize the material by setting the narrative situation in Manila and a Philippine rural area.

Secular lyric poetry was defined by the codes of courtly love, which came down to the Philippines through the literary traditions of medieval Europe. The codes, first set into writing by Andreas Capellanus in 1170, included the lover’s devotion to the ideal of womanhood and virtues of humility, fidelity, and selflessness. The love between the man and the woman was forbidden, but it inspired the lover to perform heroic feats. Spanish poetry expressed these codes through devices that became, in 19th-century Philippine secular poetry, mechanical conventions: the apostrophe, personification of abstract or philosophical concepts like death, forbidden love, and the effusive description rather than dramatization of sentiment. Balagtas’s poem “Labindalawang Sugat ng Puso” (Twelve Wounds of the Heart), 1869, exemplifies the poem of courtly love.

The awit Pinagdaanang Buhay ni Florante at ni Laura sa Cahariang Albania (Life Experienced by Florante and Laura in the Kingdom of Albania), ca 1838, by Francisco Baltazar, aka Balagtas, is a synthesis of all the literary traditions that came before it and became, in turn, the primary source and influence for the romantic impulse in the literature that came after it. It combines the conventions of the literature of courtly love with the moralism of 19th-century Tagalog society. It contains the elements and devices of the metrical romance, folk poetry, and dramatic forms like the loa. A feature that it derives from folk poetry is its monorhyming quatrain, which actually consists of two couplets. The quotable aphorisms that can be lifted from this awit are echoes of both the folk proverb and the didactic character of missionary poetry. The talinghaga (metaphor), is used in combination with figures of speech like personification, metonymy, synecdoche, and so on. But the dramatic quality of Balagtas’s awit is the result of his skill and experience as a playwright.

Literary historian and critic Virgilio Almario has remarked that “if Rizal was the model for the novel, Balagtas was the model for poetry and drama” (1984, 57). Because Florante at Laura contained the forms of the awit, pasyon, proverb, riddle, and folk song, it was a powerful influence in continuing the tradition of oral poetry. But it also determined the topography of written literature in both theme and form. Works that were influenced by Florante at Laura were Iñigo Ed. Regalado’s “Ang Tula Mo” (Your Poem), 1911, which expressed anti-American sentiments; the novels of Roman Reyes, which depicted courtly love between the main characters; Jose Corazon de Jesus’s Sa Dakong Silangan (In the East), 1928, an awit with allegorical characters, princes and princesses embarking on a journey to seek freedom from American rule; Teo Baylen’s Tinig ng Darating (Voice of Things to Come), 1963; and Amado V. Hernandez’s Isang Dipang Langit (A Stretch of Sky), 1961. The two female heroes in Nieves Baens del Rosario’s war novel Erlinda ng Bataan (Erlinda of Bataan), 1946, are modeled after Laura and Flerida of Balagtas’s awit. Twentieth-century popular novels in the Balagtas tradition used courtly love and family relations for plot complications that would depict the theme of good versus evil; characters functioned as symbols of conflicting forces. Some of the novelists were Gregorio Coching, Rosalia Aguinaldo, Jovita Martinez, Roman Reyes, Teodoro Virrey, and Teofilo Sauco.

During the first two decades of the 20th century, the Balagtas tradition became a means of resisting American colonialism. The Balagtas poets’ reaffirmation of the traditions of Christianity and the spirit of the propaganda and revolutionary movements was to them a patriotic stance. Hence, the balagtasan, a form of extemporaneous poetry derived from the older forms of the duplo and karagatan, was born in 1924. However, as the Balagtas school became more and more insistent on the correctness of its beliefs, it became more didactic, abstract, stilted, and stagnant. Therefore, what had been a form of political activism in its day became merely a style of florid sentimentalism as Americanization began to take root. The Balagtas tradition, however, persists to this day as a literary form and technique used by poets of different political persuasions.

The costumbrista (local color) movement of 19th-century Spain further enriched the Philippine novel. Costumbrismo is evident in de Castro’s Urbana at Feliza (Urbana and Feliza); Pedro A. Paterno’s Ninay, 1885, also considered the first Filipino novel; Jose Rizal ’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1887; Valeriano Hernandez Peña’s Ang Kasaysayan ng Magkaibigang si Nena at si Neneng (The Story of the Friends Nena and Neneng), 1903; and Roman Reyes’s Luha at Pag-ibig (Tears and Love), 1905. Magdalena Jalandoni’s Ang Dalaga sa Tindahan (The Maiden at the Market), 1935, provides vivid descriptions of the market scene, of life in an Ilonggo fishing village and in an Ilonggo town, folk and church rituals and the paraphernalia used. The concern for local color, evident in Paterno’s Ninay, was but one step away from the realistic novel as it was conceived by Jose Rizal.

Rizal was for the Philippine realist tradition what Balagtas was for the romantic tradition. While the novel genre itself is a European form, Rizal dipped into the literary traditions preceding his time, all the way back to the epic form, and applied these to Philippine reality. His novels, in turn, have been the source of recurring motifs in Philippine literature, especially in the novel; and the story of his life has been a major source of the nationalist tradition in Philippine literature.

It is said that Rizal held a copy of Florante at Laura as he sailed to Europe on his self-exile. Literary historian Julian Cruz Balmaseda demonstrates Balagtas’s influence on Rizal in his comparative study of an early kundiman (love song) by Rizal and the dedicatory stanza, “Kay Selya” (For Selya), in Florante at Laura. Rizal was also influenced by the awit, such as that by Joaquin Tuason, and the manual de urbanidad, such as Amigo de los Niños (The Children’s Companion). In his novels, there are foreign allusions to Schiller, Galileo, Dante, Copernicus, Cicero, Cervantes, Dumas, Victor Hugo, as well as local ones to the awit, komedya, Balagtas, Urbana at Feliza, and Si Tandang Basio Macunat (Old Basio Macunat), 1885. The precedent to the tragic love between lbarra and Maria Clara in Noli is that between Carlos and Ninay in Pedro Paterno’s Ninay.

A historical document offers what might be the source of Rizal’s Maria Clara character in Noli, 1887. A manifesto distributed by the propaganda movement in 1883 reveals that a beata of the Santa Clara order, Sor Pepita Estrada, was being abused by the vicar of the Franciscan order. She escaped the convent and managed to get her story out to the governor-general. However, the Church authorities had her declared insane and she was never heard from again. Similarities between the circumstances of this incident and those of Maria Clara’s story reveal that either the manifesto was Rizal’s direct source or that such stories circulated in Intramuros and were part of the city’s common lore. The story of Sor Pepita’s daring and resourcefulness might have continued a literary tradition already established by women warriors in Philippine epics. However, it is Maria Clara as the demure Filipina that has become the archetype against whom female literary characters and real-life Filipino women are measured.

On the other hand, one might see Gregoria de Jesus’s “Tula ni Oryang” (Oryang’s Poem), 1897, as a heterogeneous mix of both the historical person on whom Rizal’s character Maria Clara is based, the frail and demure woman that was the concoction of the Spanish colonial tradition, and revolutionary poetry’s persona of defiant action, whether female or male. De Jesus’s poem begins with a loving wife’s anxiety over her long gone husband, her recollections of their domestic bliss, and, in a reversal of the traditional portrayal of the passive, helpless woman, concludes with Oryang resolutely discarding her tear-soaked handkerchief and leaving the security of her house to take the path of revolution. However, for the purposes of American colonization, it was Maria Clara who continued to be used as the personification of authentic Philippine culture with its values and traditions still intact.

European realism, which was the dominant movement in the late 19th century, was what informed the worldview and literary technique of Rizal’s two novels. His primary influences in this regard were Benito Perez Galdos, Honore de Balzac, Emile Zola, Alexandre Dumas, Pio Baroja, and Leo Tolstoy. From these writers he adapted the realistic technique of the concrete detail and clinical description; the Victorian plot structure, with its many subplots, coincidences, and host of characters; and the satirical method.

Rizal has in turn inspired a number of works in the various genres. He is the subject matter in some Philippine poems in Spanish. Crisostomo Ibarra has served as a model for the hero or the heroine’s lover in many novels, such as Maximo B. Sevilla’s Babaing Uliran (Model Woman), 1914. The anticlerical theme runs through several works: Sulpicio Osorio’s Cebuano novel Mga Bungsod nga Gipangguba (Destroyed Fish Corrals), 1929, acknowledges the sources of its anticlerical protest in its allusions to the works of Rizal, Dumas, Carlo Guzzoni, Marcelo H .del Pilar, and Graciano Lopez Jaena. In Franco Vera Reyes’s Tagalog novel Probinsiana (Rural Maiden), 1933, the priests are caricatures of Rizal’s Padre Damaso and Padre Salvi.

The theme of modernism versus traditionalism is expressed in novels like Engracio L. Valmonte’s Ang Mestisa (The Mestiza), 1921, and Deogracias M. Rosario’s Bulaklak ng Bagong Panahon (Flower of the Modern Age), 1926. A feminist treatment of a Rizal character, however, is a short story by Lilia Quindoza-Santiago, “Ang Pinakahuling Kuwento ni Huli” (The Final Story of Huli), 1989, which recalls Juli, who was raped by Padre Salvi in El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1891; but in this modern story Huli joins the political underground movement in the end.

Another recurring motif drawn from Fili is the return of the exiled hero with a mission and disguised as the mysterious and wealthy figure. It occurs in Iñigo Ed. Regalado’s Madaling-Araw (Before Sunrise), 1909; Lazaro Francisco’s Bayang Nagpatiwakal (The Nation That Destroyed Itself), completed 1930, serialized in 1931-32 in Alitaptap, revised and serialized in 1947-48 as Ilaw sa Hilaga (Light in the North) in Liwayway; Juan C. Laya’s His Native Soil, 1941; Andres Cristobal Cruz’s Ang Tundo Man May Langit Din (Tondo Has a Heaven Too), 1959; and Rogelio Sikat aka Rogelio Sicat ’s Dugo sa Bukang-Liwayway (Blood at Daybreak), 1965. The underground novel of the martial law period, Hulagpos (Breaking Free), 1980, by Mano de Verdades Posadas (pseud., meaning “hand of fettered truths”), recalls both the Noli and Fili by its cover design, its preface titled “Noli Me Incarcere (Huwag Akong Ipiit)” (Do Not Cage Me), and the return of the self-exile, a petit bourgeois intellectual named Juan Crisostomo Guevarra.

Other works imitating or referring to Rizal or his works are Honorio M. Lopez’s awit Ang Buhay ni Doctor Jose Rizal (The Life of Doctor Jose Rizal), 1898; Maximo M. Kalaw’s novel The Filipino Rebel, 1930; Iñigo Ed. Regalado’s narrative poem Ang Ibong Walang Pugad (The Bird without a Nest), 1941; Angel L. Enemecio’s Cebuano novel Halok sa Buang (A Kiss for the Insane), 1937; Amado V. Hernandez’s Mga Ibong Mandaragit (Birds of Prey), 1969; and Fausto Galauran’s Lagablab ng Kabataan (Flame of Youth), 1970.

Rizal himself has entered into folk literature as an extension of the Bernardo Carpio myth. It is believed by the common folk, especially of Rizal’s home province of Laguna, that he is Carpio hidden in the mountain of San Mateo and that he will emerge when the Philippines has achieved true independence. Another version identifies Rizal as the stranger who meets Carpio inside the mountain and partakes of Carpio’s power through an anting-anting (amulet).

The transition from the metrical romance tradition to the realist tradition is represented by the novelist Gabriel Beato Francisco, author of what is considered the first published Tagalog novel, Cababalaghan ni Padre Bravo (The Miracle of Father Bravo), 1899, and also credited by E. Arsenio Manuel (1970, 201) with having introduced “the historical genre.” While still using the conventions and motifs of the metrical romance, Francisco also incorporated into his novels the conventions of the historical chronicle, documentary narrative, biography, and journalistic report. He showed a penchant for facts in his novels, which contained the exact dates and names pertaining to historic events, allusions to current events, passages from the Gaceta de Manila (Manila Gazette), and quotes from public decrees. But he was also clearly a product of the native literary tradition, as his novels contained allusions to Tandang Basio Macunat, Pasyong Genesis (Genesis Passion), and Marcelo H. del Pilar’s satirical Caiigat Kayo (Hunt for the Eel), 1888. Similarly, Nicolas Rafols’s Ang Pulahan (The Pulahan), 1919, is a semidocumentary account of the abuses of the Constabulary in Cebu at the turn of the century.

During the first two decades of the 20th century, the educated elite continued to read Spanish works by Quevedo, Cervantes, and Galdos; and, in Spanish translation, Tolstoy, Voltaire, Hugo, Zola, Dumas, Eugene Sue, and others. Translators like Gerardo Chanco, Francisco Laksamana, Narciso Asistio, and Rosendo Ignacio made these authors accessible in Tagalog. Some works translated were Shakespeare’s Romeo and Juliet, Victor Hugo’s The Hunchback of Notre Dame, Dante’s Divine Comedy, Milton’s Paradise Lost, Tolstoy’s Anna Karenina, Dumas’s Camille and The Count of Monte Cristo. Novelists in the various Philippine languages, however, also derived their materials from nonfiction material, like correspondences, diaries, and travel books.

article.value: As the realistic tradition became more firmly established at the turn of the century, it also influenced the awit/korido, especially as it was in the nature of this genre to allow for the use of historical persons and events as its subject matter. The brief period during which the Philippines celebrated its independence from Spain saw the production of revolutionary awit/korido, such as those celebrating the heroism of Diego Silang, Jose Burgos, and of the Filipino race.

The period also produced a stream of patriotic poetry in the local languages of the country’s various regions, which looked back to the revolutionary spirit of 1896. Spanish colonial forms such as the lives of saints, the passion of Christ, and the loa (a poem of praise to a saint) were used to express the writers’ protest against American imperialism. A loa to Rizal recalls his virtues, albeit secular rather than spiritual; a poem to arouse patriotic fervor invokes a code of heroism deriving from medieval Europe’s codes of chivalry; and a poem expressing love of country uses the discourse of the European code of courtly love (Chavez 1913; Lagos [1898] 1992; Zaragoza Cano 1918).

Well into the Commonwealth period and beyond, heroes of the revolution against Spain continued to be a favorite source for poems in Spanish, such as Cecilio Apostol’s “A Emilio Jacinto” (To Emilio Jacinto) and Pentelicas (Things from Pentelicus), 1941; Fernando Ma. Guerrero ’s “A Andres Bonifacio” (To Andres Bonifacio) and “A Lopez Jaena” (To Lopez Jaena), 1914; and Flavio Zaragoza Cano’s “De Mactan a Tirad” (From Mactan to Tirad), 1946.

The mixture of traditions in Tagalog poetry is well illustrated by the versatility of the poet Jose Corazon de Jesus. Known primarily as “the sweetest lyric poet in Tagalog,” he was also adept at satire in his column Buhay Maynila (Manila Life) and humor in his narrative poem “Ang Manok Kong Bulik” (My Speckled Gamecock).

From the Victorian tradition come the popular novel’s convolutions of plot and the gothic elements of horror and gore. Examples of such novels are Aurelio Tolentino’s Ing Buac nang Ester (A Strand of Ester’s Hair), 1911, and Marcelino Peña Crisologo’s Mining Wenno Ayat ti Cararua (Mining or Spiritual Love), 1914.

An adaptation of Alexandre Dumas’s novel Camille is Gerardo Chanco’s Sa Gitna ng Lusak (Wallowing in Mire), 1918. A recurring character, derived from the heroine of Dumas’s novel, is the good-hearted bailarina or dancer who commits a noble sacrifice for a lover belonging to the aristocratic class, and dies of consumption. This is often used by Fausto Galauran, as the novel Bulaklak ng Bayan (Flower of the Country), 1930, illustrates. In Veronidia, 1919, a drama (melodrama) by Cirio Panganiban, it is the man who ails instead. Iñigo Ed. Regalado’s Ang Tunay na Pag-ibig (True Love), 1913, not only adapts the plot, but uses metafictional devices of having the lover use Dumas’s novel to confess his love for the heroine, and a scene in which the two lovers pretend to be the Dumas characters Margarita Gautier and Armando. A cynical reversal of the Camille motif is Rosauro Almario’s Ang Mananayaw (The Dancer), 1910, which is more strongly influenced by naturalism than Dumas’s sentimental realism. Other novels with the same motif are Faustino Aguilar ’s Busabos ng Palad (Slave of Fate), 1909, and Ruperto Cristobal’s Ang Bulaklak sa Kabaret (The Flower in the Cabaret), 1920.

On the other hand, considered an innovator of the Cebuano poetic tradition was Fernando Buyser (1879-1946), who wrote poems that he called sonanoy. Although fellow poets and critics of his time thought his sonanoy to be a Cebuano adaptation of the sonnet, Buyser’s numerous sonanoy, unlike the sonnet’s fixed structure and rhyme scheme, could consist of any number of lines, with any number of syllables per line, and following a variety of rhyme schemes. One poem, “Intawon!” (Pity Me!), though having the structure of a sonnet in its stanzaic pattern, has only a three-syllable word per line, which is a feature of free verse, but carries an alternating rhyme scheme. Buyser’s innovations to the Cebuano poetic tradition through the sonanoy were furthered by subsequent generations of Cebuano poets. Notable among these was Diosdado Alesna, who, in a letter to the magazine Silaw, expressed his wish to learn Buyser’s style and technique so he could write like the master. Alesna went on to write free verse, which he called the siniloy (Evasco 1999, 57-58).
The American Influence

The second decade of the 20th century saw the entrenchment of American neocolonial culture through the transplantation of American political institutions, popular education, the introduction of the English language, and religious reformation.

Newspapers published editorials deploring social diseases perceived to have been brought about by Americanization: class exploitation, government bureaucracy, colonial mentality, the overemphasis on formal education, the white-collar mentality, materialism, and corruption in the city. Editors and journalists were also literary figures, among whom were Faustino Aguilar, Juan Arsciwals, Angel Magahum, Patricio Mariano, Valeriano Hernandez Peña, Roman Reyes, Lope K. Santos, Vicente Sotto, Aurelio Tolentino, and Serapion C. Torre. They wrote novels, dagli (didactic, satiric, or romantic sketches), poems, plays, essays, and short stories.

The writers of this period generally belonged to the Balagtas tradition that resisted Americanization, and they used the balagtasan and tudling (editorial columns) as vehicles of social protest. The balagtasan or extemporaneous debate in verse, begun in 1924, was followed by the crissotan (named after Juan Crisostomo Soto) in Pampanga in 1926; the balagtasan in Iloilo and Cebu, also in 1926; and the bukanegan (after PedroBukaneg) in Ilocos in the early 1930s.

The two strains of Philippine literature—the romantic-didactic and the realistic-nationalistic—sometimes merged within the same work, sometimes alternated with each other in the various works written within the same period. There was a profileration of love novels, such as those written in Tagalog by Gabriel Beato Francisco, Lope K. Santos, Valeriano Hernandez Peña, and Modesto Santiago; in Cebuano by Uldarico Alviola, Vicente Rama, Angel Enemicio, and Maximo D. Bas; and in Ilocano by Mariano Gaerlan. However, novels with sociopolitical themes also appeared, often by the same authors who wrote love novels.

In the 1920s another force determined the direction that Philippine literature was to take: commercialism. Although the romantic-didactic tradition persisted, commercialism was also shaping popular taste, which in turn made demands on the literary production. This orientation was reinforced by the weekly magazine Liwayway, 1922, which published novels, stories, and poems whose subject matter revolved around love, betrayal, filial obedience, and suffering.

This commercial trend was brought yet forward by the coming of the cinema in the 1930s. Novels that were made into movies were Zoilo M. Galang’s A Child of Sorrow, 1921; Antonio Sempio’s Ang Punyal na Ginto (The Golden Dagger), 1933; Fausto J. Galauran ’s Ang Kuba (The Hunchback), 1933; and Lazaro Francisco’s Sa Paanan ng Krus (At the Foot of the Cross), 1937. Cinema, in turn, influenced the novel form, which turned toward sensationalism, bakbakan (fistfights), and fantasy for some of its narrative devices. Moreover, there were novels that were “studio inspired”—that is, commissioned for the movies with a particular actor and actress in mind to play the central characters.

Novels that tried to duplicate the feats of movies, albeit only in print, were chosen for translation in the Philippine languages. There was a wave of mystery thrillers, adventure stories, or action-filled plots with spectacular scenes. Some adaptations and translations were Flaviano P. Boquecosa’s Tarzan series, 1933-34, from Edgar Rice Burroughs’s Tarzan; Florentino Suico’s Ben Hur, from the 1928 original written by Lew Wallace; Natalio B. Bacalso’s Si Kapitan Blood (Captain Blood), 1932, from Rafael Sabatini’s original; and Elpidio Fegi’s Si Doctor Fu Manchu, ang Misteryoso (The Mysterious Doctor Fu Manchu), 1933.

However, the influence of 19th-century European realism, from which Philippine realism had sprung, continued to leave its mark. Settings in the novel and short story were the factory, cabaret, hotel, market, and coconut farm; characters were the carpenter, peasant, fisher, mechanic, janitor, firefighter, cochero (rig driver). In poetry the subject matter was the carabao, nipa hut, tingting (sticks made from coconut leaves), acacia tree, rock, bamboo, carnival, opera, ship, shoes, darak at lumot (bran and moss). The founding of the regional magazines Bisaya in Cebuano, 1930, Bannawag in Ilocano, 1934, and Hiligaynon in Ilonggo, 1934, also produced the same dichotomy of tendencies. Novels and short stories initially published in these magazines were translations of foreign works by the favorite European writers in the Victorian and sentimental realist tradition: Charles Dickens, Carolina Invernizio, and Felice Guzzoni. Then, translations of Tagalog works by Liwayway writers like Susana de Guzman and Fausto Galauran began to appear. The next logical step was for the translators to write their own original works in their regional language. Thus began the careers of Cebuano writers Maximo D. Bas, Fausto Dugenio, Gardeopatra Quijano, and Ilonggo writers Ramon Muzones, Abe Gonzales, and Jose Yap.

American colonial education brought in a new wave of influences as early as 1906 and on to the 1930s: Louisa May Alcott, William Blake, William Cullen Bryant, William Faulkner, Bret Harte, Nathaniel Hawthorne, Ernest Hemingway, O. Henry, the Imagist poets, Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, Dorothy Parker, Edgar Allan Poe, William Saroyan, Daniel Steele, Mark Twain, Walt Whitman, and William Wordsworth. European literature continued to enter the country, this time in English translation: the works of Anton Chekhov, Fyodor Dostoyevsky, Gustave Flaubert, and Guy de Maupassant.

The American influence is most clearly illustrated in the history of the Philippine short story. The first real short story, as defined by the conventions of the genre, appeared in the second decade. Deogracias Rosario, considered the “Father of the Tagalog Short Story,” showed greater control of technique and, although still spurred by a didactic purpose, achieved this with more subtlety.

The first few stories in English, which saw print in the College Folio of the University of the Philippines in 1910, were romantic tales with legendary characters or were imitations of American and British adventure tales. However, when the short story writers began to be concerned about producing literature that was identifiably Filipino, they then used folklore material for local color, such as for atmosphere or for setting. This was a technique influenced by Bret Harte and his stories “The Luck of Roaring Camp” and “The Outcasts of Poker Flat.” Arturo B. Rotor and Manuel Arguilla effectively used the device to paint the rustic charm of the rural scene.

The strongest influence on the short story, whether in English or in the Philippine languages, was Edgar Allan Poe’s principle of the unity of effect. This was combined with Maupassant’s classic plot structure and O. Henry’s formula of the surprise twist. The first writer who used these formulas most successfully was Paz Marquez-Benitez.

Sherwood Anderson’s impressionistic style and subjectivism in Winesburg, Ohio was the model for Jose Garcia Villa’s Footnote to Youth: Tales of the Philippines and Others, 1933. The Anderson pattern is also recognizable in Arguilla, N. V. M.Gonzalez, and Hernando Ocampo. William Saroyan influenced Francisco Arcellana and Delfin Fresnosa. N. V. M. Gonzalez is closely identified with Ernest Hemingway. Alfredo Elfren Litiatco acknowledges Dorothy Parker’s influence in the title of his story, “It Isn’t Just Horses.” The “Father of the Modern Cebuano Story” is Marcel Navarra, whose cryptic depiction of the poverty of the country folk bears the influence of Hemingway, and whose pessimism and narrative technique are modeled after Guy de Maupassant’s.

In the 1930s, Daniel Wilbur Steele’s “fifth-act style” provided short story writer Arturo Rotor with a method by which the revelation was arrived at, at the story’s end. This influence is evident in Rotor’s two stories, “Zita,” 1930, and “Flower Shop,” 1934, in which the reader, reaching the end of the story (the “fifth act”), pieces together a narrative that transpired even before the story began. Besides Steele, Rotor himself has pointed to de Maupassant’s “The Necklace,” 1884, as having a strong influence on his writing as well, particularly in his critique of bourgeois hypocrisy. The difference is that de Maupassant’s writing is imbued with the pessimism of French naturalism, whereas Rotor’s bears the optimism of the Philippine Commonwealth period (Cruz 1970; Abelardo 2015).

The awit/korido tradition, instead of being effaced by the development of the novel, was reinforced by American and British Romanticism. Some favorite models were Longfellow’s narrative poems Evangeline: A Tale of Arcadie, The Song of Hiawatha, and The Courtship of Miles Standish; Walter Scott’s The Lady of the Lake; and Matthew Arnold’s Sohrab and Rustum. Such poems bore such close resemblance to the awit/korido that Americanization in the 1930s seemed to bring the writers back full circle to the first generation of writers. The difference, however, was that the writers brought into their works a rich variety of topics and images, because they themselves had a variety of interests. Gregorio Coching was an engraver, Antonio Sempio an English teacher and film director, and Susana de Guzman a music student.

Lyric poetry in the first decade was inspired by the British Romantic Movement, represented by John Keats, Percy Bysshe Shelley, William Wordsworth, Samuel Taylor Coleridge, and George Byron. In the next decade, however, liberties with poetic form were influenced by Gertrude Stein, Carl Sandburg, and e. e. cummings. Angela Manalang Gloria’s poetry was touched by Edna St. Vincent Millay, Sara Teasdale, Elinor Wylie, Emily Dickinson, and the Imagist Movement; Villa, by e. e. cummings; R. Zulueta da Costa, by T. S. Eliot, Walt Whitman, Carl Sandburg, and e. e. cummings.

In Tagalog poetry, experiments in rhyme and meter were tried by Pedro Gatmaitan and Benigno R. Ramos, who composed malaprosang tula (prose poem). A poem representing the transition from balagtasismo to free verse is Jose Corazon de Jesus’s “Ang Sawa” (The Python), 1920, which has the appearance of free verse but still retains the traditional rhythm and meter when read aloud. However, perhaps the earliest successful modern poems are Cirio Panganiban’s “Three O’Clock in the Morning,” ca 1930, and “Manika” (Doll). Later attempts at free verse, modern imagery, and experimentations with punctuation were done by Manuel Principe Bautista, Gonzalo K. Flores, and Hernando R. Ocampo. In Kapampangan poetry, Amado Yuson pioneered in free verse with his “Palsintan Daca” (I Love You), 1930.

Free verse also represented the spirit of rebellion against strictures. Alejandro G. Abadilla, the “Father of Modern Tagalog Poetry,” was its strongest proponent. His book Ako ang Daigdig at Iba Pang Tula (I Am the World and Other Poems), 1955, was a declaration of independence from the Balagtas Romantic tradition. Yet, ironically, Abadilla’s modernism was derived from the Romanticism of Rousseau, Walt Whitman, and William Wordsworth. This he combined with Arthur Rimbaud’s surrealist symbolism, D. H. Lawrence’s and Henry Miller’s eroticism, Schopenhauer’s philosophy of “ceaseless striving,” and Freud’s concept of the libido.

The 1930s in the United States was the Depression period, which produced a proletarian movement in literature, whose moving spirits were Upton Sinclair, John Steinbeck, Erskine Caldwell, Clifford Odets, Malcolm Cowley, Sinclair Lewis, Theodore Dreiser, John Dos Passos, and James Farrell. In the Philippines, a parallel organization among the writers in English was the Philippine Writers League, led by Salvador P. Lopez, Manuel Arguilla, Hernando Ocampo, and Arturo B. Rotor.

The Tagalog writers’ organization, Kapisanang Panitikan, 1935, deliberately used American models as a means of breaking away from the editorial restrictions imposed by commercial magazines, which were their publishing outlets. Its members had been reared during the American period and were therefore steeped in the tenets of American realism, which stressed two aspects: literary technique and the value of individualism. In his preface to the anthology of winning short stories, Ang 25 Pinakamabuting Maikling Kathang Pilipino ng 1943 (The 25 Best Pilipino Short Stories of 1943), 1944, Agoncillo explains that technique is the basis for recognizing the work as modern; and individualism, rather than membership in a community, is upheld. These conventions are evident in the fictional works of the period, such as the novels Ama (Father), 1929, by Lazaro Francisco and Timawa (Freeman/Serf), 1953, by Angel Fernandez (pseud. of Agustin C. Fabian).

Pagkamulat ni Magdalena (Magdalena’s Awakening), 1958, co-authored by Abadilla and Elpidio G. Kapulong, is considered a most daring novel in many ways. A futuristic novel set in 1980, with the Philippines foreseen to be under Chinese Communist rule, its topics are drawn directly from American culture: individualism versus socialism, antichurch sentiments, free love and eroticism, the rebellion against traditional morality.

In the 1950s, the writers’ attempts to break away from the formula of popular fiction imposed upon them by commercial magazines were met with hostility by their readers. Cebuano short story writers like Eugene Viacrucis and Godofredo Roperos tried to educate their mass readers with plotless, psychological, and philosophical fiction modeled after Hemingway’s and James Joyce’s. However, indignant letters to the editor forced them to give up their experimental fiction and to fall back on the tried and tested formulas of O. Henry, de Maupassant, and Poe.

The 1950s down to the present is marked by the interdisciplinary and intertextual character of literature. Having undergone a university education, the writers have been exploring themes provided by the various disciplines in the academe, especially the social sciences. These themes include the generation gap, the working mother’s quandary, the search for a national identity, and neocolonialism.

The stress on individualism and the influence of Freud inevitably brought about an interest in psychological realism. Antonio Sempio was influenced by the novel of sensibility of the Romantic Period in the West. Liwayway Arceo, in her short and long fiction, explored the psyche of her female protagonists through careful characterization and tightly controlled plots. Mercedes Jose added the psychological dimension to the formula of personal and domestic problems in her novels Tatsulok (Triangle), 1966, and Ina … Ina (Mother … Mother), 1971. Rosario de Guzman Lingat infused her didactic material with psychological realism in Kung Wala Na ang Tag-araw (When Summer Is Gone), 1969. Kerima Polotan-Tuvera portrayed woman’s anguished psyche and traced its roots to economic strain; sexual relationship was, to her, fraught with antagonism. Other writers in English exploring the female psyche are Gilda Cordero-Fernando, Estrella Alfon, Nick Joaquin, Aida Rivera-Ford, Lina Espina-Moore, and Edith Tiempo.

The other arts served as a source of ideas, imagery, symbol, and other literary devices. Teo S. Baylen’s poem “Obertura ng Agos” (Overture of the Stream), 1963, consists of stanzas each representing Crescendo, Staccatissimo, Diminuendo, Legato, Romanza, Acapella, and Vivace. Other writers using the other arts are Emmanuel Torres (visual arts), Rolando Tinio (dance and music), Cirilo F. Bautista (visual arts), and Wilfrido Nolledo (music and film).

The interdisciplinary nature of literature was obvious in the works of the writers in English. JoseGarciaVilla, Nick Joaquin, GregorioBrillantes, and RenatoMadrid drew from Catholic theology, while Edilberto Tiempo and Ricaredo Demetillo drew from Protestant theology. Sociology provided the narrative details in the works of Amadis Ma. Guerrero, F. Sionil Jose, Bienvenido Santos, and Juan C. Laya. Fictional explorations of philosophy were made by Nick Joaquin, Arturo B. Rotor, and Rony V. Diaz. Ideological concerns were expressed in the works of Resil B. Mojares, Jose Ma. Sison, Carlos Bulosan, Ninotchka Rosca, Luis V. Teodoro, and N. V. M.Gonzalez. Historical fiction was written by Linda Ty-Casper, Wilfrido Nolledo, Edilberto Tiempo, and Stevan Javellana.

Intertextuality is evident in the writers’ deliberate allusion to their sources and influences. N. V. M. Gonzalez in The Winds of April, 1941, makes references to his writer-friends Arcellana, Arguilla, Hartendorp, and Villa (whom he calls “the Great One”); and mentions the novels of Flaubert, Marcel Proust, Heinrich Heine, Dostoyevsky, Thomas Hardy, and Somerset Maugham. Amado V. Hernandez’s prison poems Bayang Malaya (A Nation Free), 1969, and Isang Dipang Langit (A Stretch of Sky), 1961, deliberately bring to the reader’s recollection Balagtas, Juan Abad, and Batute, with whom the political allegory is identified.

In fiction, social realism was tempered with techniques of understatement, such as those used by Chekhov and Hemingway. The influence of naturalism and existentialism gave the stories an overtone of pessimism and despair. Some Ilonggo fictionists of this school were Ernesto Javellana, Juanito Marcella, Isabelo Sobrevega, Tommy Tigulo, and Epifanio T. Tuclaud. The Ilocano fictionists were Pelagio Alcantara, Jose A. Bragado, Dionisio Bulong, Constante Casabar, Reynaldo Duque, Marcelino Foronda Jr, Juan S. P. Hidalgo, Gregorio Laconsay, Peter La. Julian, Donel Pacis, and Arsenio Ramel. The Tagalog stories of Efren Abueg, Rogelio Ordoñez, Rogelio Sikat, Eduardo Bautista Reyes, and Edgardo Reyes were anthologized in Mga Agos sa Disyerto (Streams in the Desert), 1964. Other Tagalog fictionists writing in this vein were Levy Balgos de la Cruz, Ave Perez Jacob, Domingo Landicho, and Dominador Mirasol.

Modernist poetry was characterized by an ironic tone, emotional restraint, and an objective, even clinically detached, attitude toward the subject matter. The poets of the 1960s were influenced by Dylan Thomas, John Crowe Ransom, William Carlos Williams, Hart Crane, and Whitman.

The bagay poets of Ateneo de Manila University, which included Jose F. Lacaba and Rolando S. Tinio, were inspired by the Imagist Movement in the United States to resolve to “capture things in their thing-ness” and to keep their poetry to an easy, conversational tone. The bagay poets interested themselves in commonplace topics like traffic, the cafeteria scene, coming home from a movie, a day in the life of common citizen Juan. Their models were Ezra Pound, Amy Lowell, T. S. Eliot, Marianne Moore, and W. B. Yeats.

Campus avant-gardism was led by the writers’ groups at the University of the Philippines, Ateneo de Manila, and University of the East. Continuing the rebellion begun by Abadilla against the moralism, sentimentalism, rigidity of form, and explicitness of expression identified with the Balagtas tradition, the younger poets produced works marked by intellectualism and experimentation. They brought Abadilla’s stress on the “I” to the extreme with celebrations of the private, inner self. This, however, also made them vulnerable to criticisms about obscurity. Theirs was a generation that had imbibed the tenets of the Western creative and critical movements then prevailing: New Criticism, Neo-Aristotelianism, Formalism, Symbolism, Surrealism, and Expressionism. But it was the economic and social philosophy of Marx and Engels that determined their choice and treatment of subject matter. The influence of Eliot’s “The Wasteland” and “The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock” was evident in Rio Alma’s “Agunyas-Abril sa Lunsod” (April Elegy in the City), Teo Antonio’s “Panambitan” (Entreaty), and Rogelio Mangahas’s “Sa Pamumulaklak ng Diliwariw” (When the Passion Flower Blooms). Other influences were Quasimodo on Antonio; Garcia Lorca on Mangahas; Auden and Yeats on Lacaba; and Rimbaud and H. Doolittle on Tinio.

The poets in English, like Dominador Ilio, Nick Joaquin, Edith Tiempo, Epifanio San Juan Jr, and Bienvenido Santos, continued to use classical Greek and Roman mythological allusions, in contrast to the Tagalog poets, who used Filipino mythical allusions. Federico Licsi Espino used Filipino mythical and epic heroes like Wigan, Idyanale, Indarapatra, and Sidapa. The result was a poetry that was erudite, surrealist, and, for the most part, difficult. His poem “Ang Daigdig ng Sining” (The World of Art) alludes to the four beggars of San Roque town as the symbol of the creative process. In a similar vein, Lamberto E. Antonio combined biblical and mythical allusions with native folklore to produce surreal poetry. On the other hand, Rio Alma synthesized both foreign and native sources in the hope of creating a new mythology. In “TD-14,” he merged Blake’s tiger and Bidasari into a single metaphor for the demonic character of mechanization.

The poets’ determination to avoid the theatrical and rhetorical language of Balagtas poets greatly enriched the Filipino language. It legitimized the use of slang and what used to be deemed “vulgar” words, and allowed the entry of foreign loan words like estero, istambay, polusyon, plastik, nukleyar, naylon, ismo, atom, jukebox, anderpas, ayland, inodoro, kantin, lobby, sex, tsekot, jet, elebeytor, supermarket, kosmetiks, and traysikel.

The late 1960s saw the ferment of protest which culminated in the First Quarter Storm, 1970. Mao Tse-tung’s Talks at the Yenan Forum, a collection of essays on revolutionary art and culture, inspired a wave of radical writing among both the old and new writers, like Ricardo Lee, Fanny Garcia, Norma Miraflor, Wilfredo P. Virtusio, Efren Abueg, and Epifanio San Juan Jr, who anthologized their Tagalog short stories in Sigwa (Storm), 1971. Panulat para sa Kaunlaran ng Sambayanan or PAKSA was an organization of writers, artists, and critics who were active members of the national democratic movement. It produced the PAKSA workbook, 1971, a collection of critical essays using the Maoist theoretical framework. Other writers of this same school of thought were Luis V. Teodoro, Edgardo B. Maranan, and Gelacio Guillermo.

Russian, European, and Chinese social realists Maxim Gorky, Georgy Plekhanov, Georg Lukacs, Lu Hsun, Mao, Bertolt Brecht, and Leon Trotsky replaced Wellek and Warren, Eliot, I. A. Richards, Kant, and Aristotle as dominant influences. New words that surfaced in the language were armalayt, aspekto, barikada, burukratang kapitalismo, konteksto, kontradiksiyon, demo, diyalektika, imperyalismo, molotov, papet, pasismo piyudalismo, plakard, rali, tirgas, and tortyur.

Poets and fictionists found kindred spirits in Latin American writers—notably, Nicolas Guillen, Cesar Vallejo, Pablo Neruda, Gabriel Garcia Marquez, and Jorge Amado. Imagism was enriched further by the influence of Chinese poets Li Bo, Du Fu, and Wang Wei.

The declaration of martial law on 21 Sep 1972 created what is now called the literature of circumvention, a body of works that expressed social and political protest in veiled terms. Historical and political allegory was resorted to in theater, fiction, and poetry. However, explicit revolutionary literature continued to be written in the Communist underground movement, with poets, like Servando Magbanua (pseud.), Emmanuel Lacaba, Clarita Roja (pseud.), Ma. Lorena Barros, Rojo Sangre (pseud.), Jason Montana (pseud.), and fictionists, all publishing under pseudonyms.

The 1980s and the early 1990s saw a diversity of schools of literary theory and writing styles. Latin American literature continued to be a strong influence, and European postmodernism encouraged experiments with form and technique. Gay liberation theory produced a new stream of literature by Tony Perez, J. Neil C. Garcia, Nick Deocampo, Nick Pichay, Danton Remoto, and Honorio de Dios. Traces of Sylvia Plath, Maxine Hong Kingston, Mary Gordon, Denise Levertov, Virginia Woolf, Margaret Atwood, and Latin American women writers, like Gioconda Bella, Rosario Castellanos, and Isabel Allende, were gleaned in the feminist writings of Merlinda C. Bobis, Marjorie Evasco, Fatima V. Lim, Ruth Elynia S. Mabanglo, Rosalinda Pineda-Ofreneo, Aida F. Santos, Benilda S. Santos, Joi Barrios, Grace Monte de Ramos, Marra PL. Lanot, Priscilla Supnet Macansantos, Fanny B. Llego, Lina S. Reyes, Dinah Roma, and Merlie Alunan.
Studies for Influence and Intertexuality

The study of sources and influences has broadened into various possibilities by which literary relations and indebtedness may be apprehended, ranging from the empirical identification of sources and influences; to the broader subject of intertextuality, with the intersection of texts being assumed as a given, without regard to one being the “precursor” of another; and to the multidimensional ways by which writers and texts within a literary tradition are interrelated.

Edgardo M. Reyes’s Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag (In the Claws of Light) was serialized in Liwayway magazine in 1967-68 and published in book form in 1986. For his introduction, editor Rogelio Mangahas interviewed Reyes for the sources of his fictional subject matter and characters as well as for the influences on his style and diction. Reyes reveals that his stories about railroad and construction workers are based on his own experience as a laborer in these work sites. For style, Reyes points to a specific passage in Hemingway’s “Big Two-Hearted River” as the key to his discovery of the literary power of colloquialisms. For the objectivity with which he constructs scenes that might have swung dangerously to sentimentalism, he credits Evelyn Waugh. For dialogue, he quotes a passage from Aldous Huxley’s Point Counter Point to parallel his own in his novel (xxii-xxiv).

Rogelio Sikat’s Pagsalunga (Against the Current), 1992, is divided into two sections, consisting of his short stories and his personal essays explaining how he transmutes his sources and influences into his own original work. “Bukal at Disenyo ng ‘Sa Lupa ng Sariling Bayan’” (Source and Design of “In the Land of One’s Hometown”) is the most detailed of such essays. The story’s title, Sikat states, is derived from a work by John Steinbeck. The model for his story’s main character is a person from his home barrio in San Isidro, Nueva Ecija. However, he names his fictional barrio San Roque, the significance of which may be gleaned in another essay in the same book, “Gamit ng Folklore sa Panitikan” (The Use of Folklore in Literature). Sikat demonstrates how he modifies certain details of his model’s real life for stylistic and thematic effect: whereas the graves of the real-life parents have been planted over by an orchard, Sikat replaces this with a poultry so that chicken droppings on the graves would intensify the main character’s bitterness over his childhood memories. Sikat is also particular about diction in order to invoke the appropriate mood for every scene: “itim na kotse” (black car) is preferred to “punerarya” (funeral) for the concreteness of the visual image, including its color. He chooses “bahay-pamahalaan” over “munisipyo” for its lyrical sound and rhythm (158-64).

Efren Abueg’s short story collection, Bugso: Maikling Katha, 1954-1964 (Downpour: Short Stories, 1954-1964), 1993, includes his personal essay “ERA, Anak ni Genoveva Edroza (O Kung Paano Isinilang ang Isang Manunulat)” (ERA, Offspring of Genoveva Edroza [Or How a Writer Was Born]), in which he acknowledges his indebtedness to fictionist Genoveva Edroza (aka Genoveva Edroza-Matute). Abueg observes that the emotional restraint in Edroza’s stories is created by the well-made plot, the climax of which is the narrator’s multilayered revelation, which is devoid of any explicit reference to sentimental signifiers, such as tears or a breaking heart. He juxtaposes a passage from his own story, “Unang Pagdalaw” (First Visit), 1956, with that from Edroza’s “Kuwento ni Mabuti” (Story of Mabuti), 1951, to show his conscious attempt to equal Edroza’s craft. Abueg declares that, before his introduction to Marxist readings, his first glimpse of a Marxist perspective was in Edroza’s stories, such as “Walong Taong Gulang” (Eight Years Old) and “Bangkang Papel” (Paper Boat). Finally, he states that his story “Ang Paghihintay” (The Waiting) is a mirror image of Edroza’s “Puti ang Kulay ng Pananalig” (White Is the Color of Faith).

Intertextual reading may reveal meanings common to two different texts that may seem, on the surface, to bear no resemblance to each other. Indigenous myths, for instance, belonging to two postcolonial nations may actually bear identical meanings if these were read as allegories of the colonization process. Mariang Makiling and Hainuwele, of New Guinea, formerly a Dutch colony, exemplify this parallel. The native populations, having had their indigenous value systems altered by colonization, must appeal to their goddess for material possessions foreign to their land: porcelain ware, table napkins, party utensils, and the like. In the end, Hainuwele is slain and chopped to pieces, so that from her multiple graves would grow root crops for the natives’ subsistence. Mariang Makiling, on the other hand, disappears after the Dominican friars take possession of her territory, which is Calamba, Laguna. Moreover, in the Mariang Makiling legend, the villagers’ desire for the status symbols of Europeanized urbanity is presupposed in Urbana at Feliza, which teaches the common folk that the acquisition of the good manners and right conduct of “civilized” colonials hinges on their use of the proper apparel, accessories, furnishings, and domestic utensils (Gill 1982, 58-60; Rizal 1961, 124-33).

Reality TV and metafiction may be founded on a common premise, as illustrated in the novel, Para kay B, o Kung Paano Dinevastate ng Pag-ibig ang 4 Out of 5 sa Atin (For B, or How Love Devastated 4 Out of 5 of Us), 2008, by Ricky Lee, who is also a scriptwriter and creative consultant for TV. On the other hand, his second novel, Si Amapola sa 65 na Kabanata (Amapola in 65 Chapters), 2011, is a novel in many modes: political allegory, satire, fantasy, psychological realism, metafiction, historical fiction, and pop culture.

Intertextuality may also be determined by systems of knowledge and understanding established and sustained by social and political institutions. The recurring motif of “the journey” in Philippine literary tradition radically changed meaning upon the Filipinos’ first brush with colonialism, from the Spanish to American, and finally to globalization. The epic, by its very nature as a genre, bears a triumphalist tone and spirit. When epic heroes venture across the seas, it is in search of adventure and war and, from the epic protagonist’s point of view, toward certain conquest. Spanish colonization, however, has transformed the journey into a paradoxical notion, simultaneously signifying both oppression and salvation. The government policy of reduccion, or the transfer of the colonized natives from dispersed to compact settlements, is the institutional framework for the depiction of the persona’s sufferings as an imperative to the attainment of eternal grace; this is the theme of the first published Filipino poem, “May Bagyo Ma’t May Rilim (Though It Is Stormy and Dark), 1605. This is the same motif threading through Elynia Mabanglo’s collection of melancholy diaspora poems in Mga Liham ni Pinay (Letters of Pinay), 1990, which foreshadows the historic case of Flor Contemplacion, the domestic helper in Singapore convicted and executed in 1995 for double homicide. One explanation for the phenomenal rise of overseas Filipino workers is the cause-and-effect chain of economic factors: rural inmigration results in the city’s overcrowding and the concomitant unemployment of the majority of its population. One can thus read the Manila Railway Transit (MRT) as an intertext of the Filipino diaspora, both as a social phenomenon and as literary text. The state’s encouragement of overseas employment is the same reason for its construction of the MRT: it is the state’s hope for declogging its arteries.

Philippine literature is the story of a nation constantly engaged in expression and self-authentication in the face of the political and cultural upheavals that regularly beset it. Seen in this light, Philippine literature can be appreciated as a collective and dynamic tapestry of historical forces and enduring visions.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero
